    • Bill_White
      February 2006 edited February 2006
      My name is Bill White, and I just turned 40. I'm from New Jersey, but I live in Pennsylvania now. I'm a college professor who teaches public speaking and media-related courses; I got my Ph.D. in communication in 2001 from Rutgers University. I'm married with a two-year-old little girl. My wife also teaches communication, although at a different school than mine. We met in grad school.

      I started playing D&D in high school; my first character was a dwarf fighter named Mensch who picked up the Axe of the Dwarven Lords on the 3rd level of the dungeon. I ran a long-term campaign through high school and a little bit into college (where I also played a little Champions). My D&D campaign was a thing of beauty: broad sweeping plotlines with characters scattered across the multiverse but coming together at the end to confront the Great Evil, who in one instance turned out to be Mighty Cthulhu (luckily, someone had an Elder Sign).

      I graduated from college and went into the Army, stopped roleplaying but missed it. When I got out, I went back to graduate school. I managed to sell two articles to Dragon magazine in about five years of trying--one was called "Dangerous Ground" and was about staging dramatic fight scenes. The other was called "The Hero with 1d1000 Faces" and was a random adventure generator.

      And then I stumbled on the Forge.

      Now I'm working on a game called Ganakagok that I plan to have ready to sell as a PDF by May. After that, I have a ton of other ideas I want to pursue. I love these games.
    • Jason_Morningstar
      February 2006
      Hey all, to answer Adam, the thing I'm finding most interesting is what we choose to share and what we choose to not share about ourselves. I was also a little surprised to see the homogeneity in age, education, and profession. Weirdly, a large chunk of us could have a good excuse to get together professionally and swap business cards.
    • Clinton

      Jason's right on that being interesting. I've personally gone and re-written mine like 4 times now, and kind of want to start over. "Who am I?" isn't an easy question, really.

    • warren
      February 2006 edited February 2006
      I'm Warren Merrifield, another Englishman, 30. I'm from Essex, but now live in Leeds. I've got a Masters degree in (Aerospace) Systems Engineering from Loughborough, but I've been in the computer games industry since '97. I now work for Rockstar Leeds - I was a programmer on Grand Theft Auto:Liberty City Stories for the PSP most recently.

      I was brought up Church of England, but I'm not a religious person. I play a lot of small-stakes Texas Hold 'Em with guys from work (I dislike online play). I'm living with my girlfriend - a lovely park ranger who isn't really a roleplayer but loves board & card games. I have an iMac, I worship Google in all its forms, and I drive a smart fortwo which provokes some amusement from onlookers (I'm 6'5").

      I started roleplaying with the Marvel Super Heros Basic Set at the age of 10 (I was diagnosed diabetic at the same age, coincidentally) and did a lot of Classic Traveller then a great deal of Shadowrun. A looong Vampire campaign followed out of university until our GM burned-out and I became dissaffected with roleplaying... Until I stumbled across a website that mentioned Dogs in the Vineyard last year. The Forge followed, and now I've joined up to two groups - one very wargamey that does AD&D who took to DitV pretty easily, and another bunch of Vampire players who I'm going to try running Dogs for soon. And can you believe that I had never played *D&D of any type until about six months ago?
    • Chris_Goodwin
      February 2006
      I guess I might have mentioned that I live in one of Portland, OR's suburbs. And again, due to lack of time, I haven't even had a chance to meet most of the local gamers such as Frank for a game, though I did manage to have breakfast with Chris Goodwin and family once.

      Which would be my cue, I guess.

      Chris Goodwin, age 35. Married to Lisa, we have a four year old, Andrew. I was orn in California, grew up in Oregon. Entered the Air Force at age 18, what little time I didn't spend in Texas was in California. Back to Oregon after getting out of there. Lived in Oregon until my wife and I moved to Raleigh, NC in late 1998, moved to Garland, TX in 2002, then back to Oregon in 2003.

      I currently work as a PC technician for a very large construction company in the Portland area. I use Linux on my computer at home, but I do Windows because my wife uses it and because I get paid to.

      I got started with RPGs in 1981 with *D&D, bought and played through most or all of the TSR stable of boxed RPGs, then in 1985 discovered Champions. Have been less of a Hero partisan since 4th and 5th edition came out but I still like it (though I'm not sure I can call it my favorite system anymore). I started reading the Forge in '02, registered in May '03 but in all that time have done little more than lurk, and wasn't really "into" indie games until PTA. I think half of my postings there came from birthday week this year (and I got the Last Word for '05...).

      As mentioned, we met Christian (xenopulse) for breakfast once, but unfortunately haven't had time to get together again. I'd very much like to meet up with some of the other Portland area indie gamers for (preferably) PTA or (alternately) Dogs or, heck, any gaming at all, as I've been stuck in an over six year almost-dry spell. I have done quite a bit of board/card gaming (Looney Labs stuff, Illuminati, Settlers of Catan, other hobby board games), which takes the edge off but doesn't really satisfy it, you know?
    • ffilz
      February 2006
      Portland (OR) folks - if you haven't joined the PortlandIndependentRPG Yahoo group, you may want to do so.

      Frank
    • Colin_Fredericks
      February 2006 edited February 2006
      I'm Colin Fredericks (no surprise there). I'm a 27-year old doctoral student in Physics (specifically, physics education).

      I live in Sunderland, Massachusetts. I normally live with my woman, but she's in Tanzania right now for a term abroad. I'm originally from Vernon, Vermont, and still mostly identify as a Vermonter. I went to Northfield Mt. Hermon, then RPI, then still RPI, then UMass Amherst (where I am now). I still have a lot of friends in the Troy/Albany area.

      I run Valent Games. In fact, 90% of the time it would be fair to say that I *am* Valent Games. My latest published thing was Super Console, which is doing awesome right now. I started playing games back in 5th grade, with D&D and GURPS, and have the widest (though not deepest) game collection of any of my friends.

      I'm a serial monogamist: I date the same person exclusively for several years in a row, and then end up in another long-term relationship. Unfortunately, I don't seem to be all that good at it. Hopefully this time it'll stick - I really like her.

      Miscellanea: I'm a Mac user, I help teaching American Style Karate at the dojo Monday nights, I'm running two games a week (Exalted and Sufficiently Advanced), I like using physics to break my friends' minds, and right now I have a small black kitty named Shinobi napping on my lap.

      I intend to start a private high school.
    • Faerieloch
      February 2006 edited February 2006
      My name's Nancy McKeown and I currently split my time between Santa Cruz, CA, where I'm a graduate student in Geology, and Stanford, CA with my boyfriend, Albert Andersen, who conveniently forgot to mention me in his post. :P I've lived in five different countries, studied five languages (if you include English), have three sisters, and no pets. :( Hello to the fellow Canadians! I did most of my growing up in Ottawa. I've been gaming for approximately four years now, my first game being D&D 3.5, and since then I've played home-brew, Cthulhu, and a horde of others. My current favourite is Polaris, of which Albert just gave me my own copy. :) For my research I'd like to look at Mars. I also dance: scottish country, highland, and belly dancing.
    • James Jeffers
      February 2006
      My name is James Jeffers. I am 34 years old, married and have a 4 year old child. I've lived in Raleigh, North Carolina since 1999. Before that I was a graduate student at the University of Florida. Before that I spent a few years as an unemployed Mass Comm graduate in Tampa, Florida. I work in software, but I dream daily of owning and operating a inter-planetary ore mining conglomerate. Either that or retiring so I can hike tha Appalachian Trail from Georgia to Maine.

      Cut my teeth on the old, old Red Box D&D in 1982. One year my older, Satan worhsipping cousin from Texas showed me how the game was really played. He made me distrust sneaky NPC magic users forever. I don't really know if he worshipped Satan, but he had cool sunglasses.

      I am very surprised at the number of RPG publishers and designers who live within an hour of my house. Something good will come of this, I just know it.

    • neelk
      February 2006
      My name is Neelakantan Krishnaswami, and many people call me Neel. I am 29 years old, live in Pittsburgh, and am a graduate student in computer science. Poetically speaking, I make up new logics, and prosaically, I study the formal semantics of programming languages. Before that, I lived in Boston and worked as a computer programmer.

      I've been playing roleplaying games for 17 years, starting with Red Box D&D, and moving on to GURPS for SF, and then really branching out 11 years ago, when I went to college, and discovered Internet discussion fora.

      Of the earlier posters, I have played with peaseblossom and her husband Jere, and with Mr. Teapot and his wife.

      I played my first rpg on my tenth birthday, but for most of the 90s gaming was replaced by the Society for Creative Anachronism, social activism, and travelling.       IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve been lurking around the Forge and other such indie rpg sites for a couple of years now, but as it seems to take me hours to write anything for the web, donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t expect an overwhelming stream of posts from me. But IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be around.

    • Andy
      February 2006
      Damn, I'm normally all over posting to these kinds of threads, but lately I've been kinda spiritually ill, physically worn out and busy as all hell at work. Anyway, I'll post something quick here, head to bed and maybe add more later if I'm up for it.

      I'm James Andrew Kitkowski (age 31), so I always comment on the Anyway blog as "JAK". I lived in New Jersey, Baton Rouge, Chicagoland, Green Bay, Tokyo and Gunma Japan, and now live in the Triangle (specifically Cary) in North Carolina, and loving it here. I really think that this place is one of the better places in this world to be.

      I've worked all kinds of jobs, but my career is currently enterprise-level computer support (focusing on storage, but also Windows, Unix and Networking). I don't help you with yout mouse, I help you when all of your email servers in your data centers are down. It's high stress, but luckily it's also medium-high reward, and I love the work too.

      I'm married to Orie, my wife of some seven years. No kids in the picture, but three cats. She is the most awesome cook in the world (she's basically cooked like a housewife since the death of her mom, so some nearly 20 years now). Our conversations at home look pretty much like the conversation between Han Solo and Greedo. Also, I've been reading a lot more Japanese stuff during the day (about 30-60 minutes every evening), which I realized is directly proportional with the amount of severe headaches I've been having as well. Ahhh, living the bilingual life...

      I love all sorts of games, but lately I've been a little burned out an balls-to-the-wall narrativist gaming, and am looking to play more structured stuff over the next two months (and things like simple board and card games), as well as read some books and stuff to recharge over the next two months.

      I love music, primarily (real) experimental, new age and techno, but am up for just about anything. I used to be the station manager of my college's radio station, and also a techno DJ at small raves and the like in the US and Japan, though I haven't been to a club since my return to the US.

      I used to be really heavy into dancing and martial arts (namely Aikido, Wing Chun Kung Fu and Tae Kwan Do), and had been doing them for years, but nothing lately, which is why I've become a big fucking creampuff. That and I have very little self control when it comes to food (No, Andy, your metabolism is not what it was in college!). My goal is to lose 20 pounds this year, and to lose a total of (from Right Now to My Goal) some 50 pounds in the next 3 years.

      Uh... Er... I'm listening to this week's broadcast of Hearts of Space (www.hos.com), which is rocking, I'm doing more Tenra Bansho (www.tenra-rpg.com) translation tonight, and I'm writing an RPG which I realized needs a bit more rulework, and is totally going to look like a bastard hybrid of a filthy hippie Forge game and a "Hey, GM, your cock is in my ass!" traditional sim game. You basically hunt down Clive Barker-ish evil in your modified green El Camino and shoot it with shotguns, and that's about it. It's gorgeous.

      That's about it. I also have blogs on www.kitkowski.com (read only), and my LJ name is "zigguratbuilder" for my gaming and "stuff I don't want my family to see" stuff.
    • beingfrank
      February 2006 edited February 2006
      IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m Claire, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m 28 and IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m from Melbourne, Australia. Ethnically, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m part Manx, the celts even the Scots and Irish think are insane weirdos. Religiously, raised atheist, sent to an Anglican school, currently oblivious. Those are the bits I put in because other people were mentioning them. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s weird to describe myself that way.

      I work as a statistician for the police force. Previously IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve worked in market research and data entry. I have a BSc in Psychology and a BA in Criminology. I got into gaming during university after reading and loving the Amber books by Roger Zelazny. I searched the student union libraryÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s catalogue for other books related to Amber and found they had a copy of the Amber DRPG. I borrowed it, found it rather strange, found out more about it online, and joined a PBEM. When I took a year to study in Glasgow as part of my degree, the first friends I made just happened to be major lights in the roleplaying club.

      When contemplating post-graduate study in psychology I was thinking of researching social interactions in virtual and imagined space, which led me to look at roleplaying theory. This then exposed me to a number of different games.

      Roleplaying is not my first hobby. ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s actually Guiding, as in Girl Guiding. I am a Brownie Guide leader, with a group of 19 girls aged 6-10. My friends say they are my minions, and that IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m teaching them to take over the world. Well, of course! A lot of my approach to gaming has been shaped by my experiences as a guide leader. I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t design games. The weekly challenge of facilitating 7 year olds to set, plan, execute and evaluate their own shared creative endeavours puts me off the idea of doing anything similar for adults. Kids donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t assume that stuff is too hard. And kids have more powers of awesomeness!

      In my fleeting remaining spare time I read, cook, make silly jokes, sleep and never manage to watch the tv I recorded because I was too busy at the time.

      I have a blog where I talk about gaming and a livejournal (beingfrank) were I rant, complain, am silly, and put stuff I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t want to take time crafting.

      Hi, I'm RamÃƒÂ³n Nogueras, and chose my nickname because it sound pretty cool tome. Also, I dig Roman stuff a lot.

      I'm from Granada, Spain, and living with my awesome and very geek girlfriend in Madrid. I have also lived in Barcelona (Spain), Sweden and Ireland.       I've been playing RPGs for 20 years, starting with Red Box D&D, and have played tons of things. I've discovered the indie scene in the last year, and my gaming is better.
    • Shawn De Arment
      February 2006
      I am a 43 year old white, male, fish monger, who lives with his girlfriendÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s cat in Chantilly VA. I guess Thor & I will have to arm wrestle to figure out who is the eldest poster.

      I was born in Germany (army brat), but moved to Fairfax County VA before I was 1 and have lived here ever since.

      Religiously, I am too Pagan for the Christians in my life, and too Christian for the Pagans in my life.
      LetÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not even discuss politics.

      I have been role playing since 1976, and am presently playing in 2 campaigns that are over 20 years old.

      I have no free time. But what time I do have I try to juggle between: petting the kitty, keeping the girlfriend (Michele) happy, making mead, helping out my mother, role playing, gardening, taking care of my fish, reading, watching DVDs, and generally consuming data.
    • szilard
      February 2006
      I'm Stuart Broz, a 33 year old guy living in Champaign-Urbana. I work for a non-profit, where I do a bit of everything. Most of that everything, however, seems to involve either grantwriting or coordinating mental health service access for underserved children.

      I'm overeducated. I have a law degree and a Masters in philosophy, both of which are from Georgetown. I stopped writing my dissertation after determining that I have a strong dislike of lecturing. Before that, I attended college in New Orleans (at Tulane). I've been feeling a pull to go back there lately.

      I live in a large, run-down house with several friends, reptiles, and rodents. One of these rodents is my pet chinchilla, Luna. I'm not married, but I am far from single. I am fairly certain that I have no children.

      I started using szilard as an online handle almost fifteen years ago because I felt like the physicist Leo Szilard, who was the closest thing I had to a personal hero at the time, had been largely erased from history. I just stuck with it.

      I spend much of my free time reading, painting, cooking, or noodling around with RPG-things. I have a new blog up at neitherworldstories.blogspot.com.
    • John Marron
      February 2006
      Wow, it' s realy cool to read about the real people behind the posts, and see how many of you I've met (mostly thanks to Ron Edwards letting me help out with the Forge booth at last year's Gencon).

      I'm 42, married to a rabid non-gamer (which has been an issue throughout our 16 year marriage, but we've come to a decent compromise on it). I have a lovely 2 year old daughter who talks non-stop and who we think is a genius.

      I grew up on military bases up and down the east coast of the US (navy brat), from Jacksonville to Norfilk VA to Providence RI. My family moved to Naples, Florida when my dad retired, and I lived there until I moved to Gainesville for college (University of Florida). I have a BA in Anthropology, with a focus on Historic Archaeology (basically, post-European contact North America). I dropped out of grad school in Archaeology and went to Japan, hoping to make a bunch of money teaching English. Unfortunately, I jumped on that bandwagon a little too late and came back after only 3 months.

      I got married, went back and finished an MA in History (Early Modern Europe) studying witchcraft and the Inquisition. I worked off and on as an Archaeologist for 20 years (with 5 years doing data management for a research project on pre-natal cocaine exposure while my wife finished her PhD). The most interesting places I worked were the first European settlement in the new world (a place called En Bas Saline in Haiti where Columbus had to leave 39 men when the Santa Maria sank on his first voyage over here) and a Desoto contact site in Arkansas. We finally moved from Florida (after 18 years in Gainesville) to Maine (Bar Harbor) for 5 years for my wife to do a post-doc position (2000-2005) and moved to Birmingham, Alabama last year when she got a faculty position at the university here. It's a surprisingly nice city, which I never would have considered living in before visiting. We just bought a house (this morning!), and are looking forward to settling down for a while. I stopped doing archaeology and now do data work for a cancer outreach project that tries to get folks in poor, rural African-American communities in Alabama and Mississippi to get screened for cancer.

      Gamewise, I started playing at 13 in 1976 with Empire of the Petal Throne. I did eventually play some D&D, but only for 4 years (AD&D from 1978-1982), so my gaming experience is kinda different from most folks I meet. I worked in a game store for 10 years during college and grad school (and sold Ron Edwards comics and games before he became a Big Time game designer).

      I've been sort of burned out on games for a while now and am trying to figure out what I really enjoy about gaming and why I haven't been able to get it for a long time. I occasionally whine about it on an LJ.

      I have no apsirations to design games, but really, really appreciate the fact that the internet has made it possible to find a supportive community of interesting folks like you all. I spend way too much time reading gaming fora and blogs.

      I don't understand computer games at all, although I did like mashing buttons while playing Soul Blade years ago, and can't for the life of me figure out what the draw is for mmorpgs or any computer "RPG" really. I love serious anime, but know next to nothing about it. I read Bronze Age archaeology for fun, and my musical tastes are pretty eclectic (I'm trying hard to fill up a 40 gig iPod with everyting from Big Band to Nordic Roots to 80's New Wave to Tuvan Throat Singing to ...)

      John

    • Michael Curry
      February 2006
      My name's Michael Curry, and I've never gotten the hang of the whole having a handle on the 'net thing, so I usually just go by some variant of my real name. Sometimes I fear this implies a lack of imagination on my part.

      I'm 39, single, and I've lived in New England all of my life. I'm currently residing in a town in northeastern Connecticut that I don't feel especially attached to, but I can't see myself living anywhere other than the northeastern U.S. At least until I have to flee the country. I have a BA in Psychology, and I'm employed in the HR department of a faceless corporation that wants to destroy all life on Earth, or, as an alternative, sell them health insurance. And since other people seem to be mentioning their religion, I'm an atheist.

      I've been playing RPGs on and off since I was a teenager, first during the "usual" D&D phase (though my first actual RPG purchase was a box of Runequest), followed by various homebrew fantasy games in college, then a period where I mainly gamed via the old Compuserve RPG Forum, followed by far too much Amber DRPG. That last one might explain why I'm currently helping to run an Ambercon-like convention called The Black Road that's held outside Boston, MA. I'm in two D&D 3.5 campaigns at the moment, but I'd really like to actually be playing some of the fine indie RPGs I've bought over the past couple of years. I'm not sure I see that happening in either of my current gaming groups. I'm not currently past the mild tinkering stage of designing my own RPG, but that might change this year.

      Other than RPGs, I read plenty of spec fic, something that's become an even bigger part of my life since I became friends with a talented literary agent who has taught me more than I ever thought I'd know about publishing. Someday this might lead to a career change, but for now I'm just her faithful sidekick and permanent intern. I also like to listen to a lot of music, which usually falls into either the category of ectophilic music or of Irish traditional music. I'm currently learning how to play the tin whistle, and I'm thinking I might take up the flute at some point.

      Oh, and I have far too many blogs, including one about gaming, one about politics and one about books/music/movies. None of them get updated as often as they should.

      In case I haven't mentioned it before, I think this forum is just great.
    • misuba
      February 2006 edited February 2006
      Okay, okay: Mike Sugarbaker, 30, unmarried, just moved to Portland OR to live with girl and cat. Administer and co-edit a website and podcast about RPGs as well as board games, card games and whatever else we are into. It's at OgreCave.com if you care.

      Played redbox D&D with my brother starting at age 8 (he was 11). Mostly couldn't keep my head in the game, even up until now. I'm embarrassed at how long it took me to realize why: "hey, all my brother's friends made fighters and I didn't, and I get bored when they have their three-hour combats. Hmm." So I'm very interested in games that might fulfill the promise of rich, interesting worlds and events that I always thought RPGs would get me. That, and absolutely nothing else of any interest is happening in games, for many reasons. Well, minis games are getting interesting, but back to the point: I ran Ghostbusters and learned how hard it is to notice when one of your players had the problem I had in my bro's D&D games. I tried to run Teenagers From Outer Space once and learned how important it is for the PCs to want something. I ran Paranoia, mostly very successfully, and learned how to be flexible... or at least how to be in a lot of trouble when your railroading isn't effective enough. And then I kind of stopped with the RPGs and fell out of gaming until I got into CCGs in college.

      Apart from gaming and the usual geekly spate of interests, I do web stuff for a living and hope to start a band again soon. I've tried my hand at game design a few times and have not completely ruled out attempting a new-style RPG. Lately, though, I've mostly been contributing to my honey's research of local happy hours. *hic*

      I have been known to go by misuba. Free gift to anyone who can guess the etymology there.
    • James Holloway
      February 2006
      I'm James Holloway. I'm a 27-year old graduate student in archaeology; I have a little crude website about my research here. I'm married to a fellow gamer -- three and a half years now, no kids. I was born in the UK, but my family moved to America when I was four. I grew up in the Bay Area, which is where I know Albert and his brother from, and I once picked up a recruiting note for John Kim's Vinland game off the board at Gamescape in Palo Alto, but I never followed it up.

      I've been gaming since I was a little kid, always as kind of a way to give my nerdy creative dork-self some social status, but it's grown into a cool thing in my life, rather than my whole social context, which is nice.

      Now I am back in the UK -- I live in Cambridge, where I read, write, teach, game, paint miniatures, and, er, read some more. As you can tell, I need to get more exercise. My research affords me the opportunity to travel some, which is really nice.

      I think that's about it, really.

      Hello friends,

      I'm Andy Hopp. This is my first post on this forum, on account of I just joined. So, hello everyone.

      I work as an illustrator, writer, and game designer, but that's the work stuff and this thread is about personal stuff, so here it goes:

      I live in Akron, Ohio with my wife Heather and our 19 month old daughter Iliana. I'm 33 as of two weeks ago and I am freezing my wazoo off as I type this in my basement studio/office.

      I went to Kent State University where I majored in art and zoology (which influences my current job remarkably). Oh, I guess I majored in gaming too, since that's what I did more than homework.

    • JasonP
      February 2006
      I'm Jason Petrasko, a soon 31 year old game designer that works in the ever-annoying field known as retail. I live in Euclid, Ohio and spent most of my non-working hours:

      Programming or learning about programming.
      Designing and playing RPGs.
      Watching anime or other quality movies in most genres (last awesome movie watched: Millenium Actress!).
      Sorting out the million idea in my head.
      Trying to aquire and read all of Philip K. Dick's work.
      Developing my website/projects via inkarbon.com.

      That about sums it up. Somehow I still schedule myself a few hours of sleep a day ;) and make up for it with espresso.

    • Joe Murphy
      March 2006
      I'm Joe Murphy, about to turn 31, and I live in Scotland despite being Irish. I've travelled around a bit, and have had lots of odd jobs, from theatre work to chef. I have plenty of _skills_, just haven't found a job to settle in yet.

      Gaming started for me with the Fighting Fantasy solo adventure books, then ShadowRun, then Storyteller games. So D&D anecdotes don't mean much to me. I bumped into the Forge back in 2002 or so, having had serious problems with gaming and having left my previous group.

      But I subsequently met some curious gamers (and curious non-gamers) in Edinburgh, and we've been trying a bunch of new things. Aswell as posting Actual Play reports, lots of out of game discussion, and so on. The Shadow of Yesterday is on tonight, whee!

      I've also found a few people locally who have an interest in design, so I'm hoping that our shared energy and enthusiasm will get some games off the ground. Bit like AA.

      Joe.
    • James Holloway
      March 2006
      John:

      yeah, the "worked" in the states means worked in the business sense, sadly. I wasn't sure what I wanted to do after graduating, so I dicked around, working for a non-profit in San Francisco and then for a big internet firm in Redwood City (these being the days when you could get a decent-paying job in that field if you had a pulse). I had done some archaeology in my final year as an undergrad, but I didn't really get serious about it until I started my MA in Durham. I'm still kind of a weird hybrid of a historian and an archaeologist.
    • Lxndr
      March 2006 edited July 2006
      I'm Alexander Cherry, publisher through the Twisted Confessions label, which has put out such games as Fastlane and, through the No Press Anthology, Snowball, which is also available free on my site. There are other games out there that I've designed, but the only other one that's any good is Creeks and Crawdads: Revisited, a homage to the original Creeks and Crawdads. I have a number of other projects on my plate, which I'll talk about in other threads.

      Who am I outside of gaming?

      *I'm a Student Older than Traditional Age at Arizona State University where I plan on getting some combination of Economics and Mathematics major and minor (currently Math major/Econ minor, but that might switch, or they might both be majors). I'm more excited by theory than application, or at least by abstract over concrete.
      *I'm a hobby hypnotist with basic hypnotherapy certification.
      *I'm an avid reader, though I don't read nearly as much as I used to. Tragic.
      *I'm a fan of the theatre, musical and otherwise, though I don't go as often as I should. Again, tragic.
      *I'm a motorcycle rider. Currently, I own a Victory Vegas - 100 cubic inches of solid power. Haven't been behind the wheel of a car since I was 18.
      *I've lived a significant length of time in 6 of the US States, and have been to over 30 of them, many during a 60-day bus trip around the country. Also I've been to Canada, Mexico, Germany, the Netherlands, Austria, Hungary, and some parts of the former Yugoslavia.
      *I've been homeless. I've also worked in telemarketing, customer service, spent several years as a security guard, and spent almost 5 years as a cubicle jockey. Currently I'm focused entirely on school, so I'm not working.
      *I'm a homeowner. I am renting out two of my rooms to help pay for aforementioned schooling.
      *I am single, potentially polyamorous, and surgically childfree.

      Anyway, there's a good start as to Who I Am.
    • Alex F
      March 2006 edited March 2006
      Another Alexander, for your delectation.

      I'm Alex, an English-Catalan (but shamefully monolingual) mutt. I'm 27 and have recently finished up my PhD on the psychology of time and memory. Now I'm enjoying calling myself a working scientist: I'm employed on a project investigating how HIV affects the brain and cognitive function. London through and through, although I can see that changing in the future, most likely to Sweden or the (coastal) States.

      I used to have cool hobbies to boast of: capoeira, singing in a rock/post-hardcore band, science and political blogging (ok, so I lied about the cool bit). A nasty and enduring back injury put paid to the first, the pressures of phd writing starved the last, and the band died as a consequence of the two cornering it in the rec room and gutting it with a shiv. Ah well. But, uh, I read! And watch movies! Hide your jealous faces.

      Now we're onto fiction...
      I was a massive consumer of sci-fi, fantasy, horror, comics and cult film from my single digits into my early twenties, interspersed with fitful periods into other stuff (from 19th-C Russian lit to police procedurals); for better or worse I don't now inhabit any genre particularly, but flit around all over the shop. Which is to say, I'm as consistent in my fictional interests as I am in other parts of my life - very much Jack(x) rather than Master(x), where x = trades. (Yes, I know that this makes a PhD a dumb vocational direction. No, I don't want to talk about it.)

      The things that are constants in my life are my girl: amazing, beautiful, smart scientist; my family: copious and extended, fractious but vital; and my friends: a motley crew the bulk of whom I've known for 10-15 years.

      Gaming has definitely not been a constant. I broke a 12-year abstinence this autumn past as a consequence of stumbling across indie games and discovering that more of my extended social group had a gaming history than I'd thought. Bit of a struggle scheduling at present but I'm slowly demolishing my regrown gaming virginity, one...no, even I'm repulsed by my metaphor. I'm getting to play, that's all.

      Uh, I still blog, a little, with some tentative gaming stuff, here. You might also enjoy a nonsense skit on armour fashion sense I wrote a while back. I'm a contributor to Mindhacks (the blog and the book) but I've been lazy, lazy, lazy recently.

      [edited for inproper semicolon use. May god have mercy on us all.]













    • Mike Montesa
      March 2006 edited March 2006
      OK, time for me to ante up and kick in. I have a tendency to run my mouth so I will try to keep it short.

      I'm Mike Montesa. When my mom gets angry at me, she calls me, "Michael John Montesa!" The family name is Spanish by way of the Philippines, though I was born and raised in the San Francisco Bay area (El Cerrito to be exact). The rest of the family is Dutch, Italian, and Mexican, and when I get around to having kids, we get to add Japanese into the mix (my wife, Emi, is Japanese though I think she's sort of a human/panda mix). My at-home conversations resemble Andy's as well (which get weirder when I speak Greedo to her and she speaks Han Solo to me).

      I'm 38, and for 15 of those years I've taught English in Japan. This is coming to an end this year however, as Emi and I are pulling up stakes and returning to the U.S. To make a long story short, I'm due for a career change and it's time to move.

      I'm obsessed with gaming. I think about it *a lot.* Been playing since I was 12 and started with AD&D1e like everyone else. Was big into Warhammer FRP and Shadowrun for many years, and now I drift from game to game looking for the perfect meld of rules and setting. I run games more than I play them. Got turned onto indie games about 2 years ago and I'm in awe of some of the stuff that's coming out these days and despairing of my inability to ever create something like The Mountain Witch, Polaris, or DitV.

      I have freelanced for a couple of publishers, most recently GWG/PEG, writing the Weird War Two setting for their Savage Worlds line. Working on that, with its gamist (my understanding of the term) focus, has got me seriously trying to come up with a WW2 RPG that isn't Advanced Squad Leader disguised as an RPG. So far, I keep getting blown away as soon as the landing ramp goes down and scrapping whatever ideas I've got since they just seem to suck.

      I could blather on some more, but I will stop. If you want to actually *hear* me blather on some more (god help you), check out the Godzilla Gaming Podcast!
      godzillagamingpodcast.libsyn.com/rss
    • Ivan Dervisevic
      March 2006
      Hey all,

      I visit story-games kinda irregularly and this is my first post here.

      My name is, as in my username, Ivan Dervisevic, I have lived in yugoslavia/serbia and montenegro for my whole life. 22 years old.
      I'm getting a degree in theoretical Computer science, which would be something like a major in math or CS and a minor in the other. I *love* RPGs, started playing them in the 4th grade (11,12 years old?) with ad&d e2 and then,... RIFTS... I am currently trying to get a Polaris group together. I hope.

      I just recently (somewhat less than a year) discovered the Forge, cool indie games and joined up with the people from indienetgaming where I try to get in a game sometimes. Mostly I use iLikeSpoons as my nickname.

      Whate else, that is fun? I traveled through a large part of Europe as an exemplary highschool (and now university) student. I fell in love with Norway and plan to live there, if at all possible (yay for graduate degree scholarships).
      I am really, really in love with my camera (that I am still learning to use properly), but I almost never get the time to put up my photos online... a small selection is on my flickr account:
      Here

      I also collect and paint minis, mostly the lovely, lovely Rackham stuff.
      I haven't and don't plan to write any rpg material soon.

      I'm also a huge BSG and Whedon fanboy right now.

      and, well, that's enough rambling for now.

      Hi, I'm Per Fischer, 42-year-old Dane residing in Edinburgh, Scotland. Married to Susanne and we are raising two great kids, 13 and 16 (nearly 17).

      I've had a hard time finding similar minded roleplayers since moving to Scotland, but luckily I have found a few, one of which is Joe from this forum.

      I have been writing convention scenarios since 1993 and am moving to get my game design ideas out in the open. I have a couple of elderly teaching degrees in Music and History as well as a brand spanking new in Journalism. I write anything. Comic scripts, animation, feature articles, reviews, business plans, you blimming name it. Maybe even rp games.

      Most of my time is wasted at a job-type job doing tech support.

      • I was raised a strict Seventh-Day Adventist (my father's a pastor), but in the last two or three years I've accepted that my personal beliefs fall much more in line with secular humanism.
      • I'm pretty big into Linux and open source software, doing a bit coding myself as a hobby.
      • I"ve visited four countries outside the United States including Kenya where assisted a humanitarian aid effort.
      • I currently work as a Entertainment Specialist for the Target Corporation.
      • I first played an rpg with an older neighbor when I was in first grade, then rediscovered gaming in highschool where suddenly realized what it was I'd been playing as a kid.
      • I have a wiki where I post all my gaming related notes and ideas.
      • I've been toying around with several rpg ideas for a while but finding the time to develop them into actual games has been trying.
    • joshua neff
      March 2006 edited July 2006
      Since I just registered here today, I guess I should post here, too...

      I'm Joshua M. Neff. I'm 36 years old. I identify as Irish and Jewish, but I'm really mostly of Secular Humanist Left-Wing Activist Eastern European Jewish descent, with some other stuff (including Secular Left-Wing Irish) thrown in. By that, I mean that no one in my family has ever really gone to temple or church (my great-grandmother apparently used to spit on the ground whenever she saw a rabbi, being the good Marxist that she was), although my parents got involved in the Unitarian-Universalist church while involved in the Civil Rights Movement, and I grew up going to UU church. (I don't go to church anymore, and my father, who was a UU minister throughout my youth, has since quit and disowned the church. See, there isn't a religion liberal enough for my family.)

      I post on the Forge and RPGnet (although not much lately) under the same username as here, and occasionally make fairly pointless comments and marginalia asides on Anyway as "jmn." I currently live in Olathe, KS (which is now in the ever-expanding greater Kansas City Metro area), but have lived all over the place, including Detroit, Long Island, Iowa City, Chapel Hill, England, Ecuador, Japan, and Milwaukee. I'm a reference librarian at my local public library (which I love like I've never loved any other job). I'm married to a beautiful, witty, wacky, geeky, sexy, moody redhead, Julie, and have adopted (well, not legally--yet) her beautiful, brilliant, nerdy daughter, Morgan, who just turned 9. I've been gaming since I was 10. Julie is also a gamer, going back to high school, although she's much more sporadic about it than I am. I've recently inducted Morgan into the world of RPGs, playing a one-on-one game using the rules of The Shadow of Yesterday adapted to the setting of S. John Ross' Uresia.

      Apart from playing with my daughter, though, I've been taking something of a break from playing RPGs. I've found, though, that I really can't let them go, which is why I registered here.

      Besides playing RPGs and other games and being a librarian, husband and father, I also write (mostly fiction these days--I'm currently working on a hero pulp adventure novel that I intend to serialize on my website) and spend way too much time on-line.

      Oh, and I've recently taught myself how to tie a proper bow tie, which I'm very proud of. My profile picture here is me showing that off. Yes, I wear bow ties to work.

      EDIT: I actually type that my Marxist great-grandmother spit on the ground when she saw a "rabbit" rather than a "rabbi"--and no one noticed! But I fixed the typo anyway.
    • Christoph
      March 2006
      Hello,

      I'm Christoph Boeckle, living between Lausanne and DelÃƒÂ©mont, in Switzerland. I mainly speak french, but having grown up near Zurich I also speak swiss german. I learned english during a three year stay in Ennis, Ireland (I love that country btw). I speak a few words of italian and understand it pretty well.

      Currently I'm slowly turining 23 and studying physics in Lausanne, with a big interest in astrophysics.

      Apart from RPGs, I enjoy all sorts of litterature and movies. I also listen to a lot of metal style music (favorites include Isis, Arcturus, My Dying Bride...), weird stuff (Godspeed, Ulver, Max Richter...) and enjoy going to electronic music parties (from trance to hardcore to drum'n'bass).

    • Old Scratch
      March 2006
      I'm Garett and I post here and elsewhere under "Old Scratch".

      I'm in my early '30s and have been involved in education for some time as both a student and teacher. I'm a trained historian and anthropologist with a focus on Africa and gender issues and I split my time between the States and the UK.

      Interests: vegetarian cooking, gardening and guerrilla gardening, reading, foreign and indie films, and gaming (predictably)!

      Here, I suppose I represent the user end of gaming, whereas many people here are from the design and production end. I really got into gaming with the gaming books like Fighting Fantasy (I remember the first one I ever saw: The Forest of Doom and can recall with perfect clarity passages and images from the book as I experienced them...) and gradually started buying into games... Probably one of the first books I bought was the Mines of Moria for MERP. I spend maybe a hundred hours sifting over that supplement and imagining things long before I even bought the book. It's funny now, because I find reading anything like that now exceedingly difficult!

      I started off quite conventional: playing Robotech and buying early D&D stuff, before I found my main stay of WFRP which I wrote a lot of crap for. A lot. Gradually, I started running games without character sheets, hidden mechanics with the focus on activities, that sort of thing and gradually began experimenting with Hogshead's NewStyle games like the Baron, Pantheon, Puppetland and the like. As I've headed in this direction, my long-time gaming group (12 years plus) seems to be heading in a different direction...

      And here I am now, finally having found something in roleplaying that better meets my need of telling more compelling stories. I think its an incredibly exciting and innovative time in role playing for many of us, and the internet gaming community has really become a fertile garden for innovation.

      My goal is here to continue to be inspired. There's a lot of great conversation going on here with a lot of enthusiasm and courtesy, and ultimately I hope to share and contribute some of my own ideas and enthusiasm with you.
    • Merten
      March 2006
      Hi. I'm Merten and I'm a latercomer.

      Behind the pseudonym, I'm Jukka Koskelin from Helsinki, Finland. I'm 31, married and father of a five-year old girl. I work as a technology specialist, doing computer stuff, currently at insurance sector.

      I've been roleplaying since 1987, both tabletop and live-action roleplaying. I don't live in Turku, but I've been influenced (or the other way around). Other than that, I play floorball, read and try to find time to play console- and computer games.

      I have co-organised a few LARP's and played in some. I'm a sporadic contributor in a (roleplaying) gaming magazine. I'm involved in organizing a (roleplaying) gaming convention.
    • Doug Woolsey
      March 2006
      Before I begin I would like to say that I really dig this community. I've haunted many boards and this one is the only one that feels like a community.

      My nick and my name are the same. I'm living in Springfield, Virginia, having recently moved here from Seattle where I lived just a block away from Pagan Publishing.

      I am presently one of two partners of Sixteen Coal Black Horses. We publish the Battleaxe RPG, a free fantasy RPG.

      I recently graduated from Cornish in Seattle where they eventually decided to award me with a BFA. I concentrated on video and photo, but tried, unsuccessfully, to major in RPG design.

      My first real gig in the game industry was as one of two designers working on one of the designs being considered for a Wheel of Time card game. Our design has never seen the light of day as the contract was eventually awarded to Mayfair, but our little design earned the interest of Mr. Jordan himself.

      Bolstered by that near-success I, and my business partner, decided to try our hand at an RPG. We worked in our spare time while trying to raise our respective families and work full time. Needless to say, it was a long, painful exercise that ended in a ruined marriage and the death (or, at least, deep coma) of the game (World Bazaar, aka Archena Roleplaying). The trauma of that time still haunts that game. I can barely muster the will to speak its name for fear of summoning that time.

      The frustration of that experience fueled the desire to 'get something out there.' The end result was the Battleaxe RPG, a game put together in just a couple of weeks. It felt good to get something done and I put it on the web as a free game. Very soon, one download a day became 20 downloads a day, and, before I knew it, people were writing me to tell me how much they liked the game.

      I applied at a job with Mythic Entertainment citing Battleaxe as prior game experience. The guy who hired me is an avid roleplayer and seemed impressed with Battleaxe. I was hired as a content developer on Imperator. After Imperator was put on hold I accepted a position on the Warhammer Online (WAR) team as lead quest designer. I am now working as lead quest designer and as one of two lead content developers for WAR.

      Battleaxe opened many doors and it continues to teach me valuable lessons. I discovered that design doesn't need to feel like giving birth, but can be loose and organic. I learned that the sacred has no place in design and that the only thing that matters is the vision.

      I am currently working on a second edition of Battleaxe, Black Sunshine -- a little post-apocalypse game that may or may not see release, and am working to publish the strange ramblings of Dr. Jack Roman in an effort called Project Gamma Ray (although that has hit a few snags that may prevent its release).

      I first discovered tabletop roleplaying back in '83 with Stormbringer. That led to Call of Cthulu and then Elfquest. I played a little Star Frontiers, Middle Earth Roleplaying, Marvel Superheroes, and Twilight 2000, but I really started to love roleplaying when I got into Palladium. That led to TMNT and then, of course Rifts. I didn't really like the system of any one of them and the roleplaying group I was in started tinkering and seeing what we could put together. We created a Star Wars and GI Joe RPG sometime in '86 and had a blast playing that for a few years. We would photocopy the rules and hand them out to other friends. We even started leaving stacks of them at our local hobby store.

      These days I don't get enough time to roleplay. There just doesn't seem to be the time. Most recently I had to turn down a Rifts campaign. It nearly broke my heart to say, "No, I can't play."
    • Doug Woolsey
      March 2006 edited March 2006
      Oops -- please delete this post.

Right now I work at a community college, tutoring students in math, but I'm applying to graduate schools.

      Besides gaming, I go hiking, read non-fiction, play around with blacksmithing, and do miscellaneous computer stuff (including a little freelance web/graphic design, but I don't pretend I'm really good). I practice some historical European martial arts; specifically Renaissance German longsword. I'm an atheist.

      I don't game as much as I like, but I have found people who like indie games.

    • Thunder_God
      March 2006 edited March 2006
      Well, been here for a week, today posted my first couple of posts.

      I'm the third Israeli to post here. I live in Alphei Menashe, in the occupied territories.
      I'm 20 and serve as a Medic in the IDF. I serve where they train PE instructors, gym operators, shooting instructors, Krav Maga instructors, etc. The Physical Education center of the IDF.

      I'm an Atheist Jew. Judaism is my culture more than my religion. I don't believe in any being that is higher and/or more powerful than myself(that may or may not contradict belief in God).

      I've been playing DnD since age 9, moved to MtG which was the reason to learn English, and back to RPGs 6 years ago with DnD 3.0. I've been playing competitive MtG for a while, quit and recently returned to it. I'm an Uber-Geek, with Anime, Manga, computer games, console games, comics, etc.

      I'm smarter than most people. I believe modesty is there to make lesser people feel good about themselves. I am bilingual and hope to learn Japanese and Latin in the coming years.

      I have a rarely updated LiveJournal. Mostly because I do not really have a soul. Since I've left HS and got drafted I've been cut off both from HS and from the online Chat I participated in(New Bremen), with the end result of spiritual decay coming over me.

      I read a lot, as much as 1k pages in Hebrew or 700 in English in one day. I'm currently working on my first RPG to be published, Cranium Rats(name may change based on legal state of the term). I am virgin and proud of it.

      My room has no space as it has books, comics, manga and discs all over the shelves, floor and on the table. I used to have a cat but no more, it pains me that my parents will not let me get another one.

      I have studied Computer Programming and Physics at HS and am currently studying Philosophy at the Open University.

      I am not fully sane, The Obsidian Throne has much control. Cold and sane.
      Cold and Sane.
    • DannyK
      March 2006
      I'm Danny K, full name Dan Krashin.

      I live in Seattle, which I like very much even though it's dark and overpriced and rainy. I'm Jewish, although I also have strong Buddhist leanings. I'm also a psychiatrist, which makes me a big ol' walking stereotype. When I grow a beard, I look like somebody's rabbi grandfather.

      I'm 38, so I played D&D in the blue box after I read about it in the cover story in "Psychology Today", also Top Secret, Gamma World, and so on. Later I lived overseas wtih my family and spent a lot of time gaming with grown men, soldiers who were avid gamers in their time off. I played a whole lot of crunchy gamist games like Rolemaster and Arduin Grimoire, which eventually drove me out of the hobby for about ten years.

      About four years ago, a friend of mine got me interested in Vampire: the Masquerade, and that pulled me into White Wolf gaming. After some years of Werewolf, Vampire, and Mage, especially Mage, and spending a lot of time on Ex Libris Nocturnis, I found RPG.Net and discovered a whole new world of gaming.

      I got very obsessed with Nobilis for a while, also discovered Sorcerer and from that found the Forge, have had my ups and downs with the Forge and now try to post judiciously, once in a while. I've tried lots of different games, and now I've settled pretty much on Wushu and PTA as my favorites, only playing other games when there's a good reason to do so.

      I like thinking about and playing with game mechanics, but I don't have the interest or stamina to be a full-fledged game designer. I'd like there to be more games like Sorcer or Dogs where you can tinker at the edges to "roll your own" version without starting from scratch.

      I like hiking and travelling, too, but that's probably enough out of me. I'm happy to see a lot of familiar faces on this site, including folks like Neel, Shreyas, John Kimj, and Paka who are always stretching my mind with their ideas and their play. Oh, fun fact: I'm the only person I've ever met who has GOODLIFE tatooed on them. It's a reference to Saberhagen's "Berserkers" novels, but nobody ever gets that.

    • Mo
      March 2006 edited October 2009
      Hey all,


      I am a woman of mostly Irish descent living in Toronto, Ontario, Canada where I was born, 33 years ago. I'm married to Brand who wooed me in RPG about 8 years ago... and then made me wait five an a half years before getting his damn ass up here from California. We were married on a yacht on Lake Ontario in the summer of 2004, and he landed with full permanent resident status this last November. I don't think I've ever been happier. We have no kids, but might adopt someday.


      I have a BA in English and Cultural Studies from Trent University in Peterborough Ontario where I was a crazy theatre geek and all around nogoodnik freak. My mother was sure I'd be dependent on her until her pension ran out, but two weeks after graduation I got a job for a major telecommunications company to pay my student loans. Ten years later, against all odds (and frequently my best instincts!) I'm now a Business and Systems Analyst in the IT wing of the company.


      Besides the stint at school I've spent most of my life in Toronto. I lived on international assignment in Brazil (Sao Paulo, Campinas, Rio, and Macae) for six months at the start of the millenium. I'm politically leftist, spiritually complicated, and morbidly introspective.


      Hobbywise, I started playing D&D at the York Quay Harbourfront Centre when I was 7, which made my mom happy because it kept me out of her hair for hours at a time on Saturday afternoons. It didn't make her so happy, however, when I was killed (while fighting the giant crab in White Plume Mountain) and ressurected, given a title of nobility. I've never had confirmation from my catholic mom that this was the reason I didn't go back, but I'd say it was a safe bet.


      I came back to gaming in university when a fellow actor asked me to audition for a serial improv "soap" based on VtM but before Mind's Eye, and performed in front of a live theatre audience. I continued to rp through school, but play far more often now than I ever did then. I think it has, in many ways, takenthe place in my life that theatre used to fill. I'm a heavy immersion player (that maintains full authorial control), and I have a strong emotional socket in the characters I play.


      I did a number of books for Tribe 8 a couple of years ago, and learned quickly that there was little reward, either monitarily or emotionally from the process.
      Now I'm interested in design, have a blog over on Sin Aesthetics in which I periodically blather about the stuff I'm interested in. I just finished Crime & Punishment in the Game Chef, which I think I did as a kind of calisthetic brain preparation for finishing 1000 Stories, the game Brand and I working on together. I also have a couple of ideas kicking around in the back of my head that I hope will make it to fruition one day.


      I tend to come and go with my time and focus, so if you ever want me to respond to something that I seem to have missed, feel free to mail me or post over on my blog.


      Outside of RPG's, I make leather molded masks, and am teaching myself to draw. I goof around with graphic design and create crazy elaborate character sheets. I have also recently gotten involved with Habitat for Humanity.


      I'm also, apparently, overly verbose.

    • dyjoots
      April 2006 edited April 2006
      I'm Chris Rogers, I'm twenty-four, and I'm currently living with my wife in Japan. I used to live in Athens, Georgia, but after twenty years, I felt like some change was overdue. When I graduated from college, I was accepted to the Japanese Exchange and Teaching Program, so I've moved about as far from Georgia as you can get. It's quite an experience.

      I miss tacos*.

      I've been playing RPGs for about 13 years, starting with the second edition of WEG's Star Wars. Truthfully, I had read an article in Games Magazine about AD&D 2nd edition a few years before I purchased that book, and had bought dice and devised a couple of rudimentary RPGs on my own. My progression went something like this: Diceless Homebrew --> Star Wars --> GURPS --> White Wolf --> TONS OF STUFF. My wife does play RPGs, so I get some gaming in (most notably The Pool/Puddle, Trollbabe, HeroQuest, and TSoY), but I really miss being able to play with a larger group.

      Outside of games, my interests include linguistics (my major of study in college), Japanese language, jazz saxophone, cooking (despite being rather terrible at it and having a shitty sense of smell), long walks on the beach, and I want to be loved by you. Sounds good to ya, don't it?

      *ahem*

      When I get back to the states in about a year and a half, I am planning on going to grad school and hopefully making my way to some big (or even little) cons so I can meet the people behind the posts.

      I've got a million and a half ideas floating around in my head about games, campaigns, techniques, mechanics and the like, and hopefully I'll get some out on paper in a format that someone wants to read one of these days. While I work on that, I consume any RPG theory related stuff I can without giving myself a headache.



      *Actually, I miss the Cheesy Gordita Crunch, the miraculous ambrosia bestowed upon the common man by the god-king Taco Bell. It's probably the thing that I can't get here that I miss the most, and don't ever let me tell you any different.
    • kleenestar
      April 2006
      I'm Jessica Hammer, I'm 29, and I'm very new here, so, uh, hi. I'm told you don't bite. Please let that be true.

      I'm a graduate student at Columbia in their new game research lab, looking at role-playing and narrative creativity. This means that I basically spend my time role-playing, playing computer games, talking to role-players, watching other people play computer games, and the like. It's a pretty sweet situation, except the grad-student impoverishedness.

      Most of my actual income comes from teaching game design, consulting about games and play, and building games on the side. My first role-playing credit was for writing on Deliria, last year, but I've done computer games, card games, and a massively-multiplayer board game, too. (The consulting stuff pays way better than the game design, though!) My eventual goal is to be a full-time academic, but working on "design research" which means that I can design games and then publish about them.

      I live in New York City with my boyfriend, too many cats, and a small personal library. The boy's a Java programmer; we take turns supporting each other while one of us is unemployed or in school, and right now he's my rock and my compass. He's also my favorite collaborator.

      I've got a brilliant, fantastic group of eccentrics as my RP group, including some of the most talented artists and musicians I've been fortunate enough to meet. We keep meaning to get down to hang out with the nerdnyc folks, but, um, yeah. We'll get there at some point!

      In my (not nearly copious enough) free time, I read, read, read, read, read. I get obsessed with particular topics at times (ancient Rome, cryptography, travel writing), but mostly I'm a fiction junkie. If it's got a good story, I'll read it, watch it, play it, listen to it, improvise it or just plain make it up.

      I also volunteer for an animal rescue and do mentoring for women entering the game development field. I study Spanish and take Tae Kwon Do. I love to cook but hate to wash dishes. I am an ardent feminist, an semi-observant Jew and a passable programmer. I'm just getting involved in improv theater, and wondering why I didn't do so years ago.

      I've got a bunch of personal game design projects going on, including a couple of card games and two role-playing projects. I've got a website at replayable.net, but right now nothing much is up there. If you want to get a look at what I'm working on, I put together Decade for the Game Chef contest. On the non-roleplaying front, my team just won the Mobile Game Mosh, a 24-hour game design and development competition. That and other projects should be up at replayable eventually (i.e. when I finally finish the *@#&;$ book chapter I'm writing!).

      I'm quite shy about meeting people in the community, but I recognize a lot of the names here, even if I haven't met most of you. Hello, smart people. I'm looking forward to playing with you.















    • JDCorley
      April 2006
      Arizona Bar Association represent, yo.

      I'm Jason Corley, I'm 31, I live in Tucson, Arizona, where I'm a lawyer who represents Child Protective Services in cases of child abuse and neglect. Basically I help children. That's my job.

      I got there via a degree in mathematics and another in philosophy.

      I'm married to a brain researcher, I have no children, a nice brick house in a very Latino neighborhood. I've won National Novel Writer's Month twice (out of four tries). However, I am very proud of my Yoknapatawpha County supplement for Trinity, because that was sheer total fucking insanity - and it got finished.
    • Ian Cooper
      May 2006
      I'm Ian Cooper. I'm 38 and live in London where I work as a software developer.

      I have a degree in English Literatrue and a post-graduate diploma in computer science (I never had time to do the project that makes that a masters).

      I'm married to Vanessa, a lawyer for the local council. We have no children nor real plans for any.

      I got into gaming when I was 10, gamed until I went to university and then really dropped out for lack of time and interest. I kept reading gaming material for games I loved, but never had much enthusiasm for tabeltop gaming.

      I got back into it when Issaries relased Hero Wars, because suddenly I found a game that worked for me as I was now. The Forge really helped me to see why, but I still feel I am on the journey back from the habits I learned to new ones. Now I play every week again.
    • munkholt
      May 2006
      I'm Thomas Munkholt, 35, living in Copenhagen, Denmark. I was educated to become a teacher (major subjects were English and Religion), today I work as editor of a small publisher of children's book.

      I am married Ã¢â‚¬â€œ my wife and I met through RP, actually, but didn't hook up until a few years ago. We'll have a kid in a week or two, which is pretty daunting. We live with two friends in a fantastic apartment in the old part of the city.

      We're all four of us active in the RP-community. My current project is to create a forum for Danish writers of convention scenarios, which is a strong and rather unique subculture.
    • talysman
      May 2006
      I didn't even realize this thread was here until Ian and Thomas resurrected it, but I'm always slow to post to threads like this. My name is John Laviolette, which is why you occasionally see a few people here call me "John L." I'm 42 ad thought I was the oldest gamer here, but it looks like Thor and Shawn got me beat. The number of 40+ people here suprises me.

      Ethnically, I'm pretty mixed, mostly Scots Irish, French, and Cherokee. Geographically, I was born near Sacramento, California and have lived here most of my life, but grew up in Rantoul, Illinois (which isn't that far from the Champaign-Urbana area where Stuart lives.) There were stopovers in Hawaii, Colorado, Wisconsin and Oklahoma as well.

      This means that i was in Illinois in the early '70s, where I was introduced to a weird variant of brown-box D&D (someone had renamed Wisdom to Piety and added a spell point system.) I played several other games since then and tried designing a couple, then kind of set that aside and started thinking about creating setting materials until I discovered the Forge and wound up getting seriously into game design.

      I don't get to actually play much lately. I see the guy I played Traveller and D&D with almost every week, but he's too busy to game these days, while the people I played Tibet/Fates Worse Than Death/In Dark Alleys with moved up to Eureka (not far from Arcata, where Ben grew up,) so I only game with them about three times a year. I get most of my gaming in conventions, which I only started to go to in the last two years.

      My big time eater isn't roleplaying, it's writing, video and music. I'm apparently the only person here who is into experimental music/noise, so it doen't mean much to anyone when I say I perform noise and have tracks on a couple comp CDs. I also compose lyrics and arrangements with friends as part of that insane humorous band InterrÃƒÂ¶bang Cartel that I've mentioned before.

      I also like to travel, when I have spare funds. I visit friends in Boston, Providence, and DC about once a year and made it to England twice. Aside from visiting friends on these trips, I also take in historic and bizarre local sites.

      Professionally, I work in tech support. Familywise, I've never been married and have no kids, and though I would like both of those things, I've come to the conclusion that it's better for someone of my personality to stay single..

      This is already far more than I've ever written about myself, so I guess I'll stop here.
    • thor
      May 2006
      Experimental Music, what sorts? (Ears perking up)

      I am a big fan of the minimalists (Terry Reiley especially) and old noise rock things like the Swans or Foetus. My wife isn't into it much so I don't listen much anymore.
    • mneme
      May 2006
      Hi -- I'm Joshua Kronengold, Aka mneme, mnemex, mnemesys, Josh, Joshua, or Josh K, or Joshua K (but not Josh Kronengold). I'm 34.

      I don't have a lot of industry cred -- a UA writing credit, a bunch of playtest credit, and some design credit for Shadowfist (the hong-kong movie CCG). I've been a contributor to the venerable RPG APA Alarums and Excursions for over 12 years. And I've got two livejournals -- a personal one, mnemex and a gaming livejournal I share with Lisa Padol, labcats. I live in Queens, NYC, but work and spend most of my time in Manhatten.

      I'm into RPGs (Theatre Style LARPs, quasi-freeform and indy RPGs), sf and fantasy, sf fandom and filk music, board and card gaming (which I play with the Columbia Games Club on most friday evenings), the CCG Shadowfist, and perl. I've been into, but am currently not really active in historical and classical fencing, the SCA,, and origiami.

      I'm partnered with Lisa Padol, and have done most of my recent RPG play with her. We're currently doing a PBEM set in her older-than-a-decade long campaign, Cthulhupunk, Messages in a Bottle, a letter game with (currently) three players (readable here: http://labcats.org/pipermail/bottle_labcats.org/ ), Lisa's Sorceror game, playing in Beth Bartley's recently re-activated Hub game (SF, OTE rules, James Schmitz's hub as setting), and playing in a friend's D&D3.5 game.

      I'll occasionally get the urge to design something. Usually, I sit quietly until it passes; occasionally it will get loose (which is why you'll find some LARP mechanics on the labcats journal). Maybe some day I'll do something more coherent. In the same way, I'll occasionally get the urge to write a song, usually, though not always, to someone else's tune.
    • Larry
      May 2006

      John L,

      I'm really interested to know more about this D&D variant with Piety and spell points, since that's the system that was used by the computer game Wizardry. (1981) I always thought it was an odd thing to change from "real" D&D, it didn't occur to me that it might have a P&P antecedent, but I suppose it makes sense.

    • Arref
      May 2006 edited April 2007
      Just for fun, I am going to Pull (see other threads.)

      I am not Arref.
      In living fiction I have become more real.
      Neither am I young. Neither am I religious in any Western sense.
      I began doing rpg when I was seven or eight years old. Many of my campaigns have been influenced by comics more than SF or Fantasy, yet I have done more Fantasy campaigns than not. I love rpgs.

      The imagination is a great gift.

      I live in Pittsburgh and hope to meet NeelK someday.

      I have a blog for Amber DRPG ideas and rpgs in general. I have a livejournal but can't explain why.

      I can't keep up with Forge-speak, even having a go at the glossary that Doyce so kindly provided. The lingo drifts into the early morning mists and is gone.

      I am the oldest poster so far (by a lot). That's probably of little merit or interest.
      For more of who I am not, you may read the blog.
      Thanks for sharing. Pretty exciting diversity.
    • rrr23
      May 2006 edited May 2006
      Hello all, here is a collection of random facts about me.

      I'm Drew. I live just outside North London in the UK. I'm 30 and live with my troo love Jen and a roguishly delinquent cat called Zoe. Despite what you may believe about any other felines in your acquaintance, my cat actually is the most beautiful cat in the world. This is a scientific fact, I can prove it with an etchasketch.

      I was born and grew up in London, so naturally, whilst I hate the place in many ways I can't bring myself to live too far away. Hertfordshire is a good compromise: nice countryside and not too polluted and dirty, but only 30 mins from the centre of the Big Smoke.

      My job is "technical support coordinator" in a large college. It's pretty good. I used to work in TV production until I realised I don't like being exploited by assholes.

      I like old classic cars, and have 2 currently which I am attempting to restore and hope to rally one day. A 1968 Triumph Herald 1200 (runs, used daily) and a 1973 BMW 3.0si (sat in a garage awaiting major work). I had a Ford Capri 2.8i Special too, but I had to sell it (*sob*) as I couldn't really afford them all.

      My favourite movies are in no particular order: The Big Lebowski, Withnail and I, The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou and The Princess Bride.

      I like reading; favourite authors at the mo are: Greene, Ballard, Dostoevsky, Vonnegut, Le Guin also just getting in to Le Carre.

      I've not published anything in the RPG world, although I'm working on a couple of designs.

      Lots of people think I look like Dr Green from ER, that's cool but the resemblance is superficial only: I am slightly balding and have the same beard.

      Anyway, that about it for now.

      Drew
    • talysman
      May 2006

      Thor:

      Experimental Music, what sorts? (Ears perking up)

      I guess you could describe my stuff as a cross between musique concrete and algorithmic music used to create ambient sound textures. Except that I use a lot of delay and effects, because I mostly play in settings where the preferred styles are tablecore, power electronics, free jazz, and percussive or drone pieces. I'm getting harsher all the time.

      Larry:

      I'm really interested to know more about this D&D variant with Piety and spell points, since that's the system that was used by the computer game Wizardry.

      I don't recall all the details and might have a slightly skewed version of the system. A friend of mine was in some kind of remedial math class in junior high; the teacher used his modified version of D&D as a teaching tool. My friend then ran D&D games with me and one other person and I was able to get copies of his spell lists, saving throw tables, monster tables, etc., which I later discovered were exact copies of the tables in the original rulebooks, so I was playing D&D without ever seeing either the original books or the full house rules this teacher had created.

      As far as i recall, this system renamed Wisdom as Piety and otherwise kept clerics the same. However, as I've thought it over, I'm wondering if Piety was a separate score and I'm just forgetting how he used Wisdom.

      The spell system was the exact same spell list, but instead of memorizing individual spells, you had so many points of "Magical Conductivity". Every use of a first-level spell cost something like 1d4 points of Magical Conductivity, second level cost 1d6 or thereabouts, with the range and at some point the number of dice increasing for each spell level. We played this way in either '75 or '76, since it was before I went to junior high myself and my friend was a year ahead of me.

    • Judson_Lester
      May 2006
      My name's Judson Lester and I always feel weird about talking about myself. You'll sometimes see me posting as nyarly.

      I'm a 30 year old systems admin, living in Burbank, CA with my partner Stacey and the rest of our postmodern family. We're rapidly approaching the final planning stages of having kids.

      I've been role playing and gaming pretty regularly since about 12, and I've got a few games currently in design, but for the most part I think I've yet to make any lasting mark in the hobby at large. Yet.
    • buzz
      July 2006
      (Apologies for the necromancy, but I'm having such a good time here that I wanted to post.)

      My name is Mark Delsing, though my username "buzz" is actually a genuine meatspace nickname I've had since about '97 or so. It's also my username on ENworld, RPG.net, The Forge, Hero Games' forum, and other places I've probably forgotten about.

      I'm a soon-to-be 36-year-old living in Aurora, IL and work for OfficeMax as a UI Designer. I'm married to Earth' Greatest Wife; she's teaches high school. We have no kids; just a dog and cat. My dad is Punjabi and my mother is German, which makes me... an American. I went to Bard College in upstate NY and received both a BA in English and a massive pile of debt. I grew up in Skokie/Evasnton, IL, and lived in Boston for a while after college.

      I started RPG'ing in 1981 with the original Moldvay Basic D&D set (no dice, just "chits"). I played mostly AD&D1e and V&V in high school, moving to Rolemaster, Call of Cthulhu, and Champions in college. Then came the Great Dark TimeÃ¢â€žÂ¢ from about '91 to '01 when I didn't really game much at all. Then 3e came out, and there was much rejoicing. Since then, I have gamed more often and more regularly than at any point in my life previous.

      Currently, I am in three biweekly groups: all-D&D, mostly-D&D, and HERO. I also act as organizer and pimp-type-guy for ENWorld Chicago Gameday.

      It was a few months ago that I somehow happened upon Chris Chinn's blog, Deep in the Game, which is now a daily stop for me. This initiated a snowball effect that eventually got me thoroughly converted to Forge theory and interested in indie RPGs. I hope to actively play more of them in the future.

      I have no published RPG credits, though I did get a letter printed in Dragon once.

      Outside of gaming, I like to record relatively offensive yet humorous rock music. I read a lot, though lately it's been mostly game texts and graphic novels. My "Joss Whedon is my master now" t-shirt is a prized possession. My wife and I rarely go out to the movies anymore, but Netflix and Buffy/Angel DVDs (see above) are our close friends. Oh, I'm a dedicated Mac user, too.
