    • Dave Younce
      July 2006
      Wow - I totally missed this thread. Here goes:

      I am 28, married, with an almost-three-year-old daughter (Hilde) & a just-turned-one son (Enoch). I'm in Centreville, VA, where I work as a software engineer/web developer for a smallish defense contractor. Degree is in CS, from George Mason University nearby here.

      I like to garden a bit, like to cook (and eat!), watch a lot of film, and read books on everything from salt to Rastafarianism to mythology to whatever. I'm active at my church (Mormon), which is part of what piqued my interest in Dogs in the Vineyard and from there I got interested in all kinds of story-gaming. I also like boardgames and just started CRPGing in WoW.

      I started roleplaying sometime in the late 80s when I found my sister's old copy of the D&D 1E Players Handbook, and have played off and on (mostly on) since then, largely with the same small group of gamers, and almost all D&D, with a little Marvel Superheroes & Star Wars back in the day. Now I GM, and I'm pressing for more indie-gaming. It's going to be lots of fun.

      I havent designed any full games, but I have a couple of ideas brewing and a few thoughts on mechanics & such. I also have a cool idea for an online gamehelp application that I'm excited to start working on.

      I've never met any of you in person, yet.

    • Doyce
      July 2006 edited July 2006
      Didn't know about this thread. Buzz can resurrect the thing, and I'll feed it some brains.

      I'm Doyce Alan Testerman, and I'm surprised how many of you people I know.

      I started gaming back around the time that E.T. came out in theatres, I think. DnD red box. I was about 10. I didn't know what the hell I was doing, but I did it. Got the hang of AD&D in high school.

      Played Ad&D and Shadowrun and Champs and d6 Star Wars and WarhammerFRP and Dangerous Journeys and about a dozen other things in college. I also started playing and coding mushes back then. I put up my first web page (bears-cave, which I still own the .com for) in '91 or '92. I also got married back at that point, for about a month. Let's just pretend that didn't happen.

      I bought AmberDRPG in somehting like 1994 and it blew my tiny little mind. Started running a game before I'd even found the Amber books. Started reading the Amber Mailing List (which would be when I first 'met' Arref and Iago (that crazy bastard who wrote about running Amber using FUDGE) and keeping a web page for my Amber stuff, which is still up.

      Moved to Denver in 1995. Started another Amber game and coding on a MUSH on which I met Adam. I gave up mush and mud games a little later. Ran d20 for awhile, for the old-skool.

      I got very very tired of the ADRPG 'system', got into Nobilis for awhile (which I still really like). It was on that mailing list where I first read stuff by Tony LB, I think (and I think I was one of the folks telling him to get his butt over to the Forge).

      Since the Forge infected my brain, I've run Sorcerer, Paladin, TSoY, Inspectres, Trollbabe, Heroquest alot, DitV a little, and I own a bunch of other things like Donjon and Universalis and Capes and (most recently) Don't Rest Your Head and Nine Worlds. I need to get With Great Power.

      Edit: Oh yeah -- I host RandomWiki, which in turn hosts a whole lot of indie game stuff. The core seed of that wiki is the Sorcerer section, which I put together to help me grok that game. In turn, people have been using it toward that same purpose with a bunch of other games, as well as game theory -- all of which I think is awesome, even when (like Arref) it's Theory stuff that I'll never really 'get'.

      I was married to a gamer for about 6 years. We have an amazing daughter, about a year old, and her mom and I are still very good friends, and even game together -- fuck all those divorce stereotypes: it's all about the best thing for your kid. I haven't gamed much at all in the last year, due to the little girl -- that's starting to change again, and I'm happy about that.

      I date a gamer-girl who plays on the periphery of the nerdNYC crowd (and yeah, that's a long-ass commute for me), and through her I've met some of those folks in the last six months or so. I'm acquiring a literary agent right now to work on mainstream publishing the books I write.

      I'm 35. I haven't met any of you face to face, and I'd kinda like that to change.

      Hmm. That's about it.



    • Marhault
      July 2006
      I'm James Crook, but I go by Jamey. I am married (non-gamer), with no kids. Instead, I've got two cats and a dog. I grew up in upstate New York (Almond, NY. Just try to find it, I dare you!), but moved to Columbus, Ohio about five years ago.

      I love games! I love Indie RPGs, and have been working on developing my own, off-and-on, for quite a while. Unfortunately, I haven't played enough, mostly just read them.

      Man, it's weird coming out from behind the handle like this.

    • efindel
      July 2006
      ... and another who didn't know about this thread.

      I'm Travis Casey, 36 years old. Online, I go by efindel everywhere I can (strangely, the name was already taken on AIM, so there I'm targaroth). I live in Tallahassee, Florida with my new wife Sandy (just got married July 1!), two cats, a dog, a ferret, and two part-time children (my daughter by a previous marriage, who I have half the time, and her son by a previous, who we have summers and for holidays).

      I started gaming with D&D at 10 years old, and made my first system (a superhero mod of D&D) within a year. Since then, I've read and played pretty much every RPG I could get my hands on. The ones I've played the most are AD&D1 and 2, FASA's Star Trek, TORG, first edition Chill, Shadowrun, Elfquest, and my own homebrew universal RPG... but more about that in a minute.

      After high school, I went to FSU here in Tallahasee, and got a BS in physics. My undergrad years were when I designed and threw away three different universal RPGs before hitting on the one I used for years -- "Omniverse", a sort of hybrid of 1st edition CORPS and TORG. Late in that period, I also got involved in the design of FUDGE enough to earn a credit in it.

      I'd minored in Computer Science, and my grades there were actually better than in Physics, so I turned to CS for my Master's. While there, I got involved with MUDs, eventually becoming an administrator on SWmud, a Star Wars-themed LPmud. I started work on PsyberAge, a cyberpunk-with-psionics mud, using a variant of Omniverse, but it fell apart due to interpersonal issues before it got anywhere.

      Around that time, I started doing PBEM RPGs, then got into an online D&D campaign with old friends, run using WebRPG, then OpenRPG, then KloogeWerks. I've played via IRC with the Indie-Netgaming crew, and was a playtester for Capes.

      I wrote a column called Things That Go Bump in My Head for the short-lived gaming magazine Cryptych, and later wrote another column for Skotos -- Building Stories, Telling Games. Both were paying gigs that helped finance my RPG habit for a while.

      Speaking of habits, I collect RPGs -- mainly ones that I consider to be of some historical significance to the hobby, or to have interesting systems. I've got a couple hundred right now.

      The games that I'd most like to play, but haven't, are Burning Wheel, Dogs in the Vineyard, Polaris, and The Shadow of Yesterday. I got divorced and then married again in the last year, so I haven't gotten much actual play done in about a year and a half now.

      My wife is a gamer as well -- these days mainly playing freeform online RPGs. She's also active in the SCA.

      My day job is as a Unix system administrator. At home, I ran Linux for several years, but last year finally got tired of being my own sysadmin at home as well as work, and switched to OS X. Which still has me doing sysadmin stuff, but not as often. I don't have an intense dislike of Windows, but do hate Microsoft's current licensing schemes. I keep checking on ReactOS in hopes that they'll get to something useful... but don't currenly have an Intel-based PC at home to play with it on.

      I have a LiveJournal that's rarely updated, and a web site that's even more badly in need of updating.

      My "current" gaming project has been on the back burner for most of the last year, due to the aforementioned life events. It's a vampire game called "... and cast no shadow", and I hope to get back to it soon.

      I haven't met anyone here face-to-face. I'll be at DragonCon this year, and would sincerely like to meet people. I'm hoping to get to GenCon sometime soon -- maybe next year (cross fingers).
    • Mcdaldno
      July 2006
      My name is Joe McDonald.
      I am 18 years old, currently live in Nakusp, BC, Canada.

      I hate the people I have grown up with in this town, and am leaving in 18 days forever.
      Which might sound a bit harsh... but being a open-minded, atheistic, non-jock, bisexual in a redneck, church-heavy logging town is hell.

      Highlight of my life thus far was going to Sri Lanka, where I spent a month doing tsunami rebuilding and teaching ESL. I really want to work overseas at some point - possibly teaching ESL.

      I'm starting University next year at University of British Columbia.
      I'm leaning towards majoring in Gender Studies and minoring in Linguistics, right now...
      But I don't really have to make that decision yet.

      I am an atheist, and a nihilist.
      I believe that the lack of inherent meaning in life or an afterlife is both liberating and inspiring - I have only to empower myself, earn some form of personal fulfillment, and become the person I want to be. There is no higher code or doctrine that I believe in. Yeah, liberating.

      My job is currently Content Developer for an online game project based out of Vancouver. It's basically my dream job right now - high pay, work my own hours, a lot of focused creative energy... nice boss, cool project.

      Um... I love Chuck Palahniuk's books. Haunted destroyed me. Fight Club has been the single largest book influence in my life to date.
    • Meguey
      July 2006 edited July 2006
      I'm Meguey Baker, I turned 35 in March, and I've been actively in a game ever since my neighbor got the red box D&D when I was 7. The 'gue' in my name is pronounced as in 'guest'. It's Spanish, and my parents were hippies *shrug* I'm German-Swedish-Scottish-American, in order of amount. I grew up in upstate New York in the 70's and went to high school in San Diego in the 80's. After 6 years, I got as far as possible from SoCal, and came to MA.

      I'm a Unitarian Universalist with eclectic Pagan tendancies.

      I live with my most excellent husband/partner/friend of 15 years, Vincent Baker; our great sons, Sebastian 9.5 yrs, Elliot 6 yrs, and Tovey 7 mos; our three cats who go by Goofy, Needy, and Bossy currently; a couple thousand books; and my 30+ boxes of fabric.

      What do I do with my time, ideally?
      Quilt (graduated Hampshire College w/BA in early American textile History),
      Dance (started studying belly dance 10 years ago),
      Talk about sex ( I teach sex ed to high school kids in the UU church),
      Play outside (planting irises, mucking about in the woods, badminton, swimming),
      Read (a lot, in all genres)
      Play (RPGs, board, card)

      Want more? There's a whole bit [url=http://www.fairgame-rpgs.com/comment.php?entry=8]here.[/url]

    • markv
      July 2006
      I'm Mark Vallianatos. I post as markv here & as redivider to rpg.net and the forge.

      I'm 35. I live in Pomona, california with my wife Johanna (a professor of children's theatre, creative drama, and puppetry at Cal State San Bernardino), our nearly 2 year old daughter Katya, and 4 cats.

      I work at the Urban and Environmental Policy Institute at Occidental College in L.A. where I'm currently the institute's managing director and director of its Center for Food and Justice. I'm co-author of The Next Los Angeles: the struggle for a livable city, a book about L.A.'s hidden progressive history and its political possibilities). Before moving to Cali in 2000, I lived and worked in Washington D.C., specializing in international trade law and environmental issues.

      I grew up in Alexandria VA. I started role-playing in 1981 and played a lot of AD&D, gama world, top secret, and boot hill, with a bit of exposure to a few non-tsr rpgs. I stopped playing rpgs between about 1988 and 2001. D&D 3rd edition got me back into things and I've branched out from there.

      I've been working on a few game design projects for 3 years or so. I haven't published anything (although my late 90s report 'License to Loot' on the multilateral agreement on investment Sounds like it Could have been a game title.) I hope that Heads of State: nine short games about Tyrants, which our LA Games group recently play-tested, will see light later this year or early next.

    • Frank T
      July 2006 edited April 2010
      Me too.

      IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m Frank. I live in the Free and Hanseatic City of Hamburg, GermanyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s second largest and clearly most beautiful city, where I was born and raised, just like my father and grandfather before me. My last name is Tarcikowski, but nobody can pronounce that.

      IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m 29, divorced from my Persian ex-wife, but still a member of the Persian shiite community since I never bothered to quit. But actually, I consider myself agnostic.

      I have studied law and work as a lawyer for corporate and insolvency law. Next weekend, I will move into a nice new flat with my fantastic girlfriend Nicole. SheÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a 21 year-old secretary and part time goth, which is probably why I am getting tattooed and pierced, and hang out at metal concerts and SM parties while my schoolmates buy houses and get babies. I could go on about how Nicole keeps me young and how our relationship is everything everybody kept telling me was impossible, but itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s boring without the nasty details.

      Nicole is also getting into gaming a little lately. She is one hell of a kick-ass gamist if IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve ever seen one.

      Of course, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m an RPG fanatic (why else would I be here). I would gladly become a fulltime RPG author if only thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d pay the bills. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m also a sucker for GunsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢nÃ¢â‚¬â„¢Roses and Manowar. And I love all kinds of fantasy novels. Never could get myself to read Ã¢â‚¬Å“realÃ¢â‚¬Â literature. Do love Shakespeare, though.

      Some other stuff I have some talent for, but didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t really get around to much, include drawing, piano, composing, and writing. Well, I published a short story in an anthology for Ã¢â‚¬Å“Das Schwarze AugeÃ¢â‚¬Â once. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m hopelessly useless at sports, though, which sucks, but what can you do.
    • MikeRM
      July 2006
      Ah, good thread resurrection, I missed this one. Let's see if this tag will fix the formatting:

      I'm Mike Reeves-McMillan. The Reeves is from my wife, who I met online before that was common. We were friends for a couple of years then figured ourselves out, and she left California (she's from Bakersfield) to live with me in my hometown of Auckland, New Zealand. We have the standard 2.2 cats (they give 110%).

      I'm glad to discover I'm not the only Mike, the only New Zealander, the only Mike from NZ, or the oldest person here. I just turned 39.

      I have a lot less RPG experience than most of you, having only played for a few years in my late 20s (AD&D mostly, a bit of d6 system in a setting mashup of Star Wars, Star Trek and Doctor Who). I don't have a gaming group at the moment but reading about all these great indy games makes me want to assemble one in order to play them. My friends are all postmodern hippy creative people so my chances are probably better than average, though most of them have small children which means their time and energy is limited.

      I get interested in far too many things for me to ever do any of them well. Hopefully that is changing; I've finished both a nonfiction book and a novel this year and the next step is probably to self-publish (since with traditional publishing of your first book you generally end up doing most of the promotion anyway). Most of my creative stuff is over at my website: C-Side Media.

      I have an MA in English language, which got me into publishing, then technical writing. I learned enough to become a systems analyst, which is more or less what I still do. However, last year I did a Certificate in Celebrant Studies with the aim of making rituals for people in transition through crisis, and this year I'm doing an Advanced Diploma in Hypnotherapy which I hope will enable me to earn a living in a way that isn't IT, and more importantly make a significant difference to people's ability to live their lives positively.

      I practice a slightly odd kind of Christianity and hope someday to get good at it. I like to say that I'm not a heretic, just orthodox in an unusual mode, but I don't think anyone is fooled.
    • Meguey
      July 2006
      MikeRM
      I don't have a gaming group at the moment but reading about all these great indy games makes me want to assemble one in order to play them. My friends are all postmodern hippy creative people so my chances are probably better than average, though most of them have small children which means their time and energy is limited.

      Speaking as an indy gamer parent, there are a whole slew of games that fit with parenting. I particularly reccomend Primetime Adventures, InSpectres, Dogs in the Vineyard, Breaking the Ice, Polaris, and (if I may say so) 1001 Nights. I just ran a Buffy-verse PTA game with 5 kids ages 6 mos to 6 years running around in the background.

    • MikeRM
      July 2006 edited July 2006
      I can't believe I didn't mention books, given that it's the nearest thing I have to an addiction. I just spent $1200 on bookcases. Probably denial or something. Anyway: F&SF, for a long time more the F than the SF but that seems to be changing more recently - I'm just getting so sick of "genre fantasy" recycling the same ideas. Permanent favourites are Terry Pratchett and Lois McMaster Bujold, others come and go. Also a wide range of odd nonfiction stuff in the realm of spirituality, esoterica, the mind and suchlike.

      Like Kuma, I have a creeping sense that games are a genre whose time is about to come, hence my interest in being around where the foundations are being laid. So I can bore people when I'm old by telling them that I hung out on a forum with all the game designers that are now household names, yeah, I knew those guys back before they were even famous...

      EDIT: You know, famous outside the 'hood. World famous.
    • ross

    • susan
      July 2006
      I'm Susan Harper.
      I love to role-play, enjoy making up worlds, quite like running games, but don't like reading rules.

      (Born in Wellington, New Zealand in 1969, and living here now too, my Philosophy degrees have been a more useful grounding for my career as a parent than I expected them to be for anything).
    • Matthijs
      July 2006
      I haven't posted here yet? Huh.

      I'm 34 years old and live in a small town (approx 10,000 inhabitants) in Norway. It's great in summer and depressing in winter, and now it's summer, so I won't bitch.

      I'm married to a pretty girl who's also a psychologist, and we've got two children, Peder Benjamin (almost 5) and Oda Jeanette (1). They're amazing in very many ways, and I learn a lot from them; what fascinates me these days is how different children are even from birth, and how much effect small initial differences can have on personality. One is more sensitive than the other, which causes radically different behavior. I used to think you could teach kids anything, that they were blank slates, and that later they could just change their personality as they liked, but these days I feel pretty deterministic.

      I've written the Norwegian RPG Draug, and recently received an arts grant to work on the holocaust RPG "We all had names". With the recent developments in Israel, I have a lot to think about.

      I've internalized a lot of Big Model stuff and Forge-speak in the last two years; however, I'm also part of the Nordic tradition, which softens things up and lets me be more slow about everything. I wish I were a Kenotic Immersive, since that's such a cool term, but I'm just this guy, you know? Perhaps I'll write an article about immersionism sometime.

      Besides playing a lot and reading & talking & thinking WAY too much about RPG's, I work as a programmer, design stuff for my board game "Kampen om Rai", and write fiction, and never cease to be amazed at the difference between what's important in the world and what people get paid to do.
    • Meguey
      July 2006
      Posted By: Matthijsnever cease to be amazed at the difference between what's important in the world and what people get paid to do.
      Hear, hear!

      As a 'stay-at-home Mother', I *hate* the 'so what do you do?' question, because the person asking wants to know one thing I get paid to do, not the five things I get paid for and the 500 other things.

      When someone asks me what I "do" I say I take care of my wife and children.
    • rossum
      July 2006 edited July 2006
      I'm Mischa Damon Krilov, male, 31. My girlfriend and I have our seven year anniversary in January.

      I've lived in New Orleans all my life except for five years in Baton Rouge for college and the last ten months in Austin due to Katrina.

      I got my first modem for my Commodore 64 in 1986 or so.

      I cut my teeth on Red Box D&D in the mid eighties and grew out of roleplaying until high school, where I heard about other games, particularly Cyberpunk and Call of Cthulhu. I honestly believe that these were my formative years when it comes to roleplaying; not-traditional-fantasy and character-driven-intrigue is very integral to my style play.

      I think I'm a better player than GM.

      To the best of my knowledge, I personally only know Clinton and Judson here.

      My first real live published roleplaying game, 1984 Prime, won the 2005 Game Chef competition.

      I'm too pleased that my post is #187 in this thread. (Seen Demolition Man? All will make sense.)

      I play the didgeridoo.

      I've always been something of a computer geek, and I currently get paid to be a sysadmin/IT guy, but I want out. I'm generally platform-agnostic, but I own a shiny new MacBook and my girl runs Ubuntu Linux.

      I will edit this in the future.

      I have a blog you can read.

      MDK







    • Iskander
      July 2006
      Aaaah, the sweet smell of necromancy in the morning!

      I am Alexander Newman. I live with my beloved partner of nearly 3 years, Andrew, in Astoria, NY. He's a composer and pianist.

      I was born in England, and mostly raised in London, although I was exiled to boarding schools between the ages of 8 and 18, and spent summers in Greece - so I speak a little Greek with what I've been told is a peasant accent.

      I travelled around the world before going to college, stopping to teach English in Bangkok, where I also lived as a status symbol for a police colonel, along with the family astrologer. I first came out to a stranger in the hill village of Mae Hong Son in Northern Thailand, over a bottle of some awesome prune liquor. Later, on the same journey, I came out my best friend, Ben, in a sit-down fish and chip shop in Sydney, Australia. I am now godparent to his second daugher (of four or five kids). Coming out to Ben was so painful, I resolved never to leave new friends or colleagues in a position where it wasn't clear to them where my interests lay - a policy that has served me well.

      I have an MA in Mathematics from Oxford, although I only sat the BA degree - it's a quirk of history - and resided at Keble College. I got the lowest Third in my year, because I precisely deduced the minimum achievement that required the award of an honours degree. As a result I left a majority of my finals papers after 30 minutes, to the envy (I assume) of many of my colleagues. It hasn't seemed to hurt me any.

      I was an activist for many years at Oxford, and with OutRage! London, but never succeeded in getting arrested, although my friend Philip and I sparked a riot outside the Houses of Parliament, once.

      I have a BA in Acting from the Guildhall School of Music and Drama, in London, where I coincided with Orlando Bloom - who I didn't know that well, but saw regularly in tights. My acting career has yet to take off.

      I left the UK six years ago, partly because I wanted to live in New York City, but mostly because I couldn't deal with being around my crazy family any more. The Atlantic is a great healer, as are timezone differences.

      I am currently unemployed: I was laid off from a programming job for a big Wall St. firm in January, but the stars seem to be aligning for a super-cool new technical writing job in New York.

      My first RPG was D&D in 1982 or 3, and I played sporadic games of D&D, a whacky scifi homebrew and Call of Cthulhu for about four or five years after that, then went on a 20-year hiatus. I am glad the hiatus ended with the discovery of nerdNYC and the GGG. I also play many boardgames, word games, mind game, and status games. I currently have a love affair with Plunder!
    • tetsujin28
      July 2006
      Hey! Nice to see folks I recognize from other forums :)

      Anyways, I'm Britton Daniel, and I'm 39. I'm currently in my second career as a museum archaeologist and conservator -- I'll be doing my graduate work starting in the fall at St. Chad's College, University of Durham. Previously, I worked in the film industry for far too long as a best boy electric, gaffer, and lighting technician. Did a lot of theatre and opera, as well.

      Started gaming in '74, with Napoleonic miniatures. My first game of D&D was in '76, but I didn't really understand it 'till '77. And then Runequest came out, and changed everything.
    • droog
      July 2006
      Hey, tets, how come you got three weeks from RPG.net? I missed it.
    • philaros
      July 2006 edited December 2006

      Well, if Buzz hadn't revived this thread recently, I would have done so. And I was pleased to see mentioned in some other thread around here that the management (i.e. Andy) are fine with so-called "thread necromancy," as I've never really understood the opposition to continuing perfectly good threads.

      Anyhow: I'm Philip LaRose. I'm 36, a New Hampshire native, child of Franco-Americans who are children of French-Canadians stretching back to the late seventeenth century. I lived in my hometown until 2000, then lived with a couple guys and the world's largest collection of media in a rented house in Medford, Massachusetts (just outside Boston) for about 18 months, before a college friend called me up and told me to move to Seattle and work for his company, which I did. I've been in Seattle since March 2002 and will be quite content to stay the rest of my life. Oh yeah, trivia moment: I now live about 500 feet from John Harper's first apartment in Seattle.

      I first learned about Dungeons & Dragons back in fifth grade and borrowed my friend's "red box" set for a while, but didn't actually start playing until another friend ran an adventure for me in seventh grade. I made up and ran my first adventure, the "Temple of the Moon Dagger," in eighth grade, and it was awful, though we still had some fun. I think I've gotten a little better at inventing and running scenarios since then, but I'm much more anxious about it now. I discovered Talislanta in 1988, and that became the main game I ran for years, though as the years passed and some friends moved away, gaming became more and more infrequent.

      In 1995 I bought my first Mac and got on the Internet, and shortly joined the Talislanta mailing list, where I "met" John Harper. So I've known him for 11 years now, though I only met him in person for the first time a couple months after moving to Seattle. We've been good friends since then. I also introduced him to another of my college friends, Tony (Dowler, who's not on these forums (yet)), and we've done a lot of game discussion and playing together. In the latter part of 2002, after lamenting that we had far more cool ideas for games than time to make or play them, we started the blog Attacks of Opportunity to post them so maybe others could take advantage of them. I experienced John's conversion to the indie game theory and design group firsthand, as he set about explaining these new ideas to me and converting me (and Tony, and anyone else who'll listen), and that's pretty much why I'm here on these forums today.

      I work as a technical editor/writer and office manager for a small software services/development company, which in turn mostly works for Microsoft. I took violin lessons from third grade through high school, and then played with an amateur orchestra until I was 30; I've barely played since then. I do love rock music of various genres and have made it a point to catch at least one show a month since 2005. I majored in procrastination in college, although my diploma says "Literature". I am single and childless, and have no real expectation of that ever changing. However, I have a lovely white cat named Nimiel to keep me company. I am not actually working on any game designs of my own, but really should pick one of my ideas and start fleshing it out. I expect to lurk for a while as I catch up on threads. Also, apparently I'm quite verbose and should finish here.

      Edit: Tony just noticed that I wrote that my diplomacy says "Literature", rather than my diploma. How embarrassing!

    • Stuart Robertson
      July 2006
      My name is Stuart Robertson. I'm 32 and live in Ontario, Canada. I work as a professional web designer, and teach a 3rd year University course in Toronto. I have a 20-month old son, and my wife and I are expecting our second child this fall.

      When I was about 9 years old, I was introduced to an unusual game called "Dungeons & Dragons". I bought the red "Basic" book (pre-punched for a 3-ring binder!), and the module "Horror on the Hill". Since it was my game, I ended up being the Dungeon Master -- and I've been interested in games, and how they work ever since.

      I played a lot of different Role-playing games throughout High-school, read a lot of Fighting Fantasy books, and played tabletop war games - mostly Battletech, Warhammer and Warhammer 40K.

      Since going to University, I've mostly played board-games and have a definite preference for "German style" games -- although Balderdash remains a family favourite.

      I've been lurking on this site for some time, as well as other places like The Forge, and many of the RPG theory blogs. I'm currently working on a board-game that incorporates many of the elements from old school Fantasy games like early D&D, Talisman, and Fighting Fantasy -- while having more "modern" boardgame mechanics.
    • pedyo
      July 2006
      Hi there!

      My name's Peter Dyring-Olsen, I'm 33 years old and currently living in Copenhagen, which I like a lot for so many different reasons. My girlfriend's called Ditte and we have a daughter who's 1.5 years old, is called Freja and is just amazing in so many ways. Oh, and we're expecting number two come February.

      I have a Master's Degree in English and Art History.

      I work as a children's books editor at the most commercial publisher you can imagine. So, I do my very best to raise the quality. It's a daily struggle not to lose heart.

      I've been playing drums for the last - oh - 13 years on and off - been working pretty seriously on music in a number of different bands but currently I'm taking a break, rethinking that part of my life.

      I'm the type that reads and talks too much about RPGs - and consequently plays way to little. I've been trying to set up a couple of regular groups for a long time. Hopefully, this effort will meet with some success soon.

      I hope to play Burning Wheel, TSoY, DitV, AG&G and others very soon!

      I like throwing dice (I'm not kidding you - I just do for some reason!). I think I'm a better GM than player. I suck at immersive play. My skills as a strategist are almost nonexistant. I get ideas for game design and then I drop them again.

      My favourite book might just be Crime and Punishment - other than that, I guess it has to be BrÃ¸drene LÃ¸vehjerte by Swedish genius Astrid Lindgreen.

      The best album in the world is either Abbey Road or Sgt. Pepper by The Beatles. A close second would then be A Love Supreme by John Coltrane.

      I ride my bike to work almost every day.
    • Gaerik
      July 2006
      Howdy!

      I'm Andrew Cooper. I'm a 35 year old Software Developer from East Tennessee. I obviously like to play games or I most likely wouldn't be here. I was introduced to role-playing as a plebe at West Point. While this makes me a relatively late-comer to the role-playing scene (I was 18 before ever playing) I'm old enough to have a few years in the hobby under my belt anyway. Other than gaming, I read a good bit of fantasy and sci fi fiction. My current favorite being George RR Martin. I also play trumpet and am the worship leader at our church.

      I'm married to a wonderful and gorgeous Filipina woman named Hazel. She is currently finishing up her degree in Business. She is a dancer and runs a dance and Pilates studio. She also heads up the dance ministry at our church. We have 1 child, Gabriel, who is 2 years old. He is proof positive that a perpetual motion machine is completely possible. Hazel and I want to have 1 or 2 more children and then we'll probably adopt a couple also. Kids are the bomb.

      Um... I think that about wraps it up.

    Comments

    • Neko_Ewen
      July 2006
      I'm Ewen Cluney. "Ewen" is pronounced like "Aaron," though my parents have yet to give me a satisfactory explanation as to why. I'm 27 (until next month), and live in San Jose, CA. My background is a bunch of European ethnicities mashed together, and supposedly a tiny bit of Native American somewhere. I just graduated from San Jose State University with a BA in Japanese, and I'll be starting on an MA in the same at San Francisco State University in the fall. Through having friends in the right places and dumb luck, I've been able to become a freelance translator, mostly working on video games, but hopefully expanding to some other things in the near future. At some point I definitely need to try living in Japan. I used to think that becoming a programmer would be a good idea for me, which is why it took so long for me to get my BA in Japanese.

      I was raised Unitarian Universalist, but on Sundays I'm usually too lazy to go to church, so I'm mostly just a generic agnostic, though I've been leaning more towards atheism lately. I'm single, and that doesn't bother me as much as it probably should.

      I'm big into writing, though as with RPGs it take forever for me to finish revising anything to my satisfaction. I literally have about three novels in various states of incompleteness. Somewhere along the line I started writing the occasional poem, though I like writing in blank verse for some reason. I play video games, but not nearly as much as I used to, and most of the really popular genres (especially MMOs) totally leave me cold. I like to read, mostly really whacked-out speculative fiction or Japanese light novels, and some manga. I like certain comics, and too much anime. I have a crappy webcomic that I do mostly as a vehicle for in-jokes to amuse my friends, but creatively I consider myself a writer who doodles a bit, and not an artist.

      I got into RPGs in middle school with Robotech, and played mostly Palladium stuff through high school, then got away from that when I realized that absolutely every new system I ever tried made more sense to me in one way or another. My group can never seem to settle on any one system for more than a single campaign, though Mekton Z has recurred a lot. We're currently playing Truth & Justice.
    • Andrew Kenrick
      July 2006
      Hey guys - I'm new here so go gentle on me!

      I'm Andrew Kenrick, I'm 25 years old and live in Sherwood Forest in England (yes, really!). I'm a freelance games designer, writer and editor, as well as owner and publisher at Steampower Publishing. We produce games now and again, our most recent indie game being Dead of Night.

      When not writing or publishing (which admittedly takes up most of my life), I run the IT helpdesk at a local college. Believe it or not, I'm an archaeologist by training, but haven't dug anything up (living or dead) for a good few years now. I live with my girlfriend, Ruth, who is most assuredly not into gaming, although can handle Munchkin. She's wonderfully tolerant, and is even the co-director of SP.

      I have a blog too - littlestkobold.livejournal.com

      Nice to meet you all!
    • komradebob
      July 2006
      Hello all:
      I'm Robert Earley-Clark. I'm living currently in (not-so) sunny San Francisco. I'm a western New Yorker by birth ( The beautiful Finger Lakes, northernmost outpost of Appalachia), although my heart belongs to New Orleans where I lived for ten years before heading West. By the western zofdiac, I'm an Aries, so red things are supoosed to be good for me. This explains my politics. By the eastern zodiac, I'm a pig: This explains my incessant need to eat bacon.

      There is a former-Mrs.Komradebob in my past, although it has been years since I was married. I also have a lovely 9 yo daughter (Threnody), who lives with said former-Mrs.Komradebob in Northern CA, hence my current location. I'm single, and have mixed feelings both about that state and alternately ending that state.

      I've been gaming for an embarassingly long time, playing just about every one of the old TSR games form the 1980s at one point or another, most of the WW stuff in the early 90s, and all kinds of other stuff along the way. My current interst is in creating horrific Frankenstein's Monster like hybrids of minis games and these crazy indie-designs these kids are making today.

      Confession: I choose music based entirely upon how I feel about the way fans of the particular genre dress. Nope, I swear, it's true. Thus, Rockabilly, Punk, Swing, Goth-Industrial, Worldmusic ,and Jazz are all Good Things. Disco is Bad. Funk is marginal, as is Trad and BlueGrass, though I secretly like those too.

      I started college working on a double major in History and Archaeology, but got thrown out during Gulf War I for protests I was involved in and never went back to the halls of higher learning. This stressed me for a long time, but I'm kind of liking my prole job these days.

      That cover all the important bases?

      Best regards,
      Robert
    • Tyler Bachelder
      August 2006
      I'm Tyler Bachelder (pronounced bockelder) I live in Scottsburg, IN... southern end for those who are interested. I'm about 45 minutes from Louisville, which according to this thread, would put me in the neighborhood of a couple of users here. I'm one of the forum's vibrant youth at twenty years old. I'm currently transitioning from high school into college... transitioning in that I still have no idea what I want to do and am trying to figure that all out. I guess that comes with youth.

      I am partially blind, and the disorder is congenital. At least being born with it makes it impossible to -not- cope. It really isn't all that bad, excluding the fact that my hobbies of choice are hobbies in which having better vision would be to my benefit. I'm thinking specifically of RPGs, of course, and the reading of their rulebooks.

      I started out on D&D 3e. Having been raised in a highly religious setting, I didn't get to try out the games I always wanted to play until I got a bit older and more rebellious. My experience with actual game systems is pretty narrow because I play with narrow-minded players. I'd like to change that. I'm currently plugging for PTA in our group, and should be GMing a season shortly if things go as planned. I got hooked on the whole indie scene thanks to FATE *tipping the hat to Fred and Rob, who've provided excellent support for the game in the mailing list* and from FATE, I found The Forge. It all branched out from there.

      I'm particularly attracted to indie games due to their accessability. Plain and simple, I cannot read mainstream published books unless I put in the time to scan, OCR, and edit them. There are far too many mainstream games I'd like to play for all that. So, I play mainstream games through friends that give me the rules as we go. But in the indie scene, we have pdf files. With the use of some nice software, I can have them read to me, which is to my benefit. I'm also skewed heavily towards a more narrative form of play, so it was a pretty organic transition for me. I'm particularly interested in playing FATE, PTA, DitV, Don't Rest Your Head (just bought), Polaris, TSoY, The Mountain Witch, and My Life With Master.

      Random facts:

      I read, a lot. I write a lot less, but want to do so more readily. I know a little bit about a lot of things. I guess that comes from having too much time and broadband, eh? I'm a huge music geek, and enjoy a load of styles from jazz to metal to rag time to just about anything else. I used to play video games a lot, but thanks to a recent surgery, I'm much less inclined to do so. I lost a fair amount of vision in my left eye, putting me out of the end of my senior year in high school. That set me back roughly a year's worth of time. It also killed my video game hobbie pretty definitely with the exception of the occasional game or two now and again.

      I'm hoping that I can provide some insight to these discussions with my unique view (no pun intended) on the gaming hobbie.

      I also think I've rambled on for long enough at this point. Any minute facet of my personality you folks want to target will inevitably come out eventually. I'm a pretty up-front sort.

      Here's to some kickass discussion!
    • iago
      August 2006
      Fred Hicks, 34. I live in Silver Spring, Maryland, and up until February of this year I was working in the internet industry doing, essentially, intranet web application development.

      Then I realized I hated working in the internet industry. So my wife encouraged me to quit.

      I've been unemployed since, and probably won't be getting back on the "day job" horse until early next year ... which has given me the chance to really put the spurs to the whole Evil Hat Productions game design thing. Plus, I'm actually sane most of the time. I like sane. It's comfy.
    • Thomas D
      August 2006 edited November 2007
      Wow. I really should update this. So here goes:

      Howdy. I'm Thomas, a mid-30s cartoonist. I'm currently attending the University of Arizona in my spare time, going for a BFA. Recently, I've decided to make the plunge into gaming web fora at RPGNet, the Forge, and here -- at all three places, I post under Thomas D. Like JDCorley, I'm in Tucson, Arizona, and am married to a brain researcher. Husbands of Tucson-based brain researchers represent, yo, indeed.

      I started playing D&D with the basic box set, the one with the all-blue cover. My dad gave it to me because his wife at the time and he "didn't understand how to play it". Several years later, after he became Born Again and started watching The 700 Club, became concerned about me playing those evil role-playing games.

      I still have the dice from that set.

      As I've said, I'm a cartoonist. I have some of my comic works at TheSnakeFarm.com, I've been published in a few small press papers, and have developed a few comic book titles for a company that does educational material for the K-6 set.

      I've been to high school in West Germany, when it was West Germany, down to college in Texas after which a friend said they needed an illustrator for a company working on this new thing called "the Internet" that might turn out to be popular. A few years later and I'm in Manhattan, coasting along the dot-com bubble, when some asshole flies a plane into the building next door, and we wind up in Arizona.

      I've participated in the 24 Hour RPG project twice now, once with a television action show game called Scene Stealers and with the Owlbear Challenge (Winnie-the-Owl-Pooh: Adventures in d100 Acre Wood and The Cave at Owl-Pooh Corner).
    • Paul Watson
      August 2006
      Hey, folks. This seems like as good a place as any for my first post to this board.

      I'm Paul Watson (I got tired of coming up with board handles a while back), 39 (almost) and married to a wonderful woman for the last ten years. She's not into RPG/Story Games, but she supports my hobby and puts up with my infrequent pestering to start gaming , and enjoys my collection of board and card games. We have one child, a daughter, ten years old, and very much into gaming. We live in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada, and I've been living here for about 20 years now.

      Politically I don't identify as conservative/liberal/right/left/etc. My staunchly liberal friends are convinced that I'm conservative and couldn't possibly have a liberal thought in my head. My staunchly conservative friends believe the opposite. Meh. I'm a middle-path kind of person.

      Spiritually/religiously, I'm mainly a Heathen with some Thelema and Taoism thrown in for good measure.

      Professionally, I work for IBM Global Services doing internal tools development, mainly in Java (some desktop, some enterprise), with a little PHP and a dash of Python. I've been there for about 8 years now. Before that, I did some work for the federal government, and a little teaching (taught programming to teens).

      I've been playing RPGs since 1981 or thereabouts, staring with that boxed D&D set moving on to AD&D, RuneQuest, GURPS, Werewolf, and something like 30 or 40 other games. A few years ago, I lost almost all interest in RPGs after a fairly disastrous, short-lived campaign. The problem wasn't the system, it was me. I had just lost interest.

      Aside from roleplaying/story games, I'm into boardgames (like Settlers and Carcassonne), card games (like Killer Bunnies and Munchkin), computer games (I've put an embarassing number of hours into WoW), writing software for pleasure, miniature gaming (Confrontation), great novels, poetry, history, TV, movies, music, snakes, lizards and rabbits.
      In one last attempt as salvaging my interest in the hobby, I did a quick search for FUDGE variants, finding FATE. FATE introduced me to roleplaying concepts that were completely alien to me. Browsing the FATE mailing list, I found a reference to a site called The Forge ... and now I own quite a number of indie/small press/narrativist/hippie-commie/whatever games . I'm a bit of a compulsive collector.
    • Malcolm Craig
      August 2006
      I'm Malcolm Craig. Hi!

      Aged 31, originally from Falkirk, a boring town in Central Scotland. Now living in beautiful Edinburgh.

      As a day job, I do online marketing and advertising for a financial corporation in Edinburgh. By night, I occassionally design games. Other than this, I love mountain biking, snowboarding, movies and lots of other stuff.

      Hang on, this is beginning to sound like a dating agency!

      Well, the first game I ever played was CoC, age 14. It lasted 30 minutes and ended up in total chaos. This, I thought, was roleplaying. Then a few minutes later I played 1st ed Twilight 2000. Maybe this explains a lot? Maybe it doesn't. And the first game I ever ran was an awful Traveller scenario I'd written myself. A truly desperate attempt. But I think things have got better since then.

      My gaming epiphany moment? Playing in a demo of Dust devils run by Matt Snyder at Gen Con 2005. Great times.

      Cheers
      Malc
    • Matthew D. Gandy
      August 2006
      I'm Matthew Gandy, 32, currently residing in Raleigh, NC. I'm working on my first design(s), mostly at the inspiration of Fred Hicks and Rob Donoghue. Fred and I gamed in high school and reconnected after I finished my Master's. I have a non-descript day job, a game-tolerating (and occasionally -playing) wife, and three cats. Of my various other hobbies, I'm a bit of a gadget geek, anime junkie, and preschool-level Japanese student.

      I live in the same area as the Durham3, whom I hope to meet in far distant Indianapolis next week. Go figure! Guys, I'll buy you lunch back in Raleigh sometime soon.

      Clinton, I think I work a few blocks away from you.

      Malcolm, my brother-in-law and his family currently live in or near Edinburgh. It's a small world.

      My first gaming experience was definitely one of the early D&Ds (probably Basic), but I don't know exactly with whom. My parents forced me to "retire" from gaming for a few years. When I convinced them to let me play again, I played some Palladium games (BTS, TMNT, Robotech) and CoC (during which I unleashed the *brilliant* plan to summon a monster *as a diversion* and later pressed the button that unleashed the shoggoth), but it was Fred introducing me to Champions and getting me to read superhero comics that really turned on the lights. It's been a looong time since then, and I drifted from the mainstream a few years ago. My last regular game was a FATE supernatural western for Fred, Rob, and their posse, in which they all played hanged criminals brought back from the dead to work for the Devil. Since that ran down about a year ago, I'm out of practice GMing (and way outta practice playing). I just started running The Mountain Witch for two local groups. I hope to play about a dozen indie games at GenCon next week. After that is almost certainly Dogs in the Vineyard and some playtests of my own projects.

      And Fred Hicks is most certainly not sane. Less stressed, yes, but not sane. We prefer him that way.

    • MRUnderwood
      August 2006
      Hi everyone, I'm Michael Underwood (The MR in my username isn't for Mr., instead it's my first two initials, (M)ichael (R)obert. So you know.

      I'm 23, born in Bloomington, Indiana with early stints living in Texas, Brooklyn, New Jersey, back to Bloomington through undergrad at IU (East Asian Studies and an individualized major in Creative Mythology--ie. fiction writing+mythology). I'm about to go back to Eugene, OR to start my second year of a Master's degree in Folklore.

      I'm an aspiring speculative fiction writer, and this year, have started and become somewhat obsessed with Argentine Tango.

      I started gaming when I was 8 or 9, when classmates in Brooklyn grabbed me to make a character for this neat thing called D&D. We were playing Al-Qadim, and I made a Barbarian. With a dune buggy. I like to think this was somewhat indicative of my approach to life. I've been gaming pretty continuously since then, as well as getting involved with a Changeling LARP in Bloomington for several years. I also worked at a FLGS for four and a half years before moving out west.

      I live in a graduate-student co-op, which is an amazing experience and more functional than I suspected it would be. It's a great environment, and our dinner conversations are some of the most mind-blowing (or odd) things in the world.

      I'm writing my thesis on RPGs, with the focus on the way that people bring different creative expectations/backgrounds to gaming (IE a group of fiction writers playing a tabletop game to simulate making a novel vs. drama students playing a game for character immersion, etc.) and how that creates interesting variances in the way RPGs are played and designed.

      I've had many gaming epiphanies, but my biggest moment was playing in a Cinematrix game (modification of Engle Matrix Games) in the designer's personal fantasy world and maintaining a really strong IC state while also working to collaborate with the other players on the OOC level to make a campaign-defining scene.

      I may have begun designing my first RPG for publication with the niggling idea that's developing over here:http://www.story-games.com/forums/comments.php?DiscussionID=1195&page=1#Item_2
    • jake richmond
      August 2006
      My name is Jake Richmond. I'm 28. I've never met anyone I liked well enough to marry. I live in Portland Oregon in a house I share with some friends. Its the most relaxed and comfortable place I've ever lived. I've tried going back to school three times in the last 5 years,but each time I get bored and end up dropping out. I make my money illustrating games and comics, and doing a bit of freelance writing. Which ex-plains why I'm almost always broke.

      My work takes up most of my time, but when I can I like to read sci-fi novels, watch import movies and eat Hawaiian food. I've spent my last year working on the games "Panty Explosion" and "Iam a Survivor", and I'm looking forward to finishing of the rest of the tear working on my new game "The Goodship Malcadia".

    • Kudzu
      August 2006 edited August 2006
      My name is Steven Jarvis. I'm 37 and live in Fayetteville, Arkansas (the upper left corner) where I'm a web designer/developer for a newspaper group, though I also do a lot of freelance work (Kudzu Design). I have a poorly-updated blog at sjarvis.com. I like to characterize myself as an overeducated underachiever. I have a B.A. in English/Creative Writing, an M.A. in American Lit, an M.A. in Southern Studies (think American Studies, only concentrating on the American South), and a J.D. (law degree). I've worked as an English teacher, a radio DJ, an editor, a lawyer (no more, thank God!), a reporter, a graphic designer, and now the web designerating. I have an awesome wife, Hallie, who teaches German to high school kids, and an awesome son, Daniel, who is 3.5 and a real lover of polyhedral dice ("Let's play dice, Daddy!") and a practiced slayer of ogres and trolls.

      In what little free time I squeeze out of the day I make electronic music (in the ambient-ish IDM and synthpop sub-sub-sub-genres under the moniker Iterate), and I also play drums, guitar, bass, and keyboards (primitively) but these days play mostly laptop (a Mac, of course). I've been playing RPGs since the summer of 1981 where I learned to play D&D at band camp, and I've played off and on since then, mostly on through college then off through grad/law school, but pretty consistently for the last 2 or 3 years. These days it's mostly hippie indie games, including a lot of Burning Wheel. I've been a Forge lurker for a couple of years and semi-active on some other RPG-related boards as Kudzu or sjarvis. I'm currently working intently on my first real game design (the first actual was when I was about 13) after getting inspired at GenCon 2006.

    • VictorGijsbers
      August 2006
      People call me Victor Gijsbers, which also happens to be my name. I live in the Netherlands, in the city of Utrecht; while I work some 60 kilometers eastward in Leiden. My job is at the Philosophy Department of Leiden University, where I am writing a PhD-thesis on the philosophy of explanation, and am teaching students the basics of philosophy of science and epistemology. I'll also be giving a course on Richard Rorty soon. My previous education was in physics and philosophy. I am currently 23 years old, but this number tends to change with some regularity.

      As to roleplaying games: I started playing them some seven years ago, but it was a mixed experience until I tried out My Life with Master and became sold on indie games. From that time on, I have been interested in these fun little games, with some of my favourites being Polaris, Bacchanal and Breaking the Ice. I used to hang around on the theory fora of the Forge; nowadays I have my own theory and design blog. I am also playtesting a game called Shades, which I want to turn into an actual book. (I love books. I love to read them, sure, but I also love the very material presence of books. My room is full of them; philosophy, fantasy and high literature, mostly.)

    • Jim DelRosso
      August 2006
      My name's Jim DelRosso, I'm 29, and I live in Ithaca, NY. I work as a web editor and reference assistant at the Catherwood Library, which serves Cornell University's School of Industrial Labor Relations. I've got a BS and MPA from Cornell, and I plan on pursuing an MLS within the next year or two and becoming a Real Librarian. With the exception of two years lived in Baltimore and a summer lived in Palo Alto, I've lived in Ithaca since I graduated high school, and have no real plans to move again. I am a semi-retired test prep instructor for Kaplan, Inc.

      My first game was WEG's Star Wars RPG, when I was ten or eleven. I love gaming ridiculously, and was thrilled when Judd invited me to join the BW game he was gearing up for when I first got back to the area. Games I've played include the aforementioned Star Wars, AD&D, Shadowrun, Vampire, Feng Shui, Coc, Fading Suns, Adventure!, Unknown Armies, WFRP, Baron Munchausen, Dying Earth, Riddle of Steel, D&D3e, Sorcerer (Dictionary of Mu), ocTaNe, d20 Modern, Burning Wheel, Dogs in the Vinyard, Don't Rest Your Head, Lacuna, Iron Heroes, Shadow of Yesterday, and Spirit of the Century.

      When not gaming, I tend to read, watch movies or TV (almost exclusively netflixed these days), lift weights, take martial arts class (looking forward to having Judd kick my ass in thai boxing this semester), play guitar, and write competitive poetry. I also drink more coffee than is healthy, am lucky enough to be loved by two amazing women, and have a large dog.

      I started going bald when I was 16, but it took me six years to decide to finish the job.

      Howdy, all.

      I'm D.J. Chagnon, 31 (and counting), and living in Somerville, MA (just outside Boston) - which means I really ought to try to connect with the local SG crowd, since it sounds like this area is a hotbed of it. I think I know some of the same people as a lot of folks but haven't met them. Same goes for the Ithaca crowd, since I did my Master's at Cornell and was pretty active in the Games club there.

      Anyhow, back to Somerville/Boston, where I'm happily married as of just over a year ago, working as a Landscape Architect, and getting my weekly RPG fix on through two alternating campaigns with one slightly-dysfunctional but good group (one high-fantasy epic D20, one Serenity). Currently, I'm not running anything - when I get a chance to do so, I'm looking to branch us out into something more indie, shake things up a little and help us find some new tools to bring into the more mainstream stuff that bunch prefers. I'm also a fairly frequent player of the Vampire CCG - the only one that really keeps my attention anymore - and my otherwise-non-gaming wife and I play boardgames when we can with whoever we can.

      I haven't yet brought any RPG designs past the rough-preliminary-notes stage, but for a while I was involved in a few CCG lines. If I weren't a landscape architect, I think I'd be a graphic designer - I really love tinkering with it even though I've got no formal training in that particular branch of design.

      Life's pretty darn peachy, all in all.

      - D.J.

      Hey, my name is Jeff Bent. I'm a Canadian fella living in Austin, TX. In my free time, I'm a webcomics type guy, doing random shit at random intervals. While I think MUSHing is a fantastic venue for RP in theory, in practice the crazy people there pretty much left me burnt out. These days I play tabletop DnD with wife and friends, but wish for better, more clever games.

      August 2006 edited August 2006
      Mark Nau, life presently divided into 4 roughly equal time slices.
      1) Family guy. Father to two daughters, 6 and 3. We play pretend and make up games together. My wife and I have been together so long we practically function as a unit. Meaning she's in charge.
      2) Creative Director for the Spider-Man 3 console games. 10 years ago, I joined a small company early and over time we grew and then got assimilated.
      3) Sleep. Wife has trained me to do so face down to abate snoring.
      4) Me-time. Subdivisions:
      a) Finding some interesting challenge and seeing how good I can get. Currently working on my mad poker skillz.
      b) Checking out interesting indie/niche-market games of all media. Currently digging "Dwarf Fortress" and "Toribash" on the computer. I generally don't play mass-market games. Yes, there is some tension between that and item #2.
      c) Reading. Currently evolutionary psych and economics.
      d) Screwing around on the internet while the TV is on, occasionally chatting with the Wife. That's where you guys come in.

      Good day. I'm Zach Welhouse.

      At 22, I'm hardly the youngest here but decidedly part of the Still an Undergraduate club. I'm presently enjoying my last few days of this Wisconsin summer before heading back to Mount Vernon, Iowa to earn my degrees in English and History.

      My gaming history began in 3rd grade with a copy of DragonQuest and has taken the predictable path from overpowered TSR fun to surly indie navel-gazing, with the occasional side-trek into samurai and cowboys. As the historian for the Cornell College Chess and Games club, I tend to spend more time organizing and running games than being a player. If this doesn't change soon, there will be a reckoning.

      December 2006 edited December 2006
      Better late than never, right?

      I'm Sara McAtee from Twin Cities, Minnesota.
      Just another Blond in hiding, I masquerade as a fiery red head with brown eyes, olive skin and some freckles.
      I never went to college, although my goal was originally a double PHD in pyschology, (with a minor in Child Autism), and Philosophy, (Minor in documentation), and a third minor in Theology. (Needless to say, Money matters; I didn't have enough of it and opted to not go at all, if I couldn't go for what I wanted - I'm a rather stubborn girl)

      I'm 25, married to the most patient man in the world (Ryan McAtee), have the most adorable, abeit vain, cat in existance (Bridget), and get to rock out in the most wonderful band that I couldn't imagine life without. (Aria Sharp)

      We can't afford a house yet, but we're working on it!
      I used to teach pre-school of all ages, specializing in ages 2-4, but due to the need of paying bills, I now work as a security guard for Emerson and Vance instead.
      I've taken nine computer courses during public school, but unfortunately didn't learn much from them since they were craptastic at the time, so instead I've taught myself HTML, adobe, outlook, word, etc, etc C++, a little latin and a smattering of other languages.

      I'm in the process of writing a gaming world called "Sanctum: The Fallout", that is for use with Adam Cerling's ""Ends and Means, and the date for our playtest of potentially 20-50+ people is set for January. I'm both nervous and excited as since it has only been actually gaming for a few years now, and only recently that I've started to take leadership roles.

      I'm an Alumni Volunteer for Big Brothers, Big Sisters of America, and when I'm not being a wife, gaming, working, volunteering, playing with a band, being a politcal activist or working with children, I run my own business,Oracle: Mind and Body as the alchemist, owner and marketing manager. I still try to make time for writing and have a habit of writing theoretical musings and poetry that are surely destined to collect dust. I do not consider myself terribly religious, but I am very spiritual, consider myself a christian, (jesus and all), and I do believe in divination and psychic ability.


      All and all? I'm just a big geek who lacks the ability send an e-mail or make a post without having to edit it, or send a second one, has a love for music, gaming, kids, and learning about people, This thread was a jackpot for my mind!

      Sara.
    • MattJohnston
      December 2006
      Didn't notice this thread until shutupgirl resurrected it.

      I'm Matt Johnston and I live in Ireland. I've travelled over Europe and been to the US twice but all in all I love Ireland the most. I'm 34, happily single, heterosexual, have two kids, a girl aged 4 and a boy aged 2 that I am utterly devoted to, still married to their mom but we don't live together any more and we do get along fine. I'm tall, freckled and brown haired, charming, gorgeous, wonderfully good in the sack, terribly polite, helpful and dependable. It's true! I tend to be a bit stubbly and am pretty pleased that it's going a distinguished grey at my chin. Score one for me! Raised as a Roman Catholic but I've given up believing in all sorts of fairy tales since I was a child. I spent 3 years in the Army. I speak basic French and German and started learning Mandarin.

      Workstuff
      I've got a degree in Genetics and postgrad qualifications in Computing and IT. I've done heaps of IT courses and for a little while was a Network Consultant for Nortel after being a Mac guy, a generic IT guy, a PC guy, a UNIX guy and a Network Guy. I used to teach pre-degree courses at my local technical college and I've done a few guest speaking and writing spots over the years. For the last 3 years I've been running my own IT company - we fix Macs. That's what we do. I've also started up a software company and I'm going to be launching two more companies next year. I like being busy.

      Gaming
      My gaming history started with White Dwarf issue 55 which mesmerised me and also introduced me to some gamers in my school. I was 11. I still have relatively fond memories of the Spiderbite scenario for D&D within. I'm a vigourous and experimental gamer, owning hundreds of books. I used to be an active member of TwoMoons MUSH as well as The Masquerade and City of Darkness MUSHes among others in the early 90s. I do miss it and it's ironic that I now have the time and the net connection when previously I had neither. I used to be President of my university gaming club and ran their convention, Q-CON for two very successful years. I started the gaming company Crucible Design and ran it from 1996 to 2001 publishing "The 23rd Letter", "SpaceNinjaCyberCrisis XDO" and "Zombi", all of which I still own. It feels a bit weird as while I was out of gaming, this whole "indie" scene started up yet back in the early 90s I was a major player in the indie scene.... I took a haitus of nearly 3 years as my company built up and my marriage failed but things are much better now. After the other guys in Crucible Design and I split, I started my own imprint LateGaming and produced 2 PDF games (Creed, Testament) and now run lategaming.com as a blog and game design...er...place.

      I am a Mac user as mentioned above, but despite running my local Mac User Group since about 1997 and running the only Mac repair place in Northern Ireland, I'm not a Mac bigot. I write for 3 blogs now and spend altogether too much time talking to people online.
    • tadk
      December 2006
      You know Matt I think there is a copy of "SpaceNinjaCyberCrisis XDO" in the half price section in my local game shop. If there is I am going to have to get it just because now. I had seen the title, but never opened it up to look at it. I will now.
    • crowyhead
      December 2006
      Well, heck, since it's been resurrected I might as well jump in here and do a real intro.

      I'm Kirsten Brodbeck, I'm 27, and I grew up in mid-Michigan (Alma, mostly, and went to Kalamazoo College). I've been living in West Philly for the past 5 years and would like to stay here for a while. I live in a rambly rowhouse apartment with Dave (my partner of 6+ years), two rats named Toxie and O'Malley, a couple of cranky budgies, around 2,000 books, and a basement full of power tools. I'm a children's librarian, and Dave's a PhD student at U Penn in computer science.

      I knit a lot of intricate sweaters and such (and a bunch of my gaming buddies are getting knit dice bags for Winter Holidays). I read a LOT, tons of kids books (due to the job, but I'd be reading 'em anyway), lots of fantasy and sci fi. I'm also hugely partial to Sherlock Holmes and Lord Peter Wimsey. I watch a lot of PBS. I have an affinity for good scotch and good beer. Sometimes I get drunk and talk gaming theory at parties, and I actually have friends who think this is a good thing, or at least humor me. I perform as a drag king under the names Pelvis Thrustello and Mad Cow Billy.

      I've only been gaming since July of this year, but I've come to realize I must have had a gamer residing fully-formed in my head. It apparently fulfills a lot of creative urges that have been without outlet for some time. A friend recruited me for a TSOY campaign in July, and I haven't looked back since. It helped that I was stuck in an awful job at the time and would thus spend hours at work reading The Forge and Story Games instead of doing work... (I'm much happier now) Now I'm still playing the aformentioned TSOY game on a generally weekly basis. I'm also playing a monthly homebrew game run by my friend Corvus, and I'm planning on running The Mountain Witch next month.
    • Penn42
      December 2006
      Hey Y'all, I never did this before, so let's do it now.

      I am Chris Hanrahan. Proud father of 2 wonderful boys (13 and 3) and Husband to the best wife a guy could have. Why? Cause she supports my career move into owning/running a small FLGS. I left a decent paying job in high tech marketing with the sole goal of giving back to the community which has given me joy for roughly 30 years now. I started with a copy of "Dungeon" back in third grade, and haven't look back.

      I also participate in the Ogre Cave Audio Report and 2d6 Feet in a Random Direction gaming podcasts.

      That should be enough...maybe?
    • Caesar_X
      December 2006
      I'm Chris Bennett, 38 years old and living in Alameda, CA (close to SF). I moved out here back in 1995 after a disappointing college career and several years "finding myself" (AKA working crappy jobs). I was lucky enough to get into the video game business at the bottom rung, and have spent the past 11 years making cool games for companies like EA and Maxis. Now I have an awesome job as producer and game designer making casual downloadable games at PlayFirst in SF and get to take a ferry to work everyday! Plus next year I am getting married to an awesome girl named Rachel who guides me through the tough times and embraces my passions.

      I started playing RPGs back around 1980, but I never had a regular gaming group and the games didn't fulfill the expectations I had for them. At some point I stopped playing for 15-20 years besides the occasional GURPS game. Fast-forward to a year ago and my workmate going on and on about "indie games" and "The Forge" and "Burning Wheel". I started to do a lot of reading and yeah, I drank the kool-aid. There's some awesome stuff going on in this community and while I make my babysteps towards designing for paper-and-pencil, I am awed by the combined talent I see here everyday. I also found an awesome game store in Oakland called EndGame, and they have made me very welcome. It's a second home, I tell ya.

      I am very passionate about making and playing games, but I find myself drawn towards making games for "non-gamers" both in my professional career and in my hobby time. I dream of the day that kids and adults have games that they can use to create exciting stories together. I think we are moving in that direction and it's what gets me up in the morning.
    • King Turnip
      December 2006
      I'm Justin Grosvenor Smith, 29 of Roseville (Sacramento), California. I am a life-long NorCal-er, I occaisionally use the word Hella (the true mark of NorCal.) I am a fan of the Sac Kings, and I'm sad they are moving to Vegas.
      I am married to a non-gamer-- Khamfong Khanrasa-- and have a soon-to-be 5 year old daughter. Frankly, my wife is far more interesting than I am.
      I went to Cal Poly, San Luis Obispo for a few years studying Mechanical Engineering before we had a disagreement about what constituted satisfactory progress toward my degree and they asked me to seek educational opportunities elsewhere. That elsewhere was California State University, Sacramento, where I got my BA in Philosophy. I can build an engine from scratch, and I have written award winning essays in Semantics (philosophy of language.)
      I have a profound dislike for the California Air Resources Board. They are deathly affraid someone, somewhere might enjoy their car, and they write laws to stop it.
      I have had a number of shitty jobs, but I (mostly) love the one I have now: Admissions for a small culinary school. I truly enjoy being able to help people build their careers, and I also enjoy the food. I enjoy the food a bit too much in fact, as I tip the scales at about 230 these days.
      In gaming, I started with Red-Box D&D, and I still enjoy the occaisional dungeon hack. I have just recently discovered indie gaming with the Burning Wheel, and the scales have fallen from my eyes. I need deep involvement, immersion, and player-driven conflict. Now I need to convince my gaming group of the same.
      I don't listen to music. Really, I don't.
    • martinh
      December 2006
      Last time I posted a brief biography on the web was 1995 and it still comes in the top ten search results on my name in Google. You can find it here. So I'm not going to post my age since it will be shortly wrong. All I'll say is that Thor is no longer the oldest person on this list.

      So an update from the previous bio.

      I still live in Wokingham , England and still work in software development but no longer as a freelancer. I am now married to my long time girlfriend. No children and non planned.

      My role playing had died out by the mid 90's and was revitalised this year with the discovery of indie rpg's through Paul Tevis's "Have Games Will Travel". One of the primary reasons my previous role playing career died out was the amount of prep time require even for games such as Pendragon and so many of the new games reduce this dramatically if not entirely as well as being being highly enjoyable.

      Back in the days of The Clash and Sex Pistols I fell in love with Punk Rock and still enjoy listening to a wide and eclectic mixture of music.

      Since I am now working from home I spend little time commuting and reading. Most of my remaining reading time is spent reading new role playing games. When I have found the time to read fiction my current favourite author is Joe Lansdale.

      I occassionally post to my blog
