      Hello, I'm Tony Dowler, and I didn't know this thread existed.

      Some facts about me:
      I could almost create my profile using cut and paste from other profiles.
      Like John Harper, I live in Seattle.
      Like Matt Wilson, my user name is my real name.
      Unlike Matt Wilson, I did not previously live 60 feet from where John Harper lives now. It was four blocks.
      Like Jason Morningstar, I'm married to an awesome librarian.
      I a Canadian, but I am married to an American. Like rosses wife, she does not automatically get citizenship (and neither do I).
      Like MikeSands I have a philosophy degree.
      Like Johnzo I adore Seattle.
      Like Philaros a college friend called me up and told me to move to Seattle and work for his company, which I did.

      Some other facts about me:
      I am Catholic.
      Chances are I'm more conservative than you, but I'm also more liberal than that conservative Catholic guy you know, and no, I won't do apologetics for any opinions I am presumed to share with him.
      I am a PHD dropout.
      I am a technical writer
      My blog is also my name.
      I own my own company.
      I'm trying to work less and make games more.
      I have also lived in:
      Yellowknife, NWT,
      Edmonton, Alberta
      Vancouver, BC
      Nashua, NH
      Victoria, BC
      Washington, DC

      I think we should all meet at Go Play Northwest and continue this conversation in person.
    • Hexabolic
      December 2006
      Hey Howdy,

      My nameâ€™s Blake Hutchins. Iâ€™m 43, turning gray at the temples and neck. Does this make me a contender for oldest on the thread? I live in Eugene, Oregon, U.S.A., with my lovely (and patient) wife, our two brilliant young daughters, and four extremely spoiled cats named Rogue, Hotspur, Hector, and Amoke. Iâ€™ve been here since I came to Eugene to attend the U. of Oregon law school in 1990, and just sorta stuck among the Douglas firs and sword fern.

      Notwithstanding the gray, Iâ€™m holding up pretty well. I stay in good shape and at my basic set point can get out and run six miles any day of the week. I figure Iâ€™d like to be around with all my teeth and most of my brain cells intact when my moppets grow up and start having their own kids. I believe in quality over quantity, environmental responsibility, proactive social policy, and not assigning value based on material success. Also, hot sauce is good, but not with bananas.

      I was a State Department brat, so I lived in Sweden and Finland as a kid, alternating with northern Virginia, a place I loathe (no offense to any Virginians out there). Went to high school in N. California. At the University of California, Davis, I majored in International Relations, mostly because it was an interdisciplinary major. I spent my junior year abroad in Lund, Sweden, where I became fluent in Swedish down to the dialect. I was flattered that it took Swedes about 10 to 15 minutes of conversation before they suspected I wasnâ€™t Swedish. And then they never guessed I was American. Since I lived there as a young kid, itâ€™s really the place that feels like home. Western Oregon evokes Scandinavia in much of its landscape, so thatâ€™s probably why Iâ€™ve put down roots here so easily.

      I sometimes feel like the original jack of all trades, master of zip. Iâ€™ve worked a number of different jobs. Typesetter, firefighter, line cook, baker, basic labor, graphic designer. I got a teaching credential in â€™88, taught middle school for awhile, then went to law school. After law school, I worked as a librarian, a software company administrative manager, and (finally) a public defender in a rural Oregon county. In 1998, I started at Dynamix, a computer game company in Eugene, where I wrote the story and backdrop for an epic video game sci-fi franchise (Starsiege, later Tribes). Sierra closed Dynamix in 2001, and I started a new company with a few other ex-Dynamix folks. We produced Enigma: Rising Tide, a WW2 alternate history naval action game. After a couple of years there, I left that company to start as a tech support and sysadmin manager (and general counsel) with a more pedestrian software company. I eventually became the COO, essentially, before finally leaving last spring to avoid becoming a heart attack victim. Normally a pretty even-tempered, easy-going fellow, I encountered my limits on stress for the first time ever.

      Iâ€™m now trying my luck as a full-time fiction writer and family caretaker, doing some consulting contract work on the side. Weâ€™ll see how the writing venture goes. Iâ€™m one of the winners of the Writers of the Future contest, and my story â€œThe Sword from the Seaâ€ appears in the just-released Volume 22â€”the first one in the anthology, no less. Iâ€™m under no illusions about the prospects of supporting myself with fiction, but itâ€™s worth taking a shot at anyway. I write SF, fantasy, and twisted humor.

      RP-wise, I started playing blue book DnD way back in â€™77, a game that morphed into a hybrid of DnD and Runequest before I went off to college at UC Davis, California. I dropped out of RP in college except for a couple of toe-dunks into The Fantasy Trip. Came back to it in â€™87 with GURPS. In law school I got into Ars Magica and Vampire. Later did some homebrew cyberpunk, dove heavily into the rest of the WW games during the mid-â€˜90â€™s. More of a GM than a player, though the best game I ever played in turned out to be an intensely political Werewolf chronicle. After I started in the computer game industry and became interested in design, I did a little experimentation with Forge games and others, but nothing lasting came of it. Iâ€™m more interested in play technique and facilitating creative agenda (i.e., Actual Play) than in producing my own game. Over the last few years Iâ€™ve been an armchair gamer with occasional short-lived forays to try out non-trad game designs like The Pool, PTA, Story Engine, etc. Iâ€™ve just started running a Dragon-Blooded Exalted game using a heavily-drifted Wushu conversion. Weâ€™ll see how long that lasts, but itâ€™s looking promising for a long-term campaign. Though I prefer rules-light games, I have this unholy itch to run Burning Wheel.

      My wife is a sometime gamer. She really loved the aforementoined Werewolf game, in which she participated. Sheâ€™s interested in starting up again, which is cool. We have a real challenge with a two-year old and a six-year old running underfoot, so Iâ€™m always interested in hearing from other gamer parents.

      Letâ€™s see: other interests include marathon running, European Renaissance martial arts (sword & buckler), history (esp. the Battle of Britain and Battle of the Atlantic), politics (Iâ€™m a deep blue, far left progressive), oral storytelling, folk music, mythology and folklore, epidemiology, alternative energy and green living, musicals, the sociology of demographics and social change, and Pythonesque, scatological humor.

      Favorite novels: Dune, Tai-Pan, Summerland, Nine Princes in Amber, A Song for Arbonne, Count Zero, The Lords of Discipline, Three Hearts and Three Lions, A Wizard of Earthsea, probably about fifty others. Iâ€™m currently reading Kate Elliottâ€™s Crown of Stars series, which is surprisingly good in the George R.R. Martin vein (and complete!). Kateâ€™s a local Eugene writer as well, which is cool. Eugene turns out to be a hotbed of professional F&SF writing talent. I knew Johnzo through that circle, as it happens. Brilliant writer, that guy.

      Favorite tunes: Pretty much anything by Sorten Muld or Triakel. Also listening to Cake, Enya, Evanescence, Dar Williams, Dead Can Dance, Jolie Holland, and about fifty other bands. The whole iTunes phenomenon has made musical exploration easy as sin.

      I really like this community, both for the creative output and the easy-going courtesy it extends. Like Old Scratch, Iâ€™m a user of design and technique theory, not a designer. Nice to have a place with solid, mature discussion that at the same time feels like a comfortable hangout where one can chew the fat. A big thanks to Andy and all the rest of you.

      Iâ€™ll sign off now, so I donâ€™t use ALL the available pixel space.

      Best,

      Blake
    • thor
      December 2006
      Gods, people are adding so much about themselves that I feel my posts don't cover enough.

      I'm married to a non-gamer retieree, I have two children, one a Lawyer/Mom and the other a riding instruter/ Biology Doctoral candidate. 5 grandchildren: twins 5 one 11 one 20 and one 24 who lives with us. My oldes grandson games but he thinks my stuff is stoopid and enjoys Rifts.

      I am a non practicing atheist, who enjoys other religions and their practices but has no faith.

      I started with white box D&D but had to play over the phone because none of my friends lived near enough to me to play face to face. We played fairly regularly in high school and into collage. D&D, Traveller, CoC, were the big ones. Flashing Blades, Marrow Project, Top Secret, Aftermath were the couple of times ones and there were about a dozen others.

      I have never been much of a joiner which has limited my play. I was at least partially responsible for the founding of two collage gameing groups at two universities but never joined either.

      I think I said before that I have stopped gaming two or three times depending on how much you consider thinking about game design without playing. I was in a comitted and loving gaming group last year but they fled the country ( I honestly think it was the President's fault more than mine). I am in an every two weeks Tekumel group and thinking of hanging out a shingle to play pickup playtests at a local game shop.

      By the way I married the mother of my high school sweetheart if that adds anything to my die roll.
    • Joli
      December 2006
      I'm glad this thread has ressurrected. Gets us newcomers on the social radar.

      So: I'm Joel P. Shempert, 31, divorced after a mercifully brief marriage, now in love with the most amazing woman in the world who I'm gonna marry someday. She's never gamed, but we've talked about it and she's interested, with what looks like a strong bias toward Narrativism (yay!). I live in Portland, Oregon. I puttered around community college for several years, mostly as a Music Major, with dabblings in journalism, philosophy, political science, and literature. I ran the usual gamut of fast food and retail jobs. I now work as a caregiver at an Adult FosterCare home for the developmentally disabled.

      I sing in a choir of mostly-alumni volunteers from said community college. We're called Unistus ("fantasy") and our fantasy is peace. We were inspired by the country of Estonia, particularly by her 1991 Singing Revolution, which turned away tanks with singing. No joke. We sing lots of Estonian music and go to Estonian Song Festivals. The music and the people are full of love. We're personal friends of people like composer Veljo Tormis, which is awesome. He writes songs filled with a deep and primal power and spiritual energy. Anyone who hasn't heard him should really check him out, his music's on Amazon.

      I was raised very Christian by a Baptist minister and his wife. Grew up smug and know-it-all about it, then got out into "the world," and had my conceptions shattered. I've explored a lot of avenues and accumulated much knowledge and insight from diverse traditions, and put it all together to become. . .I have no idea. I've been working up from first principles and have "God is Love" firmly fixed; all else is up in the air. The Jesus and divinity thing, I'm wrestling with. Right now, my rough model is, "Jesus was an amazing and charismatic and possibly supernatural person whose Way is compelling and challenging," "Jesus shows what God is like through his words and actions," and "I believe I can talk to Jesus because, well, he's talked to me." I'm considering calling myself a "Yeshuan" to distinguish from the "Christ"-iness of Christianity. Fortunately I go to a very cool and accepting church where I don't have to live in fear from the repercussions of these explorations.

      Other stuff that's important to me: Art, beauty, self-expression, individualism, literature, fantasy, games, comics, truth, world-changing activism. As for that last one, I've had a hard time figuring out how to make that work; I can barely follow world and domestic news, much less do anything about it. And I have personal difficulty in that politics isn't really THE THING that I want to care about; I see it as the thing that makes all the other things possible. Regarding the other stuff, some specifics, in scattershot fashion: JRR Tolkien, J.D. Salinger, Rembrandt, Mozart, C.S. Lewis, Hayao Miyazaki, Fyodor, Dostoevsky, Joss Whedon, Five Iron Frenzy, Neil Gaiman, Sting, Katharine Blake, Shakespeare, Socrates, Vincent Van Gogh, Veljo Tormis (see above), The TÃ¡in BÃ³ CÃºailnge, The Psalms of (among others) David, Robert Heinlein, Final Fantasy, Kevin Smith, Mr. Children, Mark Oakley, Ursula Le Guin, Hideo Kojima, Poor Old Lu, Alan Moore, Beethoven, Steven Lawhead, Ben Harper, John Stuart Mill, the Gorillaz, Frank Herbert, John Stewart, G.K. Chesterton, pre-soulless George Lucas.

      Another noteworthy: My friends, Todd and Angie have totally pioneered new ways of doing music; first at the Church I go to, they head up the "worship music," and it is totally off the hook in ways I cannot even describe. Totally breaking out of old forms to make it relevant and alive. Second, the've formed and hosted the Ink Brethren (that's my washed-out face below the logo), a gathering using techniques for spontaneous group songwriting. It's liberating and hella fun. And loaded with interesting parallells to roleplaying, I think.

      Last noteworthy, I promise: I'm involved with the SCA (Society for Creative Anachronism), a bunch of Medieval reenactment folks. It's way fun. It's equal parts historical education and hard partyin'. I'm a Bard. And when I say that, I don't mean it in a D&D "I'm a half-elven fighter thief" way, or even in a "I dress as a Bard" way. The SCA has afforded me the opportunity to be something I've always yearned for. I sing, tell stories, recite poetry. I participated in my first Bardic festival this October, and won high honor and fast friendship. Life is good.

      I think that about does it. . .except maybe a brief (I promise!) roleplaying history: I started at about 13 with heavily Pawn-stance (which is to say, "Glorified boardgame") Marvel Superheroes, then Middle Earth Roleplaying (MERP) from ICE. The fact that that D&D was Satanic and Forbidden played some part in both those choices. Somewhere in the midst of MERP the idea that I could actually play a character with real personality, goals, desires, dialogue, etc. emerged, and got off to a rocky start as it met with. . .uneven support from my fellows. We also played Heroes Unlimited, hastily selected by me as an antidote to the "too loose" MSH, and we spent several years trying to play superheroes with a derivative of a third-rate D&D clone.

      That group dissolved after high school due to people moving and being unable to get together often enough. A couple years into college I met new friends, and played DD 2E with them, bringing with me my two brothers from the childhood group. This has been my group ever since, albeit with some notable shakeups and roster changes. We play D&D 3x and Big Eyes Small Mouth run by one GM, more D&D run by another, and Over the Edge run by me. The games carry varying degrees of satisfaction withme, with a volatile oscilation between awesomeness and agenda clash boredom/occasional hostility.

      I discovered the Forge and Hippie Games about a year ago. I read about Narr and went "Oh! So that's what I've been yearning for all this time and pursuing in an entirely unproductive manner!" I grabbed PTA in January and have been playing a season with a couple of non-previous-gamer friends. A rocky, stumbling start, but with steadily-increasing success and much enjoyment. I got Heroquest and played in Fred Wolke's short-lived Regain the Stars IRC campaign, along with Mike Holmes and others. I miss it. I've purchased Trollbabe, Sorceror, and DitV, but have yet to play them.

      Ok, I'm done. Hope it's interesting. I certainly enjoyed writing it, but you know what they say about everyone's favorite subject. . .

      Peace,
      -Joel

    • Rich Stokes
      December 2006
      I've been meaning to post this for a while...

      My name is Rich and I'm reinforcing the age bracket for the site by being 31.

      I've been using my real name online for as long as message boards have let you put a space in your UserID. I sometimes feel like making something really cool sounding up whenever people ask what my real name is: "Yeah, I post under the name Rich Stokes, but my real name is Legolas Dragonslayer." Something like that.

      You can add me to the Secular Jewish posse. Probably count as a Humanist or something, I never really dwell on it to be honest. My Dad once said something about my family being from Romania, but that's not really something that's important to me.

      I was born in Kent, grew up in London and I now live in Southampton, England with my girlfriend, Claire. She just got into gaming earlier this year. She'd been badgering me to let her play for a while and in February I started a new campaign, she joined in and now there's no turning back. She's working of a game she wants to run soon, which will be interesting. We aren't married because we don't plan to ever have kids. In the social strata we live in, people only ever really seem to get married if they want kids. Since I hate kids, animals and almost everything else there doesn't seem much point.

      I have a degree in Acoustic Engineering, which probably sounds a lot more interesting than it actually is.

      I'm one of the creators of TotL.net and Microsith.com, except some evil domain squatter own Microsith.com now. I once convinced the world that I'd built a computer that was powered by potatoes, but that's not something I'm entirely proud of.

      By day, I'm either a Systems Administrator or De facto IT Manager depending on who you ask. I work for a company which manufactures parts for ships. The actual product is very dull, but there's one in every single nuclear submarine run by either the US or UK navies, so it's simultaneously very dull and very secret.

      I've been gaming for something over 20 ish years. First game I played was RuneQuest. I think we played Dragon Warriors after than and we finally graduated to Merp. First one I bought was the Games Workshop edition of Merp in the purple box. I was 11 when I bought that. I've always liked the idea of wargames, but actually playing them was mostly very disappointing. Games like M'44 and Battleground: Fantasy Warfare seem to have a much better effort/fun ratio and that works for me. If only I could actually beat Claire at either game occasionally, that would be nice.

      That ratio of effort to fun is what I'm all about. I think one of the reasons that these MMOs are popular is that they are so little effort. For a game to appeal to me it has to be easy and rewarding or fairly easy really damn rewarding.

      I have written games, but don't consider myself a designer as much as a tinkerer. I aspire to be like a mechanic that understands what goes on in a car engine rather than the engineer that builds the car, if that makes sense?

      Other than gaming? Videogames, I'm a real console nut. I have pretty much every console made since the Sega Master System and play them on an AV projector in my lounge. I know the Japanese for Yes, No, Save, Load, Save and Continue, but nothing much else.

      Plus booze. I'm a real beer ponce, I hunt down imported beers from all over the world. This makes me fat. Since I stopped spending every weekend at raves in the countryside or dismal industrial clubs and started sleeping on a regular basis I've become really rather out of shape.

      I used to read a lot of comics, but find that I have less time and enthusiasm for them these days. I still keep up with Stray Bullets and Fell though. I never liked superheros though.

      And I like to cook, much to Claire's delight. If only I'd crack the washing dishes afterward thing...

    • Rich Stokes
      December 2006
      Posted By: MelinglorPosted By: Rich StokesI think we played Dragon Warriors after than [snip]
      Never heard of that one. Who published it? What's it like?
      It was an early Fantasy game, published in the UK about 20 odd years ago. It was published by Corgi Books I think, who were a kids book company. It was sold in book shops and supermarkets alongside the Fighting Fantasy stuff. It was a core book, about 200 pages like a paperback novel.

      I think it was available in Australia as well.

      For me, it occupies the same place in my heart that red box D&D does for a lot of people. See, when I was a kid, D&D wasn't on sale by the tills at ADSA, but Dragon Warriors was.

      Good times
      Posted By: MelinglorReally? Maybe we're emplying different definitions of "effort". . .granted, I haven't been an active MMORPer since Everquest i, but what turned me OFF was the effort required for fun: the busywork, the loads and loads of running everywhere, the molasses-slow level treadmill. . .I understand WOW is brisker, but still. . .
      Ah, yes. I was referring to the effort required to actually get the game up and running.

      Turn on computer
      Click Icon
      Wait for game to load and connect to server
      Play

      is much easier than:

      Arrange for 3+ mates to come over on the same night
      Hope no-one cancels
      Prepare adventure
      Play

      My computer breaks down way less often than one of my players has to cancel. (I am cheating though, because keeping computers running is my profession, but you see where I'm going with that)

      A good system can reduce the effort of prep and increase the amount of fun I have. If only someone could make something that would increase the regularity with which the players attended...
    «1234567…15»

    • Alex F
      December 2006
      Dragon Warriors... ahhh.... I remember picking up book 2 (sorcerors and mystics?) thinking it was a choose your own adventure book (I was hooked on the Fighting Fantasy stuff at the time), as it was paperback sized and had spells and 'game book' written on it. At first I was disappointed when I realised I couldn't actually play through the book on my own. Then, my head exploded.

      Never actually got to play them, alas... but I sure did read em a hell of a lot. That's your gateway game right there: an rpg disguised as another product!
    • Rafael
      December 2006
      My name is Rafael Chandler. I'm 32. I live in North Carolina.

      I've been working as a writer and designer in the video game industry since 2000. I worked for EA and Ubisoft, then went freelance. In addition, my wife and I run a consulting company.

      I've been married for three years. It's great. One kid, a little pink snorty baby. He's a lot of fun.

      I listen to metal. I watch The Wire, BSG, and Heroes. I like to read books by guys like George V. Higgins, John le CarrÃ©, and Clive Barker. I play a lot of video games -- I've got maybe sixteen consoles, stuff like the Sega Master System and the NEC Turbografx-16. And the current-gen stuff too.

      Used to smoke and drink and eat fast food all day. Now I eat healthy and get lots of exercise. When the doctors told me that the tumor in my throat was benign, I figured that you only get so many lucky days in your life. So I made some adjustments.

      -- Rafael
    • [Deleted User]
      December 2006 edited July 2014
      deleted
    • Geoff Hall
      December 2006
      Since this thread got necro'd back from obscurity (where it apparently lay before I started reading these forums) I've been intending to post and let y'all know a little bit about my good self. I actually started doing that some days ago but, I'm sorry to say, the fickle whim of my laptop keyboard intervened and caused my partially written epic to be BELETED!, Strong Bad-style. Disheartened by this set-back I put away the post for another day and now another day has arrived (and I'm bored at work) so I shall once again attempt to inflict upon you a little something about me.

      First point, I ramble. A lot. (Just in case you didn't figure that out from the above.) Bear that in mind when reading the below ;o) .

      Anyway, my name is (as you can probably guess) Geoff Hall. I'm 27 years of age and live near Bristol in the south west of England. I'm not a pirate born and bred though, I grew up a touch south of Croydon (that's south London for you foreign-types) and spent most of my life there, barring a couple of lengthy stints in Birmigham for various university based hi-jinks. More on that later. I'm of average height and build with blue eyes and hair that I still describe as red but, well, I can't actually begin to give an accurate colour for anymore. It was red when I was at school, it varies between red, blonde and brown now depending on the weather, the time of year and, I assume, the alignment of the stars and planets. I'm married to a wonderful (if slightly insane) woman called Steph and we have 4 kids. The older 2 are my step-kids, Darren (nearly 15, bloody hell!) and Jordan (or Jay, he's 11.) The younger 2 are rather more recent and are mine (in the biological sense, all 4 are mine in the emotional and responsibility senses) and they are Cameron (who is 3) and Finaly (who is coming up to 7 months). Steph and I have been married for nearly 4 1/2 years now and have known each other for a bit over 6. We currently live in a rented and immensely cool old house in a tiny village. To an extent I love the place but, well, we can't go anywhere without using the car, which is a royal pain in the arse, so much so that we're looking to move and actually (finally) buy a palce of our own. Unfortunately having 4 kids (along with 6 cats and a frickin' great german shepard dog) is going to make finding a suitable property in our price range problematical at best... (Curse you UK housing market, curse you to hell!) Anyway, as you can imagine things get rather hectic at home and free time is something of a rarity for me (which is why Anarchy will be lucky to be ready for DragonMeet 2007 and why Finger on the Button is still just a single LJ entry) but that's okay, the kids, animals and wife are all good ) .

      So, other than getting married and producing offspring what have I done with my life? Well I attended school (as you do) and got a bunch of GCSEs, went to college and got another GCSE (Astronomy in this case) and some A-Levels. From there I went on to the University of Birmingham to study Physics with Astrophysics. I did one of those (relatively) new fangled MSci 4 year undergrad degrees and netted myself a 2 (i) with honours at the end of it. Perhaps more importantly, though, it was during my time at uni that I got into roleplaying and met some of the people that I'm still friends with and still game with today (including Andrew Kenrick, to name check someone here who has an actual game or few published ;o) .) After that I moved back to Croydon and in with my then girlfriend (and now wife), bummed around working for the local council for bit before deciding that I needed to earn some 'bread' and get myself a career. To that end it was back to Birmingham where I did a postgrad masters degree in The Physics and Technology of Nuclear Reactors. So, I can now put MSci and MSc after my name should I so desire. Aren't I lucky? Anyway, from there I ended up working in BNFL and, when that got split up, BNG (the Project Services part) and that's where I am now, writing and running radiation shielding codes and performing radiological consequence assessments in order to facilitate the decommissioning of the UK's ageing fleet of Magnox reactors. Of course I'm also acutely hacked off with my job and the direction that the company is taking and fully intend to quit next year and go and work with Steph on her business (she sells ballgowns and jewellery on ebay/the internet).

      "But what about the gaming!?!" I hear you cry. As I said earlier I'm actually comparatively new to the hobby. I only started gaming after D&D 3rd Ed. came out. It was recognised that the uni RPG society would likely get a significant membership boost with the advent of 3rd Ed (and it did) and I lived in a house of roleplayers by that point. Andrew wanted to playtest the game before running a campaign for the society so he roped the other 2 Rpers into it and I volunteered after checking out the book. I ended up playing a ranger (it was only later that I came to realise that 3rd Ed rangers were mechanically busted, I was new, so sue me :op) and had great fun. I then got drunk and joined another 3rd Ed game that was starting up, this time as a Bard (yes, I picked 2 of the mechanically weakest 3rd Ed classes, sod off ;o) .) To say that I had fun playing Owyn (my ranger) and Jayce (my bard) would be something of an understatement. I had an absolute blast and it wasn't too long before I was hooked. Since those heady days I've tried quite a few games and moved away from my d20 roots and now find myself drawn more and more towards the small press scene. In fact at the DragonMeet just gone I ended up buying 7 indie games and already owned DitV, tMW, Sorcerer, TSoY and Dead of Night. I now have an insane amount of reading and playing to be getting on with! Of course I've not stuck soley to the RPG side of gaming. In fact I was very big into Magic at one point and still have a couple of shoeboxes worth of cards. I think my favourite CCG was the B5 one though. I keep intending to break it out again and play but I'm damned if I can remember how and I've got so many cards and no idea how to make an effective deck anymore! I'm also getting more and more into stand alone games now like board games (I've recently purchased Warrior Knights, TI 3rd Ed and Beowulf) and non-collectible card games (Three Dragon Ante, Chrononaughts, etc.) which I can play with my family (Darren, the 14 year old, is into roleplaying but Jay really isn't and nor is Steph and, at 3 years and 7 months, Cam and Finn are a touch young just yet!) It's a rare week that I don't end up playing something with the kids (and frequently one of my friends who lives in Bath and, if we're playing Beowulf and she's not too busy, Steph.)

      Finally (on a similar note) I'm trying to make the jump from player to publisher. All of the rocking games that people are producing these days are pretty inspiring and I've got the odd idea that i think is cool so I figure, what the hell, I can give it a shot too. I have 2 games in the works, Anarchy (a game about a future, dystopian Britain where the players play terrorists/revolutionaries trying to bring down the fascist government) and Finger on the Button (I don't know what the hell this is going to be yet!) I don't get a whole lot of time to work on them so they're not exactly moving at a great clip but Anarchy is pretty much ready for some mechanical playtesting, something that I hope to do soon.

      So, yeah, that's probably far more information than anyone needed to know about me and, on that note, I'll end this post. Peace.

    • eruditus
      December 2006
      Hey there, my name is Don Corcoran. I'm 37 years old and have been gaming since 1978. The same person introduced me to my other love, martial arts and combat in all it's forms, however the cerebral is winning it's battle against the physical.

      I live with my lovely wife, two dogs and two cats in a row home in Philadelphia, PA.

      I am an application trainer and senior help desk analyst in the 9th largest law firm in Philadelphia. Despite it being law it's a very positive environment and I don't dread going to work. My wife is a low level analyst for the National Board of Medical Examiners. If your a physician chances are you had to take one of their tests to get liscenced to practice. Her supervisor is a psychometrician which I was disappointed to learn had nothing to do with psychometry.

      I love driving and travel and long to visit Europe and Asia.

      I dig writing but I am a stronger idea man than a writer. I tend to be very ADD on projects and get easily distracted which has led to the downward spiral of hundreds of cool projects. I am a poor self motivator and look for support mechanisms to keep me on the path.

      My wife games more than almost anyone I know save myself. We maintain about three games a week, although only recently has it been at all regular. Gaming is my third love (God and my wife take the top spots but I can't say it's not a juggling act sometimes). I own thousands of books in over 300 systems (and thanks to many of the folk on this list, growing by the week). I have read them all and played 90% of the collection. I have demoed games at cons offically for DP9, AEG, Iron Crown, White Wolf, WotC, IMAGINE, Black Dragon Press, and a handful of others and have minor credits in a few other publications for development, playtesting and minor contributions. The Burning Wheel is my gaming god and I am adapting offical rules for the Artesia RPG to be played with BW.

      I have several blogs (I too am an ametuer HTML/ASP developer) that I have just started after being on LiveJournal for a few years. Anything else you'd like to know?
    • Lord_Minx
      December 2006 edited November 2010
      (Heh, I get the feeling I'm posting only in the community/about the forum threads, but whatever...)

      My name is Aaron, I'm 22 and I have neither job nor much of an education, although I meant to change that for a while now. I'm currently living in Langenzersdorf, Austria, which is more or less right next to Vienna, where I went to the equivalent of High School before finally dropping out in the last year out of a combination of lazyness, depression and "too in love to care". Since then, I worked various low-pay sorta-students jobs, bought and read a huge amount of books, did my mandatory service for Austria as a paramedic at the Austrian Red Cross, did a bit of gaming, drawing, painting, writing and idea collecting (Though not nearly enough, in my opinion.), had quite a few nervous breakdowns (Way to many of those for my taste.) and spent much time expanding my sexual horizon.

      I have an incredible girlfriend who was the reason I was "too in love to care", we've been together for roughly five years now and it looks like we're on our way towards another five years. Before getting together in a strange, very complicated, very awkward but in hindsight terribly cute and romantic way, we were first "friends" and then "best friends" ever since ages 10-12, when we first met in the train on the way to school. For years while we just friends, I had a terrible, terrible crush on her, which resulted in angst-filled journal entries, sad poetry and very depressing pictures, although it's, again in hindsight, very cute and romantic. (In a way, it feels really nice to be the guy who fell in love with his female best friend and not only got together with her but is now, five years later, in a great relationship with her, filled with fun, love and naughtiness.)

      EDIT: The last few years, I got heavily into this "internet" thing and developed a massive hard-on for the whole Social Software/Networking/Indie/DIY/PoD/Forum/...-thingy and now try to suck up every bit of information on stuff that connects people, makes doing your own thing easier and so on. Maybe it just appeals to the hopeless nerd in me but I really like some of the development towards geography-independent social circles and I can't wait for more mobile ways to connect to the internet, to make this kind of stuff even easier. My heads bustling with ideas about connecting people, wether it's my halfbaked idea for finally starting an Indie-focused community here in Austria or the one about playing around with wireless, wiki/forum/chat-based communities for "meatspace" locations like bars, gaming clubs and so on. Of course, because it's easier to have an idea then to actually do something about it, nothing has come from them so far.
      (Although I sold a friends mother on the whole Indie/PoD idea, so I guess thats a win. ^_^ )

      I started gaming way before I knew that there are things called "roleplaying games", when I was about 10-14 and learned that some of my (much older) friends played this strange game called "Das Schwarze Auge" (The Dark Eye). I read the books and was fascinated and so I borrowed the starter box and just tried running a game for (IIRC) my brother, my older male cousin and his half-sister. It was a complete disaster, I have no idea what I really had to do and the whole thing ended in a near party kill. After that, I didn't really follow gaming until much later, probably at about 15-16, when I overheard to older class-mates one row behind me talk about something called "Shadowrun". (Before that, I had read an interesting SR novel called "Wiener Blei" and so knew that setting without ever realizing that it was a roleplaying game.) I asked them about this and they explained that Shadowrun was a "Roleplaying Game" like DSA/TDE, and that they were running a game. I've been hooked ever since, although my tastes have changed. (Or more likely haven't changed, I just found games that fit my tastes better then Shadowrun.)
    • Chiv
      December 2006
      i have been avoiding it, i am terrible at bio's.

      ahh lets see, my name is Daniel Chiavaroli. I am 31 and a recent (6 months ago)transplant from Harrisburg, PA to Carrboro, NC.

      i was not aware, until i read the 30 yrs of DND book, how long i'd been a gamer. i remember being excited for the 2nd ed Monster Manual 2 to come out. I played DND for several years in HS. I decided it was too static and picked up Shadowrun and WoD for a while. I was eventually lured back to midnight sessions of DND in college. I forget exactly how i stumbled across BW, but it has lead me, meandering into the indie games world.

      Other Things: i'm a comic book nerd, a big one. It was very long ago my mother decided to infect me with her vile pack-rattery, . she marched me down to the local news agency and set up a pull service for Batman, the Flash and Superman. i read them for a while and evolved to the X-flavor of the month. I eventually stopped reading "capes" all together, which earned me a good natured hard time from the store owners in PA.

      I' m also in the SCA, i only mention it because Melinglor mentioned it. I have been much less enamored of it as of late. My group in Pa had no time for people that wanted to play royals, and it seems like thats all they want to do here. Thee's and Thous and M'Lady.

      I have been a techie of one type or another since 1998 and i am working at UNC's help desk right now. I have a BFA in Related Arts from some tiny cowtown Uni in PA called Kutztown. Related Arts was the easy out degree, "pick 3 disciplines and do them". I picked English, Theater and music. I know, my grammar and sentence structure does not say...ENGLISH MAJOR..but my writing is much more conversational. Also, i seem to have slept through the nuts and bolts of language in highschool. How does an English/theater/music guy become a techie, might be your next question. In college i spent a great deal of time with some proto-geeks that had removed one of the beds in a dorm room to put more computers in.

      Let's see what else, i moved to NC to be with my lady, Abbey. She is a Library Science grad student at UNC. She is from California but met on tribe.net (internet romance ftw). we've been together almost 2 years, no children, one bitchy little cat and lovable mutt dog. She loves boardgames and is interested in RPGing but it was a "boys night" activity with all her ex'es.
    • fifth_child
      January 2007
      I'm 23 years old, so on the younger end of the users here. White male. Name's Dan Riley. I grew up in Massachussettes and Connecticut, then joined the Air Force. Went to school at the Defense Language Institute in Monterey CA where I studied Korean for 8 hours a day, 5 days a week. I... uh... enjoyed that a lot more than the description might make you think, because I'm really all about language at heart. After that I lived in South Korea for 2 years, which was really pretty damn cool. Especially when I got to attend a semester of college at Yonsei University and live as a civilian for 3 months in Seoul. After that it was back to California for another year and a half, though in a much less-nice part of the state. I just got out of the military in December and now I'm with my family in Georgia (they moved here while I was in Korea) looking to go back to college.

      So, other than roleplaying, I'm interested in... well, everything, really. I speak, read, and write Korean fluently. I speak Japanese passably but unfortunately am almost completely illiterate. I plan on moving on to Mandarin Chinese once I've mastered Japanese. I took 5 years of Spanish in high school and managed to remember hardly a word. I read a lot, collect movies and television shows on DVD, and play a lot of roleplaying games, video games, and board games.

      Music is a huge part of my life. I listen to everything at least a little bit, but identify most strongly with indie and alternative stuff. Favorite bands are Pearl Jam, Radiohead, Death Cab For Cutie, The Yeah Yeah Yeahs, The Strokes, The Shins, Snow Patrol, Aimee Mann, and Ani DiFranco, among others. Since I was introduced to the magic of the iPod, I'm listening to music almost literally every waking minute that I'm not actually interacting with someone. I play the bass guitar, not particularly spectacularly.

      As an aside, I read "pretentious" literature, collect independent movies, and listen to independent music. Indie games and I were pretty much a perfect match.

    • nikodemus
      February 2007
      My name is Nikodemus Siivola. I'm a 31 years of finnish male. I live together with my partner in Helsinki, Finland. No kids, no pets. I am self-employed: since last autumn I have a small IT business of my own.

      I love books. I love historical fencing, but haven't actually been to class for ages. I listen to music very seldom, maybe a few nights in a month. Movies, lots of movies. Did I mention books? Nice wines, decents beers, good old single malt whiskies, well made dinners. Black: the only color you'll ever need. I seem to be in the extreme lower left corner on the political compass.

      I've been roleplaying since 1983 or so. I was an avid larper in the later 1990's and organized one in 1997, but have since then gravitated pretty solidly back to tabletop.

    • kkriegg
      February 2007
      Hello, everyone! I was directed over here from my first thread and thought maybe I could introduce myself. I'm 23 years old, live outside of Seattle, WA. I work as a carpenter. I've been roleplaying since I was in the 3rd grade, and I've designed so many game systems I've lost track of them all, which is fine since the majority of them were based on a single idea and never really finished. Anyways, you guys seem like a cool group, and I'm eager to read more of your posts!
    • John Anderson
      February 2007
      Well, I can't think of a better first post than introducing myself. My name's John Anderson and I'm 37 years old. I live in London and work part-time as an EMT for the London Ambulance Service and am in my final year of a full time BA Politics at Goldsmiths College, University of London. The thought of going back to work full-time fills me with absolute horror!

      I was born here to service parents (both in the RAF) and the family emigrated to New Zealand when I was 6 after the reality of Europe becoming an irradiated glowing wasteland seemed to be getting more likely. Happily that didn't happen and I spent a wild childhood in NZ living north of Auckland, in Christchurch and in Greymouth, the most god-forsaken place on Earth.

      Christchurch was were my gaming took off as the Christchurch wargaming society and the University of Canterbury gaming society allowed me to meet like-minded wargamers and roleplayers. I spent many a happy evening (and sometimes weekend) playing Harn, Traveller, WFRP and many many more...good times.

      Returning to the UK when there were no jobs in NZ and I drifted from the obligatory "Kiwi barman in England" role to assistant manager of a pub in Barnes, west London before realising that that role wasn't for me. A short stint doing aid work in Croatia during the war led to meeting my partner for 13 years, Kelly. We then headed off to the Slovak Republic for a two-year stint teaching English and generally drinking far too much with the ex-pat teaching community.

      Back in the real world and I've been working with the LAS doing stupid shifts for the past 10 years and pretty much stopping my gaming as I was totally unable to commit to even weekly games (Bloody shift work!). I've since managed to return to gaming regularly since being a slack-arsed student and have discovered the joys of a different style of play from my Christchurch days. I'm predominantly an Intarweb loiterer with my nom de plume popping up on the harnforum, the forge, the burning wheel forum and now here. I notice the same old names popping up.

      While I've managed to collect alot of games and gaming stuff in the past twenty-odd years, I've certainly become more indie-orientated of late. I'm a BW/BE gamer currently playing once a week with a lovely bunch of lads who've been playing together for years. Tomorrow begins a BW game set in the world of Glen Cook's Black Company.

      John
    • John Anderson
      February 2007 edited February 2007
      Oh, by the way, free PDF downloads of all six books of the Dragon Warriors series are available here. I'd never heard of it until I was thrown head first into it when I joined my current gaming group and this is the setting used. How's that for a small world?
      John
    • guildofblades
      February 2007
      Hi All,

      My name is Ryan Johnson and I am a 33 year old male living in Clawson, Michigan, a northerly suburb of Detroit. I am happily married as of april 2006 to my wife, Amnouy, who has a masters in computer sciences and currently a programmer. Being From Thailand I've had myself a few interesting trips out east and we've had all kinds of fun going through the mountains of paperwork involved with US immigration.

      I grew up in Clawson, then after high school took a tour in the US Navy before returning back to Michigan to resume my education. After a year long process of gathering the investors and local town support in Lansing, MI to get a large scale night club business plan rolling had failed, I had business in my blood. So a couple months thereafter, in Feb of 97, myself and few others got serious about taking the Guild of Blades Publishing Group (which to that point had only published a gaming club zine and a photo copied minis rule set) and turning it into a real game publishing business. I am currently the Guild's President and it is my full time career and livelihood, other than a bit of side money I make doing a little consulting on the side. (though my wife has a very good job implementing and managing CRM systems, so in 2007 it may be a toss up who is the primary bread winner....).

      For the first 6-7 years the Guild of Blades was a part time gig, so I bounced around a bit in my other professional experiences. Of my most notable positions during that time period I was a brand manager for one dot com tech property, the director of marketing for another dot com start up and marketing manager for a trucking company.

      My gaming experiences began at the age of 13 when I had begun designing something of a solitaire board/rpg game system. After a while I showed it to one of my friends who happened to already be a D&D player, so D&D roped me in early. But I quickly expanded my gaming tastes to games like Risk, Axis & Allies, Diplomacy and then into wargames with my favorite being World in Flames by the Australian Design Group. From the start I was always designing games, mostly RPGs, board and war games. Though oddly enough, as broke college kids who couldn't afford to buy into expensive miniature games, the first game published under the Guild of Blades was a house minis game initially designed to give our own gaming group a cheaper minis gaming option. These days the company keeps me very busy so I don't get to game as much, but we have a group that is currently playing the old FASA Star Trek RPG set in an Mirror Universe style setting around the Enterprise (most recent tv show) period and we play via VOIP since our players are spread over three states. I get to play our MMO online games 1483 Online and Thermopylae Online, but thats about it. Having recently moved, I am now happy to have a full sized basement where I am in the process of setting up a nice wargaming area and I WILL get to play World in Flames again!!!! :)

      Ryan S. Johnson
      Guild of Blades Publishing Group
      http://www.guildofblades.com
      http://www.1483online.com
      http://www.thermopylae-online.com
    • tadk

      Tad Kelson
    • reaction

    • guildofblades
      February 2007
      >>Wait, Guild of Blades? The Dark Realms Guild of Blades? I've got that book around here somewhere, I had pulled it out to reference the Halfbreed humanoid races. I picked it up at here in Lansing years ago. Now *that* is a proper small world situation.
    • kesher
      February 2007 edited February 2007
      Howdy, all.

      I'm 37, a happy Jew, live in Minneapolis in the occasionally frozen North, and started gaming back in 1982 when my parents bought me the dear ol' Moldvay Red Box Basic set for my 12th birthday. It would still be three more years before I had a mullet...

      I have a BA in English Lit, and taught English to grades 7-12 for the last five years. When it became obvious that that just wasn't gonna work out, I briefly considered becoming an architect or a computer programmer, but instead ended up currently making my living as a diversity trainer and freelance writer for this company. I also just started my own tutoring business. Teaching was a love/hate thing that just about made me insane, but I did manage to run a gaming group with some students afterschool for a couple of years; we started out playing Tunnels & Trolls and ended up with a system that was pretty much equal parts Fighting Fantasy and The Mountain Witch, so it wasn't a complete waste...

      I was in a band called Passage for four years in the latter half of the 90's, in which I played guitar, wrote all of the lyrics, and did some back-up singing. We were a six-piece with mostly acoustic instruments inluding (wait for it...) a hammered dulcimer. We played everywere there was to play in Minneapolis, and it was a freakin' blast. Lots of free beer, and we put out a CD that I can, thank God, still listen to without wincing.

      I've been married to the same bee-yoo-tee-ful woman for creeping up on nine years. We have a hilarious three year-old who's obsessed with the Hot Wheels AcceleRacers movies, which aren't as bad as you might think. Really. We also have a new child due in September, after the arrival of which I will join the ranks of Stay At Home Dads (I think there should be a Guild, or Brotherhood, or SOMEthing...)

      I met my wife doing theater, which I is another one of my interests, along with reading, reading and more reading. I also speak, read and write pidgin Hebrew, and wrestle wolves.

      One of these statements is false.

      Aaron

      *Edited because, well, the forum software didn't like my link to the AceleRacers link on Wikipedia...
    • MummyKitty
      February 2007
      I'm Dan Owsen, I live in the Seattle area, married with children and old (41 at last count). I work at a video game company on their website and so you might say I also play games for a living. My main hobby is playing games, I play board games like Advanced Squad Leader and GMT strategy games, "Euro" games like Settlers of Catan, computer games (current favorite is Eve Online) and video games on Wii and Nintendo DS. I'm an old school RPGer, used to play a ton of D&D and Classic Traveller, recently have been getting back into it with GURPs, but looking for something different too... I also like to read history (ancient, medieval, military and religious history), comic books, HP Lovecraft and friends and sci-fi/fantasy, and drink a lot of wine or beer.
    • kesher

      My mullet was, of course, stylish, like Mel Gibson's...

      I'll show you a picture sometime...

      A.
    • Fredzor
      February 2007 edited September 2007
      I'm Fredrik Sellevold, a 30 year old (1976) Norwegian from Trondheim. I have my Master Degree in Science & Technology Studies, writing a thesis on library automation in the 1970s. Sometimes I get pangs of regret that I did not become an actual librarian. In the future, I wouldn't mind working at the state archive, but in the present I work as a Technical Oracle, dispensing words of computer wisdom to the confused masses. After finishing the degree I teleported to England to test the view from another another angle, and so I spent a year doing Tech Support in Nottingham. For Norwegian customers. That's globalisation, folks.

      I began my roleplaying career in 1992, GMing MERP and playing in a few runs of RECON (incidentally, it was only earlier this year I discovered that Recon is not actually supposed to take place in Vietnam). I moved over from MERP to RoleMaster not long after and kept running random adventures in Middle Earth until I shifted to the Shadow World around -96. That was also the year I first accessed the internet, and I've stayed hooked up to it ever since. Among my first actions online was subscribing to the Shadow World email list; that's where I first crossed words with Mike Holmes, which would eventually lead me to HeroQuest and The Forge. But that didn't begin until 2003. In the meantime I'd played a fair amount of Call of Cthulhu, D&D3 and a bunch of other games with and without boards.

      Aside from gaming, I've been part of an amateur theatre group, helped organising international student festivals, read books, played computer games and shot numerous arrows at bales of straw and other immobile targets (Which among other things has thought me that the common rpg practice of searching for your arrows after a battle will be mostly futile)

      Since coming to England, I've gotten less gaming done, but I haven't given up hope that I'll get some use out of the games I did travel with.

      Update: No longer in England. I returned to Trondheim one month ago, and I'm happy to report that my gaming opportunities have exploded again.
    • Tim Boser
      February 2007
      Might as well join in on the festivities....

      My name is Tim Boser. I am 25 and live in a small town called Cabot, Arkansas. I work full time as a store-room clerk for a transit company. I grew up in Jacksonville, Arkansas where my father served in the Air Force at the local Air Force base, and my mother took care of me and my sister. Around the time I turned 5, my dad got transfered to Minot, North Dakota, where it can snow well into summer (which sucks as a small child, because winters could get really bad). Since we didn't go outside a lot, my friends and I turned to other hobbies to keep us occupied, namely RPGs. I know we played a couple, but the only one that stood out in my mind was Buck Rogers, but that's a different story. We moved back to Arkansas, living in Hot Springs until my dad retired from the AF, and then living in Jacksonville, and finally moving to Cabot, where I graduated from high school with honors. I attended multiple colleges, but could only barely squeak out an Associates Degree before I got tired of it. (I will return, I vow it!)

      Outside of gaming, I have a few hobbies:
      - Reading (Current titles include Max Brooks' World War Z and Chuck Palahniuk's The Haunted)
      - Watching Movies (Usually whatever's on IFC, plus any odd stuff I come across)
      - Music (I like to listen and I can play a few instruments: saxophone, piano, drums, a little guitar)
      - Computers (Programming, web stuff, whatever catches my interest)
      - Video Games (Bow to my mad Halo skillz)

      I'm currently single, and sort of looking. I'm not all that religious, but I do think there's something more to life that I just can't define in any terms. I'm also trying to find some sort of creative avenue to take with my life, so I'm tinkering with a plethora of ideas (including writing a few games of my own) to curb my creative urges I can't satisfy elsewhere.

      I guess that's it, I can't think of anything else to say.
    • nick3.0
      February 2007
      Hello, Iâ€™m Nicholas Freney. Iâ€™m 25 years old, and currently an undergraduate English major at the University of Nevada Las Vegas . I hope to put together an rpg.net column within the next year, and write my own story-game. The story game will be nothing fancy, but I figure it be fun to try to write one. I have been seriously involved in gaming for about two years. Before that, I only collected White Wolfâ€™s Mage the Ascension books and played the occasion game of Conspiracy X.

      I like Hip-hop, decent comics, and anything else that catches my interest. I have several learning disabilities including Dysgraphia, which makes life as an English major interesting. I promise to do my best to be clear, but if you have trouble understanding me feel free to say something. I have no firm religious beliefs, and see people as more important then ideological beliefs.
    • Leaps-from-Shadows
      February 2007
      Hey all!

      I'm Shannon VanDenbos, a 31yo male, living in the great state of Minnesota in the You Ess of Ay. I've taken crap for my name ever since I can remember. i work at a couple of lame part-time jobs at the moment. I'm still trying to get back into my chosen field as a computer technician/builder.

      I've been playing RPGs for 15 years or so, and my experience includes Shadowrun, D&D, d20 Modern, oWoD, and nWoD. Other hobbies include reading, movies, and posting on RPG forums. I'm an atheist, for those who care about such things.
    • Parthenia
      February 2007
      I'm Julia, I'm 36, I live in Greenfield, MA, I'm originally from Memphis. I ended up in Western Massachusetts by way of college, where I majored in Religion. After I graduated I decided to stick around twon for a few months, but I fell in love with one of my housemates and never left. We've been together 11 years, married for 8, and have two daughters, so it was a good idea not to leave town.

      I work for pay and I hate my job, so it's not worth broadcasting. This year I'm trying to get an apprenticeship as a homebirth midwife, which is what I've always wanted to do, but didn't have the ovaries to try. During the summer I peddle homemade herbal body products and soap at our local farmer's market.

      I've only been playing rpg's for a tad over a year, and for some godforsaken reason I decided to try to write one tentatively called "Steal Away Jordan". I think some of the lovely and kind people I play with have mentioned my work-in-progress here, and maybe someone here playtested it at JiffyCon in November. (Thanks!)

      So in my short time playing I've played PTA (a Buffy the Vampire Slayer spinoff set in Cleveland), DITV, 1001 Nights, and Sorcerer for several sessions each, and playtested a few games, too.
    • OKeefe
      March 2007
      Hi, I'm new too.

      My real name is William Austin Schoonover (pronouned with a SK sound, not a SH) I'm 32, married, no kids (but we're considering some)

      I'll get this out of the way first, I'm the Art Director for Steve Jackson Games. That means I currently live in Austin, Texas.

      I was born in St Joe, Missouri (just like Walter Cronkite) an was raised by conservative protestants in a tiny town North of Kansas City. My mom's a gamer, but doesn't know it. I've been playing boardgames and cardgames all my life, but didn't get a chance to even try out RPGs until the 90s. I was, however; exposed to the entire "D&D is of the devil" propaganda, not allowed to trick or treat, and couldn't watch the Smurfs or HeMan at my grandma's house because they were "EVIL!". I still consider myself to be a Christian, but have a sorta Buddhist take on it.

      I've done four years of "college", but don't have a degree. When my best friend in the whole world graduated from college, I married her and we moved to St Louis. I finally acted on my lifelong dream to be a radio DJ and went to trade school, which ended up taking me to Truth or Consequences, New Mexico where I was the morning guy on an AM country station. TorC is a great place (if yer not a gamer) but my boss was quite possibly the craziest person I've ever personally met, so I went back to KC and got a soul sucking producer job in corporate radio. After five years of that I jumped at the chance to work anywhere in the game industry.

      That's probly enough history...

      Things about me... I collect cool looking bowling balls, currently 30, but I don't bowl. I play LazerTag about once a month, and I read all the time.

      I haven't really gotten my feet wet yet here because I haven't been able to try any of these games out, and all my prior RPG experience is bad. I hope to change that, and contribute a bit more to the discussion in the future. If you want to blame anyone for my presence here, it would be Misuba and the Sons of Kryos.
    • TG
      March 2007
      Seeing T or C mentioned above gave me just enough of a nudge to post on this thread, because I live in Las Cruces, NM.

      I am 58 years of age. Graduated from high school in 1966, college in 1970. Grew up and attended school in upstate NY. I have lived in NY, Arizona, Maryland and NM.

      Friends introduced me to D&D somewhere around 1980. Within a few years we migrated to Dragonquest, which I still play today with an entirely different group. Our host for gaming admits to having "a few years" on me.

      My wife and I keep two dogs and three cats. I inspect buildings on behalf of insurance companies for a living. Our small city is growing rapidly. The local politicians, for the most part, eagerly court the developers. That sucks; we can possibly delay it, but not likely stop it. I have two dirt bikes that I never ride and several guns that I sometimes shoot. NM is good for dirt riding and shooting.

      I haven't ever played any of the games that are usually discussed here, but keep wanting something different from our usual games.
    • Scott Dorward
      March 2007
      As my handle would suggest, I'm Scott Dorward. I'm forty-one, and was born and raised in Hong Kong (with a few years out in Switzerland). Since leaving there in my late teens, I've lived in New York, London and Dundee, before settling in Milton Keynes around sixteen years ago. Don't believe all the bad things that people say about Milton Keynes -- some of them aren't true.

      Like a disproportionate number of roleplayers, I work in IT. I have one of those jobs that doesn't really fit into a neat description, but I do stuff involving servers and networks, most of it interesting, some of it involving travelling around Europe, and I get paid for it.

      On the whole, I'm pretty boring. I'm currently single, living alone apart from a cat, and I play a lot of games, write fiction occasionally and spend too much time watching films. Writing this is making me wonder what the hell else I do with my time.

      I started gaming in school, around 1983 or so, with AD&D, and may have given up had I not found Traveller and then Call of Cthulhu. These games made me fall in love with RPGs, and I played consistently through to the early nineties. When I moved to Milton Keynes, I lost contact with all the gamers I knew in London and ended up not gaming at all for ten years. About five years ago, a friend of mine convinced me to start running games for her and her partner, and I've been playing ever since.

      The explosion in indie games over the last few years has made me more excited about gaming than at any time since I was a teenager. My patience for complex rules that simulate things that don't interest me, or for overly detailed backgrounds that make me feel constrained from making stuff up is low; focused, short games play to my strengths as a player and GM, especially as my memory isn't what it once was.

      These days I'm a member of the Milton Keynes RPG Club, which has turned into quite a lively and diverse gaming community, where you're as likely to find a game of Dogs in the Vineyard or InSpectres as you are Dungeons & Dragons or Exalted. We hold a one-day convention every six months, called Concrete Cow (Milton Keynes is famous for a herd of concrete cows situated in a field in Blue Bridge), which is gradually building a name for itself on the UK con circuit.
    • mcrow
      March 2007
      I'm Michael Crow

      I'm 29, and live In Hutchinson(Minneapolis), MN with my wife Kim. We were just married on 12/13 in Jamaica.

      When I'm not gaming or trying to design games, I'm a Medical Lab Tech. I hav a degree in Medical Technology, Electronics Technology, and in the past have worked as a Biomed Tech. I also worked for a time in a research lab @ the Unversity of Minnesota. Kim is an occupational therapist.

      I started gaming aroung 1990 with D&D, then TMNT and other Palladium games to follow. I have been a playtester for multiple game including CCGs,Boardgames, and RPGs. Being a tinkerer, I have always been messing around with game designs of one sort or the other. The last few years I have been writing a lot of gaming reviews and in the process have come arcoss indie games. I found that there were a lot of indie games I liked, some I don't just like traditional games.

      When I'm not working or gaming I like to play Discgolf,camping, reading, watching tv (Jericho,Hero, BSG, Dresden...ect), and going to movies. I just started using Liver Journal, and like reading other peoples gaming stuff and having others read mine. I also enjoy endless and sometimes useless debates on games.

      I guess thats about it.

    • Novembre
      March 2007
      My name is Paolo Robino. I'm 39. I currently work as R&D manager in a company that produces color concentrates for plastics (aka masterbatches). When I mention my previous career, people seem baffled: in their opinion, no one sane of mind would sell his own pharmacy to become an employee in a company. They keep asking me medical advice, though. I live alone near Vicenza (Italy), have a (new, non-gaming) girlfriend, love to read non-fiction and listen to jazz and strange covers of pop music. I'm mentioned in the credits of Unknown Armies, 2nd edition, among the "Rumormongers". This fills me with pride, and shows how wrong my priorities are.

    • BastardToadflax
      March 2007
      I've been lurking long enough, I may as well post something. I'm 35 and a professional procrastinator, by which I mean I am a lawyer, in Portland, Maine. I publish way too much personal information at mazirian.com I'm trying to shift my current gaming group away from what is here referred to as traditional gaming, but they are resisting.     • MatrixGamer
      March 2007
      Hi! I'm Chris Engle. I'll be 44 in a few months. I've been with my wife going on 20 years. We live with our present cat (Matilda Turd Cat - she bites) on an old farm outside Bloomington Indiana. Terri and I both work for Indiana University which gives us enough money to pursue our other interests - Puppetry and Game Publishing. I was born in Louisville Kentucy and raised in Southern Indiana (my family were some of the first settlers out here). I got a BA in Criminal Justice from IU and my Masters in Social Work from the University of Louisville. I spent years working in rural community mental health with a three year stint in private practice. Then I got a job at the college counseling center. I started out a nominal Anglican with Calvinist leanings but in 1986 was introduced to Sufi Islam. I converted to Sunni Islam in 1996. I'm fairly certain I have an FBI file due to that - which annoys me to no end.

      I started gaming in 1976 with the Avalon Hill game King Maker. The next day my borthers and I start playing D+D (the white box version). We soon fell in with a bunch of old miniatures gamers so I was indoctrinated by followers of Donald Featherstone and Jack Scruby. When I was in college in the early 80's I learned about Paddy Griffith and the experiemental games of Wargame Developments. I worked on the odd game but nothing serious until I was almost out of grad school. That is when I came up with the idea for the Matrix Game. Between 1988 and 1992 I wrote over 60 articles for various newsletters (MWAN, PW Review, Lone Warrior, and NUGGET, Shadis #6, and my own newsletter EGG). While I've always played role play games I've tended to self identify as a miniatures gamer so I've spent a lot more time in that world than in this one. That started to change when I saw that Matrix Game worked very well to do murder mysteries, spy games, political games and horror stories. Around 1998 I started building up to publish games like that. Meanwhile overseas Matrix Game are used by the British and Australian armies as planning tools.

      People say that gamers are not professional enough. I felt that way too so I've taken my time in getting Matrix Games ready for market. I learned how to do accounting, I've experimented with a lot of different production techniques. I've tried to build up public awareness and my network of contacts in the industry. I have a plan. If it works I hope to have 100 titles in print by 2012. It is in the realm of possibility but it will be a lot of work. Inshallah it will work.

      I saw Mike Underwood listed above. Hey Mike! I've also seen Robert Clark-Early and Ryan Johnson listed as well. They've been very helpful to me. Thanks for the tip on digital duplicators Ryan! Best machine I've ever bought.

      Chris Engle BA MSSW ACSW LCSW (CEO Hamster Press) Puppet Roadie, Therapy Slave.







    • Sharrow
      March 2007
      Hi, I'm Marc Corvin from Goettingen, Germany.
      Single, 22 years old, no wife, no kids, no Job (Student, Applied Informatics) and way to much spare time
    • Jvstin
      March 2007
      Hello.

      My name is Paul Weimer, sometimes known as Jvstin. A couple people on this board know me. :)

      I run the long running Amber PBEM Strange Bedfellows (http://www.whiterose.org/twiki/bin/view/Bedfellows/WebHome). I also am a regular at Ambercon US (although I missed this year)and The Black Road.

      In the last year or so, I've been slowly breaking out of a box and a rut, learning and growing with new systems and ideas. I've joined a group of "Indie Gamers" up here in the Twin Cities, and am interested in using and playing Independent Games.
    • GamerChick
      March 2007
      Jae Walker here, and I am very afraid I win "oldest", as I'm turning 53 in September. Besides my name, I go by "GamerChick", "JaeGamer" and "Countess" on the internet. I'm a recovering Catholic, occasional pagan and inquiring Buddhist still in search of my spiritual path. Female, unwillingly single, no kids, two cats. I live in East Lansing, Michigan, USA, in the heart of the palm, where I've always lived. My family is dead, and I had nothing to do with it. Really. Honest.

      I was in IT most of my adult life, until it nearly killed me. After six years of temping and desperate job hunting, I finally secured a full time job back at the University as a secretary for a terrific boss. Couldn't be happier, and I have health insurance.

      I remember when Chainmail first came out in 1975, but I was too busy finishing my college degree (BA in Theatre & English - would you like fries with that?) to pursue it. I finally started gaming in the early Eighties. I've helped found a club (and am currently president-for-life-or-till-I-find-a-patsy), organized and run conventions of various sizes, taught GMing, playtested various games, co-created and ran the RPGA's Living Force campaign, got Nathan Fillion to come sit down at a Firefly game (no really, I have a photo to prove it), and know people at every level of the industry and hobby. Yeah. I really love gaming. It's like that.

      In the few moments when I'm not working, sleeping or doing something gaming related, I read voraciously, collect (and watch) horror movies, SF, anime and the occasional chick flick. Never met a vampire movie I didn't like. I'm a passionate "Firefly" fan. I have a stereotypical Irish tropism for alcohol, but it doesn't rule my life. (Why did the Good Lord create whiskey? To keep the Irish from taking over the earth...) But mostly I'm doing something related to gaming...

      I'm a feminist* through and through, and I've made it my mission to seduce as many of my gender as possible into the gaming side of the Force. The hobby needs more chicks. It needs more people of color too, but as I'm all Irish, all the time, I've had less success seeking, finding and luring. I fear I lack cultural context.

      I fell in among the Indie gamers mostly by accident, but developed the addiction when I attended the GenCon workshop led by Jared Sorenson. Dayum... they made me *think*. I'm learning new ways to have gaming fun, and applying things I've learned to the old games too. (I persuaded my D&D GM to add Fan Mail to the game...)

      I'm glad to be here and eager to learn all I can. And share what life has taught me, if anyone is interested.

      * Feminist = Someone who holds the radical notion that women are human beings.
    • GamerChick
      March 2007
      Oh... and I'm #114 on the Evil Overlord's List (http://www.eviloverlord.com/lists/dungeon_a.html). "I will never accept a challenge from the hero."
    • Eldir
      May 2007 edited May 2007
      I'm a 27-year-old single Korean who moved to the States in 2006 to earn a J.D. degree. I also earned a B.A. in Korean law at Ewha Women's University, which is actually just a few blocks from Yonsei. *waves to fifth_child*

      My two previous stays in the U.S. were 7 months in Tennessee as a newborn and 1 1/2 years as a child in Connecticut. The latter period is when I picked up weirdly good English, which I apparently speak without a trace of an accent. No one can figure out how I did it, least of all me.

      Currently I'm living and studying law in D.C. Seems studying law is all I did since becoming a grownup. In my free time I read fantasy and history, dabble in amateur scripting (mostly PHP and mIRC), and keep a blog. And of course, I play roleplaying games. I'm especially a fanatic for Forge games.
    • mytholder
      May 2007
      I'm a 29-year-old Irish writer-type-thing. I've been freelancing for various rpg companies since I got very, very bored with (and, mercifully, fired from) programming. For the last few years, I've been writing full-time for Mongoose Publishing on various lines (d20, Babylon 5, Conan, Paranoia etc).

      I was on the Forge back before there was a Forge, in the GamingOutpost days, but got burned out on theorising and so missed the whole indie games movement. I'm poking my nose back in now, partially as a way to kick my Warcrack habit.

      My livejournal is at mytholder.livejournal.com.

      Sup
      I'm a 21 year old male Swede. I do art(http://northerain.deviantart.com) and I'm currently studying. I also play rpgs(for about 8 years now). I spend alot of time in Greece were I do most of my rolepaying.

    • Justin D. Jacobson
      May 2007
      I'm 36, a collections lawyer by trade, graduate of Princeton University (philosophy major) and Duke Law, and I presently live in South Florida with my wife Jeannine (another lawyer; we met in law school) and my two daughters Jadyn and Jara. (Yeah, I'm working the "J" thing.)

      I've been playing games for as long as I can remember. Heck, my dad and my uncle have been gaming since they played Diplomacy when they were in college. They introduced me (and my cousins) to D&D, Boot Hill, etc.

      In addition to rpgs, I design strategy games, including Golem, winner of the About.com shared pieces design competition.

      When I'm not doing things game-related, I spend a lot of time with my family and enjoy gourment cooking.
