    Comments

    • guildofblades
      May 2007
      >>I've also seen Robert Clark-Early and Ryan Johnson listed as well. They've been very helpful to me. Thanks for the tip on digital duplicators Ryan! Best machine I've ever bought.
    • Dave Hallett
      May 2007
      I just turned 40, and live in Oxford, UK, with my wife and assorted small mammals. You may have come across a couple of scenarios I wrote for the Cthulhu by Gaslight supplement Dark Designs, a long time ago. I'm currently working on some Fudge/FATE-based rules for Lovecraftian horror gaming. I also love Jorune, Dogs in the Vineyard, Paranoia, and a bunch of other games.

      I make a living by editing and proofreading medical research, and writing about it too. I'm currently trying to teach myself typography, layout and design to round out that skill set. My time is somewhat limited, but as Gary Sumpter will tell you, I will sometimes work for free if I find the material interesting enough. It doesn't hurt to ask, so long as a polite refusal won't offend you.

      I also play the drums, and you can check out my band The Black Hats, at our MySpace page. We're a bit new, so no "proper" website just yet.
    • Matthew_SB
      May 2007
      Hello all. I'm Matthew Sullivan-Barrett and have been lurking here for a while now.
      I live in Tacoma, Washington, just south of Seattle. I'm very much looking forward to GoPlay NW in June.
      I'm a computer programmer for cash. I game most every Saturdays, play video games most every day, and maybe every three months I'll try to pick up sketching again.

      I'm 35, and have been divorced for around 8 years.
      My daughter is 12. She's terribly bright and creative kid, and has developed great joy in really awesome manga style drawing! She's a big sweetie, and pretty much the brightest star in my life!
      My SO is also 35. She's a Speech and Language Pathologist, and while not a gamer is very supportive of the hobby and enjoys socializing with my gaming friends outside of the game. She also rocks.

      I was born in central Oregon, kind of out in the country. My family's mostly educators, and my folks definitely had hippy leanings. I got into D&D there, hooked by the cartoons adverts TSR had in the back of comic books. Mostly lonely fun, but it fired up some creative juices.

      At around age 10, my parents took on jobs teaching in a little mining town called Tembagapura in Papua (then Irian Jaya), Indonesia. So that's where I spent my middle school years. The town was very isolated, in the middle of the jungle high up in the mountains. With no TV and not enough kids for most sports, it was pretty easy to get some RPG games going.

      At age 14, my folks moved to Kobe, Japan, where I attended high school. That was pretty awesome too, but it was much more of a struggle to get some gaming on.

      Finally, at age 17 we settled down in Washington. I've been here ever since, which makes this the longest stretch I've lived in one spot.

      My transition to Story Games went from Ars Magica to Feng Shui to Wushu, at which point I've now gone all-in with the exciting things coming out of the indie RPG communities.

      The three other guys in my gaming group are not quite as excited about always trying new stuff out, but the games we've tried have mostly been successes. Wushu has taken over as our game of choice, with two current games using it and one more being planned. We're halfway through our first PTA season, which is also going well. We didn't have as much luck with Polaris, and one player melted down. I still love Polaris deeply, though.

      I enjoy reading about design, especially in practical terms, but have not found a spark that moves me to try my hand at it yet. I would very much like to, but don't want to force the issue.

      So, this has exceeded the length of post I'd expect anyone to read about me, by some margin. Thanks for the indulgence.
    • MylesC
      June 2007
      I'm Myles Corcoran, 38, father of two, Irish, living in Cork, IT guy in local university. Mostly lurking, but interested in all sorts of gaming. I'm part of a small (five person) gaming group who've been together since '99, not often moved to try new games but persuadable.
    • voicestovoices
      July 2007
      My name is Amy, 21 years old, studying French and Swedish in Minnesota right now. Recently married and my husband and I are both amateur game designers. In addition to all sorts of gaming I'm also a big language geek, like baking, shenanigans and making mischief, and all things horror-themed.
    • T-Boy
      July 2007
      Awesome! An introductory thread!

      My name’s Tariq Kamal, and I’m 26 years old. I’m Malay Muslim, and I live in Kuala Lumpur.

      When I was ten years old, some neighborhood kids introduced me to a system home-brewed from Steve Jackson’s Fighting Fantasy novels. The rules were incoherent, game-play was disjointed, we had no idea what we were doing, we all outgrew the system within a year and a half, and really, the only thing I still think was cool about that whole game was that we made pretty, pretty maps.

      Most of my friends went on to do other things, like excel academically, become doctors or lawyers, or start a rock band.

      I stayed obsessed with gaming. It’s been an interesting ride — I never had an easy time trying to find a gaming group, so in the end, I decided to make my own from hapless bystanders with my non-gaming friends. Oh, and my wife, who treats my obsession with a combination of slight exasperation, amusement, confusion and (especially after getting Truth and Justice) enthusiasm.

      At any rate, that’s all there is to it. Apart from that home-brew system, I’ve had a bit of playing experience with the following: oWOD Mage, D&D 3.5, Star Wars d20 and Truth & Justice.
    • Joe_Beason
      July 2007
      I'm Joe: 40, GWM, work as a statistician/programmer in pharmaceutical R&D, grew up in Chicago and now live there again with my partner of 6 years, Nick. I used to play D&D back in high school and college, tried out some other systems like Champions and GURPS, then got into the WoD. Most of my experience with the latter was through on-line play at GarouMUSH. I stopped playing games when I got my "real job". Over the last few years, I've started playing boardgames again, mostly thanks to my partner's brother-in-law, who's a big, big fan of games like Settlers of Catan, Puerto Rico, etc.

      In recent years I've been reconnecting with some of my old gaming buddies from college, and we've been trying to get back into RPGs. We're working on an Ars Magica saga, and I plan on introducing them to SGs as soon as I get them figured out myself! The biggest limitation is time: work takes up a chunk, family another, non-gaming friends another, and my partner is just not into RPGs. Yet. I still have hope! If only I hadn't subjected him to an evening of D&D last year...

      Other pastimes: reading (duh), knitting, cooking, baking.
    • lachek
      July 2007
      My name is not really Lachek Vojiczek Butalek, but that name (handle, actually) is original and means something, whereas my real name is similar to "John Smith" in Swedish.

      I'm 30, well 29, well just about 30 I guess (grumble). I maintain PCs for the Faculty of Humanities at our local university, which has taught me that Humanities faculty are among the most and the least knowledgeable people in the world. The phrase "angels dancing on pinheads" has been used. So has simply "pinheads".

      I lived the first 2/3rds of my life in Sweden. I started reading Lone Wolf Choose-Your-Own-Adventure books when I was 10, which naturally led to roleplaying as soon as I could figure out the rules. When I was 16, I joined a group of likeminded and eventually our gaming group grew to a dozen people - despite the fact that we lived on an island of only 14000, an old conservative farming and fishing community. Now I live in a half-a-million large North American city and can barely find enough people for a biweekly game. Shame.

      In the late 90s, MUSHes rather than MUDs forever shaped the way I would approach roleplaying - probably the sole reason I haven't joined in the mindless wailing of the choir of undead World of Warcraft players. MUSHes taught me to emphasize story over character achievement, and that the real killer of fun isn't having your character fail, it's not getting a chance to play at all. It's also where I met the woman that was to bring me "across the pond". I moved to Canada to marry this wonderful woman, and now have two kids - an 11-year old moody pre-teen emo stepson (and fellow gamer) and a 2 year old son who likes to smash windows, climb bookcases, and endlessly bring me my copy of Burning Empires (ooh, pretty colours!).

      I found indie/story/Forgeish games through podcasting (thanks Paul, Judd, Ryan, Chris, Jason, Remi, Clinton etc), which has greatly increased my interest in gaming and game design in recent years. To me, these games fill a space that other games never quite managed to fill, and fit very well with my current lifestyle and schedule.

      When I don't work, game or hang out with my family, I usually think about work, games or hanging out with my family. When I don't do that, I sometimes pretend to read an actual book made of paper, watch movies, make stuff from old Linux-powered PCs, manage my website (http://www.hammergames.org), post on message boards such as this fine example right here, and sometimes even have time to work on my game(s) - usually late night / early morning, when everyone is sleeping and with only the coffee pot as witness.

      My name's Jonathan Lambeth and I'm about to turn 30. I live in the area of Southern California known as "the 909" with my three kids and beautiful wife. I work as a Mechanical Engineer for Boeing, but my degree is in Physics. I started gaming in junior high with whatever version of DnD was around back then, but I didn't seriously begin until college. My love of Star Wars snagged me into playing the old d6 system. After my gaming group broke up I discovered the first iteration of the Forge (I think it was called the Hephaestus Forge at the time), and have been lurking around ever since with the occasional post. For at least the last six years I have desperately wanted to play any one of the awesome indie games I have read so much about. Maybe I should move to North Carolina or Portland!

      I'm George. I'm twenty one. I grew up mostly in Berkeley, CA. I'll be a sophomore at Knox College* this year. I'm in Sigma Nu fraternity. I don't actually game much myself, but I have a lot of gaming books and gaming friends and spend a lot of time on gaming forums.     • stevebarkeruk
      August 2007 edited August 2007
      I'm Steve Barker, 31, British and I fiddle with all manner of game design projects. I don't work at the moment due to a chronic health problem which also doesn't leave me much energy for game design but I do what I can.

      I haven't done any role playing at all in about 7 years due to the usual work and relocation factors, as well as the afore-mentioned health problem which has ruled the last 5 years of my life. Still, I find myself being drawn back into the role playing arena by the innovation I'm seeing in these here new-fangled story games, and the overlaps I'm seeing in some of their mechanics with the board games I am more usually playing (I can occasionally be seen at the Board Game Designers Forum as well).

      Outside of gaming there isn't much to see of me, except I help with some of the behind-the-scenes work at my friend Lisa Jonté's female artists collective Women's Work, and am an occasional sidekick on The Divalea Show podcast, hosted by comics artist and commentator Lea Hernandez (that podcast is on hiatus, by the way, while Lea and family recover from a devastating house fire last year).
    • Flynn
      August 2007
      I'm Adam Flynn, 30, married to a kind and beautiful woman (who games!) and have an almost 2 year old son.
      Born in New York, I grew up in Saudi Arabia, and now live just north of Boston. I have a bachelors in biochemistry, cellular, and molecular biology and work as a software developer in the financial sector.

      I've been roleplaying since about 7 and have never tired of it over the years. In my adolescence GenCon, unreachable far away, assumed a sort of mythic proportion in my mind as the mecca of all gaming - it's been great to attend the last three years.

      Aside from gaming I'm a bibliophile and amateur medieval sociologist. I love singing, traveling overseas, and playing with my awesome son.

    • jporrett
      August 2007
      I'm Joe Porrett, 38, single. I work as an office monkey for law firm in East Lansing, Michigan. I've been know to strum an acoustic guitar for time to time. My current obsessions include Guitar Hero (1, 2, 80's), Flight of the Conchords and Sim City DS.

      I've been a gamer since 1982, cutting my teeth on the old red box D&D. I've played numerous games over the years. These day I play mostly what would be termed "indie games," but I have a soft spot for NightLife and Talislanta.

      The most recent rpgs I've played:

      Breaking the Ice - Played a few weeks ago with my friend Ed. BtI never disappoints. I've played it twice and they are two of the most memorable games I've ever played.

      Nine Worlds - I ran 9W for about 6 months until GM burn-out kicked in. I hope to return to it because it is an amazing game. It's cool though; it gave one of the other guys in my group a chance to run a game, a Psychic game that uses psuedo- Dogs in the Vineyard rules.

      I'm gearing up to run InSpectres for the first time.

      That is all.
    • Number Ten Ox
      August 2007
      I just joined Story Games today, although I've been reading the forums for awhile and I've met some of you awesome folks briefly at past GenCons.

      I'm Jon Edwards, 40. I grew up in Los Angeles, and I've been living in the San Francisco Bay Area since '90. I'm a game programmer working at Activision; formerly employed by Take-Two, Electronic Arts, and Microprose. My specialties are gameplay programming, AI, general software architecture, and tools development.

      My gaming life started with the Magnavox Odyssey, Feudal, and Basic D&D. Through the 80s, 90s, early 00s I played D&D, a smattering other RPGs, various war and board games, 40K, a couple of CCGs, and a great number of computer games.

      I decided to go GenCon Indy for the first time in 2005. Uninterested in playing board games, minis, traditional RPGs, CCGs, and wondering what I was doing at GenCon, I stumbled across a booth selling something called indie roleplaying games. It provided a "Eureka!" moment, as I've always wanted more storytelling in my gaming and I studied improv acting for a few years and decided I was more interested in gaming.

      Most recently played: Spirit of the Century. Other hobbies include kyudo. Most of my interest in game design has been in computer and video game design, particularly strategy game design and the grand dream of interactive storytelling. As I gain more experience with PnP roleplaying as a player and GM, I am thinking more about RPG design and designing "my" game.

      I'm going to be at GenCon next week. I can't wait to check out (and support) the Ashcan Front, the Play Collective, and all the new seeds of the indie games explosion.

    • RichD

      Greetings, Story Gamers.

      I'm Rich DiTullio. I am 33 years old, married to Amber a lovely gamer chick, and have an 18 month old son named Teddy. To pay the bills, I put my PhD in Molecular Biology to work fighting a disease of the lung using a mouse model. Started with D&D 23 years ago coloring in my dice with crayon, drifted through White Wolf and Palladium with brief side trips for Tales From the Floating Vagabond, and now I stare hungrily at the various story games wishing I had a local group who loved them too. I did have a Burning Wheel group for a bit, Gm'd by Jake Norwood of Riddle of Steel fame no less, but alas that is no more. I'm currently running a BW one on one game with my wife that is going fairly well. Oh, any in Burning Wheel circles would know me as Verrain.

    • Deliverator
      August 2007
      Hi, my name is Matt Weber (oh noes! another Matt W!), and this is my first post on SG. I guess I'm coming a bit late to this party, but I hope not too late.

      I met (and gamed with) Moderator Andy at GenCon recently, and know or have met several other SG people in real life. In fact, I went to college with and used to live with Ben Lehman, who got me into Indie RPGs a few years ago. (Thanks Ben!) Before that, I played mostly traditional-but-not-D&D-games, like EarthDawn, and also a number of homebrew games written by people in the Brown college gaming crowd. That group is still a big part of my life emotionally and socially, and I go back up to New England for a boffer LARP called Aralis run by a Brown alum, but nowadays I reside in New York City.

      Favorite games today include Riddle of Steel and Burning Wheel, but I've enjoyed almost all the indie games I've played, which is a fairly long list at this point. I'm radically anti-rules-fudging and anti-GM-Fiat.

      Outside of gaming: I am 25, white, an atheist Jew, and I have relatively minor orthapedic physical disabilities. I was born in Fort Wayne, Indiana, in 1981. Before transferring to Brown, I attended Simon's Rock College in Great Barrington, Massachusetts, for two years. (There's at least one other SGer who went to Simon's Rock...) My majors in college were math and French Lit., and I recently finished a Master's program in Math Education. I worked for a year as math teacher in the Bronx, and am currently looking for another teaching job as of this posting, though hopefully I will have one within a few days.

      Although I enjoy reading sci-fi and fantasy, as well as movies and TV shows, as much as the next geek, my major hobby outside of gaming is music. I sing, compose, and play piano (poorly :-) ). I'm seriously considering trying to return to graduate school to pursue an M.A. in composition if the high school teaching thing doesn't work out. But I like the idea of being a high school teacher, because (especially in private schools) I will be more likely to have the opportunity to do things other than just teach math. I might get to use my French skills, or my musical knowledge, although of course my secret dream is to start an RPG club.

      Anything else you want to know, just ask. I hope to jump in on some regular threads here within the next day or so.

      Matt









    • Matt Schlotte
      August 2007 edited August 2007
      My name is Matt Schlotte, if that weren't obvious. I currently live in Portland, Oregon with my wonderful wife and two daughters. I was born in San Diego, lived too long in Oklahoma, changed my perception of reality multiple times and the way I live my life three times in Massachusetts before moving to Oregon, wherein I eventually got married to above wonderful wife and she bore our two exciting daughters.

      I am only now wrapping up my Bachelors degree in History with a smidge of Econ, due to at the traditional college age I was doing the college parties and knew any academic career would have been a sham at the time. There is a Masters degree in the future but that is next year.

      I too was an active Jew at one time in my life but that has not been the case for a long time. There are many other things I used to do such as playing bass, writing music, sky diving, rock climbing, smoke, read different spiritual texts, work at jobs I hated, live in a tent, hitch-hike across the country and more. Now I spend time with my wife and kids and have a blast at that, while focusing more on a few interests that have remained with me since my early days, namely history texts, anime, comics/manga, and the very occassional video game or miniature table top gaming (not mentioning RPGs since that isn't what this thread is about). The past times are enjoyed pretty closely in that order.
    • jdrakeh
      August 2007 edited August 2007
      I'm James Drake Hargrove, a 30-year-old part-time computer hardware technician, full-time mortgage application screener, and recovering drug addict. I was selected to participate in my Grammar School's Gifted Education program (where I first played D&D -- for a grade, no less). In Junior High, I was a participant in Duke University's Talent Search program, outscoring 90% of the nation's High School seniors in language comprehension and logical problem solving. In High School I became a budding substance abuser and was eventually ejected during my Junior year. I complete my required curriculum and received my Diploma via an alternative education center for troubled youth -- a month before my High School class graduated.

      After High School I went on to become a full-fledged drug addict, spending some time in the county clink, and running with full-fledged felons (from former motorcycle gang members to full-on drug manufacturers). Life was pretty much a miserable series of petty crime (and some not-so-petty-crimes) until 1997 when I cleaned up, moved to Topeka, KS and worked a series of security jobs until my relapse in 2001 and my subsequent move to California in 2002. In California, I cleaned up again and worked under contract for the Department of Defense via Day & Zimmerman Servies until 2003 when DZS lost their China Lake contract. Another relapse and multiple moves across the country followed as my physical health and mental welfare deteriorated drastically.

      Somewhere along the way, Politically Incorrect Games published Formless as a free product (per my stipulation that it remain forever free). Other than that, the exact details are pretty foggy due to excessive drinking binges at Fort Lewis and subsquent physical deterioration. When I left the area, I was suffering from alcohol-induced jaundice and swelling of the liver, which wasn't diagnosed until. . .

      I moved to Colorado Springs in November of 2004 and cleaned up again.

      Since that time I lost my (admittedly crappy) car, burned through a small number of menial jobs which paid next to nothing (and sometimes nothing), and ate many meals at the local soup kitchen for lack of finances to buy my own food. Last year, a good friend and general contractor hired me part-time to work as a general laborer. Early this year I managed to land a job with a local mortgage lead generation company. Since then, I've managed to survive multiple lay-offs and generate enough money to pay some of my bills on time, feed myself again (Ramen, baby!), and cover the necessities of living with a tiny bit left over for the occassional RPG purchase (fun is a necessity).

      I've done some volunteer work at the aforementioned soup kitchen and some other local charities this year. I donate to organizations that helped me avoid a tremendously painful death when I can afford to do so. Emotionally, I'm 100% better than I was three years ago. Physically, I have to live with a lot of my past decisions but am not much worse for wear. Mentally, I'm probably more stable than most Earth People whom I know. Spiritually, I've learned a lot about honesty, open-mindedness, and willingness. I'm "cash register" honest today (i.e., if somebody gives me too much change, I give it back).

      Mostly, I'm extremely greatful that I'm here and able to post this response today. Thank you to all of you who helped me find the will to live. Some of you know who you are, some of you don't, but you will all be in my heart for as long as I'm kicking around on this big, blue, marble. Today, I'm making an effort to do for others what you did for me, so that others can experience your good will and, hopefully, pass it on to somebody else.

      Who am I? I'm the best person I can be.
    • Kobayashi
      August 2007 edited August 2007
      Alexandre, 34, Paris, France, currently with someone.
      • Kobayashi stands for Masaki Kobayashi, one of my favorite director.
      • I have a master degree in Philosophy
      • Spent 4 months in former Yugoslavia in 1995-1996 as a stretcher-bearer during my military service, which leaved me a bit fucked up in the head.

      • Now starting courses to become a Shiatsu master.
      • Beginning my second year in Systema training. Hope to train in moscow for one-year in the future.
      On the rpg front :

      Started rpgs at 11 with a friend who had a red box. Total party kill in half an hour. Never quite understood what was happening, but I was hooked.

      Finally finished my first rpg : 10.000, which I hope to translate in english this year.

      After reading Grey Ranks and 3:16, started to work on Shell Shock, shamelessly stealing from these two great games.

      Started working on 47, an rpg about Ronins trying to avenge their lord and trying to emule movies like Baby Cart & Zatoichi.

      And I really like it here, thanks to you all.

      Greetings,

      I've been lurking on this particular site for a good six months now. I don't post often, but I love to read what is going on. I got into the whole story games thing when I read about Don't Rest Your Head on rpg.net.

      Personally? I'm a laboratory analyst and do work in both bioanalytical research and FT-IR spectroscopy analysis for QC at 3M. I live in Minnesota and other non-RPG hobbies include the requisite board gaming (Euro games especially) and animal care. I love caudates, the salamanders and newts, and other amphibians and take great joy in caring for them and potentially photographing them in the wild. Most other animals are awesome too, though I'm partial to cockatiels and dogs (especially mutts) when it comes to my non-semi-permeable skinned companion animals.

      It's great to post on this site, it has such an awesome community!
    • Gorsh
      August 2007 edited August 2007
      So who am i, who knows, but i can point to some facts anyway... IÂ´ll order this as a series of "nested flashbacks", and perhaps youÂ´ll get a picture...

      IÂ´ve been lurking around for a few weeks here at S-G, and this would only be my second post. The reason is the fact that i see a lot of deep thoughts circling around, even in the form of jokes; youÂ´ve got to have something good to say when matched against that background... So in those weeks iÂ´ve followed Graham W. lose faith and being brought back to "teh awesome"Â´s faith, picked a lot of thoughts about games that now i "get" better, watched Gen Con from a thousand miles ( in a mix of awe and dismay, due to the comparison of the size of the gamer community here and there ), perceived how accesible, real, discussable are the names of the designers of some great games; and on and on of interesting stuff.
      ( Byproduct: Load of cash just about to be sent to IPR in exchange of a big piece of the indie cake ).

      I got here mostly following the diaspora around, and specially after I ventured into the Game Chef for my first ever (in)complete take at making a RPG. The logic is "That was cool, i needed more of that, i come here". Great kudos there to Mr. Dogui, in both cases an important part of the fact of "entering".

      Re: Forge, indieness, and RPG theory, i always saw something more than fun in RPGs. Fun is a great thing, but there had to be something else that was ticking me this hard. IÂ´ve made my attempts at explaining or debating this hobby of us and never found much feedback; so when someone in our boards mentioned a pdf called "Design patterns in roleplaying" or something like that, i read it and followed the breadcrumbs to The Forge.
      I digested that all, and still do, even bringing up topics from years before; got into CostisickÂ´s blogging, into Ben LehmanÂ´s "this is my blog" series of explanations of theory, and all that jazz. And i liked it too...

      "Our forums" there means "www.deRol.com.ar", and that ".ar" means i hail from the lovely Buenos Aires city, and that this is not only an attempt to convey some meanings but also a practice in writing them into a foreign language ( Hola amigos ). The community down here is interesting, thriving, but mostly small, endogamic, and dulled out in endless d20 and bitching to each other. Roleplaying games are much newer to us as a whole, the boom for them being in the nineties ( with comics, ccgs, and all other forms of geek consumerism; something directly tied to the peso to dollar ratio of those days now gone ); and the "old guard" of enthusiasts has already phased out and replaced by a more stablished, but less proactive bunch. ( All this is MY opinion, of course ). In that context, indie-, story-, or whatever-games have a hard time reaching out; as the ones who would run them are few and spread... But that may change, albeit slowly.

      Add me in the picture: See 1995, see a nerdish kid last year of elementary school; a kid with a lot of comic/cartoon stories in his head and interested in reading and learning about those "comics" things. The teacher of the kid having made a "class library" of voluntarily lent books and comics; and among them The Killing Joke. Yes, Alan Moore, Brian Bolland; Batman, the Joker origin; gritty, thoughtful... When i finished it, i had to search a few hours for the pieces of my brains spread through the room; moments later i wanted more... And ended up with many numbers of a geekish magazine about comics and related items, and among those related were RPGs, a little explained. When the year later a mini mini con was held at my high school, i was teleported into the head of an X wing pilot and got completely hooked up to this thing to this day... From there, you can picture using the booming "internet thing" to find forums to discuss about it, and after failing converting my friends into gamers, and not finding other gamer places yet, a long history of PBP Star Wars d6, only truncated by the 9/11-induced change of atmosphere in those forums ( i remember a guy posting "I wish we turn their deserts into glass" ) and some of that annoying "real life" thing...

      The reason to name my teacher is that now iÂ´m following her path and becoming a school teacher; and that as a queue to tell you that last year i adventured into Brazil to be the first non-Brazilian to attend the IVth Simposium of RPGs and Education: something that interests me a lot. IÂ´m surprised of the non-connection of this two communities made-of-awesome, brazilian RPG theorists and education researchers and indie/story/-gamers; and i hope i become such bridge in the future: i believe shooting sacred design cows could make a hell of a change in the way games are considered in light of their educational value... But more about that on different posts, i suppose.

      Anyway, thatÂ´s quite a bunch of facts about me... Thanks for the welcome, then...
    • Valvorik
      August 2007 edited August 2007
      I'm Rob, 44 year old white ango-saxon male, born and living in Toronto, Canada. Youngest of 4 children of generally happy family complete with yard, dog and cat. Now a condo dweller with no kids, no yard, no dog and no cat.

      Poli-Economics degree and thereafter a job in the civil service I had for 6 years before I realized "criminy, I'm following my dad's footsteps" (talk about a blind spot). I'm a policy analyst developing and revising laws for consumer protection and public safety and trying not to turn into an embittered cynic after 20 years in public service.

      Used to computer game quite a bit but dropped it as absorbing too much time. Have always read tons ~ my older sister had copies of Lord of the Rings, you can blame her and a household where most rooms had bookshelves and everyone read. Being an adult means (a) reading; (b) playing cards; (c) debating politics. Try to read different sorts of non-fiction as well. Cards became RPG's, and my job means I can't debate most of the politics I know about publicly.

      Got into RPG gaming via miniatures I was getting for wargaming with my dad (who never "got" RPGing, but also never had any concerns about it, when you're the 4th kid and the first 3 have turned out okay, parents tend to be a bit laid back). Been gaming since high school and some events put on for gamers at the Toronto harbourfront area, and running a D&D game for some friends since 1986 through every edition of it. So every Thursday night I get to tell 5 people "here's the law", and about once every 5 years I get to tell 13 million or so "here's the law" (though the 5 have to take me more seriously than the 13 million). That also means I'm a world designer who probably knows way too much about the ecomonic and judicial systems of every culture. Also game less frequently with others trying out different systems (e.g., Universalis, Ryan S.'s E6 variant of D&D).

      Athiest, red tory politically, not married but thoroughly attached to a grade school teacher who tolerates my hobby in exhange for me tolerating her infatuation with Winnie the Pooh. Cat person but allergic to them.
    • redben
      September 2007
      I'm Ben, 32 year old white male living in Newcastle in the north east of England. I work for a bank to pay the bills, I've been living with my girlfriend for the last five years and we have no children or pets. I come from a family of staunch atheists and I'm extremely liberal in my political outlook. Grew up under Thatcher and would rather vote Satan than Tory.

      I train regularly in submission wrestling and mma and I enjoy watching may sports, I watch very little TV that isn't sports.

      I read a lot, I've Spook Country, The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier and Clay, and Crooked Little Vein lined up next. I read a lot of comics, like most of us on this side of the pond, I got into it reading 2000AD and was at the right age to follow all the main writers over to America pre-Vertigo. It wouldn't be too much of an exagerration to say that reading Doom Patrol changed my life.

      I know pro-wrestling.

      I like listening to electronic music and have long since lost track of what the kids are listening to.

      Began gaming aged 9 with a copy of the Fighting Fantasy gamebook, Island of the Lizard King. Moved onto tabletop rpg-ing the following year with AD&D and roleplayed religiously throughout the remainder of my school days, mainly MERP, Cyberpunk, Paranoia, Rifts, Heroes Unlimited and Marvel. Came back to the hobby in my early twenties and played a lot of WoD. Came back again early this year to play a bunch of indie games.

      Currently spending most of my spare time writing comic books and an rpg.
    • jzn
      September 2007 edited September 2007
      I'm Jason Ellis, born 1973, living in Queens. Had kind of a hippy upbringing in rural southern maryland, came to NYU in '91 to become an actor. Acting ended up on the back burner after I was distracted by running around in a band, enjoying some great roleplaying campaigns (thanks Lukzu) and trying to get rent money going.

      Hooked up with a lot of new roleplaying friends thanks to nerd.NYC in 2001 or so. Met Jenskot then, in line for Wrestlemania 20, and over the years he filled my head with stories of all the fun people he knows and the indie game movement in general. Spent some quality time internet arguing with Thor Olavsrud and others about game theory at nerd.nyc a few years back, and learned a good peck of neat forge ideas from them in the process.

      I know a whole lot about comics, computer games and professional wrestling, a good deal about theater, art, and music, a passable amount about computers, primatology, and brain science, a little bit about roleplaying games, but almost nothing about knowing when to shut up.

      I like to perform and I like to ask questions. I love game strategy. I love cooperation, I love people, and I love kicking people's butts. Its rare that I meet someone I don't like, although it happens.

      More than anything else, I usually define myself as a music making guy. You can find examples Here, Here, and Here. Oh and here's a fun free video game I had a hand in.. Enjoy!
    • Malcolm Sheppard
      September 2007
      I'm 34. I write for and design games for a living. I also do freelance IP development outside of RPGs. Before writing full time I worked part time as a literacy instructor, computer skills teacher and tech support guy, mostly in the nonprofit sector. I'm married, with two kids, acquired by marriage. I have a degree in Cultural Studies/Philosophy (I concentrated on both analytical and continental approaches to morality and identity) from the same Uni as Mo Turkington, who I used to LARP with about a decade and a bit ago. I was originally recruited by White Wolf to do some work on Mage. Now, over 20 books and God knows how many IPs/lines later, things are going petty well.

      Unlike many gamers I am not a big minis/board/CCG guy, though I do play on occasion. I like old school Battletech quite a bit.

      I did a lot of political activism when I was younger (and still am, but parenting and work have changed what I do). As a result of one related incident I had plastic surgery to fix the damage done by a murder attempt in 1993. If you met me, you wouldn't be able to tell. Like 50% of nerds martial arts is one of my hobbies. I have a junior teaching license in Okinawan-derived kempo and have dabbled in a bunch of other things. Right now I crosstrain informally with a taekwondo club and do kung fu. I want to get more submission grappling experience, but it's petty damned expensive around these parts.

      Aside from gaming, martial arts and being a father and husband I like the same crap as everybody else.

      I'm a lapsed Buddhist (Thich Nhat Hanh's liturgy), but that has nothing to do with my hobbies. My father and his father were also Buddhists and I picked it up from there.

      If you're reading this there's a strong chance you already know my opinions on a number of things.
    • Lobisome
      September 2007
      Hi

      I'm a daddy RPG player and DM from Cerdanyola del VallÃ©s, behind Barcelona at Catalunya (eastern Spain) where I live with two ladies (http://flickr.com/photos/lobisome/863234990/) and two kitten (http://flickr.com/photos/lobisome/119745573/in/set-72057594097696685/).

      Just guess which one I'm married with O:-)

      But I digress...

      I'm almost 37 and I started roleplaying almost quite 20 years ago and I even founded a quite big and active RPG association named "Els Bergants a Syl GarÃ´th". My RPG evolution started with Middle Earth RolePlaying to GURPS passing through Ars Magica, Cthulhu's Call, White Wolf's "Fantastic Five" (you know: Vampire, Werewolf and such). With GURPS I decided to stop learning new systems, but my head got collapsed and I never played a GURPS game but got a VERY interesting collection of GURPS supplements.

      But these days are long past and today I'm a daddy player wannabe (AKA no-time-to-spend-a-whole-day-RPGing) whose last RPG hope is PBEM and Indie Games. As I've seen some kinda indie examples on spanish RPG market, this vitality about systems, market and community around these Indie Games is a new world for me.

      I'm preparing a fantasy-victorian Story Bones (http://www.pigames.net/collaborative/index.php?action=read&page=293) PBEM game using Quest (http://www.foreverpeoplerpg.com/Cheap_Seats_Quest.txt) email-formatting-rules (but merging email with wiki as I told here: http://www.story-games.com/forums/comments.php?DiscussionID=916&page=2#Item_13) but there are a couple of games that will be my first choice as soon I got the opportunity to play a table-top RPG session again:
      - Dogs in the Vineyard
      - Burning Wheel

      Regards from Catalonia
      Juan Vicente MaÃ±anas Abad.

      PS: I'd also add that, once I read this stuff about GNS model I realize that I started as a simulationist (GMing MERP and such) but today I feel more as a narrativist as, maybe due to my lack of spare time, I REALLY prefer the shared story part from RPG over all.

    • UbuRex
      September 2007
      Hi. I'm Kevin, I'm almost 30, I live just outside Boston, MA, and I'll be married in about two weeks.

      I grew up in and around Buffalo, NY, and got my BA in English from the University of Rochester. I spent about a year working as a paperwork designer for a biotech company in Cambridge, MA before going to BC Law School. I'm currently a commercial litigator working at a mid-sized firm in Worcester. My most interesting job was the summer I spent as a law clerk in the Prosecutor's Office at the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia.

      I did a bit of theater in college and law school, would love to get back into it, but never have the time.

      My older brother played D&D while he was in high school, so that got me interested. In junior high I cut my teeth on Red Box basic D&D, gradually moving up to 1E AD&D. Played a bunch of AD&D, Shadowrun and D6 Star Wars in high school, and ran an intermittent Marvel Superheroes RPG campaign.

      I played a bunch of stuff in college, including V:tM LARP, AD&D, GURPS, and Heroes Unlimited. Once I left college, it's been difficult to find the time to play anything. I've played a little bit of D&D 3E and Champions, but that's about it.

      Poking around online, I found the Forge, which introduced me to Burning Wheel and the like. Since then, I've become interested in porting more "story-oriented" techniques (like flags, conflict res, etc.) into more "traditional" RPGs, whatever the heck that means.
    • ross
      September 2007
      I am a 41 year-old columnist and writer from Clearwater Florida.

      My column "Close to the Edit" just resumed after a year-long hiatus on RPG.net. I write primarily for myself, but occasionally other people find it interesting. I have been most "known" by my association with Cyberpunk 2020 and Action! System. I am also the official body model for Fat Messiah Games and the official jackass of the story-games forum.

      I have been divorced three times, have two children, and also one grandson.

      My first game was a copy of the blue D&D intro box in 1977, my second was the original edition of Traveller in that same year. I have played games as diverse as Arduin and as eclectic as Sorcerer. I am also ostensibly writing my own SF game, called Heisenberg.

      I find myself a bit awed by how far the hobby has evolved, and the speed at which it continues to evolve, most especially here. I think they keep me around only out of morbid curiousity.
    • Consonant Dude
      September 2007
      Maybe it's late but I never saw this thread until now.

      I'm 36, single and live in MontrÃ©al, Canada.

      I am francophone, so bear with me when I make ugly English mistakes or sound weird. (I'd be willing to help indie designers who need help with French terminology, BTW)

      I studied in literature and sound recording. That and many other things.

      I've worked as a journalist, a photographer's assistant and sound engineer predominantly. I co-founded a (very) small multimedia company and acted as director there. I've had digestive problems since 1984 but starting in 1998, I became very sick with an undiagnosed, severe illness. I lost everything in the process.

      A couple of years ago I finally learned I have celiac disease. I am feeling better now and starting to get back on my feet. I'm currently self-employed, doing the odd mercenary job for old acquaintances in the music business.

      My interests

      Arts. Pretty things, entertainment, low-brow, high-brow. I've learned that you can only go so far inllectualizing everything so I'm trying to keep it more simple. Before 1998, I used to sing in blues, 70s prog and metal bands. I'm trying to see if I can pick up again, despite my age. I've lost a lot of range.

      People. Before I got sick, I might have put arts before people but not anymore. I try to be nice. I hate people who are deliberately mean. Not unpleasant folks or folks who are hard to deal with but "calculated meanness". I have character flaws but I mean well, always. I can pull your leg, though. I don't take things too seriously, especially not roleplaying games.

      Cats. Especially my own. I find I can relate to cats in some strange way.

      Roleplaying. I have been roleplaying since I was 9, started with the "Orange Box" (French version of Basic D&D). Me and my friend had to learn to roleplay by ourselves and we introduced lots of people to it. It's kind of cool knowing you created a whole branch of roleplayers like that. As far as theory and things like that... I'm interested in the basics but I'm not "aligned" with any particular philosophy. I designed/homebrewed a lot of games in French, especially pre-2000. Quite a few were amusing in retrospective. These days I mostly use a Story Engine hack, D&D 3.5 and my beloved Everway.
    • Peter_Aronson
      September 2007 edited March 2009
      I'm Peter Aronson (no surprise there!), I'm 50, and live in Phoenix, Arizona, but am originally from Massachusetts. I have a BS in Computer and Information Science from UMass Amherst, and an MA in Geography from SUNY Buffalo. I work as a Software Designer and Programmer for ESRI, creating Geographic Information Systems Software, which means I'm actually doing what I went to school to do -- how weird is that? I like my job -- it provides lots of interesting problems to solve. I occasionally write science fiction, and fantasy and have a shoebox full of rejection slips around somewhere from trying to get it published.

      I'm been happily married to Casceil, who is a Staff Attorney for the Arizona Supreme Court, for 18 years. We met at a science fiction convention. She doesn't game except for an occasional board or card game, but she does encourage my gaming (after all, it could've been golf!). We still go to science fiction conventions together.

      I have two scary-smart teenage kids -- Jenny and Alex -- both of whom game, and were in fact responsible for me getting back into RPGs after 10+ gap, when they encountered demos of the Wildside Gaming System*, and got interested. (*Which we quickly discarded in favor of about anything else!) They've also gotten me interested in Anime and Manga, and I give them books from my science-fiction collection. We also have a couple of cats we rescued from a shopping center parking lot, who then took over the house.

      I got involved in war gaming (Tractics, Sea Power, Avalon Hill, SPI board games and the like) in junior high school, and ended up hanging around the MIT Strategic Games Society (which always had more members who were not MIT students than were). Then, in 1973 or 1974, Kevin Slimak came back from a convention at Lake Geneva with a playtest copy of the original D&D. Many games resulted.

      I soon started a correspondence with Gary Gygax, which led to a couple of articles being published in The Strategic Review and The Dragon. Later, I contributed occasionally to The Wild Hunt (A&E's, younger, East Coast sibling, which was sort of run out of the MITSGS, since that was where Mark Swanson and Glenn Blacow ran their games).

      I mostly ran and played D&D in the MITSGS-style, which was based on the original 3 books of D&D plus Greyhawk (the supplement, not the setting), and featured alternate magic systems, critical hits, and very tactical rules. However, we tried Runequest, Empire of the Petal Throne, Metamorphous Alpha, Villains & Vigilantes, Traveler, etc.

      I fell out of gaming when I married and moved to Phoenix, but as I mentioned, got back in when my kids got interested. These days I play a bit of D&D 3.5e, a bit more of True20, and play around with other systems (lately it's been FATE/SotC, Sorcerer and OVA, but that can change without notice). I like the forums here as they have an interesting blend of theory and practice (even if a background in a social science has made me a bit skeptical of theory) and are usually reasonably polite.

      I post on a number of forums as Father of Dragons (a bit of a joke about my kids). I'm occasionally an editor at www.chessvariants.com, and have been known to design a chess variant or three.

      I live in Ithaca, NY, and one of my housemates is Judd (of Paka and SoK fame).
      I'm a total commie.
    • Hituro
      September 2007
      Why would someone want to know about me?

      That aside I'm David Donachie, 33, an English Lit graduate working as a programmer for a political party in the UK and living in Edinburgh. I'm married and have acquired (via my wife) many many pets of all sorts

      I've been gaming as long as I can remember in one form or another. RPGs, board games, CCGs, computer games, you name it, as long as it doesn't require physical exertion I'll give it a go. I've also been designing games, for the use of me and my friends, for nearly as long, and have run more years of my own systems than I have anyone elses'.

      I'm a gamist simulationist dipping my toes in the narrativist world :P

    • Chris McNeilly
      September 2007
      Hi folks! I'm Chris McNeilly, 31, and go by donbaloo anywhere else on the internet. I'm very happily married (closing in on 3 years now) to a beautiful and brilliant gal, Melani. She took my gaming interests well into stride and adopted them for herself which was really cool. No kids yet, though we look forward to it some day down the road, and as for now our three dogs keep us company.

      I'm an ecologist for the National Park Service down on the North Carolina/South Carolina line. I've been in this mood for a few years where I've seriously considered the path of my career and am wondering whether to jump ship into something else. No real ideas on what yet though. I graduated from North Carolina State University back in '98 so I have to at least offer up the obligatory "Booo, Jason Morningstar" for working for the Tarheels. But I don't really mean it...its just a contractual agreement I was roped into upon receiving my diploma.

      Lately my wife and I have been spending most of our time mountain biking, skeet shooting, or working in the garden (though that's almost completely wrapped up by this time of year). It wouldn't be at all uncommon for you to find me shooting basketball, hiking, camping, or trout fishing either. We don't watch broadcast television, cable, or satellite but its not because we're too good to sit on our lazy rears in front of the tube....its just that our reception stinks and we don't feel like we'd get our moneys worth from service style TV. So we supplement with plenty of movies and now, several different shows as they're released on DVD (thank you Netflix): The Office, 24, Deadwood, Lost and now we have Heroes in our cue. I'm not above a good video game either...and neither is she, assuming we're talking about Guitar Hero! She's like the plastic guitar version of Slash/Eddie Van Halen! A typical evening would include us both reading a little before bed. But not the same book at the same time, unless of course its Harry Potter #7. We did indeed read that out loud together. It beat wrestling for it (she's pretty tough) or having a Guitar Hero faceoff (she would have chewed me up and spit me out).

      We're pretty simple really and just live out here in the country. No neighbors in immediate site but plenty of friends around, which is nice.

      As far as gaming history, I started playing D&D with my dad and his friends when I was about 5 or 6. I can't wait to do the same for my kids some day as it really was a special thing. Continued with D&D for the next 24 years or so, through every iteration of it, and never even really knew there was anything else out there. I've gamed with my same close friends forever so its not like I was being introduced to new stuff. Finally started getting a bit burned out and found RPG.net a couple years ago and OH MY GOD!! There's a metric crapload of games out there! Haven't really played much in that time period though outside of tinkering with Burning Wheel off and on, and staying way to active on their forums for a nonplayer. :-) Starting to get the itch again though, so I'm spreading the rash to the old group again.

      I found this site through some podcasts and through some rantings about this site on another site. Checked it out and it seems like a pretty laid back place. I'll most likely be a lurker as my lack of varied gaming experiences doesn't tend to add a whole lot to discussions but every now and then I find I have something to say. I look forward to hanging out around here.

      (To tomg above: if you're the Tom (Griff, Griffeth,etc. ?) from the Charlotte area that I met at MACE last November, then that's just weird. I meet you for the first time, about this time last year, don't speak again for a year and I sign up here and BOOM, you're right here signing up as well! Pretty cool, if that's you that is.)

    • Svante Landgraf
      September 2007
      Well, as I have started to post here (once or twice), I might as well introduce myself.

      My name is Svante Landgraf, I'm 27, and I've been living in Sweden all my life.

      I have a masters in mathematics. Currently I'm studying literature and philosophy as well as teaching maths at the university. I'd like to work as a writer or a graphics designer. I have no idea how to make that happen.

      I recently published my first game (in Swedish) through Lulu. The last few years I've been gaming once a week, mostly American indie games, homebrews or indie-ish adaptions of more mainstream games (Planescape/SotC, for example).

      I love games (all kind of games: rpg:s, card games (Magic), board games (Carcassonne), video games (Guitar Hero and Fire Emblem)), literature (Pynchon, Borges, Auster), comics (Invisibles, Planetary),writing, posthistory, ontological terrorism, maps, hourglasses and eighteenth-century typography.
    • GestaltBennie
      September 2007
      Hi. I'm Scott Bennie.

      47 male, Canadian, born in Abbotsford BC. Got a bachelor's degree in education from UBC, but got sucked into computer and RPG design instead of teaching.

      I started gaming at V-Con in 1977. It was D&D of course; my first character lasted about thirty minutes before a giant rat bit him, and he died in one blow. Regardless, I enjoyed the game immensely and wanted to play some more, so I did. After an insane "I can write articles too" moment, I was first published in Dragon in 1981. I wrote a number of books for TSR and Hero during the late 1980s and early 1990s. I also contributed to a number of APAs. Computer games sucked up most of my time during the 1990s, I produced/designed numerous titles for Interplay during that decade, earning my geek cred badge by working with the entire cast of Star Trek during several games.

      After 2000, I was cast out of the computer game business and fell like a star back into RPGs. I wrote _Testament_ for Green Ronin in 2003, and _Villainy Amok_ for Hero in 2005. My most recent book is _Gestalt: The Hero Within_ for Blackwyrm, which was released at Gen Con,it's a gooey, 400 page, fourteen-years-in-the-making, no apologies old-school campaign supplement for Champions.

      Despite being pretty traditional in my tastes, I've always looked with excitement the ability of the hobby to tell stories. I think, at its best, it's an artform with educational and transformative power that might make positive contributions to people's lives. I believe artistic expression can be found in both traditional and new approaches to RPGs, and that the worst thing we can do as gamers is to advocate or embrace One True Ways that turn the communities we build into gated fiefs ruled by the virtual equivalent of strata councils.

      Beyond that, I recently returned to my roots as a liberal evangelical protestant, which means I pretty much don't agree with anyone's theology or politics. And I lecture too much, and can get way too bloody self-righteous and long-winded for my own good. I also suffer from CMT, and recently had surgery to correct diabetic related retinopathy, so my health and vision suck. Fortunately gaming usually helps keep life fun and introduces me to a lot of good people, and thus I keep going.







    • Clint Krause
      October 2007
      Hi, I'm Clint Krause. I'm 25. I've been married to my wife, Cassie (an elementary school teacher), for almost 2 years and we're expecting our first child in February. I'm an independent game designer (3fold, Don't Walk in Winter Wood, Roanoke, Urchin) stuck somewhere between the SG/Forge aesthetic and my trad-gaming roots. I'm also a working musician (drums & percussion), which gives me a lot of free time to work on games. I have a BA in creative writing and am currently working on my master's in liberal arts.

      Gaming-wise, I grew up playing Rifts, Palladium Fantasy, and MERP (as well as millions of terrible homebrews of my own devising). I didn't really get into D&D until 3rd edition came out. In college, I started surfing rpgnet, which got me into Wushu and the idea of indie publishing. I like my games right in the middle-ground between new-school and old-school. My goal as a designer is to become something like a festering mutant hybrid of Kevin Siembieda and Luke Crane.

      Aside from gaming, I love music . . . I listen to lots of Metal (right now I'm on a power metal kick: Dragonforce, Iron Savior, Hammerfall, etc . . .), but I also love reggae, jazz, and lots of hybrid musical styles (my favorite band is 311). I also love reading and just hanging out with friends.
    • RPL
      October 2007
      Howdy,

      I'm Diogo Curado from Lisbon, Portugal (born and raised). I'm 23 and finishing (hopefully) my masters degree on Information Systems and Technology Management, I graduated in Statistics and Information Management. Not working at this time, but working on it (what a cute little word play).

      I pratice Kung Fu and Kendo (Japanese fencing) and enjoy travelling and generaly discovering all the things in the world I don't already know, wich starts in music and finishis in whatever is on the other side of "that corner".

      I started playing about 7 years ago with Vampire, The Masquerade and "moved" on to other WW games, recently I've (finally) discovered the joy in D&D and other kinds of games, like Dogs In The Vineyard and Capes. Currently my gaming crown jewels (in no particular order) are Vampire: The Masquerade 3rd Ed (yes I like the game, live with it), Exalted 2nd Ed, Don't Rest Your Head, Capes and Dogs In The Vineyard.

      All the best,
      Diogo Curado

    This discussion has been closed.

    • Ogremarco
      October 2007
      Hmmm, I'm not so good at writing about myself in narrative style, which is why I had someone else write my bio for Norwescon, so I'll just do it in bullet points.

      -I'm 34.
      -I studied history at Central Washington University, but didn't graduate.
      -I did get a two year dassociates from Wenatchee Valley College.
      -I'm originally from Wenatchee washington, and i really hate it there.
      -I currently live in renton Washington a suburb outside Seattle.
      -I've been married for thirteen years. My wife is a program co-ordinator at the University of Washington School of Dentistry (she feeds and waters dentists). She's also an avid gamer, and writes a blog, a geek culture column, and a sex advice column.
      -We have six cats, several fishtanks, and are currently between hedgehogs.
      -We share a house with a good friend.
      -I was a cook for several years, then a student, and then a nightclub bouncer for eight years until I burned out completely on service jobs.
      -I currently work as a caster for Privateer Press. I like this job a lot. It's nice to work for a company where everyone understands my obsessions on at least some level.
      -I'm and athiest and lean left politically, but I'd rather chew razor blades than talk about religion or politics.
      -I went to culinary school briefly, and learned a lot from working in restaraunts, but I feel my best education as a chef comes from trial and error in the kitchen. I consider myself an amazing chef. It's the one thing I allow myself to be truly arrogant about.
      -I watch pro-wrestling, but gave up on the WWE last year due to stupid plotlines and sexist crap. i get my wrestling fixes from NWA-TNA and various indy vids on youtube. I'll talk about the game about wrestling i'm working on in a different post.
      -I'm a music geek with wide and varied tastes and a lot of inflammatory opinions about it. I find I can now talk nicely about gaming, but i don't know if I'll ever be able to do that about music.
      -I have a livejournal where I talk about a lot of stuff, and sometimes about nothing at all. you can find it on my profile.
      -My wife says I have to say that I'm dead sexy, well, so is she, sexier by far than I am.
    • Ogremarco
      November 2007
      The single most interesting thing to me that keeps popping up in this thread is how many people are in good healthy relationships.
    • GeekGirlsRule
      November 2007
      Let's see.

      I'm married to Ogremarco and he told me I needed to join the forum.
      I'm 36
      We've been married for 13 years and together for 14.
      We have six cats, three fishtanks and will soon have another hedgepig.
      In addition to gaming, I write, knit and read absolutely everything I can get my hands on. I also cross-stitch.
      This spring my knitting group and I are planning on knitting a life-sized Dalek.
      I have an AA, a BA and am a thesis and paying up my student loans enough to graduate from getting my Master's in Russian Feminist History.
      I actually SPEAK three languages (English, French and Russian).
      I can read and write two more (Ancient Greek and Latin)
      I work at a major university, babysitting dentists, but I'm considering a return to the tech field to save my sanity.
      I was a bouncer and a bartender for 7or 8 years.
      I also collect comic books and all things Nightcrawler.
      I write Geek Girls Rule! for http://www.mediagauntlet.com, I also write the column "Valerie Strangiato: Advice for the Sexually Inquisitive." Geek Girls Rule! also has a Wordpress blog.
      I spent several years in the Tech industry once before, which was why I went back to grad school for history.
      My list of jobs includes: Clown, Hunting Dog Trainer/Kennel Help, Picture Framer, Phone Survey, babysitting, Hotel night desk clerk, shipping and receiving, bookstore cashier, and more I'm forgetting.
      I also like wrestling, but can't watch WWE anymore. TNA is also starting to get on my nerves with the sexist bullshit, but at least some of their girls look sturdy enough to be taken seriously.
      I love music, and Ogremarco and I frequently clash over our tastes in music (I married a music facist).
      I'm pretty sure that my bloodstream is at least 60% coffee.
    • merb101
      November 2007
      I said some of this in an earlier post, but figured I'd join in with the introductions. I'm Michael Erb, a journalist in West Virginia. I am the education reporter for The Parkersburg News. I'm married, have two boys ages 2 and 6, and I'll be 33 at the end of the year.

      I write two gaming columns, one for the newspaper and one for another publication, doing reviews of non-electronic games as well as a "Dad's Eye View" column for a local parents magazine.

      Other than gaming, my hobbies are writing, comic books, poetry and just about anything sci-fi or fantasy. I got heavily into board games about 3 years ago, though I've played RPGs since I was about 10.

      I grew up in Williamstown, WV, and met my wonderful wife while we were attending West Virginia University in Morgantown, WV. I ran out of money while going to school so I got a Board of Regents degree before we moved to Beaufort, SC, and I went to work as a copy editor for The Island Packet near Hilton Head, SC. I worked there for more than 3 years, eventually becoming the education reporter for that publication. After the birth of my first son being 13 hours from family just got to be too much, so we moved back up to this area, and I went to work for the News.

      We just bought a new house in Williamstown and are still getting unpacked. I'm looking for a new job because of the cost of the new home, but it makes me ill to think of not writing for a living, so we'll have to see how that one goes.

      Anyway, that's all I got for now.

      ME

      I am engaged to be married to the lovely Catriona who is asleep in the other room dur to be married this time next year.

    • Daztur
      November 2007
      -I'm 26 and I do curriculum development (making textbooks for novel reading classes, everything from Charlie and the Chocolate Factory to 1984) and teaching for a Korean cram school.
      -Lived 14 years of my life in the states and I don't see myself ever going back for long.
      -Will be married for two years this coming February.
      -Graduated with a degree in History from Wesleyan University.
      -Can speak English and Spanish well, Korean somewhat and a very limited smattering of French, Norwegian and Arabic.
      -Am a good cook and homebrewer and good food, good beer and an internet connection are all the material things I really need to keep myself sane.
      -Currently my favorite RPG is SotC and am currently trying to make an RPG that can do historical fiction/gritty low fantasy (think George Martin's A Song of Ice and Fire books) as well as SotC does pulp.





    • gamera_spinning
      November 2007
      My real name is Darren, and I'm 38. I live in Kansas City, MO with my girlfriend Denise, and moved here over 3 years ago from Florida. I grew up in Massachusetts in a little town on the border to New Hampshire.

      I have a BA in English and have a work background as an Administrative Asst. The company I worked for closed it's doors in June, so I've been working as a temp while I search for permanent employment.

      I spent some time in the SCA in college, where I also developed a love for fencing and racquetball.

      I have a passion for cinema, which I attribute to my Dad, an immense DVD collection, and an unhealthy affection for Mystery Science Theatre 3000. I also read a lot of comic books and graphic novels. I've been known to watch some anime, but I'm pretty shallow - it has to be extremely pretty to catch my eye.

      I don't like spicy foods (I'm half-Canadian in ancestry, so salt is an exotic spice), and I don't drink often; when I do it's usually something fruity with an umbrella in it.

      I have no pets at present, but I'm very fond of dogs and cats.

      I enjoy computer and console games.

      I was introduced to gaming by way of the old D&D boxed set that came with numbered chits instead of dice.

      I've discovered that the game genres I love most are swashbuckling, wu-xia, espionage and superheroes. The games I enjoy most are: Seventh Sea, Nobilis, Mutants and Masterminds, The Adventureas of Baron Munchausen, Qin, Weapons of the Gods, Spirit of the Century, Spycraft, Top Secret, and Castle Falkenstein.

      I wanted to love Exalted, but the game was too crunchy, and although we saw each other for several books, the relationship ended when we realized we weren't right for one another.

      I was a tremendous fan of Mage: The Ascension's previous editions. I've avoided the new edition in case I might enjoy it.

      I have no interest in writing or publishing a game, but will be happy to be a consumer.

    • sven
      November 2007
      The roleplaying started started at around age eleven. I got the Swedish game Drakar och Demoner (Dragons and Demons, as (almost) all Swedish rpg before 2005 a Basic roleplayng clone). It said from age twelve on the boc, so I didn't get to worried when I didn't understand how to play. Instead me and my friend Kristoffer played with just a six sided die. I played the hero, he GM:ef for a lot of years until other games started to drop in.

      At the university roleplaying turned fun again. White Wolf games, Swedish art-house larp, Swedish freeform and rpg-cons. People started to make their own games. Now I am 28 and it seem - which is rather bisarre, I think - like roleplaying just gets more with age.

      During the last two years I have lived and worked in Turkey. I mainly moved there to follow the woman of my choice. Because of this I have played very little during the last two years. Right at this moment I am in Sweden again for a few months. I will go back to Turkey again and before that time I will try to do quite a bit of roleplaying.

      I am also a master of science and engineering and have an unfinished bachelor degree in comparative literature (on the Swedish pronographic novel 1967-71).
