      I'm bumping this because there's a bunch of new people I'd like to get to know better all of a sudden.
    • David Artman
      December 2007 edited December 2007
      Hi, OK. Good bump.

      Hi, my name is David. ("Hi, David.")
      I'm single, white male; 36 years old; 6'3" 160#; short brown hair over muddy brown eyes and dark mostly-full beard (for now).
      I'm 36 and I work as a Technical Writer for IBM. I also do some (limited) freelance work in layout and editing, most recently for Passages and Perfect.
      I live in Durham, NC and spend an inordinate amount of time on Main Street. Prior cities of residence include Raleigh (attending NCSU and, later, working in IT), Kingston-upon-Hull (UK; attending Hull University), and Greensboro (raised and returned to finish BAs in English and Philosophy at UNC Greensboro in 1993).
      My primary gaming outlets for the past several years have been parlor and boffer LARPs, "Euro" board games, Clix games, and Icehouse games. Prior to that, I was a fairly active player and GM for HERO System, Warhammer FRP, and some D&D. To list the games I played and ran prior to college graduation would exceed the character limit on posting.
      Politically, I am fairly left-leaning while favoring small government for social issues and large government for survival issues (Libertarian Socialism, anyone?). I am about ready to become an ecowarrior, if our government doesn't get its head out of its ass; but in the mean time, I can maintain my peace with a bit of help from my oldest friend Mary. Pirsig's Quality, Taoism, and transhumanism are the leading influences for my current philosophy and life's goals.

      Ah, hell... what else is this thing for, anyway: http://www.myspace.com/davidartman
      Beyond that, I'd need some kind of form to complete; "I am large, I contain multitudes...."
    • Elizabeth
      December 2007
      Hi! My name's Elizabeth. I'm 25 and currently living in Columbus, OH, though that should change this spring. I'm a single mom, and I have more hobbies than could possibly be construed as healthy: I'm learning to play the guitar, I design jewelry, I love to cook, I self-publish a quarterly literary and art magazine, I design games, and sometimes, I even find people to PLAY games with me!

      I'm a voracious reader, and like graphic novels, turn-of-the-century English lit, and weirdo non-fiction. I want to write a game about the Black Panther movement in the 60s, if I can ever reach down inside my white-girl self and find the balls. I'm also a big fan of Simon Bolivar, and my favorite US president is the tragically misunderstood LBJ. I also like children's lit.

      Oh! I'm a photographer by trade. Portraiture is my first love-- weird portraiture especially-- but if it is visible to the human eye, I will figure out what makes it compelling, and then take a picture of it.

      What else..

      I have mutant pinky toes, I refuse to eat anything that's blue, I'm voracious when it comes to travel and new experiences, and I make a weird face when my nose is cold. Oh, and I could totally kick your butt at Super Smash Bros.

      I think that covers it.
    • Wirebrain
      December 2007
      Halo! I'm Mike Stevens, 28 and live in San Jose, Ca.

      Up until October, I worked as a video game tester for 6 years for a big name 3rd party publisher and just yesterday got a job as a editor for a comic book company. My heritage is mostly European, and on one side of my family, it can be traced all the way to the Mayflower. At this point, I'd tell you about my non-gaming hobbies but all of them tend to be intertwined. I've been a fan of games ever since I was three years old, when my parents got me a Colecovision for Christmas. I began playing RPGs when I was in 5th grade- my first one was TMNT and other Strangeness, followed up by Robotech in Jr. High, Cybergeneration and Deadlands in High School.

      I play all kinds of games be it card, board, role playing or video. I mostly got out of CCGs after the death of Doomtown, although I'm rather proud how I managed to foster a few regular groups who played the game in the bay area until the game died an untimely demise. Because of my volunteer ambassador programs I was involved in, I eventually worked with a local anime convention and managed their tabletop gaming dept, making it a haven for all games, not just Pokemon and D&D, for five years before one of those ugly volunteer power plays came about.
      I enjoy MST3K, collect way too much Anime, Comics and have enough video games (both ones I worked on and didn't) to choke a Chocobo. I also enjoy telling stories, and occasionally write comic scripts that an artist friend and I collaborate on.
      Right now, I've been playing in the same group as Neko Ewen and running OVA.

      I'm considered the "zombie hunting" guy by my friends, mostly due to my love of Resident Evil games (I don't own or see too many zombie flicks out there, honest) and if not that, the original jolly green giant, Cthulhu.

      This being my second post here on Story Games, I look forward in posting a bit more.
    • Brennen Reece
      December 2007
      I'm Brennen Reece. 32 years old. Married to Sarah, who paints wonderful watercolor portraits. I currently teach guitar at a music store in Auburn, Alabama. Until four years ago I worked as an art director for a small advertising agency, before that in reverse chronology I was a: graphic designer, interactive design specialist for Wyeth Pharmaceuticals, medical writer, antique restoration specialist, film student, barista, scenic artist, propmaker.

      I love (& play) jazz, blues, and country fingerstyle guitar. I'm fond of Henry Miller, Tom Waits, Federico Fellini, Hammer Films, Mario Bava, and Edward Gorey. Everything I design utilizes the Golden Ratio, or at least the Fibonacci Series. My favorite sans serif is Univers, with Akzidens Grotesque a close second. I prefer Jan Tschihold's reworking of Garamond, Sabon, for my serif typeface. You'll never catch me using Arial or Times New Roman.

      After spending my twenties as a literature and film snob, I'm enjoying some more literary escapism: China Mieville, Neil Gaiman, Robert Heinlein, and lots of old vampire and haunted house stories from the 19th century. I also like REALLY bad horror movies, and really good ones.

      Food is my drugs. My wife thinks I'd eat at an Asian restaurant every day if I could...the truth is, Asian is the only ethnic alternative in Auburn. I'll drive an hour for good pho. I also make a mean paella.

      I don't like American beer or American football.

      I run a Gothic horror campaign online using Fantasy Grounds. Somehow, all my players are Canadian. If you're Canadian and want to play in an online Gothic horror campaign, let me know. The game started out as a heavily-housefuled True20, moved to a heavily-housefuled Simple20, and we're now switching to FATE because I kept yelling "AMEN!" on every page. I can't wait for the generic FATE 3.0 book to come out...nudge, nudge...
    • despair
      December 2007
      Ok time to stop lurking and post - well at least post on this post - thanks for the bump....

      I'm Greg ..... I'm really old (41) and have been a "gamer" since the late 70's......

      I am of western European descent (mostly Scotts Welsh and Italian and possibly Dutch) and have lived exclusively on the West Coast of the United States. Currently Reside in Seattle and work for Privateer Press in the Shipping Dept. (Hi Ogre)

      I have been into Science Fiction/ Fantasy as long as I can recall, I can blame it on my Dad if I want but I really love the genre so I won't. I really like old pulp/serial era stories and am not ashamed to say I get a kick out of good wrestling now and again. (Hell Buffy I often called soap oprea with combat.....and hell how could that not e fun sometimes.......). I guess if anything I can say that I have always been more of a collector then a doer ----- but I really do love gaming and am glad that a friend of mine has talked me into not just collecting and reading them as I have for more years then I want to admit to.

      I have the luck to be involved with a woman that may not understand or want to be involved in gaming but encourages me to do what I like and want me to be more social with my friends......

      I enjoy cooking and according to her do pretty well at it and in the past have considered it as a possible career but being a vegetarian limits me a bit. When we saty wioth friends I "pay" for our stays by cooking so I guess I can trust her opinion.

      I have often tried my hand at game design and have really gotten the bug again ..... would like to try Game Chef in 2008 if it happens and I can do so.......

      I am a trained Make-up artist(love working theater) and cosmetologist (yes I have done hair too).....

      I wold list the games that I have owned and played but that list would be long - maybe I will do that on my live journal or facebook page....

      I would love to do more playtests (I have done some in the past - recent) and have written reviews professionally......well semi ---- well I got paid for them ......

      anyway that is me well at lest a little -

      Greg
    • jessecoombs
      December 2007
      Wow, this is a long thread.

      As you may or may not be able to tell from my mysterious handle, my name is Jesse Coombs. I'm 28. I live in Sacramento, CA, which I like and think that people put down a little too much. I'm a receiving manager at Barnes and Noble, and I'm fantastic at customer service and retail, and very flaky at school, which apparently is not for me.

      My "education" for the last half of my life has been a steady mixture of pop culture, movies, indie rock, and comic books. Playing rpgs with friends is one of the best things ever, and having a bad experience is like dragging my teeth on the ground.

      I'm always broke, and usually looking for a girlfriend. Those two things almost always go together.

      One day I'll open my own movie palace, but until then...I work.
    • Antoine_F
      December 2007 edited December 2007
      Hi, my name is Antoine Fournier. I am 32 and born in Toulouse, France. I studied History then Applied Arts then Computer Science.
      I met Marie in my fifth college year and we've lived together since then. We married in 2001. We have a two years old girl named Jeanne who's cuter, smarter and taller than any 4 years old boy in town.
      We moved from Paris two years ago and came back around Toulouse where we both used to live until 2000. We live now in the countryside in a 200 years old farm that I inherited from my father.

      Marie and I work at home together as independant graphic and web designers. I want some day to draw full time on my own comics or on illustration works.
      Drawing is my main obsession. With RPGs too of course. I started to draw suddenly when I was 20 and while I love it, it didn't come naturaly to me. There will be probably more on that soon in an appropriate thread as I'd like to mix drawing comics and story gaming. Some day I will.

      On the RPG side : I started to play RPGs at 12 with Red Box D&D. Then AD&D, MERP, Warhammer, Cthulhu, lots of french games, WoD, etc... One day I was forced to admit I wasn't enjoying myself as much as I used to do. There was the Internet. I searched there for answers.
      I've read the Forge since 2002 and Story Games since it exists. My first post here was on november 16th 2007. They call people like me lurkers... So, yes : it was about time I introduced myself.

      I usualy play with Marie and our friend Jérôme. Sometimes with some others friends who were all my pals (and rpg buddies) in highschool. I wish we could play more often together.

      My current loves are the Red Box Hack (which needs another title now), Beast Hunters, Spirit of the Century, Dread, Trollbabe and Sugarfighter Black.

      Preparing for game mastering has always been a big stress but thanks to Graham W's "Play Unsafe", it seems not to be anymore.

      Regarding RPG design, I have some ideas about a gamist card-game and story-game hybrid. I'd like to test it as soon as I can make a prototype version of the cards.

      I already wrote too much.
    • HinterWelt
      December 2007
      Name: Bill Corrie

      Age: 39

      What do I do: I work for HinterWelt (My wife owns the company) and have written 20 some games up to this point. I have worked in fields ranging from software consulting to engineering design.

    • doplegager
      January 2008
      It's probably time that I gave a formal introduction. My name is Ram Lama H. I'm a cartoonist from Wichita, KS. I've had the honor of meeting a few of you at GenCon2007, where I was a part of the Ashcan Front. My ashcan was the Path of Journeys, something of a fantasy heartbreaker that I came up with by putting Everway, Dogs in the Vineyard, Burning Wheel, i ching, and neopaganism in a bag and shaking vigorously.

      I currently have two webcomics up and running. The first is A Chance in Hell, a fantasy/horror comic inspired by a condition called visual snow that I suffer from. The second is Illustrated Ramblings, an editorial comic and one of the rare examples of paid journalist cartooning. I'm working on the former because I want to feel prolific again. The latter is published weekly in my college newspaper.

      I was first introduced to gaming at age 11 by my childhood mentor, who originally played DnD in the 70's and 80's and came out of retirement just long enough to teach me the rules so I could start DMing for my friends. My first experiments with game design were in middle school; "so, that's how DnD works... what if we wanted to play a game in space?" and "so, that's how dice work... what if if we use these other dice in this other way?"

      I'd love to open up shop doing freelance illustrations, but I haven't been able to beat my website into shape yet. More importantly, I have to beat my personal demons into shape. I still have a bit to do before I feel comfortable and competent, but I've made a lot of progress in the past six months.


      "Our promises are only as genuine as the delusions that they are based on"
    • Lxndr
      January 2008
      I'm Alexander Cherry - I made a post here on March 1, 2006 about myself. I figured it's worth updating myself:

      I'm 28, going to be 29 this upcoming year. In theory by August I'll have a double bachelor's degree in mathematics and economics. Thanks to econ I've got a nice helping of game theory on my plate. And no, I have no idea what I want to do with those degrees.

      I consider myself agnostic probably bordering on atheist, and more-or-less consider most religion kind of the enemy (I'm always taken aback when someone who shows themselves to be thoughtful and intelligent turns out to have a religion).

      I live in Phoenix, Arizona, where I feel it gets a bit chilly in the winter (note to you crazies who live where it snows, 'a bit chilly' is different from 'inhospitably cold'), and it rains too much here.

      I'm taking numerous improvisation courses and could be considered to be a member of at least one improv theatre troupe here in Phoenix, which seems to be becoming sort of a mecca for improvisers out west. Which is awesome for me.

      I'm a motorcycle rider that's never taken the test to drive a car. Legally, my two-wheeled contraption is the only thing I can drive.

      While abroad in Spain, in June, 2007, I started having convulsions - an apparently common symptom for having an oligodendroglioma, a brain tumor that grows between the cells. On June 18 I had surgery to have enough of it removed that I could be symptom free, and on December 20 I had even more removed to keep it from growing back. I might live until I'm 50.

      I enjoy reading fiction. Not so much non-fiction. I pride myself on living a paperless life (it's a pun that basically means no newspapers).

      As the original post says, I'm a game publisher through the Twisted Confessions label that I created myself. I've put out the awesome game Fastlane through Twisted Confessions and through the No Press Anthology, Snowball. Also it seems page hits makes my Creeks and Crawdads homage to be the talk of the town. I miss doing more game design, and hope to make myself do some soon. I'm really hoping to get the twisted confessions imprint re-done as an ambigram.

      I'm always on the look out for more roleplaying games, ideally to play. In games, I crave mechanical structure and support, especially interaction with the mechanics while hanging out in the Shared Imaginative Space. Without that I can't say things feel enough like /games/ to be games. If all it asks me to do is make scenes, but I can't interact with the mechanics while playing, I feel unfulfilled. Otherwise it's just freeform play, which is not enough of a game for me to want when wanting to play a game.

      When a child, I went to an independently run school for "gifted" children. As a result, I don't quite 'get' most references to school grades and the like (we didn't label our classes by number) and most of my knowledge of the American high school experience is taken from movies and books, etc. I had a graduating class of 3.

      I found D&D when I was 6 years old, and while it never quite satisfied me even then, voraciously reading the books (as I could not find people to play) was surely a formative experience on my life. As a socially stunted person, I found it very difficult to gather people together to play, a struggle I continue with to this day.

      Eventually I branched out into the palladium books, TMNT especially, then Robotech. After that, Rifts. My current rpg bookshelves seem to be the envy of most who view them, although I have a Wall of Shame comprised of the old World of Darkness splatbooks. I picked up Werewolf before Vampire although I'd known about Vampire - a girl I had a crush on asked me about it once.

      "Design" started for me as a kid when I created conversion materials between my favorite games. After that, my mom decided to punish me by taking my books away, so I figured 'okay screw that, I can come up with something on my own'. And so, I did.

      I find myself seeing red when coming across pointless, obfuscatory number/word trees as in FUDGE, etc. (especially when cluttering up game texts, when the words are just labeled with the numbers). These cause me more frustration than benefit.

      Found the Forge in 2003 through an invitation to the Indie Rpg chatroom. I made huge rpg purchases those days. These days, price tags above $20 make me wary, and above $29 make me wonder whether I should go somewhere else to get a better product - especially if the price tag seems directly related to things that don't really add to the in-play experience, like a hardcover or interior art.

      Since there seems to be a common thread of relationship status in here, I'm single and have been for quite some time. I'm not good at meeting people, unless you count the internet, making a social life kind of un-possible. Yay for social phobias?
    • Scurvy_Platypus
      January 2008
      Posted By: PaulieI am Paul Wilson, 27 and a am analtical chemist from Wellington, New Zealand.
      Heh. My wife is a biogeochemist, and we're going to be moving to Wellington in (hopefully) just a few months. She's got a job there, and we're working through the visa stuff now.

      Anyway, on-topic...

      Howdy, I'm Chris Fletcher.
      I'm 35, married to a really groovy woman for the last 11 years, although we've been together about 15 years. She plays rpgs too, although it's a bit more a case of being something we can do together, instead of her being really into rpgs.

      I started playing rpgs some 20 years ago, with the Red Box D&D set. Since then I've played so many different games, I can't remember them all. These days I tend to like the small press stuff more, but I still play D&D too. I don't consider myself a "gamer" although I do enjoy playing rpgs. I tend to prefer systems on the lighter side, and a lot of the reason I play is for social stuff. I've been known to hangout with a buddy that's playing some videogame, and just enjoy being with him and sharing in the experience of him playing. Sure, participating is fun too, but I don't find it to be a requirement.

      My better half has a Ph.D. but I'm not really that well educated. I grew up pretty poor to start out with, and I've been adopted a couple of times. Self-educated from 3rd grade until I went to college about 8 years ago. I went through an interpreting program and graduated as an ASL Interpreter (American Sign Language). Worked in school systems from Kindergarten up through University.

      Back in September I told my wife, "I've left my life on hold long enough, and it's killing me. I've spent the last 20 years doing marginal jobs and the only kind of creative outlet I get is through rpg stuff. I want to go back to school and get a B.A. or a B.S. or _something_. Just to prove I'm really not as stupid as I feel. I want to try and get it in something that might be useful in some fashion, but even if it isn't... I want to get something." She asked me what I was thinking of, and I had to admit...art.

      Nope, I haven't spent years drawing stuff. Half the time I look at paintings and I'm bored stiff. I do firmly believe that a person that has sufficient motivation can learn to do almost anything. Might not do as well as the "naturally gifted" folks do, but they can come close. I've got a good sense of what I like in art (my wife says it'd be classed as "popular art") and my plan is to go through and get my education as an illustrator. I figure I can transfer those skills to a computer after I get the good solid foundation stuff down. My eventual hope is to do graphic design for the regular job, and use my art abilities to do rpg stuff and my own projects on the side. So far my art teachers have been quite encouraging and even though I'm behind the curve compared to a lot of the kids in the classes, I'm pleased with my progress.

      By nature I'm quite friendly, by nurture I avoid people. For anyone that's ever seen Clerks, there's an amusing bit when the two characters are talking and one complains about not going to a party. The other guy says, "But you hate people!" and the first guy says, "Yeah, but I love gatherings. Ironic, isn't it?" That's kinda me. I tend to lurk more often than not. A lot of it comes from the fact that I'm just not interested in arguing about stuff. I try to be helpful when possible, otherwise I just watch. More often than not it seems that "discussions" are really arguments, and I'm confident that someone else will be along to make whatever point I might feel should be made.

      I shave my head, lift weights and run, have both my ears pierced, and a tattoo. I'm also co-owner of the cat, although my wife bitterly complains that she thinks the cat likes me better.

      If I were to stake some sort of claim of being "different", it's probably the animals I love. Platypuses are at the top of the list, followed by monkeys (and apes too) and then my final "top" love (my wife claims it's an unholy thing) is for the hairless cat. No the cat we've got isn't a hairless one, but it is a shelter rescue cat.

      I'm a bit of an oddity when it comes to games, in that the community associated with the game is almost as important to me as what the rules look like. It might not make sense to a lot of other folks, but that's the way it is for me. I figure that rpgs are at least somewhat social, and if I don't like the folks that I keep running into that are into the game, then it's just not a game I should be interested in.
    • shaneivey
      January 2008
      My name's Shane Ivey. I've lurked here for ages but didn't get around to signing up until a few days ago. I was 36 when this thread started and am 38 now. Married nearly 15 years and we hope to take our first international trip together this fall to visit the U.K.; I've been a couple of times and love it there, and my wife's a longtime Anglophile and can't wait to go. We have three kids, ages 12, 11 and (in twelve days) 9. The notion that roleplaying is mainly for maladjusted sad-sacks amuses me. We live in Birmingham, Alabama.

      My wife has played RPGs a few times and had fun but isn't an enthusiast. My kids love them as long as the rules are either uncomplex or handled by somebody else. I strongly wish WOTC would take the opportunity of a new edition of D&D to make it a palatable gateway game for smart kids, the way AD&D was for me, but I can't say I have hope for it.

      I started gaming in 1979 with the Basic D&D set that had the dragon on the cover staring at the wizard and the guy in platemail holding a bow. (I know -- a D&D character in platemail holding a bow? What kind of madness was that? And these were 1D6 arrows where you didn't get a Strength bonus to damage; crazy artists.)

      Over the years I played mostly AD&D at first, then left AD&D before 2nd Edition and played mostly RuneQuest 3, Palladium FRP, Champions, Cyberpunk and Call of Cthulhu. Loved Cthulhu most of all those but ran and played more RQ, Cyberpunk and Champions. I also played a good bit of the Ringworld RPG way back when and used to own it and the supplements, but they accidentally stayed with a friend when I moved from Sacramento at age 20 and I never saw them again. Same thing happened to my autographed original run of Uncanny X-Men from the Dark Phoenix saga through "Days of Future Past"; it still hurts.

      For several years I played on a couple of MUSHes very heavily, first the short-lived Danse Macabre (a medieval vampire MUSH; I didn't give a flip about the vampire stuff but loved the medieval intrigue) and longer on the Middle-earth-themed Elendor (I ran Mordor for a while in the late '90s).

      I run RPG company Arc Dream Publishing and also work for boardgame publisher Avalanche Press, and occasionally help my mother manage rental properties that my grandmother owns. I used to do a lot of freelance work but my schedule was so rough that I constantly missed deadlines (sorry, Green Ronin!) and gave it up. I founded and technically still own RevolutionSF.com, but I haven't had time to do much with it myself lately.

      Before working on games full-time I was a magazine editor for the University of Alabama at Birmingham, a copy editor for the Birmingham News, and a webmaster and writer for Hecklers Online, a dot-com that crashed spectacularly in classic dot-com fashion. Before that I attended law school for a couple of years in Brooklyn and strove mightily to become an FBI agent, and was *this* close to making it but got redlined out because of that time I took LSD. My wife is a tremendouly popular DARE officer, but she hasn't yet asked me to come be an object lesson.

      Apropos of not much, I haven't yet played Spirit of the Century but hope to get my group to play it soon. Most recently I ran Aces and Eights, which was a huge departure in terms of the level of crunch that my group and I usually can tolerate these days, but we ended up having a lot of fun with it. Our next games will probably be Savage Worlds with pirates, a Rome noir game using HeroQuest rules, and probably Traveller before it's my turn to GM again.
    • xenomouse
      January 2008
      My name is Phil. I started playing RPGs in college (so just under 10 years now). I started with ADnD 2e and moved into DnD 3e. About a year or two after I started playing, my interest in smaller RPGs was piqued with Orkworld, GURPS Lite, and Ninja Burger.

      Since college, my wife and I have occasionally tried to start a gaming group, with limited and short-lived success. Last year, we started playing consistently with a large group of local friends, starting with DnD 3.5e and moving into Burning Wheel after hearing Luke Crane's interview with Geeknights. Shortly before switching, we made it out to Ubercon last year and played in Mel's Holy Grail scenario for Burning Wheel. We recently went to Dreamation 2008 and got to meet an innumerable amount of amazing people.

      January 2008
      As a newb, I think this thread may be more useful as a sticky.
    • viktor_haag
      January 2008 edited January 2008
      I'm late to this thread.

      I'm Viktor Haag. I'm a forty-two (well, this is my forty-second year, anyway) father of two children, and husband to a woman who I met in a local volleyball league eleven years ago. With the small exception of the first four years of my wife's life, where she lived 100 kilometres from our current location, and a year of my life when I lived abroad in Europe, we both have spent our entire lives including childhood, education, and work all within a 30 kilometre radius here in Southern Ontario, Canada.

      I am a baptized conference Mennonite (largely non-practicing) with modern and slightly agnostic sensibilities. My wife is a slightly less non-practicing Catholic. Our children are currently being educated at a Catholic school simply because it's closer, newer, cleaner, and seemingly safer than the Public alternative. When they enter high-school, this trend will almost certainly reverse itself, and instead of walking one direction for 10 minutes to get to school, they'll walk the other direction for 10 minutes to get to their Public high-school (because it's closer, newer, cleaner, and seemingly safer than the Catholic alternative).

      I am, by trade, an explainer of technology, almost entirely by the written word. I suppose this makes me a "technical writer", but I don't write user manuals, and I haven't for years. For the last 6 or 7 years, nearly all the writing I have been doing explains a portion of my company's technical architecture to other technical folks within my own company. My wife is, by trade, an early childhood educator who expressed a desire to stay at home and manage our household when our second child arrived, and to all appearances hasn't spent a single moment in regret over that decision. This makes her, and by extension me, and our children, very lucky people (in my opinion).

      For exercise I play basketball on a fairly dedicated, but pickup, basis and have done so for about 10 years. Prior to that, my efforts were devoted to competitive volleyball. In college, I played (recreational) competitive soccer, touch football, volleyball, and basketball. I have, occasionally, studied Judo, Karate, Aikido, and Tai Chi. Despite all these physical exertions I generally think of myself as a not-very-active person especially when compared to my parents and their siblings who seem physically grafted to their bicycles, hiking, and skiing gear, not to mention their farming and woodcutting implements.

      For leisure, I read, watch movies and sports, and a little television (although, these days, almost all of my television is watched either on DVD or time-delayed off my PVR; I hardly watch anything live any more), and also tinker around with my various bits of computing equipment (almost entirely Macintosh OSX machines). I do not play computer games, much to the confusion of most of my friends.

      I have been playing games of all other sorts (card, board, role) since early childhood, roleplaying in particular since my teenage years. My "regular gaming" has been spent playing with the same general group of people for almost 25 years, nearly all of us family men and professionals. A few years ago I formed another regular group of players including my wife and a couple we're friends with. We have played fairly regularly for four or five years, but have had long hiaitii when our friends decided first to make a year-long world hiking tour, and then subsequently, to have a baby (which has just happened: welcome to the world, Moira!)

      At least once a week, our family plays boardgames (of which I have an embarrassingly large collection to go with my embarrassingly large collection of rolegames). Fairly regularly I write about the boardgames I've played, the books I've read, and various other topics that catch my notice on my blog which you are all free to visit and read, if you'd like.

      Occasionally I make contributions to this forum, but really not often enough.











    • DainXB
      January 2008
      Greetings!

      I'm DainXB on the Internet, Harold Michael Lybarger in official correspondence (the 'Harold' is silent ). Everyone I know except for my sister and my neice calls me 'Dain' in person, including my in-laws and the people at work. (All because 'Dain Bjornsson' was the name I chose for my SCA persona, years ago. Complicated yet uninteresting story, there...)

      I'm 45 years old, and live in St. Louis, Missouri. The work I get paid to do is Casino Surveillance, although my two previous jobs were in the burglar/fire/process-control alarm industry. Working in Surveillance is almost, but not exactly, completely unlike what you see on that 'Vegas' show on TV. In a roundabout way, though, I fight crime for a living, which I think is cool.

      I'm married, and one of the lucky ones; my lovely wife Jill is a gamer girl, and all-around girl geek. We met in college through a combination of the SCA and Archon, one of the local St. Louis science fiction conventions. She currently runs the Dealer's Room for Archon, in fact. (Come visit us in October!) Mundanely, she is the Assistant Manager of a Teavanna store.

      I attended college at the University of Missouri, Rolla, and at Southeast Missouri State University; Computer Science with a minor in History. I am a practicing history geek as well as a science fiction and fantasy geek. I'm also a fan of mystery novels. My other hobbies include comic books; model rocketry, video games; building PCs; and lately, cooking.

      I've been obese all my life, but in the past two years, I have managed to lose 150 pounds and keep it off, and I am inordinately proud of that fact.

      I am an atheist, my wife is a neo-Pagan.

      I started in gaming with board wargames ('Sorcerer', from SPI, to be exact), and got into RPGs with a copy of Blue Box Basic D&D, ordered from an ad in the back of Asimov's Science Fiction Magazine. I've been a gamer ever since. I co-wrote a couple of 'Space 1889' articles for 'Challenge' magazine (GDW's house organ) before they folded. I'm hoping that those two events are not causally related. I also contributed material to the 'Dark Conspiracy' supplement 'Proto-Dimensions'. Some day, I would like to get back into print.

      --
      DainXB

    • twilight
      January 2008 edited January 2008
      I am usually known as James, though I've been called worse. I also usually use the nick of "Twilight" or "Yonagi" in some manner or another on various boards. For those of you keeping score, I also happen to be 32 and married. My wife is kind enough to suffer through my role-playing ADD; I have an incessant need to purchase and study rule sets from different systems just to see what they're like.

      I've been gaming for about 20 years or so. I started with Moldvay Basic, moved on to Star Frontiers and kind of evolved to different systems from that point on. As I get older, I find myself wanting simpler and simpler systems. That could be attributed to my cantankerous nature or perhaps I don't like being told how a game should be played. In a Wicked Age, Wushu and Sorcerer all qualify as my current interests. Aside from tabletop role-playing, my wife and I also run Paragon, a forum based elemental wolf RP. Naturally, I think it's freeform RP at its finest, though I am absolutely biased. I also used to be found on Harper's Tale as Seamus. And I collect worthless bits of information.

      Worthless trivia regarding James? I used to be left handed, much like, supposedly, a majority of the members of the Kerr clan. I have been rehabilitated to using the right, though I still use the left to eat and open doors and the like.

      Greetings.

      My name is Tomasz Pudło (nickname kaduceusz) and at the moment I live in Krakow, Poland. I'm 24 years old and it's been been eleven years in gaming for me now. I've started with WFRP and other RPGs I've played for a longer time include MERP on FUDGE, EarthDawn, Dzikie Pola (a polish RPG about 17th century nobility), Deadlands and Eberron played with kaduFATE (my own version of FATE system). As a curiosity I add here that I won Polish Game Masters Challenge in 2006 (yup, we have such a thing!) and polish best known RPG scenario contest (it's called Quentin) in 2007.

      At the moment I am, let's call it, chief editor in polish biggest RPGs portal - Poltergeist. We try to get polish gamers get to know some of those new-and-brilliant games - actually most of the polish reviews of indie games were written by me. Some translations are on their way, too :-)

      I have played a couple of the new ones, including Burning Wheel/Empires, Shock:, Universalis and Dirty Secrets.

      Outside gaming I am about to graduate in technology of chemistry. Being a student I listen, read, dance, live on 140 m^2 with 6 other people and work at night shift in a hostel.

      Yup, that'd be it.

      And BTW: Does this thread have a google map or sth? Because it definitely should :-)

    • madunkieg
      March 2008
      Well, my name is Graham, and I'm from London. No, not that London, but a smaller one on the other side of the pond. Our bridges may not be quite as magnificent, but at least they haven't been shipped to Arizona.

      On any given 3am you have a maddeningly decent chance of finding me thrown awake by my muse and working away at one or another game design. As a result, on any given 10am you have an almost equal chance of finding me selling antiquarian books while drowning my tiredness in caffeine. One of these days I hope to move my work desk across the street to the library and get some use out of those fancy papers the university sent me.

      I am avidly amateur, designing as my whims take me. That means many of my creations use unusual mechanics and I'm prone to exploring concepts that would be difficult to market.

      I warn you now, catch me in the right mood and I can be rather wordy, but I always try to include something helpful somewhere in there.

    • TomasHVM
      March 2008 edited March 2008
      Well, I only started reading this thread to see what I might have written about myself two years ago, but seems like I haven't written anything. You see, the last few years I have been in "retreat", kind of. Been living a very quiet life with my two children and my wife, and almost no social life outside the family.

      As I write this post, I believe it is a sign I'm easing out of my retreat. Hope so.

      I'm a 45 year old Norwegian, author, storyteller, poet and gamesmith. Have written both traditional rpg's and others, a lot of them, since 1986. Fabula is one of the traditional ones. Muu is traditional in system, but avant-garde in theme (was, when it came in 1990). Pervo is notorious (rightly so) for it's enthusiastic violence and bad behaviour, and has very little system to talk of (but is traditional through and through). Livets Høst (Autumn of Life) is a more recent design, and the one I'm most proud of. It is not traditional, neither in method nor in theme (it's about old people dying and reminiscencing).

      My last design was a a game in a series building on my experiences with Livets Høst, called Løpe fra døden (Running from Death). The series is planned to consist of nine contemporary rpg's for grown ups. I also wrote a new "roleplayingpoem" called Jesus loves you last weekend, a strange title for a game written by a man who reads the bible as fantasy. It's a simple game about caring and salvation and happiness.

      Roleplayingpoems are my invention, by the way. Read more about it in the blog: Norwegian Style ( a couple of my minor games are posted there, in English). To write rpg-poems is a great way to experiment with method and theme, and gives you the chance to get instant feedback on your design (most gamers have 15 minutes to spare for a new game). And it's fun! We made 13 such poems last weekend, and played them all. Try it out!

      OK, that was me crawling out of my shell, kind of. I hope to write many roleplaying games in the future.

      Have a nice day!
    • unlikelylass

      Hello!

      I'm Dana Johnson.

      I'm female, I was born in 1970, and I starting playing RPGs in 1981 with the blue-book Basic D&D set (first game used chits in styrofoam cups!) along with my brother. Moldy old favorites include Classic Traveller, RuneQuest, Call of Cthulhu, Pendragon, Over the Edge, and Champions (yes, I have a copy of Strike Force). More recent systems of interest include Unknown Armies, HeroQuest, Sorcerer, Burning Wheel, The Riddle of Steel, Wild Talents and Seven Leagues.

      I just got Thousand Suns and it put a smile on my face, although really it should be black with a little red stripe on the cover, for maximum verisimilitude.

      I've lived in 9 states and I have a degree in math/physics, but I do computer goobery for money. I live in the frozen tundra of Minnesota, and have lurked around various RPG newsgroups/mailing lists/forums for a long time, usually as either AnyaTheBlue or more recently UnlikelyLass, or some variation of both. I tend to lurk more than post, though -- I tend to be 'bursty'.

      I like to draw. I do not fight crime.

      Hm. Anybody else feel like they're writing a personal add when they write these things?

    • ekb
      March 2008
      Hi, I'm Keith aka the new guy...

      Once upon a time in the early 70s, I went with my father into his favorite hobby store to pick up a small (5.5X8.5) rules booklet about this new game based on one he already played... That was my first exposure to RPGs.

      Outside of that, I've tried to lead a full life. I'm a few hours shy (as well as thesis defense) of a doctorate in biomedical engineering. I'm going to stay that few hours shy for a long time - I burnt out on school and decided to become a professional chef. I've also done quite a few different things to pay the bills: graphic design, programming, sales... So my current "job" of being a stay-home dad isn't exactly unwelcome at this juncture. ;)

      I have a rather untraditional family - but since this be teh intarweb I won't speak of them further except to say that a family that games together stays together.

      Sex, Religion and Politics are subjects I won't get into. Unless you start talking to me in person... and then it might happen. Might.

      I'm originally from Indianapolis, so I know a number of great places off the beaten track within walking/spitting distance of GenCon. Currently, though, I live in sunny Lake County IL - an equal drive to Lake Geneva WI and downtown Chicago... which also speaks volumes about me as well.

      Top 5 Movies: Thank You For Smoking, SLC Punk, Velvet Goldmine, Sin City, Shawshank Redemption
      "Top" 5 Bands/Musicians: Leonard Cohen, Current 93, Claude Challe, Morphine, Angelo Badalamenti
      Top 5 Comics (mostly dead): The Invisibles, Planetary, Transmetropolitan, Books of Magic/Hunter, 1602
      "Top" 5 Authors: Chris Hyatt, Mantak Chia, Neal Stephenson, Charles Stross, JG Ballard

      TV: the rest of the family are reality addicts, but I have problems in seeing human tragedy as entertainment. We tend to like watching shows on DVD rather than as broadcast. I have a love of Yo Gabba Gabba, Charlie and Lola, and a number of other kids shows.

      Radio: umm, what's that? ;)

      I can't think of anything else to add at this moment...
    • Ajax_Aldwyne
      March 2008 edited August 2010
      It’s been some months since I signed in, but, as they say, “better late than sorry”.

      [Or was it “better him than never”?]

      I began role-playing at the age of 12 or 13. I had already been exposed to non-rpg D&D derivatives, like the computer game Wizardry on the Apple ][ (a pure dungeon crawling game) and Fighting Fantasy gamebooks (I think it was Deathtrap Dungeon), or films like E.T. (although I did not understand what I saw, it unavoidably primed me). I put the pieces together I lifted the resolution system and general ideas from the Fighting Fantasy book, built a ridiculous dungeon on a piece of paper, invented some (pathetic) characters and got some friends on a rainy afternoon to run it. It was a semi-disaster, but I was hooked. Next I got D&D, a friend got Dark Eye. Then AD&D. Next came Call of Cthulhu, Warhammer FRPG, Runequest, Star Wars… and that was just the start.

      These last years I became more and more tired with published rpg and periodicals. I progressively stopped buying them, quietly slid of the mainstream rpg universe and stopped paying attention to rpg-related news. But never stopped playing or mastering. I attended LARPs (Belgian style) 3 to 5 times a year during 3 or 4 years, then stopped because the novelty quickly wore off to reveal the monotony.

      By accident I very recently discovered Indie games, story games. I regret I missed them at the start and I am trying to catch up.

      That’s it.

      Oh, yeah: Ajax isn’t my real name.
    • Frederik J. Jensen
      March 2008
      My name is Frederik Jensen and I spend way too much time on the net :-)

      I'm a Dane, born in Denmark, living in Denmark and I only fight crime in my imagination. It is usually very peaceful around here, except when young fanatics set fire to people's cars and when the police shoots criminals on the corner.

      By now I'm an avid story gamer, meaining I really enjoy getting rid of the all mighty GM and have everyone sit around the table on equal terms and make up great stories on the fly about complex situations. I believe in story games as a great way of gaining understanding and empathy about how other people perceive the world. I'm always amazed when people around me show me that the world is not as plain and simple as I have made myself believe.

      I'm a software architect in the day time in a great company.

      At night I play games, read and post on story games, and work on my hobby project: The story game Montsegur 1244. I spend my weekends at my summer house, where I also do game weekends for close friends a couple of times a year. And then sometimes I go to game conventions and help set up games, workshops and other fun stuff.

      My roleplaying history begins with "choose your own adventure", then on to Dungeons and Dragons (red basic set), Drager og Dæmoner (that Sweedish stuff), AD&D, AD&D 2, Call, GURPS, Star Wars, Torg, and then away from traditional sim game systems and into Danish style, one-shoots scenarios. Passing over Ars Magica, WFRPG and later D&D 3, before finally discovering story games like Dogs, Roach, PTA and latest Bliss Stage.

      I hope I still have many gaming years ahead of me, as I'm nowhere near having played all the great games out there.

      Homepage: http://frederik.jensen.net
    • Craig_in_ACT
      April 2008
      Hi!

      I'm Craig J. Brain. I'm a 38 yo gamer posted to Canberra, Australia, but working overseas at the moment. I've been gaming since about 1978, and have since had a couple of goes at publishing and editing products on the indy side of the house.

      I prefer sci-fi gaming, and love post apocalyptic settings, but also love some of the older games such as DragonQuest and Traveller. I have just picked up Spirit of the Century and am new to story games. BTW I like SoTC, but have only played a single game of it for an hour.

      Warmest regards,

      Craig J. Brain
    • John K
      April 2008
      I'm John Keyworth, 27, been gaming for 15 years or so, discovered indie/story games about a year ago and having been hooked ever since (although Traditional games still hold an appeal). Like most people I'm always 'working on a game' although I'm trying to make the push to get my latest effort out there.

      I live in Oxford, England with my girlfriend of 6 years, have graduated from Essex University with a Computer Science degree and I'm currently programming computer games for a living, which is nice.

      John Keyworth,
    • Starkwolf
      May 2008
      I'm Dave Kneeland and I am 29. I've been gaming on and off for around 17 years but lost touch with it terribly in the last 8 years or so. I've just recently reconnected with an old gaming buddy which sparked my interest.

      I am a Residential Services Supervisor for a Children's Home in Maine.

      I cut my teeth on 2nd Edition Dungeons and Dragons, and have played many different games in between now and then. My main interest lately has lead me to GURPS as I have started thinking about creating my own game world.
    • Eryops
      May 2008
      I'm Kristian and recently turned 33. Like a few other people I just scrolled past, I'm a Canadian living in Seattle, and I'll be married later this summer.

      I work at the UW in the fisheries department, which lends itself nicely to lunchtime trips to Half Price Books, Zanadu Comics, and if I feel like braving the bad part of The Ave, The Dreaming (Comics and Games). I have lived in Thunder Bay ON, Calgary AB, and Ames IA before chasing the woman of my dreams to the west coast.

      I hadn't thought about my first gaming experience for many years, but it came to my head the other day, and I'm sure some of you may get a chuckle out of it, so I'll share:

      I was about five or six years old and had a nine or ten year old DM showing me the ropes. I made a character that had a sword, a dog, and a horse. My character was riding happily along when a group of men stopped me. I tried to fight the lead man and remember cutting off a limb or two before the other men stopped me from killing him. They just wanted to give me a new horse and dog because the ones I had were 'bad' somehow. So after that, with my 'better' animal companions, I ventured into a cave. My dog and I ventured into a room with a door that closed behind us. Out came a group of giant rats that started to swarm us and very quickly overcame my trusty companion. I think I managed to kill a handful of the foul beasts before being overrun and killed.

      I didn't touch a roleplaying game again for the next 15 or so years.

      After figuring out that ten year old GMs aren't the best you can get, I've gotten back into gaming and am having a blast. I'm currently playing in a Reign and D&D Eberron campaign, and running WFRP.
    «1…567891011…15»
    This discussion has been closed.

    Comments

    • EarthenForge
      May 2008
      Hey there. I'm Rachel Walton. I'm 27. Born in California, grew up in New Jersey (which I staunchly defend against all the haters), and now live just west of Philadelphia. I went to Houghton College in western NY and double majored in History and Art (ceramics). I've been married to xenomouse (but I call him Phil - you can too) for 5 years. No kids yet, but we do have two cats and two chinchillas. I work a Trader Joe's. You're welcome to talk to me about our cool products outside of work, but if you come up to me randomly to complain about TJs, expect a dirty look. And a sucker punch. It's rude.

      I'm slowly working towards becoming a potter professionally. I do both artsy hand-built pieces and functional wheel-thrown stuff. I'm currently working on mastering the tricky one-piece goblet.

      My interests are pretty broad. Gardening, cooking, camping, reading, and just hanging out top the non-gaming list. I love horse-back riding and fencing as well, but I've not had the pleasure of either in quite some time. I like a lot of different music, but I'm almost always in the mood for NIN or anything by Chris Cornell (of Audioslave and Soundgarden fame - his solo stuff rocks too). "The Departed" is the best movie ever. My favorite current shows are LOST and Battlestar Galactica. Favorite authors right now include Kurt Vonnegut, Ursula K. LeGuin, and Donald Miller.

      I first started RPGs with 2nd Ed D&D in highschool, but long before that, I was the creative mastermind behind many detailed play-worlds for my friends and I, from vampires, to lion hunters, to underground drug gangs with little baggies of cocaine, er...flour (yeah, I wasn't a typical 9 year old). When we discovered ElfQuest, we loved it so much that we created our own club for it, reading comics, constructing forts, and playing elves.

      I GMed for the first time in college. Last year I introduced a whole new group to D&D which we eventually converted to Burning Wheel. BW is the meat and potatoes of my gaming right now. I love it. So I run a weekly BW game for 9, because I'm insane, and I play other games when I can. Other games I've recently enjoyed include In a Wicked Age, Ganakogok, The Mountain Witch, and Dresden Files.
    • Robert_Bohl
      May 2008
      Rachel and Phil are awesome! I'm very happy to know them.
    • Neil Gow
      May 2008
      I can't believe I haven't filled this in before now!

      My name is Neil, I'm 37 and I live with my wife, two kids and a d6 cats in North Shields which is near Newcastle in the north east of England. Newcastle is officially 'too far away from anywhere else to be useful' and 'legendarily freezing cold' - neither of which is wholly true. For years I have been known online as Vodkashok (its a B5 reference...honest) but I am starting to rehabilitate myself into using my real name more because ... well, I'm an adult. My name will do!

      I have an honours degree in Marketing Management and I am currently retraining to be an adult educator. When I first started work I worked as a warden in a hostel for homeless people trying to settle into housing - probabtioners, children leaving care, mental health patients in the community. Oh what fun! I decided to leave that job when I was shot at one too many times and began work with an organisation that helps homeless teenagers develop independence skills. That was fun until the stress of it all started to bite. Since then I have worked for Newcastle Uni Students Union as their education researcher, their student development officer and finally their Marketing Manager. My job entails a whole slew of random tasks - research, promotion, graphic design, printing and usually everything else that no-one else can be bothered to do. Its fun, but after 13 years I really REALLY need a new job.

      My wife, Christine, is an adult educator and assessor and she used to run her own IT training company. She is an inspiration to me because she has never stopped learning throughout her life and now, well, she is like a walking qualification and damned good at what she does. Lara, my eldest (10) and Emma, the youngest (8) are both little dynamos, currently obsessed with Dr Who. One of my 'must-do' things this year is to get back roleplaying with them, as their adventures with A Faerys Tale last year were Epic! The cats are ... well, maleable. We have one, officially, and then two more that use the house as a hotel and two more that seem to like to see how far the official one, Sammy, lets them in. I'm convinced that he has parties in the house when we aren't in. He's that sort of cat.

      As for my non-gaming pursuits? Well, I've got about 12,000 comic books in my loft and I've been collecting them for decades now. I'm a team book addict so its all Avengers, JLA, JSA etc. as well as a load of random crap. I love the wacky world of professional wrestling and I've been to Wrestlemania now four times (Seattle, New York, Los Angeles and Chicago). In my time I have been known to do a lot of cooking, but not so much recently and a fair bit of comics fanfic writing - again, not so much recently. Apart from those and gaming, work and the girls, I don't really have much time for anything else! Well, I do watch TV - Heroes, BSG, Pushing Daisies and Dr Who are the mainstays at the moment although I do seem to be developing an addiction to Deadliest Catch which is disturbing. Oh and football, of course. Watching Newcastle Utd - its like flaggelation of the soul. I read quite a lot as well, but nothing spectacular. A lot of history books at the moment.

      Gaming wise I have an excellent community of gamers around the North East. We number around a dozen and between us, in various combinations, we have two rpg groups, a board games group and a WoW guild. Its very much a sort of 30-somethings self help group with academics, accountants, computer geeks, engineers and all manner of other people involved. Very good stuff. Over the years I have also ran a number of CCG communities both within the UK and worldwide and that network of gamers still exists, which offers another outlet for gaming and geekdom through a community that I maintain.

      Currently I am going through the final motions of my game of Napoleonic adventure, Duty & Honour, playing in a truly excellent game of Primetime Adventures and preparing for a storygamed-up 4e campaign when it comes out.

      Cheers
      Neil
    • Grant Davis
      May 2008
      I'm Grant Davis. I'm 35 for one more month. I live in Houston, TX with my girlfriend of 6 years. I work for an aerospace firm in software. Right now I'm working on the space side and I find it very rewarding. I have a Master's in Computer Science and I'm making rumblings about a second one in Finance. I like disco (yeah, I said it), though I don't get out dancing these days. I listen more than I read; Moby Dick is slowly emerging though the CD player in my car. I dabble in the Japanese language and media. Mostly I'm about the gaming, though, and I can talk about that elsewhere.
    • Dominik
      May 2008
      My name is Dominik Schwager. I live in Bayreuth, germany together with my gaming girlfriend. I am currently studying to get a degree in law and this will take me another 3 years or so until I can finally work (and pay off students' loan... yay). I also learn chinese and japanese and would like to work in one of those countries later on (not so much in china... I like my basic human rights intact). What's more to know? I am a sucker for TV series with cool and unique casts and the all time storyteller of my gaming groups.

      Im Jeff, and I live in Hampton Roads which is a regional name for South-Eastern Coastal Virginia.
      Im single, I like long walks on the beach... er sorry wrong thread. Im a Petty Officer in the US Coast Guard and I do Marine Safety. You know oil spills and stuff. Im a fan of Sci-fi, and Fantasy, Roleplaying games, and writing, though I do the last bit less and less. Im here cause nerdly sounded fun, and because I want to get more involved with some sort of gaming community. Also if your from the area and want to meet up and play just message me.

      Ok. I think thats it...


    • miedvied
      May 2008
      I'm somewhat solicitous of my privacy online, at least to the extent of mentioning my name - so I'll omit that bit.

      I live in New York, not far from NYC proper. I recently completed a master's degree in developmental biology (doing research in a breast cancer laboratory at Hunter), and I'm currently paddling water while I take some undergrad courses I need in order to apply to dental school. I'm also keenly wishing I were rich so I could just blow off professional school and pursue PhD after PhD for the rest of my life; I'm currently eying environmental science and astrobiology and epidemiology. Just to get started. I would've gone to med school, but sadly I echo Bruce Baugh in living with massive immune problems - a residency program would have ended me.

      Been RPing since I was about nine, having been introduced to a homebrew/drift of DnD2e. From there I went White Wolf for a while, just in time for some of those awkward teen years; eventually I grew despondent over the sickening social chaos that tended to follow RPG groups and gave up the hobby. I found the Forge in the latter years of college, and while I've never found anyone to play with them, I've surely grown very fond of reading the games that've come out of there.



    • fnord3125
      May 2008
      hi. i'm brian.
      i joined this place almost a year ago but i'm just now getting around to posting on this thread.
      sadly, i've probably only "met" (where met=at least a short conversation involving an exchange of names) about 3 of you. hopefully that will change eventually.

      i love stories. i love interesting stories told in unusual ways. this is one of the reasons i love RPGs. this is also why i love to write fiction, and read fiction. this is also why i play interactive fiction video games, and other video games that have strong story lines and character development. i'm picky about movies, but the ones i like are also those that use interesting narrative techniques.

      i'm 27. i'm from (and still reside in) the Quad-Cities, on the Iowa side of the Mississippi River. last week i finally finished school for my BA in English. i like the fact that i don't feel old on Story Games. in my classes i was generally one of the oldest people. most of my friends from school are around 3 to 7 years younger than me. after a semester, or maybe two, off i intend to pursue a Master's degree in library science. next year i also plan to apply to the Iowa Writers' Workshop. i look forward to being rejected with great anticipation!

      i read and purchase far more RPGs than i play, which makes me very sad.
      i discovered "indie" games through Have Games, Will Travel, and purchased my first couple (The Mountain Witch, Polaris, and The Shab-al-Hiri Roach) at Gen Con Indy '06, which was, incidentally, my first time at Gen Con.
      i have, however, considered myself a gamer of the table top role-playing sub-species since i was around 8 or so and my brother introduced me to AD&D, Dark Conspiracy, and Cyberpunk, then bought me Toon and TMNT and my first set of dice.

      that's me. hi. nice to meet you.
      oh and i'm on last.fm if you want to know about my music tastes. if you want to read my random thoughts or some of the short fiction pieces i've posted, i have a blog. i'm also on both of the myface if you do that kinda thing.
      i'll be quiet now.







    • Capulet
      May 2008
      Hullo.

      My name is Adam Riemenschneider. I live in Shoreview, MN, which is a northern suburb of the Twin Cities (although I still consider myself a Minneapolis resident *in spirit*). I'm 32 years old, and am an indie game publisher (www.othercourt.com). I work in a luggage shop mostly full-time, and am a lead bartender at the only Goth/Industrial club in Minneapolis, Ground Zero. I attended college for many years, but stopped short of graduating; English Major, Creative Writing Minor. I am also a musician, performing the functions of lead vocalist, bass, and song writing (though I find playing bass and singing lead vocals at the same time to be nigh impossible).

      I like motorcycle, knives, and firearms. I was raised Roman Catholic, but am an Atheist. In my life, I've been a bouncer, a library desk clerk, a payroll accountant (for the Sheriff's office, no less), a home security dispatcher, a customer service rep, and a delivery driver. I like Libertarian ideals, but think there ought to be a sort of safety net which the government provides. I dislike the Big Brother society that America is becoming, and hope that things get better, instead of getting worse. I am addicted to coffee.

      I've played RPGs for about twenty years. Really, I'm a "vanilla" gamer... I prefer traditional RPGs a majority of the time, but like board and story games now and then, to fill the gaps in scheduling and whatnot. I've been a Forge member for a little while, but not long enough to say I fully understand GNS Theory. They haven't lynched me for it, so I guess it's all good.

      That's about it.
    • Jono
      May 2008
      My name is Jonathan, but everybody calls me "Jono". I'm 28 and just moved from Chicago to Mountain View, CA (it's in Silicon Valley) to work for Mozilla. I'm searching for a new gaming group in my area.

      I have a blog, frequently updated with stuff about gaming but also politics, computers, comics, adventures, et cetera. I occasionally draw a webcomic called Yuki Hoshigawa and the Scariest Thing in the World; it's a sort of shojo-cyberpunk-office comedy. It's been several months since I last updated it, but I hope to fix that soon.

      Before Mozilla, I was a computer programmer for a four-person startup software company in Chicago called Humanized; before that I was a research assistant at Argonne National Laboratory, and before that I taught English to junior-high school kids in the mountains of rural Japan. I speak Japanese pretty OK and I like a lot of anime and manga, although the obsessiveness of American otaku-fandom culture scares me.

      I was a Physics major in college. I have a tattoo of Maxwell's electromagnetic field equations on my right shoulder.

      I'm just getting back into Aikido after several months away from it; I've been doing it pretty seriously since fall 2000.

      I volunteer for the Obama campaign.

      I'm friends with Ben Lehman in real life; I met Paul Czege briefly at Forge Midwest in 2007; I might know more people here, but not know that I know them. Hello!

      When I was thirteen I saw some high-school boys playing AD&D 1st edition in the cafeteria; they wouldn't let me join but I watched enough to get the basic idea of what they were doing, then went home and immediately created my first RPG, which I called "Master Plan". Inspired by equal parts Lord of the Rings, the Legend of Zelda, Phantasy Star, the dungeon-crawl board game "Hero Quest", my brief glimpses of what the D&D players were doing, and my own deranged imagination, it was a very, very silly game. 100% Gamist; early version even had Save Points in them. Japanese console RPGs have Save Points, I reasoned, so why shouldn't my game? I played it with my cousins; the two PCs were a slime-monster wizard named Globble D. Gleep and a dragon who rode around on a piece of magitech construction equipment. They were on a quest to save the world from an evil corporation full of undead real-estate salesmen and undead lawyers, who could only be killed by Holy Hydrosulfuric Acid. The game used lots of d12s and mostly revolved around intricate dungeon maps full of traps and logic puzzles. The campaign fell apart right as they were assaulting the flying death-ray airship fortress.

      After that: basic D&D (Rules Cyclopedia style), miscellaneous Palladium games, AD&D2 (a lot of messing around with the Spelljammer and Planescape settings; boy they were cool but I had no idea how to run adventures in them); a little Rifts, a little Shadowrun, more homebrew systems where I never quite got the campaign off the ground because I was much too obsessed with trying to create The Perfect Rule System; a few really horrible failed attempts to play GURPS, absolute failure at running Call of Cthulhu, a couple sessions of Vampire that were pretty OK, some attempts to adapt Planescape to D&D3 which went pretty well all things considered, and then an absolutely disastrous D&D homebrew-setting game which was so bad that the first and only session permanently destroyed friendships and convinced me I had to reconsider everything I thought I knew about GMing. Almost played Exalted but walked out during character creation; a Google search for the phrase "Exalted Sucks" in the winter of 2006/07 led me to the Blog Diaspora and thence to The Forge, which completely blew my mind.

      Since then, I've played Dogs in the Vineyard, Trollbabe, Shock, Bliss Stage, The Mountain Witch, The Shadow of Yesterday, 1001 Nights (once), Hero Quest ( the Glorantha one this time) and some playtests of several unfinished games including, most recently, The Emperor's Heart -- and loved them all! For the first time since Master Plan, gaming is fun and satisfying again, rather than frustrating.

      Nice to meet you. (I wish English had a better equivalent to "Yoroshiku onegai shimasu...")
    • wundergeek
      May 2008
      Um. I don't think I've ever done this before, so here goes?

      My name is Anna Kreider, but I tend to use this alias out of habit. I'm 26, have been married for almost six years. Two years ago I relocated from the United States to Canada and have been enjoying Canadian communism ever since. (I have to say that, since the nice mountie has a gun pointed at my head.) I have a bad habit of being sarcastic with a completely straight face, which sometimes gets me into trouble but is terribly amusing none the less.

      I went to school for five years to get a Bachelor of Fine Arts in photography so that I could enjoy a very boring career as a medical secretary. Filling out forms in quintuplicate has been very motivational to get myself out there, and I've had a number of freelance projects including illustration for a few games, some portraiture, and web design. I'm also releasing a game at GenCon this year, much to my chagrin because I have to finally admit that I might actually be a game designer.

      It is my fondest hope to some day NOT work in a Dilbert strip, but for now I put up with it because it motivates me to be productive.

      I'm hopelessly addicted to RPGs, especially any RPG made by Squaresoft. I used to be addicted to Dark Age of Camelot before I kicked the habit, but am realistic enough to admit that I am just saving myself for Warhammer Online. My husband and I have a board game addiction and have an entire closet full of excellent games that I don't play enough. Also, I'm a gigantic movie buff.

      I lurk on the Forge and post intermittently over on Knife Fight. And... uh... that's about it.
    • noisms
      June 2008
      Hey all,

      I'm new. My name's Dave, I'm 26, and I'm a Japanese - English translator currently living in Yokohama. Contrary to what that might make you think, I hate anime and manga.

      What I love is RPGs, particularly Dungeons and Dragons, believe it or not. I started off with Basic D&D, moved onto 2nd edition AD&D, then after a long extended detour through the World of Darkness and then various more "worthy" games I realised that I got the most satisfaction out of 2nd edition AD&D and went back to that. I do occasionally foray into MERP and HARP, though, and recently I've been playing a bit of Homebrew ORE and getting somewhat excited about it. But 2nd edition AD&D mixed with a bit of BECMI D&D is home to me.

      I write a blog, like most people do.

      Nice to meet you all.
    • ad1066
      June 2008 edited June 2008
      Hi, I'm Ben, and I'm a gamer. [Hi, Ben.]

      I'm 34, and I was born and raised in New York, and currently live on Long Island. I listen to very loud music and play way too many computer games. I probably watch too much TV. I've been playing RPGs since about 1988, and can't get enough of them (I had a bit of a hiatus for about 6 years, but I've jumped back in and started 2 new groups that are running concurrently now).

      The short answer is that I've been doing artwork & character sheets for games for about 8 years now (The longer version goes on to state that I've been doing character sheets for as long as I've been gaming, but I've only been getting paid for it since 2000 or so). Some of my stuff has made it into games written by Ron Edwards, Clinton R. Nixon, Jared Sorensen, Paul Czege, and Brennan Taylor. I'm currently working on adding Luke Crane to that list.

      -- Ben Morgan
      ad1066@optonline.net
      http://ad1066.deviantart.com/
      http://www.spookybeans.com/
    • DeBracy
      June 2008
      Hello there.

      My name's Anders Bohlin, I'm 26 and I live in Piteå, Sweden. My plan is to become a music teacher so I've spent the last six years studying (more or less...). Before that I was a conscript in the Swedish Navy for 11 months and somehow managed to only get on a boat three or four times in total (I was with the Naval Control so my primary duty was to sit in front of a computer and hit F9 to clear new and unnecessary messages from our surveilance software).

      During summers I have the privilege to work as a guide and musician in a church that was built in the early 1200s. It's been updated every now and then until the the late 18th century so it's full of things that were fashionable at their own time. Somehow it all comes together very nicely. Even though I'm mostly into old rock and psychedelia and such, I spend my summers singing renaissance and medieval music. It's great fun and great music.

      I've been roleplaying steadily since the middle of the '90s. I was first introduced by a friend of a friend and later my cousins in the early '90s. At that time roleplaying was viewed as pretty dangerous in Sweden - there'd been a lot of negative media coverage and the Swedish game Kult (Kult: Beyond the Veil now with French 7th Circle) was more or less the thing that removed RPGs from toystores and such. Hence my first gaming product was a fantasy bestiary, the "Monster Box", for 'Drakar och Demoner' (originally a translation of RuneQuest, more or less stripped of setting). At least three times I promised my mom that it wasn't a roleplaying game in it self. "I just want it for the art!" I said. And... that was kinda true. It had some great art... but naturally we used it to play anyway. Some d6 got to replace the d20 from the original (gosh, I created GURPS by myself!!).

      A few years later I visited London and found RuneQuest Deluxe (RQ3 boxed set) in a second hand store that otherwise only had clothes. Naturally I got it, and played it with my friends and... after that I've been in it. And mom's no longer worried. ;D

      What about now then? Well... 2007 really blew me away. It started with a con game in January that was just magical which really set the tone for the whole year - I was hungry for more. So when Easter came I went to Gothenburg (a 20 hour trainride) to attend Sweden's biggest con. There I got to play an off the cuff game of Dead of Night and... yeah... something just clicked. We had an awesome session in 3½ hours including prep time. Quite different from the Blue Rose game I'd run at a local con a month earlier where I spent more than 3½ hours on just writing up the characters. I was hooked.

      During '07 I also got to play a short campaing using TSOY, 1001 Nights, some Swedish indie RPGs and of course my own creation. A special mention about the Panty Explosion campaign I was in too: we started in June and played 17 session in the main campaign and a 4 session spin-off during the course of ten months. And man... despite everything being over IRC and text only, it was awesome. Our group is very spread out so the internet is the only way for us to game together regularly and it's been working terrific. And of course, we've started a new campaing. :)

      All in all, that year made gaming so much better for me so... huzzah for dirty hippie games. I'm a wanna-be hippie anyway so, I guess it's just natural.

      Uh... yeah. So as you can tell, I don't know where to stop so I'll do it right here.
    • Timothy
      June 2008
      My name's Timothy, and I work as a librarian in Queensland, Australia. I'm 35, and married. My wife and I met in the library. She was taking out some sci fi novels (this is back before she joined the library) and I was cheeky to her and told her she had them in the wrong order, and she argued back that publication order's not the right order according to the author, because the new ones were prequels and things just went from there. She saw how much I enjoyed my work and changed careers, so she's now a library assistant. She's a gamer of the hack and slash computery school. For our engagement present I bought her the collector's bound edition of "Dragons of Autumn Twilight" and we hope the Hickmans will sign it at Gen Con this year. We have no children. We have two cats, named after the witches in "Wicked", one of who is trying to fall asleep on my arm as I type.

      I first gamed using the Fighting Fantasy Paperbacks, then Red Box D&D in primary school. I'm more of an Ars Magica gamer, although I played a lot of Amber and Pendragon in Uni. I write a fair bit of Ars Magica as my main hobby. I have a history degree and I find the difficult and intricate research fascinating. It is a bit tricky to source material from Australia, but electronic document delivery is coming on in leaps and bounds, which makes it easier.

      Other than that I cook (vegetarian), read, fool about on the web and play tremendous and ridiculous amounts of Gal Civ, where I try to limit myself to the prohibitions in the Geneva Convention to make the game tougher.
    • boulet
      June 2008
      My name is Franck Michaux, 36 years old and I live in Connecticut. I was born in Paris and English isn't natural for me so please be patient. I work as a programmer and hope to fit into American corporate life. I married a lovely New Englander two years ago and we're about to have our second offspring around December.

      I started RPGs when I was twelve with the obvious Basic D&D which kept my friends and I amused a year or so. Then we fortunately discovered the prolific French RPGs scene whose many games entertained us and, I believe, made us better people too. I was a play tester sometimes. A few American games mad it through too, like Amber. Though I regret the time when I was a careless student who could spend dozens of hours playing this or that every week, at some point I got lured into other activities like free parties and whatnot. I didn't play much after the nineties. I didn't analyze this shift then but I must admit that I had probably reached a limit in the type of fun I could experience with RPGs. Or maybe I just needed a break. Would I have known about story games back then it could have changed things.

      My knowledge of new forms of RPG is only through websites, forums and podcasts. I wish I could find a group of players interested in experimentations, still looking for it. I'm a bit afraid of how difficult it might be for me to play in English but I'm not terrorized either. I miss role playing fun a lot now.
    • Logos7
