    • Arpie
      June 2008 edited June 2008
      I'm Rp Bowman.

      I'm a 37-year-old Hispanic-Caucasian Male with weight problems and money problems. My wife weeps to see how I dress on a daily basis and I'm also very grumpy.

      I live in Colorado Springs, CO with my wife and a whole bunch of debt. I've always wanted to self-publish, but I have always made the choice to pursue other responsibilities before indulging in this bit of vanity. Well, okay, I helped my wife with her Happy Childhood zine and put out a few minor games through that method, including the trashcan edition of Panels years and years ago. I even won a minor award for game design, but that's about it.

      I've worked for the County off and on for years and I'm a grumpy, fat, greasy truck or courier (in a Hawaiian shirt) driver when I'm not doing that (meaning I'm gone from home for long periods, every now and then.) I regularly volunteer for the wrong political party and work as an election judge for... someone else's precinct on the other side of town, usually. I try to dislike all genders, races, ages, classes and sexual orientations with equal disdain, but sometimes one of these horrid groups gets past my guard and I find myself charmed.

      I'm trying to get a story games group going with someone else on this site, but we're the only two people in town really showing any interest.

      I used to be pretty good at comedy and horror games, but whether I still am or not, I love to GM. I like games with a level of cute that sickens a lot of players and I hate bragging. That makes me a very poor salesman.

      My wife likes old Italian horror movies (especially anything with Paul Naschy) and sundry horror comics, so that tends to seep into my games a lot. She's also a freelance event planner, so I get to make up party games for her niftier projects every now and then.

      My favorite games of all time are Prime Time Adventures, Castle Falkenstein, Paranoia, Teenagers from Outer Space and a couple of different board games I won't go into here. In general I avoid any game with strong doses of amnesia, gothic angst or military glory.

      I'm also unreasonable fond of the BBC series, Doctor Who (and its spin-off, The Sarah Jane Adventures.)
    • Kawa

      I'm Kawa. I'm 19, currently going to college in Central Florida (Florida Institute of Technology) getting my degree in applied mathematics. I'm originally from New York City though, so you can imagine the culture shock! Anyway, I started gaming when I made my way down here, starting with in an insane D&D Modern game where I met my future fiance, best friend, fellow player, and chef. ^^ My favorite systems so far have been BESM 3rd Edition and D&D 4E. I care for said boyfriend, five lovely fish (a male and female betta and three Schwartzi corydoras), and various dying plants, including one not-dead-yet well-beloved orchid. My 'day job' (if you can call it that) is doing research; using mathematical models to understand ecology (population dynamics). I also love music (I participate in the music ministry at my local Catholic parish, as well as the college a cappella group), football in the European sense (I'm currently typing this while watching the nail-biting wonder of the Turkey vs. Germany Euro Cup game) and food (well, figuring out what tasty things I can eat despite my severe poultry allergy).

    • Daniela
      July 2008
      I'm Daniela, born 1974 in Temuco/Chile, living since 1975 in Germany (my German parents had to go back these times).
      I recently moved to Oldenburg (very north of Germany) from Stuttgart, to get a new job as a professor for database and internet technologies there.

      I started my rpg career quite late (age 23) and quite unusual. My first five games within my first year were Pendragon, Starwars, a self-built space odyssey campaign, Immortal, and Dendarii D6, playing in the Vorkosigan universe by the books of Lois McMaster Bujold -- who happens to be my favorite author -- with Starwars rules. Later we switched to TriStat and finally to GURPS. Since then, I played (both sides of 'the screen') around 40 different games.
      I love to try out games. But even more, I love good stories, and I hate it when game mechanics get in the way of a good story.

      Before 2001, my favorite game was Mage: the Ascension. I considered the system quite unintrusive, loved the flexible and creativity-driven magic system, and, as a GM, avoided many fights because of the not-so-flexible conflict system.

      Then came Engel. It's a German rpg in a post-acopalyptic SciFi-Setting (though the characters think, it's mythical), and it comes with D20 system (only for selling purpose, don't try this at home) and the Arkana, which is based on inspiration cards. This changed my way of role-playing. Dramatically.
      Arkana isn't too different from the Everway tarot cards, however, they did two major changes: first, they tailored the motives and words to the settting, and secondly, the player now explains what happens, based on the card.
      Suddenly, I loved conflicts and epic battles, even as a GM. And I realized that these inspiration cards give me everything I need in a game.

      So, I still try out new games, particulary fresh new indie ideas. I even support and promote them (if my time allows it).

      But for my personal rpg fun, I'm through with dice.
    • lightcastle
      July 2008
      Wow, this is a long thread.

      So. Introductions. I'm Laurent Castellucci, 36. I actually got my start gaming with D&D - before there was basic and advanced. It was a box with a dragon on the cover, facing off with a Knight and a Wizard. My parents picked it up, thinking it looked interesting. I had no one to play with, so I ran my sister and my dad through adventures. (Incidentally, since he had read Chanson de Roland he played the best Paladin I've ever seen.

      I've played my share of games. (Lots of the old 80s classics) and then moved on. I keep drifting back. A few years ago I found HeroQuest while looking for a new system (and had briefly dabbled with The Window). I loved the idea of it, and after encountering Mike Holmes on the Forge (while looking for more) I liked his take on it more and more, even if it meant sometimes beating on the system to try and get it to do things I wanted. (I am hoping for better from HQ 2.0, but the little I've heard makes me think all it will do is be a little easier to try and shift around.)

      A disastrous love life and job situation of late put me off gaming, but now I'm working in PR, being underpaid, but at least can entertain the thought of indulging again. (Hell, I even have someone running an Amber game I will join, and am going to give running a game using HQ another try, since I can't be bothered to wait for HQ2.0 - I'll just warn them I might shift the rules slightly on them as I go.)

      I sometimes act and write, used to dance and do some stand up, and just got back from The Dark Knight, which is a really good film.
    • sacredchao
      July 2008 edited July 2008
      I'm Ryan. I live in Fresno, CA. I have a BA in Cinema from San Francisco State, but I work as a file clerk. It's boring, but extremely easy, and pays the bills.

      I started off playing Vampire: The Masquerade, a decade ago, in high school. After playing a few sessions, I switched to running them. I've been playing ever since. I GM about 90% of the time, as I find running the games much more enjoyable then playing them.

      I'm currently playing Spirit of the Century. We've played three or four sessions, and I estimate we will complete the campaign in about two or three more sessions. We'll be switching to Burning Wheel after that, with the intention of making that our more-or-less permanent campaign. I've been building the world in my head for a while now, and I'm pretty excited about it.

      I stumbled on this site through the Forge, I think. Or, possibly, through a podcast. Probably Sons of Kryos, or Theory from the Closet. I'm honestly not sure. I found the Forge through the Dogs in the Vineyard website, which I found through RPG.net DitV got me interested in Indie games, which I hadn't known existed until I found Dogs. I ran a couple of Dogs one-shots, then went back to my Iron Kingdoms game, which uses the D20 rules. I was never fond of D20, even on the best of days. Finally, after three or four really boring sessions, I killed the game, decided I was done with D20 for good, and went on hiatus to find a game worth playing. Now, we've got a new group going, with one player who has never played an RPG before, and another who hasn't in years, as well as the two veterans from my previous campaign. Everything is going smoothly right now, and that makes me very happy.

      I am kind of working on a game of my own, called Last Girls. It is a competitive role-playing game, with an emphasis on Gamist, Story-Now play. It is basically intended to be a simulation of a slasher movie, and should take about two to three hours to play, depending on how much the players socialize. I am aiming for it to be a zero-, or almost zero-, prep game, with a very shallow learning curve. It's just in the notes stage at the moment, but we'll see.
      By the way, a Last Girl, in horror film criticism, is the last person (typically a woman, hence the name) alive at the end of the movie. Typically, she is the first to die in the sequel.

      July 2008 edited July 2008
      Wow, this thread is pretty long... and frankly, at parts, intimidating!

      Anyway, I'm Christine. I'm 21, and live in New York City. I'm going to be a senior in college in the fall, and my double major is English and Communication and Media Studies. I've set up my career path so I'm able to get my dream job once I'm out - as an children's literature editor at one of the major publishing houses. As far as marital status goes, I'm currently involved in a very long-term relationship, which will eventually lead to bigger and better things.

      As for gaming and such... I've never played a tabletop RPG. I've played loads of console and PC-based RPGs, but never one that was actually pen and paper. As a result, I've always been intrigued by them, but I quite literally have no one to play with. Therefore, I have lots of questions about mechanics and little nitpicky things, many of which I think I'll address on the forum.

      I went to Dexcon 11, my first convention, a couple of weeks ago, and it was loads of fun. Since I didn't preregister, and I could only go on Saturday, all of the events I initially wanted were taken (including a DnD4e game which ended up to be canceled anyway). I enjoy video games and board and card games as well. I guess my nature is inherently playful.

      Nice to meet you all!
    • Caesar Slaad
      July 2008
      I'm Alan. I'm 39. I've been gaming for 28 of those years. I came here for the SotC talk, but have been intrigued by a few other promising sounding story games spoken of here. I'm mostly GM & play traditional games, but I think my take on them is a bit more "story-gamish" by default than most traditional gamers.

      I used to do gaming retail and reviews (hope to get back to that soon...); I have tinkered with a few of my own games, but I'm happier these days "hot rodding" games from the factory than trying to build my own from scratch. Because frankly, I like tinkering with some parts of games more than others ("Now I have to make an equipment list? Oh bother...")

      I live in the US, mid-Atlantic, and I program during my day job.
    • M Jason Parent
      July 2008
      I'm M Jason Parent. 36, male, Canadian, married with two kids.

      I've been playing RPGs since I was 10. I'm a collector and a game-hacker with about 200 RPGs on my shelves and house rules for just about all of them. I live half-way between Ottawa and Montreal. I've run a dozen or so RPG fansites, and published my first non-fan product at the end of 2001 (a d20 supplement). I won an ENnie award for my third book that summer at GenCon, and now my wife runs the awards. I owned Ambient Inc's RPG publishing wing, and E.N. Publishing. Now I am a marketing director for an on-line school and I play games purely for enjoyment.

      Well, I'm also working on a few RPGs in the background, but nothing due to be published for another year or so.

    • Yasha
      August 2008
      I'm James "Yasha" Cunningham, a 47 year old native Seattleite. I am happily married with zero kids and one cat.

      I have been unemployed for a few months. I am currently pursuing parallel career-counseling and neurological goals which will result (hopefully) in my being able to harness my brilliance and creativity for the benefit of humanity (although humanity will probably never realize that it has been benefited).

      I am currently obsessed with the American Crow, which has an intelligence rivaling that of the great apes. The crows in my neighborhood know me by sight because I occasionally give them peanuts as I walk by. In my more deluded moments, I entertain a scheme to jumpstart the natural language abilities of crows through peanuts and live music.

      When I post to message boards, I always seem to bring threads to a halt.

      I speak Esperanto and am intending to learn Toki Pona, a 118-word language that a French Canadian woman invented to cure her depression.

      Matt Wilson is mad at me. Please tell him that I was only joking.

      My most spiritual moments have involved sound and music, so I pursue musical interests despite the fact that I seem to have little talent. I own many musical instruments, none of which I play very well. Sometimes I sit back and play my Electric Wind Instrument through a Filter Eko II (a Uruguayan looper pedal) into an guitar amp, and create wonderful, horrible noise. I am interested in microtonality and sound design, and intend to write liturgical music for a ritual that I experienced in a dream (a Mass for the New Moon).

      At times, I am the Mystery Chef, living in my orbiting test kitchen and recording radio spots for my sponsor, The Gas Company. Only my wife is able to see through this disguise.
    • Josh_H
      August 2008
      I'm Joshua James Hoade, but I am most definitely a Josh. I'm 32 years old, but most people peg me at about half that. I'm divorced and I have two daughters, high ladies of chaos, the both of them. I have a B.A. in english/lit, but neither a master's degree or teaching were appealing to me, so I went back to school for respiratory therapy. I work at Miami Children's Hospital as a ward secretary. I should be finished with school late 2008 after which I will most likely trade my telephone and keyboard for a suction catheter and aerosol mask. This will be a good day. Outside of gaming, I enjoy writing and reading, football, basketball, rollerblading, movies, and more TV than might be healthy. I love comics. Love em.

      I started gaming at thirteen. The D&D red box. I still remember the art in that book, I loved it. From D&D I moved to robotech, TMNT, Shadowrun, and west end Star Wars. Around high school, I stopped. No gaming group and more other stuff to do. Fortunately, in college I met Daniel Perez. He introduced me to Vampire: The Masquerade and I was back in the fold. I've been gaming with the same group now since '02, and no matter what I say about them, they're great guys and great gamers. People join, personalities clash, we fight, leave, make up, come back. One day we'll have a reunion, and it'll be like the Avengers Reassembled, (take that Bendis!) We've been all up and down the genre spectrum playing mostly D20 and D10 world of darkness. One year I hope to drag them all out to Gencon so that they can feel the awesome.

      Now I find myself here looking to discuss the hobby I love.
    • ScottOden
      August 2008
      I'm Scott Oden (I know, snappy screen name, huh?), a long-time lurker but first-time poster. I'm 41, divorced, no kids, no cats (alas), but I harbor a wicked love for parentheticals. I've been a gamer for three decades; my gateway drug was the D&D red box. From there, I moved on to Traveller, Call of Cthulhu, TSR's Conan (now ZEFERS), d20/OGL, and -- most recently -- Dark Heresy and In a Wicked Age. I've become quite taken with games that have more emphasis on character and story rather than number-crunching and mechanics, but I've had a hard time translating that interest to my gaming group -- a hardcore bunch of twinks and min/maxers. I hope to find inspiration on these boards.

      I'm a novelist by day (and generally by night, too). I have two historical fiction novels published in the US and the UK -- Men of Bronze and Memnon -- and I'm on the last bit of my third, The Lion of Cairo. I count Robert E. Howard and Harold Lamb as my greatest influences, followed by Tolkien, Mary Renault, and Steven Pressfield. When not writing or gaming I can generally be found with my nose in a book. Or playing video games. Or slacking.

      I have a website and a blog, but not the technical savvy to make the links show up here. My website is www.menofbronze.com ; there's a link on it for the blog. Be warned: I have a weird thing for Orcs . . .
    • Double King
      August 2008
      I'm Eric Tage Larsen. I'm a 38 y.o. designer and illustrator in Manhattan.

      I've lived in New York for the past 13 years but prior to that I'd lived all over the West, Mid-West and California. I'm a graduate form the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena. Since then graduation I've had work in Print magazine's Design Annual, Society of Illustrators and American Illustration. For a decade, I was an American Painting and Sculpture specialist for a major New York gallery. (Tangentially, I'm one of the first people to write on the outsider artist Henry Darger and only found out recently that i'd made it on to the wiki.) A couple of years ago, I decided to take my moonlighting more seriously and go out on my own.

      I started gaming in the early 80s. I was fortunate enough to not only have a group of latchkey friends that would play DnD around the clock, but I lived near a great gaming store in Minneapolis that opened me up to a wide variety of play. I've only returned to gaming in earnest in the past few years. I think working from home, alone, has probably spurred my interest in gaming - for its enforced social contract.

      Indy-Story Games are also very new to me. I really bit into the raw sociological examination that seems to be going on the exploration of new games. I find that it fulfills very similar investigations i found in fine art and design. Currently, i'm quietly slaving away on a few on game ideas i hope will create good play.

      I enjoy comfortable drink, weatherly sailboats, svelte bicycles and questionable company.

      ...

      If any of you here would know me, it would be for acting as booth assistant to the IPR/Forge booth for 2008 at Gencon.

We've been playing indie and story-games stuff for (maybe) a couple years now, and I've felt that I've become more and more interested all the time. So now (or couple of weeks ago) I signed up on this board. Pleased to be here.

      I've also participated in some game-blogging with my friends, time permitting (usually it doesn't).

    • Pandelume
      September 2008
      While this thread is at the top and I won't be involved in any resurection, I'll add my details. I'm Richard Campbell and I have been reading and playing games for 27 years. That seems like a long, long time now. I started with the Erol Otus covered Basic D&D and went through many, many systems trying to find one that did what I wanted it to do. Some of the ones I have fond memories of include Other Suns (I still love the way all future people will wear flares or tuck their leg-wear into their boots), Space Opera (long lists and tables), Chivalry and Sorcery, Daredevil, Justice Inc., Aftermath and Bunnies and Burrows. One of my best RPG moments was playing Bunnies and Burrows semi-LARP around my friend's smallholding. I had a bit of a thing for FGU games even though I never really understood them. It's not until recently that I found the indie/narrative thing and thought, THIS is the way I always wanted it to be!

      By day I am a reception (kindergarten?) teacher in England and reception teachers all have a 'role-play' area in our classrooms - all over England! All children use this term every day when they go to school! OK, it's not quite the same - but surprisingly, often there is a lot of what you might call 'role-playing' just as gamers would understand it going on in classrooms. We just obviously get to the point it's not the done thing any more and then we all become geeks. I also write music (in amateur-land) and keep cats and rats and I'm looking to do something more creative with my time, hopefully combining my educational 'expertise' and interest in gaming. Hopefully.
    • Sway
      September 2008
      Since the thread is fresh, I'll take a moment to post as well. I'm 34 and live in Clayton, NC, which is just southeast of Raleigh. My wife, dog, cat, and I moved down from Baltimore last year. I do system and application administration to feed my stomach and draw to feed my soul. Santa bought me red box D&D when I was a kid, but Dad couldn't figure out the rules, so I just looked at the pictures. And that was pretty much the extent of my non-video gaming.

      This past year out of the total social vacuum of living in a new state I visited my FLGS and let myself be talked into trying D&D. The pictures had changed since the red box, and the game was entertaining enough, but I thought I might be a little late to the party.

      I started consuming podcasts and blogs to learn about this hobby I'd only tangentially touched from other interests. For the past year I've been playing vicariously by listening to everyone else play and talk about play. Since I started listening about a year ago, all talk was about Gen Con. It seemed to be something of an experience, so I went this past month. I got to meet several of the podcasters and talk to some of you designers and even played a game or two. It was enough to make me want to explore a little more.

      I signed up here to consume even more and keep my eye out for events and people in the area and perhaps...perhaps even actually play one of these days...perhaps. It's great to see the names of so many of those I've listened to, or heard interviews with, or read about. I feel like I just snuck backstage. Please don't check my badge.
    • Jimbles
      September 2008
      Hi all! I'm new to Story Games but I know a bunch of Story Games members in real life so I figured I would become a member and join in on the online fun.

      My name is Jim Sullivan and I live in Forest Hills, Queens, NY. I'm 30 years old. I'm married (6 years as of last Monday) to a beautiful, wonderful person named Evelyn.

      I started gaming in my early teens, stopped in my late teens, started again in my early twenties and have been loving it ever since. When I'm not playing games or playstorming at The Imagination Sweatshop, I can be found rock climbing, painting war game miniatures, blogging about vegan restaurants, watching low-budget science fiction movies or playing nutball (minor league only - I just can't compete with Jenskot and Saif).
    • ChessyPig
      September 2008
      Hello. I've been lurking around reading Story Games and The Forge for a while, but I just had to post on a thread and so I finally joined up here.

      My name is Michelle Taylor, I'm 23 and I live in Cambridge (the real one in England!). I work as a software tester.

      I'm currently running and playing fairly conventional games IRL (I run a weekly Exalted game in a kind of 'sandbox' style that I've got to work out how to wind up soon because most of the players can't make it during term time, and play a weekly D&D4 game in a post-apocalyptic FR-derived setting which the DM describes as 'a sandbox on wheels'), and I also do a lot of online forum / play by post roleplaying (I'm running a Solar Exalted game which is limping along with one or two players taking an interest at any one time, a D&D4 modern-day zombie game which hasn't really got started yet, and I'm playing in a variety of D&D4 / Exalted / WFRP games).

      I've also just about finished playing my first game of Bliss Stage over internet chat (also the first game I've played online via chat) courtesy of Elliott Besler, and would like to get to run a game (either in the same way, over chat whenever enough people for a scene are free, or IRL) but I'm having trouble getting together players. (I thought about leaving a link to the recruitment page but this message is likely to persist long after it's irrelevant - whisper me if you're interested.)

      I also do a lot of LARP - we have a local weekly tavern night / adventuring system which I was part of the organising team for last year (we rotate organisers in and out each year to avoid burnout and ensure new ideas) and I also go play at various national-scale events like Maelstrom and EOS. I tend to call myself an immersionist but get frustrated at the assumption that this means I want to camp authentically in the woods and wear home-made underwear - poor physrepping doesn't concern me, poor ability to stay in character does.
    • Sean Nittner
      September 2008
      My name is Sean Nittner

      I live in Davis, CA. I game with my local group and at bay area cons. I'm 32 with a wife and two beautiful girls.

      My street cred is that I'm a Good Omens GM, I've put on a few decent sized convetions, and I just started podcasting: Narrative Control

      I just joined and will try to catch up on threads but there is a LOT here.





    • Cirv
      September 2008
      Hi everyone.
      My name's Craig Irvine and I'm a 31 year old habitual gamer. I live in Middlesbrough, England and work in the wonderful world of retail. I've been in a regular game group for the last few years but been collecting games since I was a kid meaning I've got a cupboard full of RPG books. Most of them should be eBayed but I'd sooner sell a kidney.
      D&D is still the game of choice for my group but we break up our campaigns with a bit of WoD, the odd indie game and some Paranoia.

      The rest of my life revolves around playing footie and hockey (the kind on astroturf) keeping up with the British music scene and spending too much time on RPG.net.

    • NPC
      September 2008
      Hi, I am Nathanael Cole, aged 28, full-time tech slave and part-time psycho-nerd. I grew up in Mobile, Alabama, moved to Atlanta at the age of 19, and have been living in the fabulous expanse of Portland, Oregon since 2005. There's something in the water in this town which makes it feel brand new and exciting every day that I wake up, and keeps me making tiny changes to my routine whenever possible.

      I studied linguistics in college, but quit because I hate classrooms. I used to speak fluent Mandarin, but about all I can do now is order at restaurants, and that's only provided the staff doesn't speak Cantonese. I game (I refuse to believe it isn't a viable verb) way too much for my own good, and think about it perhaps throughout 60% or so of my conscious life these days. I even frequently blog about it, among other things. I was even blessed by my parents with nerdy initials. Thanks to my fantastic roommate Bethany, I am now also a gigantic Resident Evil fanboy.

      - NPC
    • daw65
      September 2008
      I'm Dave Wilson. I've been a lurker for some time, registered here for a month (as of my typing this, of course). My first RPG experience was TSR's Top Secret, given to me and my brother back when we were in high school by my mom's boss, though I don't think she had a clue what it meant. AD&D hit hard my junior year in high school, and I played through college. Also played Star Frontiers, and a homebrew sword & sorcery game written by the brother of one of our players. Upon leaving college, I drifted away from role playing.

      20 years later I'm big into boardgames, and listening to board game podcasts, and start listening to Have Games, Will Travel. Thanks to Paul Tevis, I get curious about RPGs again, though I find I'm pretty weary of the sword & sorcery schtick. I still haven't played a role playing game since college, but I'm hoping to get a group started playing Primetime Adventures soon. I've owned the game for 15 months; it's about time. I also have a coworker interested in Dirty Secrets; we'll see what becomes of that. I'm seeing a number of other games go by that look really interesting, but I'm going to work with what I have first.

      At this point I have some interesting restrictions on my gaming:
      - Week nights only. This restricts the length of individual sessions, because I still need my sleep for work the next day.
      - Minimal prep.
      - No swords & sorcery (as mentioned above).

      I'm on the west coast of the US, SF Bay Area (Tri-Valley, for those familiar).

      Anyway, there you go.
    • akooser
      September 2008
      I am Ara Kooser. I am 33 years old.

      My mom bought be the Red Box D&D when I was 10 years old. The summer before that my cousin had introduced me to the white box D&D and car wars (black box).

      I went to a liberal arts college in Illinois and graduate with a BA in chemistry. My career sort of followed this path: Lab tech - chef - physical chemistry grad student - DOE worker - high school teacher - and now back to grad. school for Geomicrobiology (I get paid to play outside).

      I am an avid runner and outdoorsy kinda guy. I love kitties and I have several. I also do photography and play a cigar box guitar.
    «1…6789101112…15»

    Comments

    • jlarke
      September 2008
      I'm surprised to realize that I never posted here.

      I was born in 1972, which makes me 36 as I type this. I've been happily married for four years now. My wife is a professor of education, and we have a ten year old daughter together. I got my BA in philosophy and political science, decided that working in either field professionally would be awful, and went into IT instead. Now I manage a team of UNIX SAs, which means I'm doing politics anyway. You can't escape your destiny. Somewhere along the way I decided that moving was bad, so I still live near Ann Arbor.

      I've played lots of different games, with varying levels of frustration. I played a lot of Amber in the nineties, which led me on a course from "wow this diceless thing is TOTALLY GREAT" to my current passionate dislike of the Amber DRPG system and the idea of diceless gaming in general. I was stumbling around from bad idea to bad idea when I discovered the indy / story games scene and immediately sensed that there was something there I wanted to check out.

      Aside from RPGs, my main interests are computers, airsoft, and the Eve Online MMO.
    • Aaron Hamric
      September 2008
      Aaron Hamric
      Age: 25
      Sex: Mannish
      Occupation: Art Student/Game Designer
      Location: Lee's Summit, MO
      Credits: Playtesting pretty much everything ever made by Clint Krause, including his terrible games in high school(Ask him about losing to me every time in Wrath of the Axis) . Most recently I have playtested Clint Krause and Amy Garcia's Empire of Dust, and Chris Perrin's Messiah and Mecha games.
      Current Projects: Brainstorming several different delightful games with my buddies at KNRPG. http://www.knrpg.com/

      I play a little bit of everything, from D&D to Wushu and everything in-between. Personal favorites include Savage Worlds, Rules Cyclopedia D&D and Aces & Eights. I also like to collect obscure and/or "bad" rpgs. I have in my collection, World of Synnibar, F.A.T.A.L, Fantasy Wargaming, Ghost Dog the Roleplaying Game (how's that for an obscure license?) among many others.
      When I'm not doing homework, doodling or playing video games, I'm attempting to learn guitar and write songs so that one day, my dreams of rock-stardom may come true.
    • Simon_Pettersson
      September 2008 edited September 2008
      I realized I still hadn't posted in this thread, so I thought I, y'know, ought to.

      Name's up there, I'm a Swedish engineer of 24 years of age (keeps rising, though). I've been hanging on the Swedish RPG site rollspel.nu for years, under the username of Genesis (I thought it was cool when I registered. Hell, it even used to be something like ".o:~Genesis~:o." ...). I'm in the process of publishing my first game, in Swedish, called Oskrivna blad (Unwritten Leaves), which is a prepless, world-building-and-then-playing-in-it game with a narrativistic bent and no GM. There's also an expansion in the works, called Historiens vingslag (something like Wings of History), where you play through the history of your game world to givve it awesome depth.

      I've been enjoying RPGs since forever, and the indie scene since I discovered it. Been lurking on Story Games for yonks, and now I've come into the light.

      EDIT: Also, I do kung fu, historical longsword fencing, medieval festivals, language learning, and planning on going into diving and/or hanggliding. Not enough time ...
    • Ignotus
      September 2008
      In the spirit of lurkers coming late to this thread:

      My name's Sam, and I post infrequently. I'm 21 (for the next few days, at least), have a BA in the history of science, and work for a small non-profit in DC. I've met and gamed with several regular posters on this board at Dreamation and Gencon over the past few years (it's an odd sensation, being introduced to someone you recognize from lurking on a forum...)

      I started playing RPGs in middle school with Shadowrun 2e. One day I bought My Life with Master after Steve Darlington reviewed it on RPG.net and it was all downhill from there. I own a lot of games both trad and indie (too many to fit in my current apartment...), and have played a fairly large subsection of them. These days I game via Skype to keep in touch with my college friends. Currently it's just D&D 4e for me, though I have fantasies of starting a PBEM Burning Empires game.

      I'm new to DC, and in addition to settling in have started fiddling with electronics and (soon) learning krav maga. I have also recently rediscovered the pleasure of reading novels for my own enjoyment, and just finished Spook Country, by William Gibson. Next up: Living in Little Rock With Miss Little Rock, by Jack Butler.
    • jaw6
      September 2008

      I'm new here... My name's Joshua, I was born 29 years or so ago in Ohio and have since lived in Virginia, North Carolina, Missouri, Wisconsin, Toronto, Germany and, now, Utrecht, the Netherlands. I'm a web developer, my wife is an astronomer, and has lately been responsible for moving us around (they say I'm "portable"). We have two great, english-language gaming groups here, though one seems to be in long-term hiatus.

    • John Adams
      September 2008 edited September 2008
      I love this forum feature.

      I am John Adams (no relation) and I live Central Mass. I grew up in Melrose, Mass just north of Boston. I GM'd my first dungeon when I was 10 years old (D&D Blue Book!) so that's about ... 29 years of gaming.

      I'm a software engineer for IBM and I've been involved in all phases of development: coding, testing, tech support. I never set out to be a computer geek, it just sort of happened.

      I'm a music major (voice) from UMass Lowell and I conducted a community chorus in N. Reading for several years. I'm currently "between gigs" thanks to my two little boys Benjamin (2 1/2 years) and Zachary (4 months) who keep my free time to a minimum.

      In the middle of all this I've been delving into Story Games and working on my first serious attempt at publishing an RPG.

      I keep dragons:
    • psibreaker
      October 2008
      My name is Simon (or 'Si'). I'm 34 and living in the UK.

      I spent about 30 years of my life living in London, and following a brief stint in Brighton moved up to Chester with my girlfriend, where we had a boy. 4 years on and we're now moving back down to London, where we'll be having another boy.

      I'm a graphic designer, ocassional artist and writer, fan of horror, dark sci-fi and dark humour. I'm mostly into Call of Cthulhu at the moment, but am just getting into forum-based games in anticipation of leaving behind a whole bunch of gaming buddies in Chester, and not having a great deal of time to make new gaming buddies in London before settling into a routine of sleepless nights.

      Here's 20 questions answered (and slightly amended) from one of those forums:

      1.Character name? (ah, not really relevant to this site)
      2.Vanilla or chocolate? Vanilla
      3.Cats or dogs? Cats
      4.Real name? Simon
      5.Location? London, England
      6.Age? 34
      7.Occupation? Graphic Designer (though mostly type-setting at the moment)
      8.Favourite book? Short but weird compilation The King in Yellow
      9.Favourite film? Tough, tough, tough... Sometimes it's Company of Wolves, sometimes it's Natural Born Killers, although, no, recently I've loved Pan's Labyrinth.
      10.Favourite type of music? I'm caught between rock, dance and jazz. I appreciate a good dancey rhythm, or clever lyrics, or something with a bit of swagger. Over the last five years I've seen a variety - Red Hot Chili Peppers (supported by James Brown!), Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds, Nine Inch Nails and Faithless.
      11.Favourite food? It's all good... :-)
      12. What’s on YOUR mug? It's a work mug. It makes clever use of the company initials (RY), to spell out recovery. With a graphic of recharging batteries (as you get on mobile phones) on the other side.
      13.Tea or coffee? Coffee at work, tea at home.
      14.Favourite sport? Football. In the back garden. With my son.
      15.Favourite perfume/ eau de cologne? Whatever it is I'm wearing now, that smells slightly of cinnamon.
      16.Favourite colour? I always like colours that contrast, so it's hard to pick one. I usually wear blacks, but like vibrant reds and deep blues.
      17.Last album you bought? Dig! Lazarus, Dig! (Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds)
      18.Last film you saw? Hot Fuzz.
      19.Favourite comedian? Ricky Gervaise is very funny. Always used to like Bill Hicks, but I've been over-exposed. More recently I got into Dane Cook, Lewis Black, Demetri Martin and Mitch Hedberg. It's very hard to pick any one favourite.
      20. How's the weather at yours NOW? Bright but cloudy.

      EDIT: Or sunny. I may need to keep updating this...

      I have a cat. It's not in the same league as a dragon, but I think he needs convincing.
    • Wood
      October 2008

      I have a wife and two -- soon to be three -- children, and I live in Wales.

      I write for a living. I edit a magazine, and I do a bit of journalism. A lot of my writing has been for a games company. That is all.

    • Doug Bonar
      October 2008
      I admire the stamina of anyone reading this far in.

      I'm Doug. Had other names on other boards, but never posted enough that people are likely to recall them.

      I'm 42 and have been gaming on and off since 1977. It amazes me when I think how long that's been. :) Started with D&D (blue box). In the early 80's, it was AD&D, a bit of Traveller, Champions and trying to make up rules for giant robots. Now it is mostly reading, a regional con occasionally (mid NJ), and some bi-weekly D&D. I would love to get some BW/BE play in, but since I don't drive my ideal gaming locations are somewhat limited.

      Work is IT on Wall Street. I don't think I'm evil, and I don't think Wall Street is evil. I don't really want to hear it if you do 'cause that's usually not a productive conversation. Sort of like arguing over which programing language is better only with even more emotional involvement for many people. The upside of the work is it can be fascinating, and it pays well. The downside is the general perception of Wall Street.

      Other interests are pretty stereotypical. Reading (history, old pulps (neo pulps much less so), fantasy, some sf), board games and cooking (especially bread). I do a bit of carpentry very occasionally, but don't really have the patience. No kids and no pets, neither my wife nor I are found of having dependencies we need to be responsible for.
    • croute de sel
      October 2008
      Hi all,

      I’m Lou from Vancouver, Canada. 32 y/o. An avid gamer since the age of 10 or so. I found my way here through the podcasts Stabbing Contest, Independent Insurgency, and the Sons of Kryos.

      By day I repair the machines of my corporate master. There are occasions at night when I transform into a musician.

      I love gaming because it puts my thoughts in order. The world is chaos and the ability to systemize it is a great asset. By playing a scene we equip ourselves with the knowledge of what could be.

      My gaming has been stagnant lately. It seems that everybody wants to do the same thing all the time. I’ve had a bellyful of killing and looting under a vague premise. Wealth and violence aren’t the only motivations in life, right?

      There are some games I need to write. I’m always hacking and tinkering to no good end. What a waste of time. Tried Game-Chef last year but I was all over the place. Frustration seems to be an aspect these days.

      I can say with confidence that I have played HoL and Sorcerer at the same time. Hopefully this will be less disastrous but equally fun.
    • Kropotkin
      October 2008 edited October 2008
      Hey all--I've been lurking for a while now, but I recently started posting a few things, so I figured I should actually introduce myself. I'm 36 years old. I've a Masters in Creative Writing, and I teach English composition at two community colleges in Southern California. I'm happily married, and we've got a little girl who I'm home with in the daytime (I often teach in the evenings).

      I enjoy reading and we've got lots of books. I've got lots of sixties and seventies science fiction and fantasy in paperback. I also like nineteenth century lit--particularly the Romantics and the American Renaissance writers, and I read lots of comics and graphic novels as well as lots of other pop culture stuff.

      So yeah I'm probably a fairly typical example of an English teacher (if you can see past my Clash t-shirt).

      That's All For Me
      Nick
    • elliott20
      October 2008
      I'm Elliott, as you can see from my brilliantly creative and original username.

      Despite what my username suggests though, I am actually not 20, but rather am at the ripe age of 27. I am project manager working for a cable company abroad with my wife and our 6 month old daughter.

      I'm Chinese American, while my wife is Jewish, which resulted in our daughter having a 5 word full name, and already all the guilt she's going to be able to handle for a lifetime.

      I was introduced to the indie gaming scene primarily through the indy gamers I met in the North VA area, which includes Mel White and a number of other posters here.
    • fskn
      October 2008
      Hello, Story Gamers.

      My name is Ricardo Pante. I'm 33 now, and I live in Sao Paulo, Brazil. Caucasian, most of my family is from the alps in northeastern Italy. Tutti buona gente. ;D
      I'm a graphic designer working mostly with webdesign and animation for ten years now. I got interested on RPG design since oh so long ago, but never took it really seriously until a few years back, when I began studying them, reading whatever I could get my hands on that was related to RPG theory and game design in general.
      I've been playing them since 92, when I bought the black box D&D on a comic book shop. Some years after that I got in contact with quite a few different systems through a friend who's got a really huge collection of gaming books, but my knowledge of them was very superficial. Maybe I still know a lot less than I'd like to know of them, but having known different systems and reading John Kim's RPG design patterns, articles at The Forge, and designer's notes that were already inside the books but that I used to skip made me broaden what I think RPGs are in essence.
    • Burgeri
      November 2008 edited November 2008
      I am Ville Vuorela and my lair, shared with a long-time girlfriend, is in Vantaa, Finland. I design computer games for living but as for my hobbies, I am Burger Games. I have played roleplaying games for 25 years and written five of them, Miekkamies, Taiga, Mobsters, Praedor and Stalker. Of these, Mobsters is probably my most famous title outside Finland. I have also written two (and soon to be three) books. There will be more.
    • No Love Orchestra
      November 2008 edited November 2008
      I'm Kalle, twenty-odd years, a Finnish literature major. I'm into my fourth year in the academia and currently interested in the study of narrative, the fantastical and short story form. I also write and work as a part-time freelancer. I was introduced to roleplaying just six years ago but the obvious connections between the hobby and my other interests prompted me to get curious and later reasonably well-versed. I game rather infrequently at the moment and don't have enough time to pursue writing as much as I'd like, but I always have a project or two in the burner.

      Some of my favourite games are Primetime Adventures, Zombie Cinema and Theatrix.
    • Brad_J_Murray
      November 2008
      Brad J. Murray, 43 as of this writing, and an ill-educated jack-of-all-trades. I like pretentious typographic tricks and multisyllabic words. I used to be an arrogant dick but I got better. Currently I work as a researcher in the automated transit sector, specialising in operating systems, tools, and security. I get tense when I ride a train with a driver on it. My gaming life started in 1977 or so with D&D with Traveller rapidly following. I only turned hippy in the game scene around 2006 and the pendulum still swings back. I game weekly, though most sessions are design and tinkering with our current project. I am in love with one of my players' recent ideas about narrative authority context, especially his idea that there is a "table" context for authority. This is now driving our design.

      I don't smoke (except a nice cigar every now and then) and I drink expensive scotch or (absurdly) rum. I have a parenthesis fetish that results from my colleague editing out my em-dashes. I am married to a wonderful woman that I lived with for 10 years first. We exchanged titanium rings in June of 2008, witnessed mostly by gamers in suits. Our games are usually ORE (Reign) or Fate (increasingly home brewed).

    • Adrian P
      November 2008
      I'm Adrian Price, 33, been living in the UK about 3 years now, originally from Papakura, New Zealand. I've met maybe two or three people who post here in person, otherwise you're all anonymous internet creatures to me.

      I am currently a civil servant, although I've changed jobs a fair bit, and I studied History at uni (ended up with an MA, thesis on medieval history). No kids, not married (yet!), other than the UK I lived in Japan for 2-3 years, teaching English at a Japanese high school.

      Been roleplaying for ages now - 23 years give or take - and mostly play indie games these days, although the actual gaming is more sporadic lately as I'm yet to find a local group to meet up with regularly.
    • Wolfe
      November 2008
      I am Lance, and I'm shocked to find I've never replied to this thread.

      Scene Framing: Lance sits in a room just larger than 10' x 10' in a folding camping chair in front of a makeshift desk that is actually a large trunk. Scattered across the desk are various DVDs, a 30-round M-16 magazine, and two picture frames, one digital, containing pictures mostly of his wife and son, and of course his laptop. The rest of the room is subdivided by two wall-lockers, with a low bed on either side, both of them covered with army-issue poncho-liners rather than proper bedsheets. His rifle is propped up in easy reach to his right.

      Non-Gaming Interests: Absolutely nothing. I'm kind of one-dimensional like that. More seriously, I'm into reading (fantasy fiction) computers, programming, the SCA and my family.

      Life, the Universe and Everything: I'm 29, and I've been a soldier in some form pretty much my entire adult life. At this time, I am an army Staff-Sergeant, serving in Iraq, and I tend to assume that everyone knows that already, even if they don't really know me. I've been to two GenCons, the second of which was spent almost entirely in the company of indie/story/small press game designers and players, and I still feel like an outsider. I've got three games that have been "in development" since Adam turned to Eve and said "Nice going." Two of them have been in playtesting stage since the flood. I'd confess to having a problem with procrastination, but I can't be bothered to do that right now. Despite this, by tomorrow morning, I'll have finished writing my first novel.

      The most important things in my life right now are my wife (Rhonda) and my 1-year old son (Orion), whom I am sporadically watching via web-cam as I type this.
    • Raphael Sadowski
      November 2008 edited November 2008
      My name is Raphael, 24.

      I'm from Poland, "where roleplaying games grow on trees". At least the half-finished, homebrew ones.
      Oh yeah, we really love fantasy, games and stuff. Especially talking about them. We like to talk.
      It's much worse with the design though. With so many self-created game designers, we should already take over the world. At least the world of table top games. But here, everything ends on a concept. I doubt that you'll find one game you know from Poland.

      Enough with this. Back to me.

      I am a game designer with ambitions to become second Gygax. Period.
      So yes, I'm not a very humble person.

      I've been roleplaying since I was 10, and before that I have been creating little board games for me and my friends. Since I knew RPG I started creating my own games, one of them, my favourite project should soon see the networtk sunlight for the first time. After I finish this, nothing will stop me from creating dozens of board games, RPG's ad mixtures. And the world will finally be mine, as it should.

      Other things that I'm interested in are:

      media
      commerce
      psychology
      theology
      languages
      antropology
      concept art & design
      video games
      writing

      I'm getting married in next year. And I'm doing everything to become a profesional game designer, who will earn money by doing what I really dig. And a writer. I definitely want to be a writer.
    • JMcL63
      November 2008
      John McLintock, 45, single, bipolar and unemployed, but doing OK thanks to Britain's social-democratic welfare state. New to the site, I thought posting here would be a good way to announce myself before doing some lurking. What else can I add? I read, a lot. Thrillers and crime dominate my fiction fix; politics and history- WW2 especially- my non-fiction. I'm a bit of a foodie and I'm trying to develop a gym habit. That's me.
    • Alvan
      November 2008
      Petri, 29, from Finland. A graphic designer / programmer / computational linguist / North American studies major at the moment.

      I'm one of those people who swear by the "there is no reason to adjust my game to fit a system if I can design a system that fits the game" vow, and the games' rules have been going into more and more story focused direction of late. Gaming-wise I'm currently dividing my interest between making a coherent and enjoyable Urban Fantasy setting and getting the rules we're using for the heist campaign I'm running written to an understandable form. As far as street cred goes, been playing long (almost 20 years), designing systems for about half that time, tried to stay below the publishing radar and just keep my own gaming groups happy.

      Can't really remember how I found this place, but been pretty much actively lurking here all year. Just never got around to writing this post. :)



    • David_Berg
      December 2008
      My handle is my real name, I'm a devoted ultimate frisbee player and a rabid Mets fan.

      I am 30, do some programming and art for money and fun, like astronomy, have studied karate and taekwon-do, and play/design/discuss RPGs. So, clearly I belong here.

      I grew up in Ithaca, NY, attended Vassar College, and have lived in Brooklyn, NY for the last 8 years. What else... heterosexual white male, allergic to nuts and fuzzy animals, thin, goateed, right-handed, wears orthotics, enjoys jam-band jazz-rock and metal. Decent rapper, poor guitarist.

      I've known about Story Games for a long time, but I found the Forge first, and the Forge is enough of a time-sink for me that I've been wary of letting other fun forums into my life.

      I'm mainly here to spout my design goals and get advice on how to achieve them. I'm happy to reciprocate.

      I've enjoyed the indie games I've played, but my personal design aspirations run more towards traditional-style RPGs at the moment.

      I've had a great time hanging out with the few people here who I've met in person.











    • ElectricPaladin
      December 2008
      I'm new here. My name is Mark Simmons. I'm a 25 year old out here in San Francisco, California, though I'm originally from Brooklyn, NY, and I went to school in Oberlin, OH.

      I live THREE lives:

      In life #1, I'm a fledgling internet marketer working for a tiny company in Palo Alto, California, that makes educational card games about art and earth science for kids. I have no business experience, no relevant degrees, nothing but an increasing interest in web marketing.

      In life #2, I'm a hebrew school teacher in a medium-sized Palo Alto synagogue, Congregation Etz Chayim, where I teach 4th graders Jewish history. Unsurprisingly, I take a roleplaying/acting approach, where I use questionnaires to guide my kids to create characters who could have lived at various epochs of Jewish history, to give them the feeling that they were actually there. I'm the cool teacher. I have no dignity whatsoever.

      In life #3, I'm a writer. I have one finished freelance job to my name (with White Wolf) and another unfinished (with Greymalkin Designs). I also have a blog - http://burningzeppelinexperience.blogspot.com - where I talk about writing, gaming, writing games, and the game of writing (that's pretty catchy).

      I've been roleplaying and storytelling practically since I was born. Some of my fondest, earliest memories are of "running" freeform adventure stories for my little brother as we walked our dog around and around the block. That dog got a lot of walking, and we saved the world more than a few times between the two of us.

      These days I mostly run one-on-one for my girlfriend, but only because it's hard to find people to game with on a regular basis. I'm always on the lookout for people to one-shot with, though, so if you're in the area and have some free time, drop me a line. Who knows, maybe something will come of it.

      ElectricPaladin is my handle pretty much everywhere. If you see an ElectricPaladin on rpg.net or livejournal, it's me, and you can follow me on twitter, too, under the same name.

      Into rpg's, miniature gaming, designer baggy pants, zombie flicks, kung fu and hot chicks.

      I've been doing rpg's since about age six, thanks to my older brothers. Started with Miekka ja Magia (a Finnish simplified Basic D&D, pretty much), am now GMing 3:16.

      Never one for indie gaming before ("The elitist swine can keep to their Forge-manufactured high horse"), I'm now finding that there are a fair few nice games around. Lurking here does that to you.

    • lachlan
      December 2008
      I'm lachlan, aka lachlan99 at http://redesignmadness.wikidot.com , aka aquitane at http://aquitane.livejournal.com I've been gaming since 1970 or so, and discovered RPGs in 1978 (the little brown books of D&D and later the little black books of Traveller). Since then I've mostly played RPGs, with the occasional boardgame thrown in. I discovered The Forge and this site a few years ago, but have mostly lurked. I want to change that, which is one reason I joined the "redesign madness" challenge. Besides gaming, I also write a lot, mostly fantasy fiction, and have a fine collection of unpublished novels.

      During the day, I'm a mid-level government IT manager, where my degree in psychology and my language skills (I speak English, Geek, and Bureaucrat) serve me well.

    • graypawn
      December 2008
      My name is Andrew. 28 years ago i was born in the twilight of a foggy backwater world. If there's a bright center to the universe, this was the realm it's farthest from. Alone from an affliction of daydreaming and a strong addiction to creativity i was left mostly to myself, save when someone stranger to me witnessed one of the pages i'd been scrawling images on, intent on pestering me to find out what super-hero it was.

      I was known, in my hometown, as someone of a worthwhile imagination. This gave my allegiance to several meta-geeks and dork lords that formed a rather impressive rebellion against the tepid lives of the midwestern kingdom that i would soon abandon. In the ages before my sages of Gaming introduced me to strange sided dice and color images of scantily clad elven women i was merely a practitioner of the pencil and a worker of words, though never have i completed more than a short story, or finished more than a comic book page. I came into Gaming while in training under DRDrake, Lukas Myhan, and Adam Cottingham. And ever since i've grown away from my first loves and fallen deeply for the artform of story-games.

      Back home we have a few Nintendo's hooked up to the electric-generation-machines. But we don't use them much; we're not Gamers like that. And we've heard of the vast communication tools rumored to exist within an "inter-net." But we don't much concern ourselves with that. So, when i had come of age, the town elders gave me a sturdy mule named Betsy, and sent me away with a sacred relic of theirs: An Apple iBook G4, capable of an impressive 12.5 minutes of battery life, when removed from it's electro-matic umbilical cord. I took these things, and a pack of many hand-written Games, and traveled the long distance from a life of arcane adventures to the wet world of the foggy Northwest. I came here to make coin and, when i'm not working for food, to train under the gurus listed as masters of The Forge. I am, simply put, seeking a sifu.

      I am, by trade, a minimum wage warrior. I've completed over 200 credit hours of college, but nobody wants to cash in my chips for a single degree. They don't like it when you cobble together a smattering of interests instead of following a curriculum. I drive that same mule, Betsy, a '77 Chevy Impala, though she is tired still from our journey here. And i work now for a Reprographics company, driving a PT cruiser to various wonder-land destinations throughout the Emerald City. And if i had interests outside of Gaming it would be unraveling the mystery of on-line forums, Playing Pretend in other useful ways, and waring with modified Nerf guns. My fiction is Sword&Sorcery, but i'm fine with good, adventurous s-f. If i had to pick one, however, i'm not elitist enough to hang my poor head and mutter..."comic books."

      But the big mission is simple: I want to make the world a better place. And the only tools i've got to do that with are simple stories and Burned-CD-soundtracks. So, finally, i'm here. Steered to this URL by the same masters of the Gamerverse that i sought out. And, with any luck, we'll make a world brighter than yesterday.
    • Lynne H
      January 2009
      Hello!

      I'm Lynne, growing older by the minute, former research scientist turned college lecturer with a fairly long and eventful association with roleplaying. Current location - north east of England, warping fragile little minds in the field of biomedical science.

      I've played a variety of RPGs since I was at university, table-top and live. I've demo'd games for WOTC (Talislanta, back in the dim and distant past) and Pelgrane Press, play-tested bucket loads of stuff for several companies, written for Nightfall Games (SLA Industries, under my maiden name) and Pelgrane (Dying Earth, under my married one).

      I also design textiles and have an alter-ego in Second Life. It is roleplaying of a kind, at least the way we do it.

      This place came highly recommended, so I thought I'd pop in and see ;)

During the day (and most evenings and some weekends), I work as a disaster recovery engineer for one of the larger banks in the US.       My name is Jonathan McCalmont, I'm 32 and I live in London.

      I have an academic background (philosophy and international relations mostly) and I currently teach but I think of that as my license-plate stamping day job as I spend the rest of my time thinking about being a critic. I'm primarily a science fiction critic regularly published in places like Strange Horizons and the SF Site but also branching out into dead tree (haha) journals such as Vector and NYRSF. However, my interest in science fiction is starting to sag and so I'm scaling back my activities in that area in order to concentrate on writing about films. I also have a regular column at Futurismic.

      I'm 22 and graduated in the summer of 08 with a Computer Science degree. I'm currently looking for work and trying to avoid reading the business pages for The Guardian.
      While I search for work and consider getting a masters degree I am attempting to write science fiction stories to various degrees of success.
      I also have an open-source project which I should be looking after.

      I love mountains in all their rock climbing, fell walking and snowboarding greatness and wish I could live away from the mostly flat area of the world I live in.
      I once lived in Switzerland for a year and miss the city of Basel very much.

      The games I like to play ideally have a strong focus on a single idea or theme and attempt to explore them.
      The games I love to play get everyone at the table fired up with energy and hopefully draw the attention of spectators.

      My name is Hans Otterson and I'm 24. I live in a fairly nondescript smallish city just north of Seattle, WA USA.

      I have my B.A. in Studio Art (drawing, sculpture, photography, etc.) from Whitman College in Walla Walla, WA.

      I work with severely disabled high school students (Autism mostly).

      I am planning on going back to get my M.Ed. and a teaching certificate to work in special ed.

      I would really love to teach art at the high school level someday.

      I lived on the Yakama Indian Reservation for 2 years. That place takes up a large portion of my heart.

      I have never really roleplayed, aside from GMing a few sessions of D&D 3.5 for students I was working with, and playing one game at D&D gameday 2008. I have a large amount of knowledge of what's happening in roleplaying right now, and almost zero experience.
    • MJ Harnish
      January 2009
      My name is Michael Harnish. I'm 37 and am an ex-pat living in the NRW region of Germany. I grew up in upstate New York and got my B.S. in Psychology from Clarkson University. My M.S. & Ph.D. are in Biological Psychology are from the University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center. I worked for a while in the clinical sleep medicine field (research and treatment) but got really burnt out on the stress and pace so I gave it all up and moved to Germany where I now teach psychology at the International School of Duesseldorf. I love my job and get 14 weeks of vacation a year too. :o)

      I've been gaming for more than 25 years at this point, having started on Star Frontiers, 1st edition AD&D, and red box D&D. I went nearly a decade without any face-to-face RPing (I played largely via PBeM and forums) but in the past couple years have finally assembled a good group that meets a couple times per month. I also still run games online via Fantasy Grounds 2 software which is a great way to meet and play with people around the world. Nowadays most of my gaming involves indie and small-press RPGs although I do run a weekly 4E game for the kids at the after-school gaming club I run.

      In the past couple years I've finally started working on some ideas for RPGs I've had floating around in the back of my head for a while: I hope to publish Kidz (a RPG about meddlesome kids, mysteries, and adventure) in 2009 and have two other games (Desperate Measures & Behind the Music) currently in development.
    • HiQKid
      January 2009
      Hm. I'm going to be honest, here.
      I'm Alex Davis, but I rarely use my real name online. I'm 19 and live in Rhode Island, where I've lived all my life.
      I'm probably the closest here to a "negative gamer stereotype". I'm neurotic, have almost no friends or acquaintances, and continue to run and cater to a gaming group I don't particularly enjoy because I'm desperate for some form of social interaction.
      It is not all down, though. I'm going to a local technical college for an Information Technology Associates, and possibly a Bachelors. I don't particularly enjoy the school, but I do enjoy working with computers (particularly programming, which I've done on and off for a while), so hopefully I'll get a job doing that after school.
      Currently I'm employed at a convenience store; it's not particularly good because between the pay rate and lack of working hours, I usually barely pay tuition. I'm looking for a better job, but lack of transportation makes that difficult.

      Religion-wise I am... well, I don't really have a name for it. It's a bastardized form of Christianity, though. I don't really believe in organized religion.
      Politically... I'd say "disillusioned", maybe? I don't trust any politician or government. I guess the best way to describe me is a lazy anarchist / jaded dreamer.

      My gaming history... A friend introduced me to Magic: The Gathering some 6 or 7 years ago, now. I began going to M:TG tournaments at a local game store, then was enticed by the owner of the store to join an ongoing DnD game.

      It was horrible. I kept going because I liked the idea of roleplaying, and I liked a few of the people (maybe 3 out of 20).

      Eventually, the DM of that game (a pretty decent guy, even if I didn't like the game he ran) left to serve in Iraq. He left the game in the hands of his "protege" (in reality just a friend of his) who rarely showed up, showed up intoxicated to the point of being unable to run a coherent game, and ran horrible games even when sober. Eventually he just stopped showing up, so my friend started running a game. It was awesomely silly.

      Eventually the original DM returned from his tour of duty, and my friend was unable to continue DMing at the store... The owner felt that he no longer needed "amateurs" when the Original had returned. So we brought it home.

      Since then, I've played in a variety of D&D campaigns and an occasional World of Darkness game. I've run D&D and Exalted campaigns, and have attempted to run other games to a variety of effects... Unfortunately, most of my players don't seem to have a great interest in RPGs as anything other than "Show up/Play a game/Goof Off/Have fun"... Probably in what might be called "Beer & Pretzels" gaming, except they aren't old enough to drink (most of them). That's fine for them, and I don't mind it as something to do, but I must admit I would like a little bit more... My idea is to run a sort of low-commitment/pickup game of D&D as well as a game running closer to my tastes, but I've been having trouble finding players.

      I personally have an interest in Indie Games / Forge Games / Story Games, as well as RPG theory and discussions. I've begun to work on designing games, but I find it difficult to commit without support / people to bounce my ideas off of. I've toyed with the idea of finding new players. However almost all of the gamers I've found online are in very traditional D&D/WW mindsets (If anyone reading this knows of any people/groups in RI, let me know please). I'd try to introduce other people to RPGs, but... I don't really know any other people.

      Outside of RPGs, I listen to a pretty wide variety of music (Alternative Rock, some Punk, Indie, Folk, Light Rock, Hip Hop [both "real" Hip Hop and Nerdcore, but not much mainstream or what's on the radio], and a bit of other things depending on mood) and read a wide variety of books (History [I'm fascinated by the Russian Revolution and the Three Kingdoms period], Historical Fiction & Alternate History, Spy Fiction [Occasionally. I need to read more.], Young Adult Fiction, Fantasy & Sci-Fi, Graphic Novels, and whatever else looks interesting at the time).

      I don't watch many movies, as I find the idea of watching movies alone to be depressing. I do watch TV, particularly Burn Notice, The Shield (when it was on. I miss it), Sons of Anarchy, occasionally food and travel shows, and the rare anime.

      I used to enjoy playing with legos, but find I don't have much time to dig through my pieces and do much lately. I play video games, but I'm definitely not a hardcore gamer. I play Magic, but only casually from time to time. I'm interested in learning how to play music, but I'm too broke to afford any sort of instrument right now. I mess around with GIMP image manipulation from time to time, and occasionally make custom character sheets for games. I love reading the internet, especially if I'm finding out random might-be-true facts. I like to read blogs (esp. gaming blogs, but others on occasion), and I've got two of my own. I write crappy poetry and read good poetry.

      I don't smoke, drink, or do any drugs and I don't intend to. Even prescription & over the counter medicines give me the willies. I was a Boy Scout for 9 years, and I'm an Eagle Scout. I try to take that pretty seriously in how I act and think, in terms of honesty, loyalty, respect, and general decency.

      I could go on. If anyone's curious about me, just whisper me or something and ask.
      Goodnight, all.
    • Robert_Bohl
      January 2009
      Hey Alex! Welcome to Story-Games. If you want to get sucked back in to Legos, and you want to have a use for them, check out Vincent Baker's Mech-Lego wargame, Mechaton. Joshua AC Newman (designer of shock: social science fiction and fellow Rhode Islander), Vincent, and I are going to be playing a Dunelike campaign of Mechaton soon and I'm super-excited about it.
    • Andrew M
      January 2009
      I'm Andrew Morris, from Lancashire, England.

      I have been roleplaying since I was a teenager back in the 80's. I am not a game designer, excepting a prototype card game about house sharing, which plays quite well but never ends. I am interested in roleplaying design, but I am a rubbish GM, so stand no chance of getting anywhere with this.

      I am currently writing up my thesis in, river flood simulation. This thread is one of my many displacement activities.

      Other displacement activities include the Palestinian cause. In fact the reason for writing this biog now is to put out an appeal for people to support Gazan aid efforts, without spamming the main threads with non-gaming material. These people have just been through some serious shit, and emergency relief will save lives.

      There are many organizations working on the ground including the red cross, red cresent, human relief foundation, care, interpal, human appeal. Interpal are based in Manchester, UK and their website is http://www.interpal.info/
    • Rune
      February 2009
      Hi there folks

      I'm Rune B Reinås from Trondheim, located in the middle of Norway. I'm 33 years old and have had roleplaying games as one of my main hobbies for about 20 of them. I have a teacher and special pedagogue education, and currently work with children and young people with learning disabilities as well as physical disabilities. I also work some evenings helping run youth clubs in the area, where I teach band, gamemaster roleplaying games and run other activities.

      In addition to rpg's I enjoy lots of other "geeky" hobbies such as miniature wargaming (40k), comics, and literature as well as my other main hobby which is music (both as a collector as well as playing the drums myself). I'm interested in, collect, and listen to almost all rock and metal related music as well as some jazz, fusion and classical music. My main interest however is in progressive, fusion and technical rock and metal from the 70 and up to the present. I try to get to as many concerts and festivals as I can each year.

      I have a special interest in collecting Scandinavian rpg's especially Swedish games (as the Swedish market has been the biggest in Scandinavia).

      Usually I get in a couple of rpg sessions each week, and are currently running a campaing in "Drakar och Demoner Trudvang" (a fantasy setting with a strong Nordic and gritty feel) and Mutant (a Swedish post-apocalypse meets "The Wind In The Willows" game). As well as being a player in a Earthdawn and Dark Heresy campaing.

      Recently my group had it's first encounter with Indie-rpg's as we played a session of 3:16 and enjoyed it immensely. I have since ordered a few more indie games that I'm very eager to play.

      I look forward to contributing, and learning from the veterans here.

      Cheers
      Rune
