    • Bercilac
      February 2009 edited February 2009
      Hello all,

      I'm James, 21 years of age, from here and there. I grew up in North Haven, Connecticut, a boring wee suburb. My first exposure to role-playing games was "Secret of the Silver Blades", a giant-pixel computer game based on AD&D. I actually first played D&D when I was, perhaps, 15. My neighbour had a friend who DM'd a campaign for a while. I remember playing a Centaur Druid. I have a bit of nostalgia for the old AD&D rules, it must be said, and particularly the illustrations and flavour text the manuals used to have. I remember one disaster of a birthday party when I invited over ten friends or so, most of whom had never played, to try the special play-as-dragons supplement. When my regular DM showed up he was horrified that I was asking HIM to run the session (but agreed to). We spent most of the party trying to explain the rules, and played through maybe one encounter. Not many people had a good time. I felt embarassed because a girl I had a crush on was obviously HATING it.

      A friend (either at that party or later) got me the Players' Handbook, v3.0, for a prezzie. I absorbed the rules and before long was ready to run a session. I ran one with the guy who got me the book and his wee brar. I was going to run another at a friend's youth group (he was a Unitarian Universalist), but ended up getting into a fight with his youth group leader after he was picking on one of the girls there. I think he later got sacked, good riddance. I eventually ran a series of games with another friend, Chris, and his younger brother and friends. I even got my own brother to play the odd session as a dwarf fighter. Chris' younger brother was playing the barbarian, which I have called the "little brother class" for obvious reasons. My great triumph in this period was a dungeon crawl in which I drew a map of every room on paper, complete with grey shading for stone floors and little illustrations in various parts. It taught me the eternal value of props!

      I didn't do a ton of gaming in high school, just time to time, but I was definitely hooked. After graduating from high school, I went to St Andrews University in Scotland. I was originally studying medieval history (I LIKE KNIGHTS!) and international relations (I LIKE POLITICS!) but dropped both (I HATE MY DEPARTMENTS!) to study anthropology. I won't go into the details, but that degree fell apart due a combination of undergraduate hedonism, constant gaming, and student activism. In my second year of uni (okay, I'll go into some of the details), I lived with a magnificent ever-so-English (don't ask me what that means) fellow named Dave, who is currently finishing up his history degree. He was easy to convert to role-playing, and we both ran fun little campaigns that year. I also started experimenting with designing my own game, resulting in a project to create an Arthurian RPG that has gone through half a dozen permutations and is still ongoing.

      In my third year I lived with half a dozen other people in what can only be termed student accommodation turned hippy commune. Once again, no details, but you can guess why my degree started suffering. But I did get a lot of gaming done. I remember when a few of us were starting up, fiddling around with character sheets, and my flatmate Harry walked into the room.

      "Are you guys playing (snicker) DUNGEONS AND DRAGONS?" he gloated, with a huge grin.
      "Yes, Harry, we are. Would you like to play?" I responded calmly.
      (long pause)
      "...Could I?"

      Harry's a theatre/improv buff so he took to it like a fish to water. I give myself credit for his addiction. He, in turn, turned me onto a lot of the online gaming forums and blogs I now follow. We started to take games very very seriously. I ran a campaign called "The Green Isles" that year, in which the players essentially became pirates zooming around an archipellago, getting in drunken fights (mostly with each other), and interfering in politics without really thinking through the consequences. The style was mostly due to the HUGE size of the group, which probably reached 10 people in one or two sessions.

      The next semester, in my fourth year, I salvaged what was left of my degree, ran an abortive "Goblins" campaign (high rate of player absenteeism, not many sessions) and got the hell out of St Andrews. As I've posted somewhere else on the interwobs, dividing up the dice bag was one of the saddest moments of my leaving.

      I'm now at the University of Melbourne studying a Masters of Teaching in Humanities and History, so I guess even lazy students can make good. I found a gaming group before I even landed in Australia, and thoroughly enjoyed the first session. I'm working through a few ideas before launching my own campaign. In gaming, I would like to explore FUDGE, Call of Cthulhu, role-play and simulation in classroom learning, and of course some day finish my Arthurian game. After D&D, my favourite game is Stalin's Story, though I don't recommend it if you have interpersonal shit going on in your gaming group.
    • Gregory
      February 2009
      I'm Gregory. A hick from a factory town out in the mountains of North Carolina, was ripped from my little piece of the world to Great Lakes Illinois. Now a Fireman in the Navy, awaiting orders. I got bored, and got back into roleplaying. I remember when I was a kid, I would make up little adventures to play with my sister. I only knew the rules of DnD from watching the tutorial on their website, and I didn't have anything but D6's. I was a better DM back then.

      Few dudes want to play with me in my barracks, so I mostly just create things. Dungeons for Labyrinth Lord, some weird Gurps thing where the players wander about a cave complex and are attacked by monsters created from their memories, and a TON of stuff for the Princes' Kingdom, which is now officially my fave RPG ever. It's a huge beautiful campaign lovingly crafted from the folklore from my native Africa and Japan. Oh yeah, I was born in the Congo and am part of the Kusu tribe. Don't bother Googling, we're tiny.

      Hey y'all.
    • Ninesling
      February 2009
      Hey Y'all, I have been lurking here awhile, but since I met so many of you at Dreamnation I figured I would make my presence known. My name is Sarah, I am a 31 year old single mother of 4. I live on Lawn Guyland and I own and operate my own adult entertainment company.

      I have been gaming most of my life but am new to the story gaming scene. Several of my Nerdnyc friends convinced me to give it a go and I am really enjoying myself.

      I went to college for music and still play several instruments including the bassoon, bari sax and piano. I also enjoy sailing, hiking the greenbelt trails, cooking and following my Metsies.
    • JLow
      February 2009
      Hi, everyone. I'm Julie Lower. Some of you know me as "Jeff's wife from the Sons of Kryos [gaming podcast]." Others might know me as "that really tall chick." Or perhaps both.

      Anyway. I'm 29 years old. I live in the People's Republic of Ithaca, NY ("10 square miles surrounded by reality"), home of Cornell University and lots of hippies, wineries, gorges, and water. OK, it's Middle Earth. This is my hometown. I have lived here for almost all of my life, other than the six years I spent in Phoenix AZ, Fort Jackson, SC, and Fort Polk, LA (yes, four of those years were on active duty in the United States Army and no, I didn't go to Iraq).

      I am a Registered Nurse in our local emergency department. It is the coolest job in the entire world. Incidentally, I went on a ride-along with our ambulance company, and asked the driver (who had been a paramedic for about 5 years) when he eventually got tired of "running hot," e.g., with the lights and the sirens. He turned around, smiled, and said, "never." Exactly. Everyone's been speaking about spirituality on this forum so I will share this: the reason I became a nurse is because I see being exempt from Iraq as a gift from God, and this is my repayment.

      I am currently getting my Masters of Science in Nursing online through the evil cyborg company University of Phoenix.

      In terms of gaming, I started in a local LARP at 16, where I met my awesome husband, Jeff, on the very first weekend. He was an elf named Arnon "Tree" Drader, and I was an NPC orc. It was love at first sight. He beat me down with foam swords and we've been together ever since. My very favorite role-playing game is Primetime Adventures, although I also like Cat, 1001 Nights, Dogs in the Vineyard, and Polaris. And most of the con games I've played too. I've met some wonderful people through the indie scene. I love going to cons like Dreamation because for a weekend, I am surrounded by the most intelligent, creative, friendly people I've ever met. I've been to three cons total: Dreamation 2008, GenCon Indy 2008, and Dreamation 2009, and have gamed with some truly awesome people at all of them.

      Which is why I'm finally on this forum. You guys are the best!

      -Julie
    • Robert_Bohl
      February 2009
      Hooray for Julie's presence! Hi, Julie. Sorry I didn't get to hang out with you at Dreamation.
    • timeLESS
      February 2009
      Level 1 Feral Anarchist

      str: 9
      dex: 12
      Con: 9
      Wis: 11
      Int: 12
      Cha: anywhere between 3 to 18, depending

      Issue: staying human amidst the horrors of modernity

      Place: the Netherlands
    • jason
      February 2009
      I never posted on this thread? I should do that!

      My name's Jason Godesky. I have a name amongst primitivists for my old blog, where I often wrote about the history of civilization, and why it hasn't done much good, and why rewilding would make us all happier. I won't bore you with all that; I've written enough about that on the aforementioned blog, so if you want to know how I could possibly say such things, I'll just direct you there. I met my wife, Giuli, in that context (we just tell people "we met at anarchy camp"), and we share similarly unusual aspirations for our future, which was already a hard match. Add things like her complete collection of Monty Python's Flying Circus on DVD, and you start to wonder if such a thing as fate really exists.

      I make my living currently designing web courses for oncology nurses, from an office in Pittsburgh, PA, where I grew up. I had an intense faith in Catholicism once upon a time, but I left that behind long ago. Now, I think "animist" describes me best. I don't know if that really counts as a religion, though; my animism looks more like David Abram's phenomenology, the animism of Graham Harvey or Stephen Harding, bioregionalism, or Tim Ingold's "dwelling perspective." I don't particularly like where I find myself in life these days, but I'll accept it as a stepping stone. I want to live in the woods one day, with a small, sustainable community, and hunt, fish, gather and garden for my food. So to that end, I study things like primitive skills and permaculture.

      But I find that the skill most commonly cited by functional native people also receives almost no attention from my fellow primitivists: the skills of keeping a community together socially, through collaborative storytelling and oral tradition. I've studied that problem a lot, and I've come to the conclusion that story games provide incredible tools for regenerating oral tradition. I have a game that I work on called The Fifth World that I hope will aim directly at creating that kind of tradition. I know lots of people consider my fascination with RPG's a sudden, radical departure from my older work, but I see it as just the next step on that journey.

      I know some of the people here; Willem and Timeless, I know, come from a similar background as mine. I got to play some Polaris with Mr. & Mrs. Teapot (unfortunately, they live on the other side of the city, so that became untenable).
    • Omar_Ramirez
      March 2009
      Hi! My name is Omar Ramirez.

      I'm 22 and was born, rised and still live in Guadalajara, Mexico.

      I've a 33 years old girlfriend with three kids (two girls 13 and 11 and a boy 9)

      I study Animation and film making at Guadalajara International University and work as a comic artist at FABLE Story Studios (I don't draw the current comic shown in the web page). And also teach a course on digital Illustration and photo manipulation.

      I've been into RPGs ever since I was 13 and have always been very fond of GMing. I've only recently heard the term "Story-Games" but realized I've been acting on it's principles since the very beginning.

      So yeah... Pleased to meet you all!
    • Dan Eison
      March 2009
      (I guess my posting here is somewhat belated, but better late than never...)

      "Dan Eison" is not just some cool alias I cooked up for the internet, it's actually my name-- I know, it's crazy, right? I'm a recent college graduate who studied history of science for four years before realizing that I want to be a doctor. I'm currently in a postbaccalaureate program taking all my pre-med requirements at once and pining for the days when I was allowed to write long papers about historiography instead of toiling in the hypothesis mines of lab science. I'm a literature-junkie who takes frequent hits of theater, and I once directed a production of Macbeth set in the old west (my favorite part may have been designing low-budget blood-sprayers that could shoot corn syrup clear across the theater).

      My college roommate (Ignotus on these boards) is responsible for my headlong descent into RPGs, after inviting a callower, more innocent me to a late night session of "The Mountain Witch." From there, it was on to "Dogs in the Vineyard," playing insane NPCs in his Cthulhu game, and my first Dreamation in 2008. By the weekend's conclusion, I was hooked, but it wasn't until Dreamation '09 that I discovered this enclave of story-gaming, and I look forward to making your collective acquaintance.

    • vulpinoid
      March 2009
      I thought that I had already posted to this thread, but a quick scan indicates that I haven't.

      Hi, I'm Michael Wenman, and I'm an addict.

      I've been roleplaying now for 20 odd years, and GMing for most of them, with over 15 years GMing at local conventions and gradually developing a number of roleplaying systems that have seen limited use in LARP settings and a few tabletop groups in the area.

      I live in Sydney Australia with my wife (who I actually met through roleplaying), and with our dog Okami.

      Last year (2008) at Gencon Oz, I released my second roleplaying game "The 8th Sea". The first "Platinum Storm" was released in the mid 1990s in the form that has now come to be known in certain circles as the ashcan (photocopied A3 pages stapled down the middle and folded into a 40 page A4 booklet).

      As my facebook profile says, I'm a Taoist Christian with leanings towards Zen and Kaballah. I've spent a decade studying kenjutsu and far too long delving into patterns of human religion and consciousness. I'm hoping to tie it all together some day in a revolutionary idea that will shake the world (or at least the roleplaying community).

      I'm always open to new ideas and new interpretations of old ideas, and I'll probably throw more than one or two ideas out there to people who might appreciate them.

      V
      (and I sign virtually every entry on every forum with a red V)

    • arkhamrefugee
      April 2009
      Introduction time is always one of those slighty nerve wracking moments. How does one really encapsulate who they are in a few sentences or a couple of paragraphs? The answer - one doesn't. But what the heck, right? I mean lurking doesn't get anyone anything except a big collection of dead electrons and lots of pages viewed on the counters.

      So the basics first. My name is Russ Matthews and I have manage to live 33 years without running afoul of a rampaging GM or jealous husband and thus getting myself deadified. Born in Texas, raised in Mississippi and living the majority of my 20's in Atlanta, I now reside in the beautiful city of Kansas City, MO because I wanted to see what actual seasons were like. I graduated from the Art Institute of Atlanta but not for graphic design, illustration or photography. No, you see I couldn't do anything in a straight-line fashion so I graduated with a degree in Culinary Arts Management. Which is rather like that degree in restaurant management that Sally Struthers used to shill on late night television, but with fancier verbage. Naturally, since Top Chef and FoodTV have conspired to make cooking and chefwork hip, there are a hundred thousand gomers just like me out in the world trying to get a job. Which brings me to my next paragraph.

      As of this writing, I am splitting my time between doing freelance photography work and developing a better creative portfolio. One of the things I do is photomanipulation work, making all new images out of stock photos. In talking to my friend, gamera_spinning, I figure that the creative visual work that I do might find a place in the gaming industry. So here I am, looking to make contacts (maybe even pals!) and geek out about gaming. Like g_s, I am not a big creator of games, being happy with my position as a consumer and player of such pasttimes.

      For those who are interested, my portfolio site is russmattphoto.com and the digital manipulation section is here. If you are interested, my Flickr site is here and the obligatory DeviantArt account is over here.

      Looking forward to reading and commenting in the future!
    • whiteknife
      April 2009
      Hey. I'm Stephen Bretall. I live in Orange County, California. I joined the forum back in September of '08 but didn't post in this thread until now, for reasons unknown.

      I started RPGs back at the advent of D&D 3e. I've always tinkered with systems and I've actually made quite a few, but until about a year ago I wasn't ever interested in doing anything with them aside from using them myself. But I changed my mind and now here I am.

      I'm a full time college student (for now). So yeah. That's basically it (not that it's much at all). You can fill in the rest though- I like RPGs, video games, etc. etc. I love comic books and card games, I love using minis in games that don't technically need them, although I'm not a fan of minis games without any RPG in them.

      I'm the kind of person who would fill the rest of this post with supposedly humorous content, but I can't think of any at the moment so you'll have to settle for just this.
    • simjames
      April 2009 edited April 2009
      I missed this thread earlier.

      My name is James O'Rance and I live in Sydney, Australia. I don't recall exactly when I started playing RPGs, but my first convention was Necronomicon 95, and that was certainly a milestone. Played my first freeforms and systemless games that October, went to my first seminars, and broadened the range of games I was interested in.

      Since then I've run a freeform campaign, designed many convention scenarios and freeforms, converted a metric boatload of Dragonlance and Planescape 2nd edition materials to third edition back when we were still calling it "3e", dabbled with freelance writing for a would-be d20 publisher (this soured me on the whole "write for money" thing, actually - it was a lot of wasted time), run a convention (once was enough), and now I'm a karaoke-loving banker who doesn't have as much time for gaming as I did when I was a student.

      I still run games (currently a fortnightly REIGN game) and produce one to three convention games per year (this used to be up to four, some of which had 30-60 characters). I play RPGs quite rarely, though. I'll be at GenCon Australia in Brisbane this year, continuing with the SF thing I've been doing at the last two Sydney conventions.

      Hey Folks,
      My name is Seth Bashwinger (I am getting married though so I use what will be my new name Drebitko as my handle) and I am 21 going on 22 in sept of this year. I currently live in the Clifton Park/ Albany NY area, working as a quality monitor for a state contracted agency ACS. I am going to school for web development, and when I am not studying I am usualy tinkering with my game design or just chillin with my fiance.
      Regards, Seth Drebitko.
    • giullina
      May 2009
      This thread is so nice!
      I still don't know if I will be posting or lurking here (lurking is more likely) but I'll introduce myself nonetheless.

      I'm Giulia, 26, now in Torino, Italy.
      I've lived near Detroit for a year in ninth grade, then got back to my tiny hometown of 1600 inhabitants, 80 km from Torino.
      I've moved here in 2001 to study engineering and here I stayed. I was a volounteer during the Olympics and if anyone from Vancouver is reading, let me tell you this: take part in the Games. It's an experience you will never forget.

      I'm pretty loud when voicing my opinions and quite picky in my pastimes. I found that in the end I tend to spend time with gamers, which I find to be overall more interesting, educated and smart that the average person.
      My interests are quite varied and at times I fear the apartment walls will crumble under the weight of books and comics (at least, my boyfriend does - that's why we're looking for a bigger house).

      I side with ninjas in their everlasting battle against pirates.
      I'm longing to own my own top-hat.
    • Ralf
      May 2009
      Hi there,

      just a quick introduction since I started my first thread. My name is Ralf Schemmann and I'm living in western Germany (Siegen). I'm a historian by training, but lucky enough to work in the game industry, mostly as General Manager for ProFantasy Software, with the occasional bit of freelance work in map-making and web design thrown in.

      I've been role-playing since 1984, starting with the German standard rpg of "Das Schwarze Auge". I still play regularly (about once a week on average), partly with a group that was formed in high school and still contains several of the original members.

      Recently I've been discovering the joys of indie games and have been collecting and reading what I can get my hands on.

      Nice place you have here.

    • christoffer

      Hi!

      Been lurking long enough, so here comes a quick presentation. My name is Christoffer Lindström, live in Umeå in northen Sweden. I'm a libarian student, a relativly new father and a big fan of Morrissey (yeah! yeah!, birthday dancedancecelebration in a few days!).

      Between spending time with the family, trying to become a librarian and searching for holes in the schedule to do some gaming I'm working on a small game that at the moment goes by the name Best Days of Our Lives. It's a game about bullied kids, their dreams and goals and the way towards fullfiling these dreams.

      Well, guess that's all. :)

      Hello all!

      I've been gaming since late high school, so that would put it at around 17 years or so. I started with Vampire and the like, but lately I'm running two different games of Spirit of the Century and playing in a game of Don't Rest Your Head, as well as voraciously devouring my shiny new copy of Swashbucklers of the 7 Skies.
    • Tim Masiakowski
      May 2009
      My name is Tymoteusz Masiakowski (Tim in English). I also go by a nickname LiAiL. I'm a second year student of Photographic and Electronic Media course in Aberdeen, Scotland. I'm a photographer, filmmaker, DIY culture appreciator, community addict, game designer and conceptual writer. I write short stories and create plots for comics. I also do translation of varied rulebooks and comics. Systems I love: Kult, Call of Cthulhu, old WoD, Mind's Eye Theatre LARP system and many more. Can't wait to start discussion here :)
    • Tom C
      May 2009 edited May 2009
      I'm Tom Cadorette. I'm 45, and grew up in southeastern Virginia (the buckle of the Bible Belt). I'm a copyeditor for an online financial news/investing website, but I'm not a finance geek by any stretch of the imagination. I'm also a once and future secondary-school English teacher. Liz, my beautiful crafty wife, and I live in Alexandria VA, with Sophie, our incredibly smart and cute 5-year-old daughter, and our two cats, Brutus and Max.

      I also have two teenage sons (from a previous marriage): Zach, 19, who is currently exploring nothing as a career choice, and Hayden, 17, who just joined the Army and is in the 101st Airborne.

      I've been board and RP gaming off and on since the mid-70's. I'm an omnivorous gamer in that I'll pretty much play anything (at least once).

      I tend to be a literary and film snob, although I like to think I'm in recovery.

      I've edited some RPGs, and have a couple of writing credits in some others. I have an idea for a novel that has haunted me for nearly 20 years, but have not been able to make it manifest on paper. It refuses to let me be, no matter how hard or viciously I push it away.

      And I'm damned glad to be here on Story Games!
    • JAR
      May 2009
      I'm Josh Riley, and I'm a graduate student working on a Ph.D in Neurolinguistics (a subfield of cognitive neuroscience). I currently do cross-linguistic research on speech perception in healthy people (looking at electrophysiological processing differences between speakers of English and Amharic, one of the major languages of Ethiopia) and speech production in disordered populations (putting the finishing touches on an fMRI study of a patient with foreign accent syndrome). I'm spoken for, and live in the D.C. area. I've studied Arabic in Morocco and Egypt, done fieldwork in the Republic of Georgia, and missed several crucial years of my cultural development due to being in Britain.

      I'd like to do work with a more clinical focus, but we'll see how that goes.

      I adore travel - crazier the better. Turkey is one of my favorite countries in the world, and am currently plotting out itineraries for an overland trip from Istanbul to Kathamandu that I and my SO will take in a couple years.

      As far as gaming is concerned, I got my start with White Wolf stuff, bounced around the Internet White Wolf RPing scene for a number of years, then got to uni and hooked about 20 people (at last count) on White Wolf games via the medium of a long-running Hunter game. I've since become disenchanted with WW mechanics, but I still love the sprawling, baroque, borderline-incoherent settings - they're nice and messy, like real life. Wrapping up a game of a PTA version of Changeling: The Dreaming set in Baltimore that was entirely inspired by a single song.

      Glad I finally posted here.
    • konzack
      May 2009
      My name is Lars Konzack and I'm a game researcher from Denmark. I've got a Ph. D. in Multimedia. I've been playing role-playing games since the mid-1980s mostly pen-and-paper RPG. (I dislike the term tabletop RPG because it makes people think of miniature games). I've also written some articles on game culture, game analysis, and game design such as...

      Computer Game Criticism: A method for computer game analysis
      Sub-Creation of Secondary Game Worlds
      Geek Culture: The 3rd Counter-Culture
      Larp experience design
      Fantasy and Medievalism in Role-Playing Games (together with Ian Dall)

      Some of them have even been translated to Polish.
    • deadlytoque
      May 2009 edited May 2009
      I've been posting here for a while, but never got around to doing an intro.

      My name is Adam Drew. I'm 27, and I'm a criminal defence lawyer in Calgary, Alberta, Canada. I live with my girlfriend, who is a filmmaker; a roommate, who is an actor; two cats, two birds, and about a million books.

      I've been gaming for about 15 years, officially since I got Heroes Unlimited for my 12th birthday, but unofficially ever since I was old enough to realize that there were stories hidden in my Legos.

      I've written a few games, but nothing professional. I'm thinking maybe I'll publish them someday, but it's a ways off. My only "professional credit" is a playtest credit in Mouse Guard.

      I keep a LiveJournal where I post fiction I've written and also where I blather about games.
    • villum
      May 2009 edited May 2009
      My name is Villum Lassen, i'm 28, Danish and study Philosophy at Aarhus University, currently working towards my master's on expertise.

      I've been lurking here for a couple of years, since i got fascinated by indie games. I've been roleplaying for 15 years or so, and recently started fiddling with game creation again because i got frustrated with Earthdawn.

      At the moment, i play in a Call of Cthulhu campaign. I haven't gotten round to actually playing much of that indie thing i got fascinated by, and havent been able to get the little bit i tried to sing.

      I also draw, and have a (intermittently updated) blog where i put drawings up for your appreciation.
    • Stigg
      May 2009
      Hey everyone. I kinda skipped this part.

      I'm Pete Cornell, I'm 40, single dad and special educator. I will be hopefully working towards my BSN in the fall. I'm a good friend of Judd's and I've met a couple of the people on here at various conventions, although I'm not sure they'd remember me.

      I'm running a retconned Against the Giants for a group and I'm playing in a SotC game, a BW game, and occasionally a Cat game (which I take a turn at running).

    • Doc Halloween
      May 2009
      I will just cut/paste what I have on my web page: "http://dochalloween.50webs.com/FAQ.html"

      I was born in 1969 as a Gemini male. I weigh 175 lbs. and I am 5 foot 8 inches tall. I have brown hair and green eyes. I have Autolycus style (a short thin mustache and small triangle soul patch) beard.

      I have lived near the peaceful Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia all my life. I loved to move to the West Coast (Washington, Oregon, or Alaska) or Canada one day.

      I am a Christian first and foremost. Without God and Jesus I would never have made it as far as I have. Many times I have asked for help and many times I was given it. I owe THEM my heart, soul, life, love, and service.

      A Native American I am. I am 1/4 Cherokee and 1/4 Blackfoot. My totem is Deer.

      Let me tell you about Deer that I follow. Deer is graceful, gentle, and sensitive. People with "Deer Medicine" are often described as being swift and alert. They are intuitive, often appearing to have well developed, even extra sensory perceptions. Sometimes their thoughts seem to race ahead, and they appear not to be listening. Just as the deer bounds from one place to another, a person with Deer Medicine often moves quickly from one situation to another, often never staying long enough in one place to get a "full meal."

      My hobbies vary depending on the mood I am in. I love building web pages as my biggest hobby. I have been building them for 10 years. I play computer games (mostly war games). I read fantasy and sci-fi paperbacks. I also enjoy going to the theater to watch a wide variety of films except sub-titles.

      Professionally I am a social worker. I hold other degrees in architecture, drafting, and mental health.

      Favorite Color................Purple

      Role Model....The late actor John Wayne and my Paw-paw

      Favorite Music....New age, Techno, New Swing, Bluegrass, and Big Band, 80's, Native American

      Favorite Radio Station....Q99 FM Roanoke, VA Best 80's, 90's and Today's Mix

      Favorite TV Station....WDBJ 7 Roanoke, VA

      Favorite Movie....Radio; The Family Man; The Village; Crash; and just about any World War II movie

      Favorite Book....Shadowrun novels and Forgotten Realms novels; lets not forget the Holy Bible

      Favorite RPG....Word Mill's "Mythic Role Playing"; Atomic Sock Monkey's PDQ "Zorcerer of Zo"; PIG's "Coyote Trail"; PEG/GWG's "Savage Worlds"
    • Artillery_MKV
      June 2009
      Hello all!
      I'm Kevin Reid-Rice. I turned 41 the day of this post and have been gaming since I got the 1978 edition of D&D at the tender age of 10. I'm married to Aimee (14 years this November!), and I have two sons (Spencer & Quinn). We share our abode with 4 cats: Rupert, Murdock, Eartha Kitten and Xena, Warrior Kitten.

      I grew up in Massachusetts (several places, all near Worcester), got to attend my first Gen Con when it was still held at Parkside. I went to college at UW-Madison (long story), decided I loved Wisconsin, got married and stayed. Now I do Real Estate work for the State of Wisconsin. (see what an English degree can do for you kids?)

      I have GMed my entire gaming career, playing on occassion, but always more comfortable behind the screen initiating mayhem. While I've written a few articles here and there my gaming claim to fame is a distinct lack of it. I've basked in the glow of folks who will be remembered for good or ill for years to come, and counted them my friends, and been enriched for it.

      Now I'm running a 4E camoaign, but my heart still belongs to Amber Diceless.

      And a word of warning: All you Gen Con posers can step off, a Gen Con outside Milwaukee ain't no Gen Con at all. Word.
      (And if that's not ridiculous coming from the 41 year old white nerd, I have no sense of irony left at all!)
    • E
      June 2009
      I'm Evlyn Moreau. I am recently 34. I live in Montreal. I studied in arts and in anthropology.
      My first language is french.
    • Jeremy Keller
      June 2009
      I've been posting for a little while here, I should finally introduce myself. My name is Jeremy Keller. I'm 34. I live in Minneapolis, MN. By day I work as a graphic artist and animator for a video productions company. Besides Minnesota, I've lived in California for 3 years, Colorado for 3 months, and Concord NH for 3 days. I recently returned to school and completed by BA in English. I'm now considering various post-grad options.

      I've drawn a comic book, written 4 feature length screenplays, produced and directed two short films, programed the base graphics and networking code for an MMO, but all of those are just sitting on the shelf now. I have had my poems published in local journals, and I'm about to publish an RPG that I wrote.

      Nice to meet you all.
    • the cat
      June 2009
      I am Justin Jackson. I grew up poor in the streets of Burlington Iowa. It was there I learned about my love for Roleplaying. Being able to become someone I wasnt was not only a way of escape it was a way to cope with being one of the "have nots". I eventually learned to enjoy playing the game for more than just being a way to escape and it is now more a hobby than a escape hatch. I am 23, I ended up in debt going to college and now am working to try to pay it off. I am currently trying my hand at creating my own game.
    • Chairman
      June 2009
      My name is China Pittenger, I'm 35 years old and live in Aurora Indiana. I lived in Florida from 2001 till November 2007, and couldn't be happier to be back in the rolling hills of my home state.

      I'm a stay at home mother of three children, Raina (8), Aiden (5) and Xander (3). I spend way too much time on the computer, but hardly any time on the television. I tend to go from one obsession to the other, and haven't mastered the idea of moderation.

      Once upon a time I had a real job at a real company, I'm quite a people person and pick up thing easily. Now, I run a website and write with peers to give me that social aspect that I miss so much, and that sense of pride and accomplishment. So, my time nowadays is spent between Sponge Bob and trying to master Drupal.
    • Antiquitus
      June 2009
      Hello!

      I'm Julian Michels the Narrative Psychologist.

      I'm 22, and a graduate student at the University of Oregon. I'm a Story Now! designer and a psychological scientist. By day, I research and study how people learn and think and especially why they tell stories (including their mundane, everyday stories), and how these stories impact their identities and lives. As far as I know, I'm currently the only researcher examining collaborative story production, but my work is gradually becoming more well-known and I hope to see the creation of a thriving sub-field and a scholarly literature on this topic over the next ten or fifteen years.

      I organize and try to expand the small community of narrative gamers in Eugene, OR. I make fairly regular trips to visit with the GoPlayPDX community, and I love Indie Hurricane and GoPlayNW. It's really exciting to be in my position, because within the design community I can be a psychological expert and within the psychology community I can be a narrative expert, and because I feel that both fields have much to learn from each other. It's fun!

      I also practice martial arts and synthesize my own style of swordplay, based in 13th-century Italian Fiore dei Liberi but with influences from Aikido, jiu jitsu, and other sources. I instruct some folks in it locally, casually. I fill the time that's left with hobbies, like acting, dramaturgy, writing, composing, and collaborating with folks from dozens of different creative disciplines.
    • lord_goon
      June 2009
      I'm Mark Silcox. I'm a junior professor of philosophy at a four-year commuter university in Oklahoma, USA. I'm the faculty sponsor for my school's Chess and Games club, which to my delight has become a veritable haven for overworked pizza-addled D&D and WOD fanatics who use gaming as an escape from the rigors of academe and from their crummy recession-era student jobs.

      From 1998-2002 I worked as a freelance writer for a couple of commercial computer game companies, producing interactive dialogue scripts for the MMORPG EARTH AND BEYOND and the Nintendo 64 game AIDYN:CHRONICLES: THE FIRST MAGE. During this period of cheerful poverty, I was also hip deep into the interactive fiction community and published a couple of IF games online. They're still out there, somewhere, echoing in the virtual void.

      Having just turned forty, I have decided that my mid-life crisis is going to revolve around a vast increase in the quantity of gaming in my life. I've been the Storyteller a very large WOD chronicle on campus with fourteen player-characters since February of this year, and I've just joined the local Camarilla. Out here in the boonies, it's hard to find that many folks who are willing to experiment with the more open styles of narrative gaming popular in this forum, but I've had a few wildly successful sessions of PANTHEON with some of my more intrepid game-clubbers, so I live in hope.
    • anansigirl
      July 2009
      So this awesome, smart, and talented community forum has become my obsession this week. I suppose I should introduce myself!

      I'm Kira Scott. First and foremost, I'm an artist. I work in metals and glass enamels creating jewelry that I sell about town, on the web, and at craft shows. I post about my artwork, jewelry, and all my thoughts about that good stuff on my blog that I update pretty regularly. I have a BFA in metals/jewelry/CADCAM from Tyler School of Art in Philadelphia, where I moved from 2 years ago to my current residence in Columbus, Ohio. Here I live with my amazing husband Travis, and our two cats Faustus and Mika. I'm currently 28 years old, and work at the Columbus College of Art and Design in the Admissions Department, where I advise students on their portfolio artwork and travel about the US spreading the good word about how awesome our college is.

      Also, obviously, I'm a huge geek. I love sci-fi, fantasy, comic books, movies, and gaming. I have a wide variety of tastes in gaming, most of them inspired by my artistic inclinations, and have been gaming since I was 15. I started out with the goth/punk Vampire, and my tastes have since evolved and grown, and still do with every new game out on the market. Currently, I love FATE (in all its forms), In A Wicked Age, 3:16 Carnage Amongst the Stars, WFRP, Monsters and Other Childish Things, Reign, Cyberpunk, Don't Rest Your Head, and Nobilis.

      I'm Tyler Tinsley

Last year I self published a game and was able to con someone into publishing it for me shortly after check out www.4kids.tv/bigbigbattles for more on that project. i plan to start self publishing again within a year and an rpg features prominently into those plans. so I'm hear to glean wisdom and to share what I know.

      i look forward to getting to know this group better

      My name's Don, I'm 32 years old and I study social sciences in Germany (yes, I'm old for a student).
      I've only just begun dipping my toes in non-mainstream RPGs, and, needless to say, I've read a lot of things/ideas on this site that I've never even heard about.

    • bevedog
      August 2009 edited August 2009

      Hiya. I'm Steve Lawson. I'm a librarian at Colorado College in Colorado Springs. I'm 38 years old, married, and have sons ages 7 and 4. I have a blog called See Also... where I write mostly about libraries and librarianship. I'm also pretty active on FriendFeed.

      When I was about 8 years old, I got the Dungeons and Dragons Basic Set for Christmas and started playing D&D and AD&D with my friends (along with Traveler and a few wargames). This is also around the time my elementary school friends nicknamed me "bevedog" (rhymes with Steve-frog), which has provided me ever since with a handle that is almost never taken when it is time to create a new online account. No one actually calls me bevedog anymore. Please.

      At about the age of 12 I stopped playing RPGs and tended to think of them as an important part of my childhood, but something I didn't really do anymore.

      Now, due to a combination of circumstances--including unearthing my old D&D stuff at my parents' house recently, my kids showing some interest, and meeting a lot of other librarians online who play RPGs--I'm interested again. I'm trying to play D&D 4e with my kids ("there is no crying in D&D!") and am hoping to start an online/email game of Mouse Guard with some more experienced gamer friends.

      I found this site because my friend Josh Neff recommended it to me, saying it was a welcoming community. So far, I have found that to be true.

    • Victor
      August 2009
      I'm Victor Wyatt. I've been a roleplaying gamer for roughly 30 years, at least I'm nearing in on the 30 year mark. For a long time I've stuck with the larger games in the world of roleplay. Recently, over the last couple years, I have found the indie games to scratch itches I never knew I had. There is such a diversity in the indie collection of games. At this point I buy and try out anything I can get my hands on.

      My first games were D&D (red box), Star Frontiers, Marvel Super Heroes and Call of Cthulhu. At this point I have so many games on my shelves that I couldn't tell you just how many there are anymore. And, as of this GenCon I increased that number by 11 new games.

      Due to the technology and skill visible in the indie games of late I'm attempting to toss my hat into the ring and create something of my own.

      My name is Gabriel Lopes Anaya, I´m 29 years old, from Brazil. I was born in Brasilia but now I live in Natal, warm and cozy coast city. I´m married with Katya and we live with a small shnauzer called Leela.

Also I´m working to get master´s degree in History and Spaces and finishing a specialization in work related diseases and work quality of life.       Now I´m playing Sign In Stranger with Katya and Shock: with some friends.But I´m eager to play many games more: Contenders, Breaking the Ice (try the Enemy Mine variation), try Polaris (now with four "stable" friends), try some activity with non-humans with Radiance, play A Flower for Mara, Sea Dracula, DRYH, 3:16...They are here waiting... I wish I had more time to play.
      Portuguese is my mother language, so I will do my best to write clearly in English.

      It´s nice to be here and share this stuff.

      When I was a student at the University of Hamburg, we had plenty of students older than you. Some of them had been going to college for 10+ years. That's what you get with a no-tuition, no-credit (i.e., no accountability) system Plus, of course, there are no Bachelor's Degrees--if you go to college in Germany, you're signing up for at least 6 years and end up with a Master's.

    • mjbauer
      September 2009 edited September 2009
      Hello all. My name is Micah J Bauer. I'm a married, Mormon, exCalifornian, graphic designer, BMXer, father of three, living in Springville, UT.

      Random Facts: (which probably make me sound more interesting than I actually am)
      - I once wrote a college essay entitled "I Hate My Hair and Want to Die."
      - As a kid I would pick up and save already chewed gum in my jeans pockets (to my mother's dismay).
      - I was invited to ride my BMX bike in the Vans Warped Tour in '97 after placing well in a jumping contest.
      - I had a Kindergarten painting hung in my principal's office (it was Superman planting the American flag on Mars).
      - My favorite movie in sixth grade was Iron Eagle.
      - I wrote and illustrated my own "Choose Your Own Adventure" novel at 9 called Fortress of Fear.
      - I Dressed up as an evil ladybug (complete with tutu) for my Halloween office party to match my daughter's costume.
      - I got second prize in a college poster design competition, which was judged by graphic design icons Seymour Chwast and Woody Pirtle.
      - So far, I enjoy designing games more than playing them.
      - I married a Canadian.
      - All three of our children's names unintentionally start with "H" (Harriett, Henri & Hazel) we are now expecting number four and aren't sure what to do.
      - I kept an online daily graphic journal of my life for a year in 2003-04.

      I'm excited to be here. Thanks for having me.
    • songsaboutrainbows
      September 2009 edited September 2009
      Hi all,

      I'm Anna. Although I've been a big huge geek for years, I had never done any sort of roleplaying until my boyfriend (Deliverator on these boards) first introduced me to the concept of story gaming. The first RPG I've ever played was Polaris, which is an...unusual start to say the least. Now, almost a year and a half later, I've played over 20 different story game systems and GMed/facilitated two.

      I graduated from Bryn Mawr College, just outside Philadelphia, this spring with a degree in anthropology, which means I can't even do something as mundane as grocery shopping without analyzing it to death. Although I love Philadelphia to death and wish I could have stayed around longer, I am most likely spending this coming year in Washington DC, doing health education work through AmeriCorps. (Or at least I hope so...I'll know for sure after tomorrow.) Although I spent a lot of time in DC growing up, there's still so much of the city I don't know...hopefully I can come to love it as much as I love Philadelphia and New York.

      When I'm not gaming, I enjoy wandering and getting lost in new cities, baking, folk dance (mostly contra and English, though I've done some Scottish and am open to learning new styles), singing casually, reading almost anything I can get my hands on, and knitting (rather badly so far, but I'm learning.)

      Like the above poster, I'm excited to be on these boards. Looking forward to meeting new people, and having further conversations with those I've already met at Dexcon and Dreamation!

    • ccreitz
      September 2009 edited September 2009
      I'm Colin Creitz, which explains the handle. I'm an Eagle Scout and a machine learning expert, but have yet to build a classifier system out of rope and sticks.

      The University of Pittsburgh is my alma mater; I got my degree in Computer Science and Philosophy there, and I consider myself a cultural Pittsburgher. No matter how long I live in Silicon Valley, and no matter how much I enjoy seeing the sun and being dry from time to time, I imagine I'll always feel that way. Every November, when it finally rains here, I get homesick in a way that requires me to watch a lot of football and eat pierogies and drink Sam Adams Boston Lager — made in Pittsburgh by PBC, the brewers of Iron City. When I open a bottle, I know it was capped at home.

      Now I'm 32, happy and married, and have two small and adorable boys. I took a break from gaming between their births, and came back to the hobby hoping to sharpen my skills for eliciting stories from them, so we'll never run out.
    • Morthrai
      September 2009
      I seem to have missed this thread as well, so I may as well have a go at it!

      Lee Williams here, from more or less the centre of England. I am a genuine 1965 vintage human male with no replacement parts (as yet!) :) I haven't really ever had what you'd call a career, just a succession of different jobs, The most recent of these has been working in a real ale pub. I started out as a schoolboy wargamer and have been into roleplaying since I first saw the original Traveller box set when I was about 14. One of my crowning acheivements as a gamer was destroying the entire world during the 1920s, in one of the Kult Of Keeper's infamous (and brilliant) multi-table games at Continuum 2006. I was a member of the Demonground magazine team for some time and am now one of the triumvirate in charge of Protodimension, another free horror gaming 'zine.

      As things stand, I haven't got a regular game running at the moment but I am keen on throwing my mates into 3:16 as soon as they take a break in their SLA game...

    • Sebastian
      September 2009 edited September 2009
      Sebastian Hickey. Twin. Zero psychic powers.

      I had the runs on Mount Doom. I met the secret police in Bangkok. I've been in love four times.

      I'm learning Krav Maga as research for my silly, stupid, spy game. I've been writing games since I was 7, which I'm told was a good little age. I want to be a generous designer. Please visit Cobweb Games sometime... But not yet... The artwork isn't ready and I want your first visit to be a pleasant one.

      I want a dog. A huge one.

      Also, I'm a 30 year old, Irish, ex-chef, in charge of tiniest games studio in Dublin. I've got a degree in Computer Animation, I worked in the video games industry for a few years, and now I try to write food politics for the slow food movement. I've lived in Greece, UK, Australia and New Zealand. I miss Argentina.

    • skinnyghost
      September 2009
      My name is Adam! I am a big nerd and have been for some long time. I have a dungeons and dragons tattoo. I am very proud of it.

      I don't really like to ramble on about myself, but here's some things I care about - I am intensely interested in human relationships and have a handful of them. I love my little brother and my girlfriend and the people I play games with. I work in marketing but only sort of (i'm a support tech for a CMS / Marketing Automation company). I take photographs and ride a fixed-gear bike and have a lot of fun with both.

      I've been vegan longer than I haven't and consider it a mere part of my life rather than something I am active about. It merely is.

      What else? I am friendly, or try to be. Clever, though not as much as I seem. What else is there to say? I don't know. I am short and blonde.

      September 2009 edited September 2009
      Hi. I'm Tazio Bettin, I'm 29 and I'm of the Leo, ascendant in Aquarius. I'm from Padova, Italy. It's a city close to Venice, home to one of world's oldest universities where Galileo Galilei studied the stars. I'm a Japanese language university graduate, I've been living in Tokyo, I'm in love with history and world's cultures. I work in the tourism world and can speak Japanese as well as Italian and English. And I have some basic knowledge of Sanskrit, and I've studied ancient Greek and Latin.
      I'm addicted to drawing and digital painting and of course roleplaying games. I'm a bibliophile and I prefer treatises over fiction, with the important exception for science fiction, which is my favorite genre. My favorite writer is Frank Herbert.
    • Zartes
      September 2009
      My name is Jarrah James. I was named after a tree by my mum's best friend.

      I live in semi-rural part of the state of Victoria, Australia. As yet, I haven't been bitten by anything poisonous or set on fire (although a wombat did once try to take off one of my fingers).

      I'm 21 years old, male, and have long-ish hair, a goatee, and glasses.

      I'm casually employed by the Australian Defense Force, Army Simulation Wing, but I'm not allowed to say what I do, except to point out that my job, while fun, isn't anywhere near as badass as that makes it sound.

      My life dream is to be involved in a musical in some way.
    • snej
      October 2009
      I'm Jens Alfke. I'm 44 and live in San José, California. I've spent my life simultaneously exploring and running away from geekiness.

      I was first exposed to RPGs via the old-school D&D box in high school, which my group quickly supplemented with the first AD&D books, the Arduin Grimoire and our own home-brewed rules. We didn't really "roleplay" as such, but we rolled a lot of dice and killed a lot of monsters.

      In college I gave up RPGs and explored real-life activities like socializing, punk rock, and having a girlfriend. OK, and lots and lots of programming (which means my parents got something out of their investment, as that helped me get jobs.)

      Once I had jobs I was still too busy for RPGs ... first with work and socializing, then with work and marriage, then work and raising small children.

      Now I would like to get back into this stuff. I've been playing boardgames off and on for a few years, and reading up on newer RPGs including Fate, Grimm, Risus and Burning Wheel. (No D&D though, please.) But I have yet to play any of these games for real, though I've just joined a group that's tentatively planning to start a Burning Wheel campaign...
    • ldd23
      October 2009
      I'm Greg Cooksey. I'm 31, live in Austin, TX, and write test automation tools for web developers. Ladies, I'm available. I grew up outside Chicago, moved to Madison, WI to study computer science and linguistics, eventually got a master's in computer science, and moved to Austin just about a year ago. I've picked up a coffee habit since I started working full-time in the software industry.

      I consider myself politically and religiously anarchist. I like Chomsky's politics, but not his linguistics. While I was in Madison, I volunteered with a radio news show on a community station, and I try to keep up with media activism.

      I bicycle commute and don't own a car, so it's really nice living somewhere where I can bike year-round.

      In my free time I play tabletop games, both RPGs and board/card games, and go to concerts & other performances. I'm kind of a music geek, but don't have the vocabulary or theory background to really talk intelligently about it. I mostly like instrumental music with an experimental bent, but have a pretty wide-ranging collection. I learned how to play violin when I was short, but I don't remember how any more. I'd like to learn again. I also toy with making electronic music every once in a while but have really just been a dilettante.

      I drank a glass of rum to celebrate the Piratepartiet gaining representation in the EU parliament.
    • Jim_Crocker
      October 2009
      Hi, everyone-

      Jim Crocker from Northampton, MA here. I am the owner of an independent comic and game shop called Modern Myths here in town. I have been involved in the book or hobby trade for my entire adult life, starting with a job at a used bookstore that put me through college, to experience with chain stores and even some work at the corporate level of one major chain. I've been an owner for some 7 years now, and it has been immensely rewarding. My degree is actually in theater, but that world proved too mercurial for my disposition, but gaming has been all I;ve really needed to scratch that itch over the last decade or so since I stopped doing any actual organized theater.

      I started gaming with D&D in the late 70s (first 'blue box' B&W edition) and have done so with only a brief 'nerd-denial phase late in high school until I met friends in college with the good sense not to care what other people thought of their hobby. Since then, I have played many, many RPGs mainstream to obscure, and have recently become very enamored of the story-form games that a lot of the very smart and talented local creators around here are involved in. I've had a few minor bits published freelance here and there, but I am here mostly because of my personal interet in this new form, as well as the professional angle of wanting to see where different part of the hobby are headed, and how it might affect my business.

      I'll be helping out the fine folks at JiffyCon here in Western MA next month, and hope to be more involved in that effort going forward.

      I'm married to a woman who plays RPGs as well, though definitely not with the same frequency as I. Early 40s, no kids, 2 cats, vegetarian, politics and religion abut what you'd expect from a child-free adult couple who've settled in Northampton.

      I'm looking forward to seeing the discussion, maybe joining in here and there if I can think of something cogent to say, and hopefully meeting some of you at Cons or game gatherings in the future.

      -Jim Crocker
      Northampton, MA
    • Maitresinh
      October 2009
      hello there

      i've been following the thread in the darkness for a while, through rss, and i suddenly decided to make my "coming out". My english is just (on not even) average, but i manage to understand what i need to. i'm from Europe / south of France, been living in Spain and married ( yes, i'm 3x years) with a south American, so i speak usually both languages.

      I've been a big rpg gamer in the 80's ( golden years or RPG ?), Coc & stormbringer were my favorite (as a DM and sometimes a player), but i've played many many more ( from paranoia to james bond, and a lot of french rpg). My last game was form 94, a Coc. As many gamers, while entering university, travelling, working and being away from my "group", i've been playing less and less, as it became "impossible".

      At the meantime, i've been playing light /eurogames boardgames from the early 90's, probably as a substitution. BG need no preparation, are short ( compared to RPG), and do not intimidate the non (RPG) gamers. Then i realize that i was enjoying only games with a strong theme....and possibly with a space for imagination, acting, roleplaying...

      For a bunch of years, i'm trying to synthesise all this and going back to the other way: a mutant RPG that could be used with non gamers, family, kids, and so on. I first tried to look for into boardgames and BG mechanism. then, i also discovered "indies" RPG and story gaming which impressed me a lot.

      So here i am.

      I' ve open a blog (in french) in order to list all games matching with these "specifications" ("cahier des charges") and make some experiment, trying to find the perfect game, or bring life to a new Frankenstein...

      Mon cahier des charges ( my "book of specifications")

      No workload for prep. and gaming
      - no prep fro the Master ( or hopefully , no master :everyone can play)
      - Short/reasonable time og game ( 45 min-2 hours)

      Opened to non gamers / do not intimidate them :
      - Strong mechanism (like boardgames) for those who cannot
      - Fun before all ! ( dice, bid, bluff..)
      - No obscure backgrounds

    • Michael Tangherlini
      October 2009
      Posted By: ccreitzThat is an amazingly cool niche. I know, way off topic for the board (hence the whisper), but: how does one go about finding viruses in deep-sea mud? What do they infect? Aren't they really hard to culture once you've retrieved them (if you do retrieve them rather than somehow study them in situ)?
      There are many ways to look for viruses within the sediments: checking for their DNA, staining them with some kind of dye to see them under a microscope and so on. They usually infect anything, ranging from bacteria to algae to even sea turtles. And yes, we can't yet culture them, but we can still study their genome.
      Posted By: ccreitzI'm thinking this is great background material for an adventure hook!
      Hope you can find it useful! Personally, I'm trying to create a boardgame about viruses.

      -MikeT
    • The Bunyip
      October 2009
      "My name is Michael Caine." Not really.

      My name is Ben Miller and I use the moniker _The Bunyip_ online in most places, including here.

      I'm 36 and live with my wife Marie and our 3 cats. Soon we'll be having a two-legged addition to the menagerie. I live in pretty much the very center of England and work in video-games software. I started roleplaying when I was about 14, dabbling briefly (doesn't everybody?) in D&D and then moving swiftly on to Chaosium games like Elfquest, Runequest and Call of Cthulhu. Whilst at University I pretty much stopped playing RPGs totally. Most of my friends had 'grown out of them' and I had other things on my mind like girls and drinking. After a hiatus of about, um, 8 years then, I finally returned to roleplaying and latched onto The Forge.

      Since then I've been trying to write various games but never actually got very far with any of them. Somebody always seems to have thought of a better way to do what I was doing, and the wind goes out of my sails.

      Like a few others on this forum it seems, I spend quite a lot of time thinking about where to take my creative impulse, but never quite acting decisively on it. I'd like to write a story-telling RPG someday soon, but I've learnt not to promise myself that because it always ends up in frustration.

      Hmm, that wasn't a very optimistic first post now was it?!

      Ah well...
      Hello everyone
      I'm Ben
    • Holmes!
      October 2009
      Well, I'll post here, since it's The Thing to Do.

      My name's Mike Holmes, but I go by Holmes! in all of my online endeavors, and my friends and colleagues all call me Holmes! in Real Life. There are just too damn many "Mikes" about!

      I'm a web developer for a living and a punk rocker by avocation; I've played in punk and hardcore bands for over twenty years, and I'm proud to report that I've never learned a scale... I also play folk and country music, where my musical naivete also puts me in good stead. I'm about to turn 37 in a couple of days, and I live with my partner, a gorgeous gal who's game for gaming, six cats, and a dog.

      I'm an active board gamer who reads about story games more than he plays them, though I'd like for that to change. I'm an aspiring board game designer; my last finished game is about Vaudeville theater owners, and I've got some in my head with punk rock and hip-hop themes that I'm hoping to get prototyped, soon...

      In addition to music and gaming, I'm a lover of comics. Comic books are cool, and I read 'em, but my first love is comic strips. I've been a Peanuts fanatic since I was a kid, but these days I concentrate on older comics as co-curator of Barnacle Press, an online repository of comics mostly dating from between 1900 and 1920.

      As far as RPGs and Story Games go, I spent my youth playing D&D like everyone else. I've also spent a lot of time playing Cthulhu and GURPS Cyberpunk. Though I own a lot of story game source books, the only one I've spent any playing time with is Primetime Adventures, which I absolutely adored and can't wait to play again. I plan on bringing A Penny For My Thoughts to the table tomorrow night at my regular gaming session, and I'm hoping it'll go over well. Cross your fingers for me; if it "takes", I'll be trying to get some other Story Games into the mix, soon...
    • Davide Losito
      November 2009
      Hello, this is Davide Losito, also known as Khana in italian forums.
      I am 34, soon 35. Playing RPGs since early 90s and I basically played all of the "major titles".
      I have eventually become a designer and my system named Fragma has just been brought to the public in last Lucca Games & Comics event, a week ago, as native system of the game Elar. The game is the ending phase of a 4 years "travel" that brought me from tarditional RPGs to modern view of coherent design. The whole book is product of a group of people who worked together to bring the book to the point it is now.

      About me... I am a philospher for passion and a web designer for work... that's because philosophy is cool but it doesn't give you any way to sustain your life.
      I am also part of Coyote Press, which is the third, small and last publishing brand of indie RPGs in Italy. We translated Covenant, Cold City and have Committee and Solipsist under work ^^

    • Sam!
      January 2010
      I guess after posting a couple of dozen discussions I ought to finally introduce myself. First the bio my agent uses for me:
      A Texas native transplanted to the Washington DC metroplex, Sam Hawken uses his background as an historian to inform his work. Such authors as Craig McDonald, Dave Zeltserman and Western Writers of America President Johnny Boggs have praised Sam’s writing in the mystery and western fields, and Sam has contributed short stories and essays to several anthologies and fiction periodicals under different pen names.
      For those who are curious, I've used probably ten different pen names trying to settle on good ones. I currently have only one, which I use to write commercial fiction aimed largely at women. Otherwise I write under my own name.

      So clearly I'm a writer and, yes, I'm trained as an historian, with my field being Jewish and Middle Eastern history. I've done work in the field, but jobs for historians without a terminal degree have become pretty scarce on the ground. I write full-time now, with two of my manuscripts having been picked up at the close of 2009 for publication in late 2010 or early 2011 (the wheels of publishing turn slowly). In the meanwhile I'm at work on something new. You can track my progress on it by following me on Twitter and reading my blog.

      Anyway, I've been gaming for thirty years, starting with D&D — because didn't everybody? — and moving largely into modern-era games like Top Secret and James Bond 007. These days I'm very much into the indie- and story-games movement, though I'm mostly just an enthusiastic amateur. In fact the only one of these types of games I have much experience with is Apocalypse World and even then I spend half my time wondering if I'm doing it right.

      I'm not a game designer, but I can talk about games and gaming until the cows come home. I spend entirely too much time chatting on #playnow, so if you're interested in continuing the talkity-talk drop by and let 'er rip.

I hope that satisfies the demographic data collectors?

      I've been gaming since starting with the D&D Red Box at 9, but only had experience with fairly traditional games until being introduced to Unsung by its creator in 2004 or so - though I have still never ACTUALLY PLAYED Unsung, which gives me great consternation as someone whose professional field is morality and warfare (with a particular focus on peacekeeping, counterinsurgency, and Africa). Oh well. Now I play, blah blah you don't want a list of my games.

      In my non-gaming spare time I cook and lift weights, usually not together. People who tell me they aren't "into" politics give me conniptions. I have two desks, both of which are very messy. I don't live in the part of Baltimore depicted on "The Wire."

    • Longspeak
      February 2010
      Hi all,

      I could have sworn I did one of these here back when I first joined, but I guess not.

      I'm John, from Seattle. I go by Longspeak or sometimes Longspeak Teller on most forums. The name comes from back when I demoed Everway for the Rubicon Rubes. The "Teller" family was the family in Everway who told stories to the people, so Rubicon's Tellers were the demo crew. Longspeak was suggested by a friend who observed that I sure like to talk a lot (sorry, it's not for "Longs Peak," though I've been asked a few times.

      I'm 42 for now. By education I'm a programmer and network guy, but I left that behind a long time ago for the world of numbers. If you need someone to help with your old Novell 3.12 network, I'm your man! Assuming I can actually remember any of it.

      I'm married to a gamer girl, have a gamer girl for a daughter, and my son is a console/PC gamer. Sometimes we sit around the table to play Settlers of Catan, one of the many versions of Cosmic Encounter, or Munchkin. Or Killer Bunnies.

      But role-play is my first gaming love. My dad bought my best friend the blue box of D&D for his 12th birthday. He said "I guess we should try playing it," and the rest is history. Over the years, my hobby has been a continual quest to simplify the mechanics and get on with the story. AD&D lost its place in my heart to The Fantasy Trip. TFT lost to Over the Edge. OTE lost to Everway, which was my staple game for about ten years. Then I found indie games and simpler mechanics gave way to more focused mechanics. I don't go in for all the theory, but I like a lot of what that theory has produced. Everway gave way to Pretender and Wushu (though in this case "gave way" doesn't really fit; I still play Everway), then to Polaris and Dogs in the Vineyard. There have been dozens more but those are the games I'm most fond of.

      I'm President of Dragonflight, a group in Seattle who runs a convention and operates a gaming club. We're non-profit for the past 30 years, dedicated to promoting hobby gaming (all sorts, not just role-playing).

      Outside of gaming, I love film. I particularly love watching, rewatching, pausing, rewinding, and discussing what we watch together. My daughter turned me on to theater when I discovered she is (in all objective honesty) the BEST ACTOR EVER. Through her eyes I've discovered a whole new form of entertainment I'd previously ignored (who knew before movies actors performed LIVE before AN AUDIENCE? Crazy. I especially enjoy small, independent theater, though one of the most memorable experiences we've had was a couple years back when she and I dressed up in our suits (pinstripe for her, classic black for me) and drove to Portland to see Spamalot. Sure, it was coming to Seattle later, but we didn't feel like waiting another couple of months.

      Near the end of 2009, I was overcome with ennui. I'd stare for hours at what had become my huge collection of games, unable to work up any excitement. After a lot of pondering, I decided the collection had to go. I would prune away the clutter and free up spaces in my head in the process. My new rule is "If I won't play it, or run it, use it for another game, read it, or enjoy it in some other way, I will not keep it." Since that decision, I've reduced my collection to a still largish library, and cuts continue. I've also rediscovered my excitement, so there's that. I still OWN too many books, but the unused ones are off the shelf and in boxes until I can find a new home for them. In fact, it's worked so well, I plan to try it in other areas of the house. Get rid of movies I won't watch again, books I won't read again, music I won't listen to again and games I won't play again. Simplify!

      Anyway, that's me. Happy to be back.
    • cathexis
      February 2010 edited July 2010
      Hi all,

      I already know some of you from the Burning Wheel forums, so this is only sort of like going to a support group.

      I'm Colin, am 27, live in the fair city of Seattle, and have been gaming for a while. In terms of schooling, I'm a proud Hampshire College Cognitive Science dropout and an equally proud University of Washington Information School graduate, and somehow managed to get a computer job in Seattle after only seven months of unemployment.

      I have a really bad habit of picking up games that look cool without thinking first if I have any friends who I can browbeat into running, since I get really stressed out when GMing. As such, I own several games that I'll probably never get to see in action. Of course more collaborative game play is a good way around that issue, but then I have the other problem of convincing enough of my friends that it'll be fun and work out. One of these days I'll make them see the awesome and then it'll be great.

      I also like long walks, pie, and my cat, though generally not all at once since she doesn't like to go too far from my house and then fur gets in the filling.
