    • YunusWesley
      March 2010 edited March 2010
      Hello hello

      I'm Yunus. I go by Taha Celestin on various games forums when I'm feeling pseudonymous and Yunuswesley on others when I'm not. 30s, married, PhD candidate in religious studies working with Islam, Buddhism, traditional textual/scholarly culture, and contemplative and esoteric forms of religion; presently living in Atlanta.

      I got back into gaming about three years ago. In that time I've run a short GURPS Lovecraftian conspiracy/horror campaign, the Call of Cthulhu "Masks of Nyarlathotep" campaign using Trail of Cthulhu, have played in some one-offs, and am now running a short series of Diaspora sessions.

      My current group is predicated on various of us taking turns as GM of different short runs of some game or other. Theoretically people other than me are going to be GM, but it's difficult not to keep obsessively pitching scenarios and games I'm excited about. GMing has always been my favorite part of the hobby, but time commitments do make it appealing to play instead. And at some point I'm very interested in trying GM-less things like Polaris or The Shab al-Hiri Roach... not least because I have some good gaming friends online with whom running something between the two of us seems more appealing than trying to rope in a third player for a traditional game.

      I was out of gaming since the late 90s, when I was finishing college. At that time I was totally fed up with role-playing. The logistics of keeping people committed to regular games was a huge hassle, and I was longing for a depth of story and character involvement I never saw, didn't know how to do, and basically gave up on then.

      The games I play in now *are* hugely fun and satisfying. Thinking about when i quit gaming, play now does not have the urgency I wanted then: I've gotten it elsewhere through life experiences that had nothing to do with rolling dice or taking on a role separate from the growth of my actual personality and inner life. But what we do now is much better than anything I was involved with in high school or college.

      A big part of the appeal of gaming has to do with creative outlet. I love to narrate scenes, particularly scenes of wonder or horror, that come into my brain from the ether, and I'm not interested (presently) with writing or illustration. So my recent love of Diaspora has a lot to do with playing world- and scene-building with setting mechanics. Examples of playing with the Diaspora cluster generation at memorypalaces.
    • elkin
      March 2010
      Hi SGers,

      My name's Alon Elkin. I'm in my mid-20s, a resident of Jerusalem (the one in Israel, not the one in Arkansas), a graduate student of linguistic, an antiquarian and a freelance translator (Hebrew/German/English). Aside from my fascination with roleplaying, I'm also an avid cyclist, and enjoy art, philosophy, beer and old obscure Hebrew texts (which I occasionally blog about).

      I started playing RPGs at the age of 12, and have been sporadically playing since. I don't have a regular group, but since there are plenty of local conventions in Israel, I get to play and GM quite a lot.

      I began playing with a simplified version of GURPS, and later, due to the lack of a regular group, switched to more single-session oriented games such as Paranoia and Kobolds Ate my Baby. I was a member of the Paranoia Online community in 2004, when a guy called Alan Varney came along and elicited the help of the online community for writing the new edition (Paranoia XP). When asked about the mechanics, he started rumbling about "GNS" and "indie game design sensibilities", which led me to the Forge, which ultimately led me here. I since had fun with some indie games - mostly InSpectres and IAWA, for which I've also translated some play materials to Hebrew; I've also enjoyed the more esoteric games by Zack Arston, MonkeyWrench and Adventures in Space!! whose texts I've translated entirely.

      My most important insight about RPGs is that I believe roleplaying, at heart, is a children's game, no different than others like hide & go seek. And just like hide & go seek doesn't get any less fun as you grow up (yet most of us stop playing it at a certain age until we have children of our own), so do roleplaying games. Sure, you can add sex, graphical violence, insoluble moral dilemmas and other adult stuff to your RPGs to make them more fun for you as a grown-up; this is akin to playing hide & go seek with paintball or airsoft guns and camouflage suits. At its core, though, the fun comes from re-engaging in child's play. Rather then reject this aspect of roleplaying and avoid the social stigma that accompanies adults who play children's games by claiming that the games we play are adult stuff for serious people, we should be proud of our ability, at our age, to continue engaging in the sort of activities that make children the creative little fiends that they are.

      Since coming to this realization, I've been teaching D&D to children at a local elementary school. I've also made myself a habit of GMing a game for children or teens at every convention I go to, and can all heartedly recommend these actions to any gamers who wants to invigorate their own regular play experience.
    • okiran
      March 2010
      Hey y'all. I just searched this thread and discovered I haven't posted here yet, and I've been a member since 2006. However, I'm mostly a lurker on these boards.

      My name is James and I earn my living as an elementary school teacher. I started my gaming life with 1st. Ed. AD&D. I played for a few years, then left the hobby. I came back to it in the early 90's with 2nd Ed. D&D. Played off and on through the 90's. Began regular gaming around 2000, continuing with D&D and some Hero system (ugh) and Paranoia.

      Then at GenCon SoCal 2005 Wick and Sorensen introduced me to indie games (Inspectres and Cat). However, I couldn't convince my trad gaming friends to try these new games. Finally, at GenCon SoCal 2006 I played Burning Wheel (and some other indie games I don't remember now). I met some indie gamers and wannabies, like me. I haven't looked back since. I've even convinced some of those from my old trad group to give Inspectres a go.

      My current group's main game is inspired by The Song of Ice and Fire using a homebrew system that evolved from Polaris. When someone can't make it, we play a supers game using the same system.

      Games I'd like to play: Burning Wheel (I've only played once!), Mouse Guard, Danger Patrol, Happy B-day Robot, octaNe, and a bunch of other games I can't think of right now.

      April 2010
      Well, I've been a lurker up until now.

      Noah, 37, married to a delightful and tolerant woman, father of 3 superb boys. I live in Zionsville, Indiana, a small town/suburb northwest of Indianapolis. I don't get to GenCon as often as I like, or should (been once). This recently passed Easter marks my first year as a Catholic. I've been gaming for 25 years, mostly 'trad'. I'm lucky enough to have an excellent regular group in Indy, but with a few exceptions, they're not going to get out of 'trad' gaming anytime soon, if ever - but I've got a regular GM who's committed to good story, thankfully. As far as 'indie' games go, I live somewhat vicariously through the AP reports of others...

      The potential of 'indie' games fascinates and draws me in with terrible ferocity; as I've aged, the story and character development has become far more important than the list of stuff that used to be the focus of my character sheets.

      Posted By: BrendanI'm Brendan Adkins.     • YunusWesley
      April 2010 edited April 2010
      Heh, my first roleplaying was in junior high in Lexington. Lunchtime, Hardy the class clown GMed pretty freeform games of what he called "Dungeons and Dragons," with flipped coins for resolution. We went from some post-apocalyptic warzone with flying cars and bazookas to a middle ages where people spoke in first person about "10th level wizards." Were we playing "ourselves" or loose pawn-stance characters? Hard to remember at this point. The lack of books, character sheets, dice, or any intention to do anything except use our imaginations so hard it hurt... sticks in my mind as "indie" play in the sense of "punk."

    • jprussell
      May 2010
      Ah, I jumped in and forgot to post to this. My name's Jeff, I'm 25, and I'm currently in the Army, in Iraq. This is not very conducive to gaming. When I get back to the states, I'll be in North Carolina and I will start a gaming blitz! I started RPGs with AD&D2, when I was a wee lad, tooled around with that World of Darkness stuff, enjoyed numerous one off games of various systems, and had enjoyable campaigns with "Bubblegum Crisis" and "Teenagers from Outer Space". Then I moved and entered a far too long gaming drought with the occasional pick-up game. Now I've gotten into the indie hotness and I'm reigniting my love of game design. And I just recently wandered over here and am enjoying it immensely. Oh yeah, I also hang out over at the praxis forum.
    • EnricPDX
      May 2010
      Hello, my name's Harry. I'm about to turn thirty, and I live in Portland with my son, who's about to turn five. I work as a preschool teacher, which I've been doing for the last ten or twelve years. In my free time, I try to teach myself how to draw, watch movies, go to the occasional show, attend local soccer matches, and of course, play games. I played RPGs as a kid, and then lost interest as I became more invested in the DIY hardcore/punk community, which is probably the big formative experience of my adolescence. When I was about twenty-five, I started playing D&D and boardgames again with some other punk kids from around here, and that really rekindled my love of play. It's only in the last year or so that I've discovered this whole other world of RPGs, and I've been fortunate enough to meet some friendly local folks through GoPlayPDX that have shown me the ropes. I've been registered here for a while, but haven't posted very often - maybe that will change now. Have a good day!
    • Anachronist
      May 2010
      Hi, I just joined yesterday. I'm in my mid 20s and I live all over the place but presently I'm on the coast of Oregon. I'm a gardener, forager, amateur ecologist and a bit of a hermit too, I guess. My RPG experience is limited to a DnD4E campaign and some "off the cuff" games with friends, using simple free systems from around the internet. I'm interested in learning to run games well, techniques and tips for better stories, and in discovering new games that suit my tastes. I'd also be able to make it to events in Portland but not very frequently as I don't drive.
    • markpank
      June 2010
      Mark Pankhurst, 34 (I think, I've reached the point where have to count now), living in UK near Chester. For coin, I do web back-end stuff.
      Gamewise, I started out playing D&D 2nd ed. at college, but lost touch with my gaming buddies. Eventually started pining for a bit of hack-and-slash. As if by magic, discovered that several of my workmates were old gamers looking to start playing again, and we started up a new group which is still going. Currently running D&D and playing Dark Heresy, with a few other bits on the side.
      I spend a lot of time on trains, so I'm often thinking about new dungeons and such to throw at my players. I'm a massive fan of How to Host a Dungeon, which is what brought me here. Hoping to spark some interest in another collaborative HtHaD game, like the one I've seen played out on the boards here.
    • d(sqrt(-1))
      June 2010 edited June 2010
      Mark, 48. I live near Oxford. I'm a programmer and have worked in various research sites round the UK.

      Started playing about 1975 with T&T and White box D&D. Moved on to all the usual suspects: Traveller, RuneQuest, Cthulhu. Have played pretty much continually since then without any major hiatuses. Will play most things, currently have a 3.5 D&D game that's been going since 2000, before that a Runequest game 1990-2000. Also playing in a friend's D&D 4e game. Currently trying to set up and run some RQ Tekumel, of which I'm a big fan. Have also recently picked up Chronica Feudalis, Remember Tomorrow and Atomic Highway.

      Other stuff: I'm also into boardgames a lot (mostly German), which started in about 1990 when I bought a copy of McMulti, and discovered the fanzine Sumo (and have since filled the house with games). I also like cooking (Indian, Chinese, Thai, French, Belgian), am a big fan of Belgian and German beer and like to go walking when I can.

      I live with a partner who also likes RPGs (she often plays fighter types), and who is a DOOM and FPS nut. I also live with a cat who turned up in our garden one day called Pixie (the cat, not the garden).
    • Skage
      June 2010
      Hello,

      I'm Brittany. I am 21 years old and I live in Atlanta.
      Started roleplaying freshman year of highschool, with a rock paper scissors version of D&D. Did a lot of online roleplaying, in PbP threads. Played in a lot of one-shots, one BESM d20 campaign. Meet a group who was playing in Exalted, where I meet my gm who introduced me to indie games and Amber.

      Aside from the gaming: In school right now, and I'm all over the place in Atlanta (well, north half mostly). I like anime, video games, firefly, and lurking on the net.
    • Heuhh
      June 2010
      Hello,

      I am Ludovic. I am 30 years old and french. I am sorry for my english, it is not always easy. :)
      I played RPG since 1995, I started by D&D. I discover Indie and story games last year, and I like a lot. It is A Penny for my thoughts which corrupted me and now I woud like to publish Story Games in french. I wish it will come true by the end of 2010.

      In the real life, I am half engineer in reliability and half publisher.
    • shannon
      June 2010 edited April 2011
      I'm Shannon, of the Riddle clan, Seattle branch. 26. By day I'm a video game user research engineer, so I play games and design, run, & analyze studies to make them better. By night I suppose I just continue to be awesome, that's my super power. My academic background hits psychology (specifically cognitive neuroscience), minor in classical studies, MS in psycholinguistics, and additional grad work in user-centered design. Which my explain a lot of things.

      I started gaming in 2003 when my now-hubby, Paul, introduced me to D&D, and was introduced to indie games when I went to grad school in Edinburgh, decided to give the gaming society a try, was put in a Best Friends game hosted by Gregor Hutton where we all played strippers at the Pink Pony, and it was all over from there. I quite like to playtest games (what can I say, usability/UX to the core), but I have less than no desire to run games.

      Paul & I got married last August, so if you see people referring to a Shannon with the last name of East, that is also me. We have a dog named Chewy, who is the handsomest mutt ya ever did see, and pretty much the best dog in the world (verified by external sources). I'm in the Seattle Women's Chorus, which is a lesbian choir (but that wasn't part of the audition). And as the people who attended GoPlay NW this year can attest, I like to bake. I have a cooking/baking blog, Double the Sugar, and a personal blog with my ramblings on many a random thing, but don't get your hopes up because I don't talk about gaming all that much, at The Riddle Of...
    • machineiv
      June 2010
      David A Hill Jr. I write full-time. A little bit of anything here and there. A lot of freelancing in various game industry places. I just recently released my first indie game, Maschine Zeit.

      I live with my wife, fellow game designer and writer Filamena Young. We have two daughters, Acacia Crimefighter and Modistina Sophia. We sometimes make science. I'm terrible with introductions.
    • Brian_Minter
      June 2010
      Wait. Your daughter is named Acacia Crimefighter?
    • EDO
      July 2010
      Hello everybody,

      I'm Edoardo

      I'm from Lerici, in Italy. I have studied fine arts (mostly drawing and painting), but never got a degree. Now I work for this auction House, specialized in antique arms and armor.

      I play r.p.games since about 1998-1999, with the same people I have grown up (In the last few weeks we're on Fiasco and the Solar System).

      My english is poor, so I'm mostly lurking round here.
    • idle daedal
      July 2010
      My name is Travis. I'm an art historian specializing in religion, magic, and identity/community formation through visual and performative traditions in ancient Greece.

      But, really, I'm a gamer and have been for nearly my whole life. I'm fascinated by rules and how manipulating these artificial limits can create a particular kind of experience. For me, design matters a great deal, and I feel strongly that when I sit down to game, I want to go hard and fast and feel the rubber on the road. I dig good narration, too, but I like it best when it has teeth, when I can feel the push and pull at the system level, and when it makes everybody want to keep coming back for more.

      Most importantly, I'm the husband of anansigirl, another one of the tribe around here. She's super-rad.



    • Will Edge
      July 2010
      Hey there, I'm Will. 23 and living here in the UK (Reading at the current moment).

      I'm a former student moving into recruitment and human resources (as fascinating as that is). I'm an avid writer, semi-decent artist and a frothing gamer. Currently I'me experimenting with different types of game, both playing and designing, in hopes of finding new, interesting ways to expand and develop the hobby. I'd like to try my hand at some story games and publish them online for the enjoyment of others.

    • Alejandro_Etsu
      July 2010 edited July 2010
      I'm Alejandro Stratta. I'm was born and live in Uruguay, South America, and have 32 years old.My other nicks are Etsu Riot and Losstarot, my good side and my evil side, respectively. (Don't ask.) I started playing RPGs last year, in february, with a group of vereran people. (Star Wars D6.) In a weak, more or less, I was directing my own private World War II D6 version to two friends, and later to another friend, none of them experienced players (had not even heard about role-playing games before). Later, I tried with Cthulhu (with greate sessions of GUMSHOE) and eventually, I became a story gamer, thanks to Mouse Guard and Burning Wheel. And now, I am a follower of Luke Crane, Vincent Baker, John Wick and John Harper work, and I'm doing my own work too. Because my english sucks, I can't say much more. Sorry for that.

    Comments

    • Jonathan
      July 2010
      I guess I should throw this up as well, being a good citizen and all that.

      My name is Jonathan Lavallee, and I'm 29 years old and I love long lingering looks over all amazing alliterations, especially entertained and engaged by amazing assonance. I run Firestorm Ink, which currently has the line license to CyberGen and I've finally decided that I've had enough of just that and I'm putting out my own books of other stuff.

      I believe in the medieval method of creating art, which means that I work in IT to pay the bills and then do everything else on the side, much like many people who make games. I just make myself feel better by saying that it's a very medieval style. Chaucer was a customs clerk, right? Right?

      I have a masters in English Literature, though I do want those years of my life back. Learning to say, "Would you like fries with that" in Middle English isn't as fun as it sounds. I have the mental and emotional scarring to prove it.

      There is poetry when the mood strikes me, and then there is a need to fix my prose so that it sounds less like my poetry.

      I love small short sentences. I also apparently love commas.

      I'll probably not post very much, I tend to lurk in the shadows and then come out with something, possibly nonsensical, and then I return.
    • mease19
      August 2010 edited August 2011
      OK, so I'm Marshall (there are two of us now, I guess I'm the other one...). I'm 29 and getting closer to 30 than I would like. I've got a wife who plays board games with me (score!) and a son who is an amazing wave of distruction. I grew up in Oak Ridge, TN (...but don't glow in the dark) and now go to school in Boston; well, near Boston. I've got a master's in experimental psychology and am currently working on my doctorate focusing on the nutritional neuroscience of aging.

      My life has always been full of games. It all started out with chess lessons from my grandfather. A love of mythology got me and my friends into "pure" story telling games (no rules, all story) in elementary school and the games have just kept flowing from RPGs to CCGs, miniatures to Eurogames, year after year. I played a lot of 3rd edition D&D in college and slowly realized I just wasn't getting out of it all that I wanted and more or less gave up on RPGs. Eight years later, here I am!

      In my free time (ha ha, I made a joke) I enjoy hiking, cycling, and the reading of a good old fashioned book.
    • Jason_Pitre
      August 2010
      Real Name: Jason Pitre. Lousy last name to pronounce unless you speak French.
      Online Alias: Jagash. I answer to it and is usually easier
      Country of Origin: Canada
      City of Origin: Ottawa, the city sense forgot.
      Vintage: 1985. It was a very good year.

      By day I am a government scientist, specializing in ecology and large scale system. I look at ecosystems and try to figure out what is interfering with them. I make maps for my job with the latest and greatest digital cartography techniques (GIS). I even struggle to improve the quality of my French, as it is essential in the Canadian government. Yes, a few of those skills translate a bit into game design...

      I have been playing RPGs for over a decade at this point though and have been drawn by games as an outlet for creativity. Character creation, world building, maps and system hacks are my passions.

      On the rare occasions when free time occurs I try to read, to roast coffee and to mix drinks at my home bar.
    • erlend
      August 2010
      I'm Erlend Bruer and i've been lurking on and off for a few years. I've suddenly decided to spend more time on internet forums (yay!), so I thought I'd introduce myself :)

      I've been playing roleplaying games since I was a kid, and have been designing games the past five or six years. I'm generally interested in making and playing games that cross the borders between real life and fiction, whether it is through using roles that are just people in the real world, stories that somehow reflect on the players' lives or through using small parts of the player's lives directly in the games. I do play lots of other stuff too, though, currently got a Burning Wheel/Ravenloft campaign going, for instance.

      Umm what else? I finished a master's degree in social psychology this summer, and am generally active in a few norwegian NGOs, some related to gaming and some not. Doing as much writing and volunteer work as I can this fall while waiting for some job or other to turn up. Love to play the guitar. Am also fighting a growing Starcraft 2 addiction...
    • Pete_W
      August 2010
      I'm Pete. I started gaming when I was five and stumbled across some D&D dice on the path near my house; I'm 31 now, and still haven't looked back once. I started doing freelance game writing back when I was 16, at the old Star Wars Adventure Journal, and ran around some hotels testing their LARP rules with a blaster pistol and a lot of enthusiasm. A couple years later, I lucked into a gig with White Wolf. I stayed with them for about 10 years, working mostly for the Mind's Eye Theatre line, where for my sins I was eventually made developer. I left the company a few years ago to attend graduate school, and now I'm an English professor, though the game design itch is rising again, so it probably won't be long before I get back into it.

      I'm a LARP dilettante - I've tried all the big systems, most of the little ones and a half-dozen boffer games besides - and an MMO nomad. I'm a laid back 40K wargamer, an avid Fantasy Flight board game lover and a fan of many geek card games. At the tabletop, I'm equally at home throwing down in a hardcore Pathfinder dungeon crawl or as a Dog walking the plains, and I browse game rules like most people browse Ferrari dealerships - even if I know I'll never actually play with it, I still appreciate the craftsmanship, and love peeking under the hood. I'm a gaming pusher, and love teaching my friends new games.

      Lastly, I'm married to the best wife ever, a snazzy dancer and almost always barefoot.
    • Paul88
      August 2010
      Hi, I'm Paul 44 live UK Devon married to the right one with three beautiful daughters, Yes four women!!! this ant why I like gaming, luckily they all get on well.

      Gaming for me has been a great social thing. I have gamed for the last 14 years regularly at my home in the gaming shed 5-4 mtrs with pot belly stove and hot tea.
      For the last five years or so I've been trying to introduce more indie story driven games with some success in our group, gaming shows over here locally are War gaming events mainly so the indie wave is just a ripple on this side of the world. Unless someone knows different?
      I work for a boat building company, I'm not greatly academic but have an enthusiasm for art and the imagination.
      I like walking coastal paths and Dartmoor with its prehistoric sites.
      I like siting by my garden fire bear, family and good food. Yum
    • Montaignome
      August 2010
      I'm Montaigne Jean-Patrick Bouvart (it's Franco-Irish, I can't help it if it's fancy). I'm 33 years old, a freelance scholar, and happily married to a working artist. We have two cats, both adopted, both insane, that provide endless amusement. We live on the top floor of a Victorian house with non-Euclidean walls and cupboards, and I smoke pipes somewhat incessantly. I have degrees in comparative religion and English literature, which pretty much turned me into an agnostic Taoist utilitarian.

      I've been gaming for over 20 years (grasps walker/zimmerframe, wheezes), and have played most major, minor, and indie systems. I love them all in their own way, and I have a library of about 300 game-books and twice as many gaming mags to prove it.

      Grew up in a rusty steel town that was circling the drain of existence near Pittsburgh, and now live in a happening little town of artists and nutters outside of Philadelphia. I enjoy riding on trains, but rarely get the chance to do so, and am continually disappointed that, despite my superb inductive and deductive reasoning, no one ever asks me to solve a murder. I'm a serious Deadhead, a non-serious leftist-anarchist, and a downright laughable ordained minister in three faiths.

      Hoping to learn Latin this year, but aware that that seems unlikely.





    • JayLoomis
      September 2010
      I'm Jay.

      I'm 36 and an underachieving jack-of-all trades. Currently at Big Softie working as a developer documentation manager, soon to be a returning student. I live in sunny (if you count liquid sunshine) Bellevue Washington, where I while away the hours with my awesome wife and two special needs cats.

      I've been on the dim periphery of the indie-RPG movement for almost a decade. I've been designing my own games (with varying degrees of as-yet unpublished success) for many years longer.



    • Elastrius
      September 2010
      My name is David.

      I am from Seattle, Washington, near the University District. I am a student, I am on a varsity rowing team, and I love the Emerald City. I've been running and playing freeform, minimal-rules storytelling games all my life, with a focus on whatever concept the group finds interesting on a given night (in addition to some D&D and GURPS). I am smitten with IRC pickup games and I hope to find many players on Story Games. I want to learn as much as I can! My current focus is on the streamlining of RPG rules to make for very fast play, while losing as little sophistication as possible. It is a fascinating balancing act.

      If you'd like to play IRC games in any setting, let me know at any time : D I am very glad to have found this site.

      David

      I'm Craig

      I live in Baltimore
      sort of a creative geek type, I create electronic music, do random art projects, and like to write and think about stories
      RPG wise, I like the idea of Story Games but only recently fell into them. Normally I run Call of Cthulhu (but very story heavy so I suppose this is a natural flow..)
      I want to run Trail of Cthulhu, play Fiasco, and try out Apocalypse world.

      I'm hoping to meet some friends here to possibly play online, or hopefully in person at some point.
    • Tully305
      October 2010
      My name is Geoff

      I went to Kent State to be an architect....washed out and majored in Criminal Justice instead.

      Worked for 8 years as a felony Probation Officer supervising high-risk criminals and sex offenders.

      Spent the next 5 years working for a domestic violence agency as the Community Education Director.

      Quit this past February to be a safety consultant working for myself. Make enough money working two days a month to replace my old salary (which wasn't very much), so I now spend most of my time writing screenplays, remodeling our house, working on improving my health, and trying to design games.

      I do a bit of freelance writing for games, and I've been really lucky with the projects I've worked on.

      December 2010 edited December 2010
      Hi gang,

      I'm Matt, a graphics guy with an addiction to good/bad kung-fu movies, card/board games and player of RPG's (table top). Kobold Crafter for Kobold Quarterly. AIGA member.
      I have a Playstation but only 6 games. I am at the end of God of War but have not actually finished it yet.
      Most of my free time is commuting to and from work. The second I can have a speech controlled laptop I will be able to get so much created!

    • Barking Alien
      December 2010 edited December 2010
      Hi all!

      There is no real me - I had it surgically removed.*

      Actually I'm Adam Dickstein, 41, living in the greatest city in the world, New York, NY. I work with dogs, including training. I am also a freelance writer and artist whose worked on and off in the Comic Book and RPG industries for 20 years.

      I am divorced but still great friends with my ex who is one of the best RPG gamers I've ever met. Which means I'm available (Laaadiees *wink* - kidding. I am only half that obnoxious).

      In addition to gaming I enjoy comic books, anime/manga, sci-fi, folklore and mythology, movies, very little television that isn't British, cooking, walking around the city, real science and history. My best friend is my dog, Delilah, a three year old Catahoula Leopard Dog mix.

      I try to play anything and everything at least once. Favorite games of all time include Ars Magica, Champions (4th Edition), Faery's Tale Deluxe, InSpectres, Mekton (preference for Mekton II), Mutants & Masterminds, Star Trek (FASA and Last Unicorn Games versions), Star Wars (West End Games D6) and Teenagers from Outer Space. Want so bad to get a hold of Bliss Stage, Fiasco and Meikyuu Kingdom and Yuuyake Koyake (both from Japan).

      I currently run a fantasy rpg campaign best described as D&D-for-those-people-who-hate-D&D. With the new year I will probably be adding a second game to my roster in addition to playtesting my own creation.

      Yes gang, I am currently, after 33+ years in the hobby, preparing to publish my own RPG. More on that as I fail to realize how crazy I am.

      Cheers,
      Adam

      AD
      Barking Alien

      *That line is from Peter Sellers appearance on 'The Muppet Show'. I love the Muppets.
    • TheWhaleShark
      December 2010
      Hey all,

      I'm Peter Olsen, a 28 year old geek living and working in Albany, NY. I'm of Norwegian and Italian descent (Nortalian? Iwegian?) - my father was a second-generation Norwegian and my mother is a second-generation Italian. I grew up listening to countless stories from my grandfather Bjarne, passed to him by his parents. I guess you could say that storytelling has been in my blood for a while now.

      I'm a Senior Food Bacteriologist employed by the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets. My job responsibilities primarily consist of the detection, isolation, identification, characterization, and subtyping of certain bacterial pathogens - E. coli O157:H7, various STEC's, Salmonella spp.. and Campylobacterspp., as well as other microbes as the situation warrants - in all sorts of food samples from across the state. We can test - and probably have tested - nearly any type of food bought, sold, produced, distributed, or consumed in the entire state, with the notable exception of restaurants. Besides testing, we're also an ISO 17025 accredited laboratory, which means that my job also consists of developing, implementing, and auditing various Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's), as well as training and supervising laboratory staff in the performance of said procedures.

      In short, I keep your food from killing you. You're welcome.

      When I'm not saving the world from deadly microbes, I can be found playing video games (damn you Steam and the ease with which I can spend too much money), playing board games/card games/dice games/many other sorts of games, brewing beer (all-grain, naturally), listening to the most abrasive and obnoxious heavy metal music produced by humans (mmm, delicious post-black noise-infused doom), and playing around in the SCA pretending to be an 11th-century Viking named Magnus the Stout - a brewer and storyteller extraordinaire.

      And, of course, I play pen-and-paper roleplaying games.

      Like many gamers, I started off with AD&D 2nd edition as my gateway drug. Well, OK, technically the board game Dragon Strike was my introduction to roleplaying, but D&D is where it really took off. I spent many a summer putting together encounters for my party, taking them on all sorts of adventures across Faerun. Good times were had by all.

      One day, in 2007 I believe, I went with my good friends Rym and Scott of Geeknights "fame" to this convention called Ubercon, out in New Jersey somewhere. That proved to be a fateful trip, because there, the three of us sat down to play this little demo called "The Sword" for some game called Burning Wheel. The rest, as they say, is history.

      My introduction to story games completely annihilated my desire to play D&D, and since then, I've been playing Burning Wheel pretty steadily. More recently, in the past 1.5 years, I've added other story games to my repertoire - Lacuna, Dread, 1001 Nights, and InSpectres to name a few - and I'm loving them more and more. I've recently restarted GM'ing, running a weekly Burning THAC0-style Burning Wheel game.

      Very very recently, I ran a session of Danger Patrol!, as it looked super fun and neat. Having plumbed the depths of obscure story RPG's, I figured it was time to up and join a forum of similarly hopelessly dedicated nerds, to better direct and develop my inner storytelling nerd. I'm looking forward to reading and participating in many discussions, to learn from and teach other GM's.
    • Jim Sweeney
      January 2011
      Howdy, all.

      I'm Jim Sweeney, 27, hailing from Fort Wayne, IN, two hours (and 6-7 months, currently) northeast of Gencon. While I head back to IPFW for my accounting certification, I'm working part-time at Clem's, a local game shop, making sure we try to get some of the cool new RPGs in between wrangling Yu-Gi-Oh players.

      I've been gaming since middle school, and don't plan on stopping any time soon. My friend, Chris, helped guide me toward the wonder of games off the beaten WotC path (as well as to this site), and it is indeed a marvelous thing. I'm currently playing one Dresden Files game and have two on hiatus, playing in a D&D4E game and a sporadic Gamma World game, trying to get a critical mass of people interested in Apocalypse World, and carrying around my Fiaco binder just in case.

      RPGs do not plumb the depth of my geekery, which also includes comics, board games, novels, filking... the list goes on.

      Happy to meet all of you!
    • theg33k
      January 2011
      Hey, all.

      My name's Chris and I live in Vancouver, BC. I'm a freelance writer and editor, and I've recently started publishing some punk romance stories. That's the interesting stuff, such as it is.

      I've been playing RPGs since I got my first set of AD&D books at 9 (which was, god, nearly 30 years ago). Since then I've played an assload of games and worked in an assload of game stores, but I've recently gotten into story games in a big way. They're kind of revolutionary to me in how they're the way I thought that RPGs should be but pretty much never were.

      Oh, I also game with skinnyghost; he's running the Apocalypse World campaign I'm currently embroiled in. We've been geeky comrades-in-arms for several years now and I owe him a personal debt of thanks for introducing me to indie RPGs. So thanks, yo.
    • Matteo Turini
      January 2011
      Hi all!

      I'm Matteo, I'm Italian and I currently live in Lucca, home of Lucca Comics&Games, one of the biggest C&G conventions in Europe - my house's across the Games section street.
      I'm 24 (well, 25 in a few days) and, after having moved a couple of times to different cities and having learned how to make a proper pizza and how to manage a restaurant, I decided to return back to my studies - I left my Literature courses at 21 - and now I'm an in-training web designer, and aiming to get a degree in Computational and Language Science.

      I love to travel and I have seen a big part of Europe, and a little of Africa. I hope to go to the US in the next couple of years, if the occasion arises, but mostly I'd like to visit Asia, particularly Cambodia and India.
      I think I know most of the story-gamers in Italy, and a few of the internationals too. I'm currently loving and enjoying really much Apocalypse World (but then, I'm not original here: who doesn't?)

      So... Se you all!
    • MollyxEdge

      I'm Molly, 18 almost 19 years old. I currently live in Richmond, Virginia but I'm moving to Boston, MA in a few days. I have two cats and a hamster. I play Magic The Gathering (though I will admit, I'm not the best player...), Warcraft 3, D&D, and a few other various things from time to time.       I was recently diagnosed with Type 1 Diabetes. I wear my heart on my sleeve. I'm very open about my opinions or thoughts, probably sometimes a little too open. I do have a boyfriend, who's a pretty awesome guy. We coordinate our outfits 9 times out of 10. I enjoy all things that are diabetic friendly, fun, awesome, cuddly, cute, BADASS, or just down right rude loud and hilarious. I'm often very sarcastic and I try to take things as lightly as possible.

    • Noofy
      January 2011
      G'day Folks,
      My name is Nathan, but my friends call me Noofy. I'm 39, a paramagic and love telling stories. My colleagues vaguely put up with what they see as 'quirky' behaviour. After playing rpgs since the early 80's, I had a long hiatus after Uni and sorta only played boardgames for a long while. I stumbled across the forge and story games and then Burning Wheel. The rest is history.

      I love protagonist driven games and fantasy is my preferred genre (though my long suffering partner often wishes for some old school railroady CoC sometimes (poor dear), and we have been playing an awful lot of AW lately.

      I love food, surfing, tattoos (getting and giving), skydiving and moutain biking, though not necessarily in any order.

      Happy to meet you all and hopefully game face to face sometime!

    • whduryea
      February 2011 edited February 2011
      I've been posting for a week or so now, so I should probably post something here.

      My name is William. I'm 26.

      I'm a 5th generation American, descended primarily from German immigrants and a Czechoslovakian draft dodger. I live in the frozen wastes of Northern New York, about an hour south of Montreal and several hundred miles north of anything interesting. I have a degree in English and political science with a minor in psychology. I did a year of graduate work in English Lit before deciding that I wanted nothing more to do with academia. I'm now working (miserably) part time as a substitute teacher while I look (desperately) for something less awful.

      I began playing RPGs at 12 years old when I received Dragon Strike for Christmas. I played D&D for several years, and messed around with Demon: the Fallen, GURPS and other mainstream titles. A long time friend and member of my gaming group introduced me to indie RPGs and game design a few years ago.

      I have a bad habit of refusing to actual put my games in writing. I justify this by saying that if I cannot explain a game in five minutes at the table before play, and if I cannot hold all the rules in my head during play, then my game design is too obtuse and unintuitive. In reality, I'm just lazy. I've tried to break this habit recent. Last month I participated in The Forge's Ronnies game design competition, and I'm currently mulling expanding my entry, Danse Macabre, into a full, self-published game.

      I've always been terrible at conclusions, so, uh ... I'm done?

    • Ally Nauss
      February 2011
      *Waves*

      Hi! I'm Ally Nauss (and am finally not using a psuedonymn, but I sporadically used to lurk/post on the BW forums as"allywiththeface" and on KF as "karschael" for those of you who may frequent said places). I am 24 and live in Philly with my long-term manly man Don (who usually posts on any of these gaming-type forums as eruditus). I have a nearly-two-year old daughter, a Rottweiler named Morgan who weighs as much as I do, and a little mutt named Duncan. I like parentheses too much.

      I work as a sales coordinator for a hotel, though I went to college for therapeutic recreation.

      My interest are very ecclectic. I tend to lose interest in things very quickly, so I bounce around from hobby to hobby as my brain sees fit. I enjoy cooking, and do this the most often, as eating is one of those more necessary habits. I enjoy gaming, and do so between 1-a billion times per week. I may have a tendency to exaggerate from time to time. I blame this on never caring enough about arithmetic and instead choosing numbers at random to express myself. I also knit, pretend to practice Win Chung and other martial arts, drink a whole lot of beer and wine while using snobbish terms like "mouthfeel", "pithy", and "finish ( Okay, that last one wasn't snobbish, but in context one can sound like they know what they are talking about.), and use both fragments and run-on sentences incessantly. I am addicted to cynicism and sarcasm. This has made my life difficult in the past, but I'll take my d4 of trouble and roll with it. (Yes, that pun was intended. Yes, you may punch me for it)

      I recently designed my first game ever, not counting anything I "designed" under the age of six. It is not awesome. Yet. But it will be... (ish?)

      I'm an open book. If you have questions, just let me know.

    • bottlesorter
      March 2011
      Hi, all,

      Andrew here. Tragically, I am ancient, and have never grown out of games. My first contact with RPGs was in a wargaming magazine (Battle - for Wargamers, nineteen seventy-something) that talked about a brand new invention called Dungeons and Dragons. It was still 3 little books then and so weird that no one really new how to describe it. I wrote my first system then, using a d6 for everything. It was crap. Then (1st ed) AD&D came out, and I started for real. Then Runequest, then Gamma World, and so on.

      Over the years I have gone through phases of collecting every RPG system, and then contracting the collection to only those that I 'really love'. This is especially necessary now as there are so many great products out there. And this sharing of ideas over the internet makes 'ownership' not really the same thing it was in years past.

      Now days I do not play classical role-playing games at all. I really don't have much interest or patience in complex 'rules', or the minutiae of someone's very-clever system. Instead I create story-telling games in a free form style. It suits where I'm at. This is where I put them, if anyone is interested: http://shichitenhakki.wordpress.com/

      Good gaming everyone.
      Andrew

      In the rare times I'm not procrastinating, I do translations, creative writing and some other stuff.


      l.
    • DaveyJJ
      March 2011 edited March 2011
      Who am I? Hmm.

      My name's David Janik-Jones but I only gained the Janik part after marrying my beautiful partner in crime. DaveyJJ is the name most people know me by when in the online realms I frequent. I'm a 48-year old dad of two, husband, 20 year designer and creative director, typographer, artist, game developer, thinker, leftist, environmentalist, atheist, reader, cat lover (I have three), wargamer (WW2 tactical), board gamer, klutz, and narrativist/indie/unique mechanic RPG fan. I have a slightly giggly 13-year-old girl trapped inside me and my wife insists that my real name should be "He Who Makes Short Story Long". Currently ensconced in the southern Ontario city of Waterloo, but have lived and worked in San Francisco, Vancouver, Phoenix, the Caribbean, Europe and Toronto. Was that too much?

      I make games for iOS as a hobby to "relax" when I have the time, but after my first seven games I've slowed down quite a bit. Glacial development times now, but I've got one almost done and one in progress that will most likely see the light of day.

      I don't have as much time to RPG as I used to. My RPGing goes all the way back to the 4th version of the D&D white box set I received back in December of 1975 (birthday gift I begged my parents for). I managed to get both Dave Arneson and Gary Gygax to sign it at some convention or another then gave it away in a moment of madness. I gave away one of ten Yosef Karsh studio print autographed photos of Rush too, and sold my Apple stock at $17/share so this will show you what foresight and planning I am capable of.

      Oh yeah, RPGs. I own the utterly fantastic A Taste for Murder, though have only managed one play (time, lack of mature RPGers nearby etc). I have Cats, High Flying Beatrice, Mortal Coil, Mouse Guard, PtA, Extraordinary Adventures of Baron Munchausen, Wushu Open Reloaded, and a handful of others that escape me right now. I'm hoping to discover more, maybe find some local older players to RPG with, discuss the best in indie-narrativist-unique mechanic RPGs that are appearing, and generally contribute as I can.

      Final thoughts: Thanks Graham W for the fantastic A Taste for Murder. And does anyone know of a gritty, narrativist WW2 RPG (or a system that can be adapted to that setting) that's short, unique and story-driven? Not Godlike without powers, something more unique that will give me a band of Brothers type story in a relatively short evening of play?

      Thanks, and hi!

      P.S. My oldest is a hard core 4th edition D&D player. I can't even look at the books anymore without cringing at the terrible size/density and yet having a pang of nostalgia. My youngest is a gamer too. Lucky me!
    • Chris_Goodwin
      March 2011 edited March 2011
      Time for an update. I suppose I'm not the same person I was... geez, five years ago?
      Chris Goodwin, age 40 (41 in less than a week?!). Married to Lisa, we have a nine year old, Andrew.
      I live in the boonies of Hillsboro, Oregon, and work (currently) as a software tester at a very large company that makes computer chips. I've been a perma-temp for most of my adult life, with a couple of exceptions here and there. My wife and I have been going to GameStorm for at least four of the last five years, and we've taken our son for the past two. I am pretty bad about making it across town for gaming but will endeavor to be better about it in the future. Maybe this will be the year I try to get something regular going on this side...

      Christian and I are evil twins, born exactly seven years apart and on different continents.

      I'm trying to be much less of a dick online than I used to be. I've been a Hero System snob and an indie games snob, and no game, no matter how awesome it is, is worth being a dick over. If I refuse to play a game anymore, it will be because I've tried it and didn't enjoy it, and for no other reason. I still love me some "indie" games and some Hero System and every so often some D&D and other "trad" games, and board and card games and... and.... I have gamer ADD, which I attribute to also having regular ADD; I go through phases where I am intensely into one game, system, or setting for a few days to a month or two, then get distracted by the next squirrel. I call it the "wheel of ADD" -- round and round it goes, where it stops nobody knows.
    • rian_bean
      April 2011
      Hi All!

      I'm Tori from Seattle, WA. 30 years old, and I live with 3 roommates, 3 cats, and 3 chickens . I currently work at 2 different bars as primarily a bookkeeper, but I also do prep cooking, run a karaoke night and a movie night, with the occasional hosting of Bingo thrown in.

      I am part of a non profit urban farming collective that runs two mini farms in Seattle, and all the food grown goes to the volunteers who work it and local food banks. We do all our produce deliveries by bike.

      I am in a ridiculous band called Adult Contemporary in which we mash up awful adult smooth rock songs from the 90s and attempt to make them danceable (emphasis on attempt!)

      A lot of my time now is focused on our RPG podcast, Self Critical Hits, which got started back in October and is (in my mind) slowly but steadily improving (fingers crossed!). I am trying to create a new side project of the podcast that feature folks using "nerdy" habits to build community and foster relationships. So interviewing folks who run cons, or start sci fi book clubs, or run public games- etc. If you have any ideas, please send them my way!! We want to highlight Pacific Northwest folks specifically.

      The folks I podcast with are pretty much the only people I've ever gamed with, so my goal for this year is to game with some other people, mainly to get perspective, but also to connect to our community and make friends!

      I only started gaming about 6 years ago- so I've mainly played a lot of D&D 3.5 and CoC, but this last year or so we've been focusing more on indie games, including Dogs in the Vineyard, Apocalypse World, Fiasco, Burning Wheel/Burning Empire, Everyone is John, and Drifters Escape- Drifters, Dogs, and Burning Wheel being my favorite so far.

      I feel pretty late to the table with indie games so I predict a lot of new games being purchased, played, and podcast in the next few months. Also, it seems Washington is having basically a con-a-month from June- October, and I will be doing my damnedest to be at all of them.

      Thanks!
      Tori
    • edomaur

      Well...

      I am Antoine Boegli, currently 40 years old, single, roleplayer, publisher, larper, writer, etc.

      Living in Switzerland (where I was born) I am a IT system security specialist or something like that, and I've been roleplaying since 1984. Also, I have written a bunch of totally imperfect systems, and around 1995, I've fallen in love with the minimalistic kind of rules sported/sproutted by games like Over the Edge, Amber, etc. I am also know for being the publisher of the French version of Nobilis (second edition, the GWB) and of some other French-only games. Currently, after helping the translation française of Archipelago II, I am working on my own theory about rpg, and trying to put that in pratice with a new game system.

      I used to play WoW, but I'm better now
      I start 10 RPG projects and finish 1
      I owned and painted a small Space Marine army and never used it
      I lived in Japan and failed at learning the language
      The DC metro area needs more FLGS's
      I play the Violin, Viola, Clarinet, Alto Clarinet, Timpani, and sing Bass

      I’m Dan Cetorelli, 40 yrs old living in Pittsburgh PA. I am a professional forum lurker so many have no idea who I am so I figured this was a good place to say hi. I hiked the Appalachian Trail through 4 states, in my youth, but now I am fat and old. I now manage a Business Intelligence and metrics group for a major US Bank. Never Married but have two fabulous nieces that my brother adopted from China so I get to have kids without all that messy care and feeding. I consider myself an omni gamer and play just about anything tabletop but my first love is Role playing and in recent year Indie\Story games. Always preferred to GM over Play but the evolution of RPing has shifted my position a bit.

      My greatest Gaming accomplishments…

      With the help of many others we grew a local gaming club from 12 guys in a basement to a club that meets every month with over 200 members and a regular attendance of 60+ people GASP

      A yearly gaming convention that I have coordinated since 2005 that grows every year GASPcon

      Combining my inner desire to be an Artist with my favorite Hobby through book binding Books

      I'm Ville Halonen, born in 1980, started roleplaying in 1990, I guess, with the red box.

      I have two kids (girl born 2008, boy 2010), I try to write my master's thesis on Guy Debord's theory of the spectacle, and I work at the help desk of a large Finnish internet service provider. I used to dream about being a researcher of philosophy, then I thought of not doing it, and I dream of it again so I could leave the ISP and focus on thinking and writing. We also have a border terrier called Hugo.

      I'm a vegetarian since 1999 and although I occasionally buy food that has milk in it, I haven't cooked a non-vegan meal since 2003. I'm not militant about it.

      When I have the time to do anything but the above, I read all sorts of books and read and play roleplaying games, which hugely influence the other stuff I read. I also listen to music and watch movies and select tv shows (The Wire, Babylon 5, and The Prisoner stand out as favourites), but I've given up computer games for RPGs.

    • AJohandsome
      June 2011
      Hi,

      I'm Andreas, I am a happy 28-year-old Norwegian. I live in Oslo. It rains a lot in the summer, and in winter we get an equal amount of snow. Mind you, it's not all sleet and rain.
      I am a journalist by education and interest, and a software licensing specialist by trade. I actually quite enjoy it, but they pay is irregular, to say the least. I used to write about mobile phones and communication, but that line of work dried up once people started buying iPhones. If I had my way I'd find a job writing about technology, but there aren't many of those jobs going.

      I used to play in bands, and I miss that, but my band mates had kids and thus cannot find the time to jump around on stages. We released some EPs, and it was all good fun.

      I've played roleplaying games since I was 11 or so, starting out with the D&D Rules Cyclopedia. We consequently played every version of D&D up to 3.5.
      My favourite game ever was a Cyberpunk 2020 campaign based on Twin Peaks. It was awesome, and I played a hardboiled investigator!
      Lately we've been playing PTA and Burning Wheel, as well as some other things.

      I've designed a game set in Oslo, about fifty years into the future. It started out as an idea of jumping off high buildings, but ended up as a game built on relationships and strong emotions. Also, there was violence. It was fun.

      I also work on a game I call Heartlands, which is about riding across a beautiful continent, looking for a home inbetween ancient ruins and small holdings.







    • Evan_Torner
      June 2011
      Hi,

      I'm Evan Torner, a Ph.D. candidate in his late 20s soon to defend his dissertation in German Studies and Film Studies. My home is in western Massachusetts, where I live with avid role-player and Internet recluse Kat Jones.

      I played "pretend" until I was 8, and have been role-playing since then. My first system was the Marvel Advanced Set, and from there I have waded through dozens upon dozens of different systems – Cyberpunk 2020, Street Fighter, Traveler, Werewolf, Amber, Rifts, In Nomine, AD&D, Unknown Armies, Riddle of Steel. Conventions are my bread and butter; I run one-shots there like nobody's business. I am a regular at Origins in Columbus, OH, though I also help run JiffyCon with Kat, Emily Care Boss and Julia Ellingboe.

      Bill White and I are currently editing a multi-contributor volume tentatively titled Immersive Gameplay which is under contract with McFarland Press in 2012. The volume looks at discourses of principles of game immersion across role-playing games, reality television, and video games.

      I think I know many of you.

    • miedvied
      June 2011 edited June 2011
      I'm James Stein, a long-time lurker here and on the forge. I'm now 25, recently having finished my BS in Biology in NY and in just a month or so I'll be moving to Boston to start my Master's in Public Health (concentration in Biostatistics) at BU. The plan for after being the PhD, and I really wish I'd done a hell of a lot more math in my undergrad time so that I didn't have to do an MS as a prereq to the PhD. For the past few years I've just been doing research in a breast cancer lab (I'm not upset at the fact that people are trying to break our current theory of metastasis: I thought it was pretty fuckin' weak myself).

      I got into RPGs at the age of 8 or 9, when I got my first unsupervised computer and AOL account. I think the AOL freeform chat rooms were called Rhy'Din? I remember being excessively enamored of standing around pretending to be a dragon in a tavern. I soon got onto UseNet contributing to fiction (alt.dragons-inn), and basically by age ten I was writing on the order of 20 pgs/day and had completely merged "RP" with "writing." They stayed merged for well over a decade.

      I was not a geek in HS. I was well-known for being a funny slacker. I woke up in my senior year of HS, when I came down with nasty immunological problems, nearly died, and realized "Holy fuck, this is my life - I need to get crackin' on not wasting it!" My GPA went to 4.0, and my social life went to 0.0. I may have overdone it. It took a few years (and a BS in Biology) to realize that those immunological problems weren't going to allow me a career in medicine, and that I'm not sure I want to be an MD anyway ((a) partly rationalization, (b) medicine is kind of boring; they don't get to solve any really awesome problems, (C) Biochemistry's fucking awesome!). I had a torrid, blouse-tearing affair with biochemistry before I realized that with my health problems I can't be a biochemist either. I settled on Biostats as allowing me to continue to do awesome medical research but without being quantitatively stupid and allowing for working from home when ill.

      Every wall in every room of my house not occupied by door or window is covered with bookshelves. I am not unhappy with this state of affairs.

      I have 3 nieces. They have been brainwashed into thinking science is the bees knees (and it damn well is, in no part due to the fact that I show them how to make simple things go boom.) This is not unrelated to the deafness I have in my left ear (I really thought that CO2 gas pressure would blow the cap off the soda bottle. The cap started to blow, and then stopped hissing, and then the bottle went boom. I decided to get between it and my nieces and suffered for the choice. It was the right choice.) I have snuck over 40 pounds of dry ice out of a laser physics lab to dump into my niece's in-ground pool for her birthday party. The entire backyard was covered in fog and the pool bubbled for ages. I'm the best uncle.

      In HS I wrote ~40-100 pg/day with my then-gf, until she died suddenly (car accident.) I have not written for pleasure since.

      I am willing to spend 10 hours and upwards of 40 dollars making BBQ sauce from scratch. I am unwilling to eat fish.

      I was born an atheist (seriously, you can ask my 2nd grade hebrew school teacher). I find the religious worldview completely, utterly, baffling. It took many years of growth and maturation before I could begin to understand that religious folks are actually religious, and not just using 'god' as a metaphor for other shit (like I did when I was a kid, and hadn't realized I was an atheist yet). I still can't honestly put myself in their shoes, and have to consciously remind myself that when people couch things in religious terms that they're not just being disingenuous - they may be sincerely expressing a world view. This may be my parents fault for letting me get at Greek and Norse mythology before introducing me to hebrew school and synagogue. Once you've gone through Edith Hamilton (with the stipulation it's just fiction), it's hard to take the next set of myths as Serious Facts.

      I've only ever lived in Brooklyn NY and then Staten Island NY. I'm a 5-boro hermit crab.

      My only professional occupation is tutoring (college maths, biology, chemistry). Other than my willful wandering in this post, it turns out I'm generally pretty good at teaching people difficult stuff. I will gladly give this up to become a biostatistician.

      I have never played a face-to-face RPG in my life. I wish I had, and if I were less shy, I'd go to a con and do so.
    • intorporeal
      June 2011 edited June 2011
      Hi!

      I'm Brad. I'm almost 25 and currently live in Chicago, though I grew up in California and hope to move back some day. Right now I'm a software engineer for a company out in the 'burbs, but I'm actually looking into changing careers and going to culinary school instead. I like 80's glam metal, and 00's girlpop. I used to drive an '87 el camino, but donated it to charity at the end of last year.

      I was introduced to video games at a very young age, having "been released" (so to speak) only a few years before a year after the US NES release. Freshman year of high school, I was introduced to both WarHammer and D&D, and we played them both pretty similarly -- primarily as a combat simulator, with a bit of fun narrative thrown around to make things more exciting.

      Then I came across InSpectres one day. It was my first introduction to real roleplaying, and to this day continues to be my favorite game. I own many more games than I've actually played, but I'm working on fixing that (just putting together a group to try out Apocalypse World in a few weeks!).

      The majority of my gaming experience is with d&d and world of darkness, which are both great, but I really love the less-structured smaller games more.
    • LearnedKnave
      June 2011 edited June 2011
      Howdy, y'all.

      I'm Henry, a 23-year-old College Grad from Canada.

      I've been playing D&D since 2nd Ed, but dabbled with GURPS and other systems like that until I got into college and things really got rolling. Traveller, Savage Worlds, Spirit of the Century, Shadow of Yesterday, Burning Wheel, FATE (the Dresden Files version, specifically), Apocalypse World, Microscope... Haven't had more'n one game in the last five years last ten or more sessions, irritatingly, but a lot of fun all the same.

      Definitely want to play and learn more! Excited to be here.

      EDIT: Feel like adding some more...

      I'm an Alberta boy, born and bred, but living in the Pacific Northwest and finding I quite like it out here. Went to college down in the States, not sure at all what I'll be doing now. All my passions pay terribly, writing, acting, and I'm not sure about going professional in either, and that's not a cocky thing, uncertainty as to whether or not I COULD is a big part of that.

      Hoping to design a game someday. Have a few ideas, but nothing worth talking about yet, alas. It's just a goal.

      Oh, and I love the Ancient World and history spanning the whole length and breadth of human history. I can translate Ancient Greek kind of okay, but I'm not where I want to be with that just yet.
    • WarriorMonk
      June 2011
      Hola!

      I'm Paulo Rivas, a 33-year-old peruvian comic artist/editor/designer/publisher. You know, Peru? somewhere in South America? You've got to visit us some day, our food might not be the best but our way of cooking it IS superb.

      I started roleplaying in my twenties and find it the most amusing activity a group of creative people can make. It all started with Vampire the Masquerade and pretty soon I was hacking ol' Paladium's Robotech to GM a campaign of my own. Ok I also hacked the Argentina module but it was almost unrecognizable when I finished with it. Sinde then I tried D&D which went good for a while until our GM ruined the fun, which made me prone to try and hack any other RPG that I run into.

      I'm currently working full time as a graphic designer, and creating my own comic publishing company, probably the first in Peru since the 90's. Of course, I would love to sell RPGs here too, however we must start with the simplest ones, since people here doesn't have the smallest clue what are tabletop RPGs about.
    «1…9101112131415»
