    Comments

    • Squideye
      June 2011

      I'm Ilan Muskat. I'm 32, and I work for the Ontario Public Service as a project manager and analyst in information technology.

      I live in Toronto, which is a big and culturally bewildering metropolis. It gets cold here sometimes, so there's sometimes a muted tone to the street life. In the summer it is pretty vivid.

      That does afford me a lot of opportunity to do things like sing in groups oriented to straight-up musical performance as well as doing community theatre, which keeps me going when work is particularly dreary - and in my very bureaucratic environs that's more often than I'd like.

      I have a fairly regular uber-group of minis and boardgame players at the Meeplemart store on the east end of town. RPGs are really only accessible with any sort of frequency at the Hairy Tarantula, though, or when I make it out to Montreal to visit Valet d'Coeur.

      I do a podcast with my friend Justin Mohareb, called "Squideye and The Bitter Guy", and I take way too long to produce and upload the episodes after we record them.

      I have a cat, named Pixel, who is making me age prematurely.

    • otherdoc
      June 2011
      Greetings!

      I'm Jim Ryan. I'm a broadcasting student, writer and podcaster currently residing in Charlotte, North Carolina.

      I'm approximately 36 - give or take a couple of weeks.

      I have a geeky, introspective blog/podcast called Jim - Yes, THAT Jim and an RPG podcast called The Great Debate!, in which I pretend to be a bunch of different RPG characters arguing with each other about subjects relevant to gaming. Mostly it's an excuse to do silly voices.

      I'm also a former theatre guy and have a book of monologues coming out. I have a habit of making up odd characters, writing monologues for them and performing said monologues at various open mic nights. Once again, it's mostly an excuse to do silly voices.

      I participate in a local writers' circle and try to write fiction every now and then. Most of the stuff I write I describe as "darkly comedic science fiction and/or fantasy detective and/or adventure stories." I've recently realized it would probably be easier to just call it "pulp."

      As for RPGs, I'm a fan of Amber Diceless, Deadlands (and Savage Worlds in general), D&D (all editions), World of Darkness (both tabletop and live action) and Call of Cthulhu. I'm also playing (and heartily enjoying) a lot of games like In a Wicked Age, InSpectres and Lady Blackbird - the only problem being that it can be difficult to find groups willing to play them, so I try to spread the word about them as much as possible. I have a near-desperate desire to get into games of Don't Rest Your Head or Dread one of these days. I'm learning more about Spirit of the Century and other FATE-based games and would like to try those out as well.

      I've also recently decided that one of my missions in life is to play as much Fiasco as possible.
    • Nicholas Moore
      July 2011
      Hey everyone!

      I'm Nicholas Moore (or Nick if you prefer), where my real name is not an available handle I go by a gra, or n_o_moore. I'm 22, a recent graduate of Sarah Lawrence College, and live in Westchester.

      I'm a poet by degree (and trade?), and have a great passion for rpgs and rpg theory. Which naturally lead me here.

      I have a penchant for being academic and pedantic. Please forgive me that failing. I am very excited to discuss the finer points of gaming with you all.
    • Qui
      July 2011
      I'm Felix Qui, living in Amsterdam (Netherlands).

      Started roleplaying with Red Box DD, got fed up with ADD rule-lawyers & tables, tried my hand on generic rpg (GURPS, Dreampark, WOD).
      Nowadays I like playtesting other rpg: Ghost/Echo, Blackbird, ORE, PDQ, FATE, FUDGE

      http://kwoiwo.blogspot.com/
    • Bazin
      July 2011
      I'm Josh Bazin. I'm 29 and live and grew up in the Edmonton, AB area. I'm hoping to be granted the Certified Management Accountant designation in a few months - I've completed all the requirements, I just need a final grade.

      I have a young son and I expect a daughter any day now. I hope they are as interested in gaming as I am when they get older. My wife is a RN, and I've yet to convince her to play games with me. I hope out hope that one day she'll convert.

      I work for a not-for-profit.
    • Asylos
      July 2011
      My name is Chris(tine).

      I am a pharmacy technician (well, technically I *was* a pharmacy technician, and soon will be a Registered Pharmacy Technician). My day job mostly involves billing med checks and running reports of many types, and spending a lot of time with Excel.

      My gaming group has yet to finish an adventure, as we keep jumping systems. Most recently we've been playing Deathwatch (FFG) and Shadowrun, and I've started running Lady Blackbird. Past games include Don't Rest Your Head, Dresden Files, Rogue Trader, Pathfinder (several starts, but no actual play as of yet), DnD 3.5/4, and various board/card games made by FFG.

      Hobbies include many Xbox games and writing, as well as reading as much as time allows.



    • Chill K
      July 2011
      Hi!

      My name is Chill and I think gaming is cool. My interests besides gaming are helping people, making movie scenes out of lego and reading. I suffer from chronic pain which makes me unemployable to most people so I don't really have a job but I volunteer with various charities. I'm currently in university not studying anything in particular with aspirations of working with disadvantaged peoples.

      Gaming wise, I'm still new to forums in general and don't really understand a lot of "gaming theory" but I'm keen on figuring out my own games and figured this is a good place for such ambitions.

      Top 5 dead or alive is Gumshoe, Happy Birthday Robot, Dogs in the Vineyard, Ghostbusters and Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay.
    • jkubli
      July 2011
      Hi. I'm Joshua Kubli. By day I'm a computer technician (mostly desktops, but some networking, web design, servers, you name it) at a hospital in a small town in Oregon. I'm 36, married to a beautiful, creative woman (who swears she will get me housetrained one day), and have an amazing, funny, sweet little twerp who just happens to be severely autistic.

      I've been roleplaying since I was in junior high, and developing games since high school. I've got a website (http://www.imperfekt-industrees.com/?gammes/imperfekt-gammes.html) and game design blog (http://invulnerablog.imperfekt-industrees.com/).

      I love extremely spicy food, iced mochas, fantasy, science, science fiction, comics, horror, history, some good movies, most bad movies, and philosophy of all kinds. I've a smattering of martial arts training. I have no pets but wish the house I rent would let us have a cat. My favorite authors are probably Roger Zelazny, David Gerrold, and Ken Wilber. I can't think of anything else right now, need more caffeine.
    • ennui
      July 2011 edited July 2011
      Oops, I don't think I ever posted here. Well, it was time for an update anyway.

      My name is Matt Sanchez, a 30 year old American married to an awesome Japanese girl (with no gaming inclinations). I am working for an international logistics firm and living in Japan; I am studying to get my customs broker license when I move back to the States next year.

      I've been playing video games since I was a really tiny human, and now that I'm a bigger human I still enjoy the glow of the screen. I found out 7 years ago, however, the joy of dice and face to face interaction. Since then I've been obsessed with pen and paper role playing games, and I've been devouring everything I can get my hands on.

      Given that I am currently living in Japan, I've found the local scene and games very interesting. I have been translating them when I have free time; my Ryuutama translation has been released and I have another big project coming up later this year (I hope). I run a blog about Japanese RPGs at d66roc.wordpress.com as well.

      Other than games, I enjoy cooking, dancing salsa, reading and writing short stories of weird fiction, and sampling the local beer. Cats are pretty awesome, too.
    • Agemegos
      August 2011
      G'day

      I'm Brett Evill, but I don't use my name much on-line because I'm sick of being given crap about it. I use the handle "Agemegos" pretty widely, and used to use "Agback" and "Silverback", back in the day.

      I was born in 1964, which makes me forty-six as a write this, but not destined to remain 46 for very long. I grew up to age 15 in Kempsey, a small country town in northern coastal New South Wales, Australia. Then I went to Sydney to get an expensive education, then to the University of New South Wales to study electrical engineering and computer science. In 1986 I went to Canberra to study economics at the Australian National University, and there I got stuck for 17 years, working as a transport economist and modelling programmer for the Australian Commonwealth Department of Transport (Bureau of Transport Economics). I retired in 2002, and in 2003 moved back to Kempsey partly because it is a nice area to retire to, and partly to look after my elderly (and now departed) mother.

      I got into RPGs in 1980 playing AD&D in the library at Sydney Grammar School and with fellows I met there. Later I took part in the RPG scenes at UNSW (1982–1984) and ANU (1986–1990), though with little enthusiasm for D&D in any form because of its arbitrary complexities and failure to support emulating any sort of fiction. I designed the 'module' for the first (1984) convention of the UNSW RPG Association, and later was involved with the ForeSight flexi-form adventures at CanCon. I have run free-forms at Sydcon '98 and CanCon, a tabletop game (Après Moi L'Enfer) at Necronomicon '04, and was one of two designers of a hybrid freeform/tabletop Vampire game "Canberra By Night". Apart from that, you might recognise one of my handles or my acerbic style from GMAST-L, TAOGM-L, <rec.arts.frp.advocacy>, the HERO Games forum, the Steve Jackson Games forum, or ENWorld.

      There is no gaming to be had where I live now, so until I can sell this dump and move to a city I am stuck with gaming by VoIP and InterNet video conferencing. And with making a very long drive for two monthly games.

      I'm single, my house is way too big, and I have an elderly Labrador retriever named "Lily".
    • Adam_Dray
      August 2011
      Hey, Brett! I remember you from rec.games.frp.advocacy, GMAST-L, and TAOGM-L. Welcome to Story Games!
    • Agemegos
      August 2011
      Thanks, Adam. I'm looking forward to learning a lot.
    • James G
      August 2011
      I'm James, a 28-year-old graphic designer from Utah.

      Not sure what else to say.

    • Cneph
      August 2011 edited August 2011
      I'm Ian Raymond, an IT support consultant from the US/UK via Norway who lives in Christchurch, New Zealand.

      I wrote quite a long and detailed post about my background and gaming history, but the session gods called timeout and it's been lost to the ether.

      Much more briefly, since the mid 80's I've played (amongst others) D&D red box, AD&D 1 and 2E, Warhammer FRP, CoC, Shadowrun 1e, DND 3.0 and 3.5, Cybergen, V:TM, Mage, Werewolf, Champions, Pendragon, BESM, Buffy and collected many many more, in fits and starts with several multi-year fallow periods owing to moves. My favourite gaming-item-as-artifact is of course my GWB. I saw it on the shelf at Orcs Nest in London- you could hardly miss it, sticking out three inches- and was enthralled. Even if I never dared run the thing...

      For years I was very reluctant to GM games following some stressful experiences, but the reduced emphasis on the GM-as-source-of-all-fun (a major stress factor) and the more structured role in wonderful games like Mouse Guard, AW, Leverage, PEP, Diaspora etc etc have got me dipping my toes into running one shots and short games again.

      So, a big shout out and thank you to the wider storygames community for putting these great games together and giving me this opportunity to put something back into the hobby in a small way.







    • Bad_Santa
      August 2011
      My name is Garret, I'm 31 and I live in Minneapolis, MN.

      I started gaming when I was 13, my half brother found out a week later and gave me a near complete collection of AD&D books. I've been hooked ever since. I was introduced to story gaming about 2 years ago and have been enjoying it more and more.

      I tried going to college but dropped out and joined the military. I got out after 7 years and since then I've been drifting in a fog of depression ever since. It's something I've battled all my life and it's nearly won more than once.

      I've been a fire-fighter, a stable boy, a volunteer science interpreter and manager for Goodwill. I'm an avid outdoorsman, my earliest childhood memory being riding in a canoe in the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness. I have chased and been chased by bears. I can sail a boat, saddle my own horse and usually start a fire.

      I don't normally use the nickname Bad Santa, but at a house con several years ago it was given to me, so I used it for the forum.
    • packy666
      August 2011 edited August 2011
      Wow, I missed being #666 by a single entry . . .

      Anyhoo, my name is Pat, and I've been a serious gamer since 1979 or so -- 1st ed. ADnD. Off and on for the last 30+ years I've played a ton of different games, but lately I've been doing a lot of Savage Worlds and Castles & Crusades. Just discovered Old School Hack as well as Lady Blackbird, and can't wait to get involved with either game.

      Like many folks my age (47), I went through a time when I couldn't or didn't play. Over the last 10 or so years I figured that was BS and got back into it. Just two weeks ago I got back together with some old friends to play a game -- some of these guys hadn't been in the same room with each other since the '80s! We had a great time and hoping to get together again soon. One of my old cronies became a Master Brewer over time and brought in some of his mead. Now that was cool!

      Professionally I'm a music teacher in a small school district in Western Oregon, and have been doing so for the last decade+. Prior to that I was a performing musician, but do to a neurological disorder had to adjust my career. I am employed in my field, which is a good thing in this day and age . . .

      Anyway, I look forward to being involved in this forum. I'm also trying to find gamers in the Willamette Valley, specifically Eugene.

      Pat (packy666)
    • Will_GM_for_Food
      August 2011 edited August 2011
      My name is Todd Furler. I was born in 1961 (more meaningful than my age, since that keeps changing) and started role-playing in 1978 or so. I run traditional RPGs. I also occasionally play, but mostly I GM. I also enjoy light- to middle-weight Euro-style board games.

      I'm a chemical engineer by education, but have never held a job as a chemical engineer. I've worked for the same electric utility in eastern Pennsylvania since I was 22 years old. For my company, I've worked as a chemistry technician, technical writer, computer support guy, instructor, and a few other things that can't be easily described.

      What's been my favorite job so far? Twice a year, my employer conducts a company-wide drill, where we pretend massive storms have caused extensive power outages throughout our territory. I train and coordinate 30 volunteers who pretend to be 200 repair crews that our storm-response personnel "dispatch" to these simulated outages. The whole exercise is, in essence, a corporate-wide role-playing game, and I get to help GM it.

      - Todd
    • The Convenient Skill
      August 2011
      My name is Steve, my user name is an anagram of my real name. I came across this site while looking into John Harper's excellent Danger Patrol beta.

      I was born in '77 (about the same time some people started playing it seems). I've got a fairly large collection of RPGs, but trimmed back a little when I moved to Dorset in the UK (from Hampshire).

      Highlight games along the way Heroquest (the MB boradgame introduced me to gaming in general), D&D very briefly and GURPS (long time fan until the skill list reached more than 2 pages of small type). Through the name Steffen O'Sullivan found Fudge, then FATE 2.0 then a whole new world! Current fave is FU: the Free Universal RPG by Nathan Russell, check it out if you like rules-lite narrative games.

      I love it so much I run the Fan Made FU RPG Yahoo Group.

      I'm an accountant (manager, possibly partner one day or my own firm), have two girls (2002 and 2005) who I'm starting to game with and a long term partner who won't. I never went to uni but my career's been fine so it hasn't mattered.

      I have no trouble coming up with ideas, but seeing them through is a really big problem! A bit more application and I might be known here, but as it is I'm mostly happy flitting here and there (mostly).

      Lost my gaming group a little while back so solo play is where it's at until my kids grow I suspect.
    • Nachte
      August 2011
      I'm Tera Benoit, I'm 21 years old. I was raised in a tiny little town In Southeast Texas. I moved to Bellingham, Washington about two years ago. I'm half way through my graphic design degree and I draw comics as a hobby and a past time. As well as read them in large quantities. My favorite genre is cyber-punk and I spend a lot of time with m nose burried in books by Masamune Shirow and similar genre writers.

      I write and work on tabletop games with my boyfriend and my room mate as a small group with the working name of Running From Skeletons.

      I was introduced to this site by several people at PAX prime and I was so excited to find a group of people into the construction of tabletop story games and talking about them.

      My first game was dungeon and dragons back when I was 12 and 3rd edition was still pretty new. Since then i've
      played dozens of games and have to say it's probably my second passion behind art.

      You can call me Tera or Nachte, (nah-kh-ta) I'll happily answer to both.
    • KaneBlaireau
      August 2011
      Wow, I feel late to the party!

      I am Matt Razincka. I am 32 and live in Seattle (yes, right in the city!) with my wife, Caroline. I grew up here for most of my life but spent a couple years in northern Wisconsin and my high school days in Bozeman, Montana. I started in tabletop gaming with Star Frontiers when I was about ten years old. That lead to the TMNT RPG, then D&D, Warhammer, etc, etc.

      Somewhere along the line, I started writing an RPG of my own, taking bits and pieces from every RPG and video game I could get my hands on. It has gone through many iterations. It was originally a fantasy game. Over the years, it has become a post-apocalyptic fantasy game. In the last few years, the world has begun to take shape in leaps and bounds. The rules are coming along slowly, but are certainly getting there. I call the setting "Crushed Earth" and the system "Multiversal". Will post more about this in a separate post.

      Feel free to call me Matt or Kane. I'll answer to either!
    • scndthe2nd
      September 2011
      Alright, lets do this.

      My name is Tony. I'm local to buffalo and take host in a bunch of different activities, right now mainly atheism and gaming. I'm a psychology major at SUNY Buffalo, I work with kids who have high functioning autism, specifically, we use video games - basic retail stuff, your halo and mario brothers - in order to identify emotion, processes of others and such.

      Eventually I'd like to work in the game industry, either designing system mechanics in education once someone decides that k-12 should be streamlined, or working in the indie games market, sinking my hooks into a garage programmer rock star and feed them scraps of cognitive psych under the table so the little company can get big and strong

      Ultimately, I've been designing a little here and there. I was a John Wick fan for a while, particularly of his youtube series in '09. I made a game for Tron Legacy once it came out, which played through well, but I saw my stream of ideas die out before my eyes.

      Anyways, I've taken up too much screen time

      Holler at me if anything I'm talking about sounds interesting -- we'll chat.
    • quizmaster

      Hello!

      My name is Rob and I live in the Seattle, WA area. I'm a 26 year old gamer of all kinds (board games, card games, video games, tabletop RPGs, etc). I'm new the the indie-RPG scene but I'm starting to embrace it with a passion. PAX has shown me some wonderful games.

      Outside of gaming, I'm married to a wonderful woman for almost a year now and I'm a system's administrator for a large company.

      This looks to be an awesome site for information on different RPGs. I plan to poke around for ideas and suggestions from those of you more seasoned in the RPG world than I.
    • horn_head_o

      Huh, missed this thread.
      Hello! I'm Max and I also live in the Seattle, WA area, though I'm much closer to Tacoma. I've gamed for 4 years now, my entire high school career, with one group and played D&D 3.5 almost the whole time, with a year set out for our Star Wars RPG game(pre-Saga edition). It started getting stale, so I looked around and found Indie games. We've now played Lady Blackbird and are extremely excited to try more.

      I now go to university at Pacific Lutheran University, though I don't live there, I commute. If you go to PLU too, contact me, we're desperately looking for another player!

      I'll probably ask a lot of questions, but I hope I can contribute too.

      Seriously I'm a long time gamer looking to learn about the newer forms of gaming. I was pretty up on the indie gaming seen until about 2007 but I've been busy with school and other obligations but now time is allowing me to check out my favorite hobby again.

    • rabalias
      September 2011
      I don't think I ever replied to this thread. I'm Josh. I live in the UK, near London, where I work for the Government, currently on climate change policy. I have a girlfriend who roleplays, and two cats who don't. OK, so they probably roleplay as well, but they do it systemless. When I'm not working, sleeping or roleplaying I like looking after my garden, strategy games, cooking and eating. Yet I weigh practically nothing.

      I play a lot of different games, primarily of a slightly more trade cast, especially investigative and horror games, or better yet investigative horror games! But am just dipping my toe into the wonderful world of Fiasco, Dogs in the Vineyard and all that other good stuff.

    • todd
      September 2011
      I've had an account for a full week, I suppose this should be my first post:

      My name is Todd, I'm 37. I grew up in Kentucky (Bowling Green, Elizabethtown, then Lexington), but I've lived in New York City for the last 10 years.     • HyveMynd
      September 2011
      Hello everyone,

      I'm Chris (or Wayne, take your pick) and I'm a 31 year-old Philadelphian native who has been living in Osaka Japan since 2006. I found these forums a few days ago after stumbling across a link to "Lady Blackbird" and "Danger Patrol Beta" on another forum.

      I started RPing back in the early '90s after I got the old Milton Bradley "HeroQuest" game and then found the original, first edition "Gamma World" boxed set at a flea market for a quarter (awesome!). I then moved on to AD&D 2nd edition, Westend's StarWars d6, D&D 3.5, and more recently D&D 4e, the new World of Darkness, Savage Worlds, and Ubiquity.

      When I started playing RPGs, I was primarily a gamist, probably due to my Magic: the Gathering upbringing. Everything had to be balanced, rules had to be clearly spelled out, and I wanted a rule for every possible situation that could arise. D&D 4e took that to the extreme however, and kind of broke me. In the past two years or so I've started becoming more of a narrativist, and have started looking at story games rather than "traditional" RPGs. I've really come to appreciate their simplicity and the freedom that they give players. Plus running them will hopefully make me a better GM.
    • JLHBurnett
      September 2011
      Hello, I'm Joshua LH Burnett!

      I'm 36 years old recovering slacker.
      I married my best friend, Ivy, seven years ago and we have an awesome son who's just starting to get into RPGs.
      I grew up in a small town in northern Ohio, and I now live in Toledo.
      I started gaming in 7th grade with "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and Other Strangeness," and the hobby has dominated my life ever since.
      I do creative stuff for a small game company, do freelance illustration, make webcomics, and participate in an actual play podcast.
    • Matt Kauko
      September 2011
      Hey everyone, I'm Matt Kauko. I live in Nashville, TN, a teacher by trade. I've got dreams of being a writer some day, and have been writing on a blog everyday for the past couple of months, at North of Nowhere.

      I found story games a while ago and joined, but this is the first time this thread has made it's way to the top. Looking forward to discussing and finding a lot of great games and ideas.
    • CorvusE
      October 2011 edited October 2011
      Wow. Weeks worth of compelling reading right here in this thread. But before I start that, I think I'll toss my pebble in the pond.

      I'm Corvus Elrod, a full-time independent game designer and contract writer for casual and social games. I'm a thoroughly and gleefully married 40-something, happy caretaker of a miniature poodle, proud bi-cyclist, and frequent imbiber of the myriad of stouts and porters that Portland, OR's local brew pubs have to offer.

      Despite having run RPG campaigns since 1990, I've never actually run an RPG using someone else's system. For the last 3 years I've been focused on bringing my latest effort to market and I'm on the verge of doing so now--Bhaloidam will be available in 2012!



    • Ethan K.
      October 2011
      Ethan K, 22yo digital media analyst based in San Francisco. I just moved here from Portland (where I graduated from college), and love the story gaming community in the Bay.

      I'm a cyclist, beer fan, and will probably chase after a PhD in a couple of years (in case nothing else changes).

      I first ran DnD for a cousin when I was, like, 11, and I've been the GM for my friends' games ever since. I loved the performance and transformation power of these games, and feel like I've finally found the appropriate tools (particular indie RPGs) for creating the experiences I've wanted but couldn't create with Cthulhu/DnD.

      Also, crushing all over Fabricated Realities and looking forward to it next June.



    • MikeT
      October 2011
      Hi, everybody! I once subscribed here as Michael Tangherlini, but lost all account info and had to make a new one.
      I'm back here to showcase my creations: I started my own small endeavour, focused on weird games.
      Have fun!

      -MikeT
    • Madu
      October 2011 edited October 2011
      Holy shit, I’ve been lurking for four years and never managed to write one of these.

      I’m Gary, age 38 and change; married, and father to and pal of a little boy who, to my everlasting nerd-parent joy, now asks for The Empire Strikes Back by name. My first gaming experience was circa 1981, when some forward-thinking elementary school teacher took me out of class to play something Dragons-something. I recall being assigned the thief, Bilbo, and rolling dice while moving checkers around a map, and not knowing what the fuck was going on but thinking it was kinda cool.

      In the last oh say ten years I’ve made the shift away from White Wolfy games into a more indie mode, and while I do enjoy a rollicking session of Emo Supervillains With Fangs or Mage: the Ascension Unto The Soapbox*, these days I am more of a Burning Wheel/Apocalypse World/Stolzean Weirdness gamer.

      Quite apart from that, I’m on the downslope of a Master’s in GIS, I write lurid swords-and-sorcery stories for my own amusement, and I like spicy food, the ethnicker the better.

      ~Gary

      *Not to pick on Mage. Hell, half of my graduation gift to myself is a Metaphysic of Magick tattoo – so if it’s goofy, I’m goofy right there with it.
    • blackhatmatt
      October 2011
      Hi, all! I'm Matthew McFarland. I live in Ohio, outside of Cleveland. Recently divorced, already engaged, two kids, and I'm not going to talk about them here because then I wouldn't talk about anything else.

      I worked as a freelancer for White Wolf, then as a full-time developer (Dark Ages), then laid off, then freelancer, then said, "Screw this noise" and went to grad school. And now I'm a speech-language pathologist working for the Cleveland Metropolitan School District, freelancing on the side (mostly for White Wolf, though Green Ronin and Eden have occasionally thrown work my way).

      I'm currently putting together my own game, called curse the darkness (more at cursethedarkness.net). Would love feedback and opinions and stuff, but I'll post to the appropriate threads. :)
    • Evil Genius
      October 2011
      I'm Drew. I'm 43 and live in Essex, England. I'm married and have a teenage son. I'm a housing officer for a large RSL.
      I've been playing rpgs since 1980 and have played a lot of different systems. Recently (partly due to playing too much D&D) I've been looking at other game systems which have lighter mechanics and more emphasis on narration.
      I've started to play ICONS and Apocalypse World and Barbarians of Lemuria. I have Fiasco, Dead of Night and Hollowpoint but have not played them yet - my games group is a bit trad and one player pretty much refuses to play anything other than D&D.
      I played 'A Penny for My Thoughts' and it was the most immersive roleplay sessions I've ever had. I'm going to use it to help in character generation for other games.
    • scndthe2nd
      November 2011
      I'm Tony Scinta, 23. I tried to sit down and get into these forums a few times, but I havn't been feeling very talky lately. I'm from Buffalo Ny, I'm a student, soon to be graduated by University at Buffalo with a BA in Psychology. I'd like to work in the video game industry some day as a producer, as I have no real skills. In my free time, I play yo-yo, I play rpgs, I build stuff and I design games which i'll talk about later.

      I've been playing savage worlds for around a year, played a 2 year long serenity game before that, and various rpgs before that. I'm nervous about GMing, so i usually stick to picking apart mechanics and subsystems and trying to apply them to new content as I get the chance.

      I built a little Tron thing when tron legacy came out which turned out pretty well, and I designed some subsystems for savage worlds which turned out -- well i'm not publishing them anytime soon.

      Anyways thats me, well met.
    • StephaniePegg
      December 2011
      Hi,

      I'm Stephanie. I'm 34 and based in Wellington, NZ. I started roleplaying when I was 13 and my twin sister and I were the only regular female roleplayers in our entire city (plus a couple of older women who occasionally dropped in or came to the same parties) - Wellington is much better in that respect. I've been larping since my mid twenties.

      Er, what else may be of interest? I'm officially both a tech geek and a book geek (degrees in Engineering and English Lit/Latin), and know rather more than anyone probably wants to know about St Margaret of Antioch. I work for the local railway company. My partner and I recently embarked on Responsible Grownup Things like buying a house, and I'm finding that the best bit is being able to do what we like in the garden. I've published a couple of larp scenarios (Flying Monkeys on DriveThruRPG) that were very silly, with a third more serious one planned for February. I sometimes write fiction for fun, and have recently dipped my toes in the heady waters of fanfic.

      I generally prefer system-light gaming. The Indie RPG movement is still something I'm trying to get a handle on - I play some games on offer from time to time at local conventions and hear people talking about them, but it's not my Big Thing.

      [waves hi]
    • woodster
      December 2011 edited December 2011
      Hello, everybody!

      I've been lurking here for some time, posted thrice. I feel it's about time I introduced myself: I'm Rafael Ferreira, nice to meet you. A brazilian lawyer and aspiring copywriter, these days surviving as a webmaster, who lives in Rio de Janeiro (were I was born and raised).

      Born in 1980 (31), started playing in the 90s. Though most of this time I've played "traditional" roleplaying, lately I've been moving towards "storygame sensibilities" and games that support them, like Cinematic Unisystem, Fiasco, Cortex Plus and Microscope (I'm yet to play the last two). This shift, so to speak, brought me here. As I've stated in my application for the forum, I'm looking for better (more fulfilling) gaming experiences.

      Other than gaming you can count movies, fiction books, comic books, parties, science trivia among my favorite things.

      - Rafael
    • TheOtherTracy
      December 2011
      I'm Tracy Barnett. I live in Central Ohio, am working on becoming an English teacher for either grades 7-12, or as a professor. We'll see how the wind blows. I'm 31, and only in the last few years have really discovered how much I love gaming.
    • mostlyjoe
      December 2011
      Joe Meyer

      Born: Tacoma, WA
      Living: Melbourne, FL
      Age: 35

      I'm a Generic System junkie who lives for tactical combat, but is trying to get his local groups to eembrace more indy development. Enjoys freeform online roleplay for characterization, but LIVES in the structures of rules. I don't see 'fluff' I see 'crunch' and then build on it little empires of madness inducing mechanical mayhem. Been playing since the early 80's and unlikely to stopy any time soon.

      I'm the guy who thinks you have have GREAT characterization in GURPS or HERO as long as you know how to use the cruch to empower the fluff. Etc.

      See also: Magical Engineering Commando
    • Mr.A.Green
      December 2011 edited December 2011
      Hello everyone,

      My name is Aidan, I'm 28 and I live in Vancouver, Canada.

      Professionally I am a video game designer working for an Activision owned studio.
      Personally I am a huge RPG fan. I've spent the last few years trying to, well, try every game I could get my hands on. Mainstream, indy, in-between, you name it, I love to see what people have come up with. Unfortunately it's been hard to find enough time and people to play them all!

      I started with AD&D 2nd, then did some oWod (V:tM & W:tA), then onto D&D 3.5. I was loving it, but started wondering what else was out there. From there I started getting into all kinds of other systems and games thanks to the internet. I was ignorant of things like the Forge, and the works of Jared Sorenson and Vincent Baker for a long time, I'm glad to have finally discovered them.

      I'm currently working on my own personal game project called Dungeon City Blues, it is a low fantasy detectives game. Nothing groundbreaking, I'm not re-inventing the wheel, it's very traditional, I'm just trying to build a free, simple, flexible system with which to run some mystery games.

      Outside of gaming I am also a big music fan, I play bass guitar in an urban folk rock band and am starting to amass quite the collection of instruments and gear, far outweighing my actual skill.

      Well that's me in a nutshell, nice to meet you all
    • dldzioba
      January 2012
      Hi, I'm Dominique.
      I'm a 24-year-old gamer girl from North Carolina (by way of New Jersey) and I've been roleplaying in some form or another since 2000. I work fast food during the day, write novels in my free time, and game once a week with a group I've been part of for five years or so. I'm engaged to marry my favorite DM.

      I'm actually very boring. O.o
    • wicked.fable
      January 2012
      Hey all,

      I'm Daniel and I started gaming when I was about 13. My first exposure to RPGs, however, was through online forums, mostly RPoL.net which is where I developed my interest for gaming. I never had a lot of money to spend so, naturally, I played a lot of free RPGs which led me to become interested in the indie subset of gaming. Now-a-days, I'm very interested in games like World of Darkness and Dungeons & Dragons, but my roots are definitely in indie RPGs especially because I love the collaborative storytelling aspect of gaming. Whenever I game, it's usually because I have ideas for stories in my head that I want to play out. I could just write the stories down, but I always find it more fun to flesh stories out with a group under the framework of a game.

      Currently, I am 19 and am majoring in graphic design. I do freelance graphic design on the side to try to help pay for my studies and I've actually recently started designing my own RPG. I'm mostly doing this to add some extra graphic design pieces to my portfolio, but I'm also hoping it may help me pay for college. We'll see how it goes, of course. My other main hobby is competing in speedcubing competitions where contestants try to solve Rubik's Cubes and similar puzzles as quickly as possible. I'm also an avid comic book fan, love playing tennis, and am always excited to check out art.

      Anyway, I'm happy to be aboard, and will definitely have fun lurking about the threads,
      -Daniel
    • Connie
      January 2012
      Hi everyone! I'm not sure why I haven't shown up on here sooner. I'm just that good at procrastination, I suppose.

      I'm Connie Allison and I was born and raised in a small town on the South East coast of Florida called Fort Pierce. In 2008 I moved to Philadelphia and I have been here since. I'm 24 years old and a Community College student studying Early Childhood Education and still quite unsure about what I want to do when I "grow up". I have 3 siblings, a brother, 40, and two sisters, 37 and 22. They are all married and the girls have children. I'm kind of the odd one out in my family. My sister's think I'm so very wild and crazy because I live in the city and I take public transportation! I think they need to get out of our hometown and experience the world.

      I started gaming in 2008. I was enticed by Tales of the Fisherman's Wife. Then 3:16 Carnage Amongst the Stars. Then Annalise. My only background knowledge of RPG's was that the cool kids in Marching Band who were also in Swing Troupe played D&D on occasion. After playing so many indie games, I finally had an opportunity to try D&D and I wasn't all that impressed. I'd been spoiled by story gaming. I've no complaints.

      In the beginning I was quite introverted and I worried that I would "do it wrong". But over time I became more and more comfortable creating things with friends. As ridiculous as it sounds, gaming brought me out of a shell and helped me to develop more confidence and respect for myself and my ideas.
    • Adam_Dray
      January 2012
      It's unforgivable that we haven't gamed together yet, Connie (but please try to forgive me). Joanna, too! Let's make this happen at a Dreamation or a Nerdly or something!
    • biggles
      February 2012
      This seems like an appropriate location for post #1.

      I'm Sam. 22, from New Zealand. About half the people I know use my government name, and the other half call me "biggles," a nickname I picked up at about 14. I started RPing fairly recently, when I was 18 or so at university. I've been inventing games since before I can remember and programming computers since about eight. I started roleplaying to expand my game design vocabulary by figuring out how it works. I have a Comp.Sci degree, but quit my honours year half way through 2011 to waste my time trying to finish my video games and sell them (life goals!!!) and work as a web application developer. I don't cope well with time-pressure and high workloads. I'm quite into math, hip hop (tried running a rhyming rpg on a forum once! hard to make PCs feel heroic when you can out-rap them easily!), electronic music, and open source / open media stuff. My RP bros and I play using a system we made up by playtesting and aggressive deletion of rules that we would maybe like to share with y'all when we're done typing it up (incl fantasy supplement thingy.) Assuming that doesn't break hidden rules of etiquette. Also here to participate in the class A roleplaying discussion. I learned a bunch of cool things lurking today.

      What else?? No idea. This marks the end of the line. My personality ends here.

      This is my second post here, ever. :)

      Hi, I'm Rowan. Geek girl originally from San Francisco, now transplanted to Central Pennsylvania. I grew up playing D&D and World of Darkness, and a few weeks ago (no, seriously) I discovered that there's this whole world of awesome games out there and that all this critical theory and "how do I find a game that does [x]" is actually talked about by other people and that I don't have to be a freak at my gaming table because I want to talk about this stuff.

      When I grow up I want to take over the world. :)

    Comments

    • Izraphael
      February 2012 edited March 2012
      I'm Marco "Iz" Valtriani, born in 1980 in a cold day of october
      I live in italy, I'm married with a son.
      I am a (board)game designer. I'm also an advertiser and graphic designer. I'm trying to design RPG to, and my boardgaming experience is influencing me a lot... but we'll talk later about this :)
      After a short experience as an amateur board games self-publisher, I designed a couple boardgames "on demand", Fiume di Parole, for italian schools, and La Grande Opera, for the "Museo Ideale" of Leonardo da Vinci. In 2011, Scribabs published my first "gamer's game": 011.
      From 2008 to 2011, I was the president and the "mind" behind Creatori di Divertimento (ital. "Fun Makers"), an association of game designers, illustrators, and workers of the "gaming world", focusing on "luding culture"; the association, that is well-known in italian gaming community, works to help luding operators, to organize events and fairs.
      In 2011, I left the head of the association to avoid any conflict of interests, focusing my activities on the creation of games.
      Talking about RPGs, I began with Merp and D&D 1ed, then I played and enjoyed a lot Call of Cthulhu and Rolemaster, and a lot of other stuff with more or less fun.
      Now I like a lot some "new" games (my favs are Polaris and Don't Rest Your Head), but I never disowned my passion for "old" RPGs.
      After a few "bad" attempts, non I'm working on a game with my wife, which is called Sakura. The game is gm-less, is set in medieval japan and is based on the concepts of duty and desire. One of the reasons I signed in is to talk about it with all of you.
    • catty_big
      February 2012 edited February 2012
      Hi all

      I live in London, UK. I'm an ex-EFL teacher, now games designer, started out designing a playing-card word game but now want to design RPGs (got one in the works already, have posted about it separately). Got into role-playing when exposed to RPGs for the first time at IndieCon 2010, UK. Been hooked ever since.

      I'm 46 (but feel and- I like to think- act younger, daddy-oh!); unmarried, no children, no pets, too busy for a social life- Hell, the internet is my social life! (Yeah, sad, aren't I?).

      Cheers
      Leo
    • aaarg_ink
      March 2012
      Hi, my name is Justus. I'm 33, an architect, and currently living in Houston but was raised in California. My primary hobby is boardgaming and I'm not sure how long my interest in indie RPG's will last (re: my dead flickr account). I have essentially no RPG experience but I just stumbled across the world of indie RPGs I love reading game rules and I find the idea of structured storytelling fascinating. This seems like a great chill place to be and I hope enjoy conversating with y'all!

      For what its worth my handle on boardgamegeek is also aaarg_ink and that place is essentially my home on the internets (aside from gmail).

      I live with my girlfriend and two very cute, mischievous, loving (to each other, not us), destructive bunny rabbits.
    • foulowl
      March 2012
      26 year old illustration student. I live in the East Bay and played my first story game (Apocalypse World) just a few months ago.

      I love the immersive, transformative element of this game style (versus the handful of traditional games I played in high school) and feel pretty lucky living in an area with lots of little cons and gaming communities to explore. I'm looking forward to the Monsternomicon at EndGame in May and Big Bad Con in October. Hopefully I'll be able to make it out to Fabricated Realities in June.
    • SavageCole
      March 2012
      My name is Dave and I live in Bucks County, PA where I also grew up. 41 years old, married and beagled. Professionally, I work with Fortune 500 clients leading financial and technology project teams. Educated at Penn State (undergrad) and Cambridge University (M.Phil). My hobbies include building and racing cars, action pistol competition, theatrical productions, and travel. My proudest "accomplishment" to date is overcoming long odds to survive Stage IV cancer. Living 4 years cancer free and loving life, baby!
    • malcolmpdx
      March 2012
      Hello all,

      I'm Malcolm Heath, and generally can be found on the internet as malcolmpdx.

      I'm 40 years old, as of 2011, and rapidly approaching 41. I live in Portland, Oregon, and have for the last 22 years, having come out here for college, and deciding to stay. Before that, I grew up in Minneapolis, Minnesota. I've been gaming since I was 8 or so, having first been introduced to RPGs via the 1979 Basic D&D edition.

      In the 80s I played many of the games that were popular (at least in Minneapolis) at that time, ranging from Traveller, to the Morrow Project, Gamma World, Villains and Vigilantes, Behind Enemy Lines, Space Opera, various Palladium games, Mercenaries, Spies and Private Eyes, James Bond: 007, Paranoia, and so forth, along with the usual D&D stuff.

      When I was 15, I was introduced to Tekumel (AKA, Empire of the Petal Throne) and got completely obsessed with that for quite a while. I think that this point marked a big change in how I approached gaming. The depth of the setting allowed for an immersive experience which I realized that I'd been looking for and not finding for a long time.

      Then in 2002, I attended U*CON in Michigan, and met some folks who played Amber. Somehow, I'd missed that. It was a life-changer, too; Amber gaming showed me that it was possible to do things without the sort of rules I was used to, and showed me that I could run and play in games that were more about the characters involved than their powers or external capabilities. I attended AmberconNW shortly after, and found a pile of gamers who were really, really good at the sort of gaming I'd come to realize was what I wanted. Joy ensued, and continues each November.

      Since then, I've been slowly finding my feet as a GM, learning how to run the sorts of games I like, and having rather more awesome gaming experiences on a regular basis than anyone should likely be allowed to have.

      Outside of gaming, I have worked as a systems admin, IT manager, and security geek for many years. This is despite my degree being in Religious Studies (i.e. comparative religion). On that note, since others have posted in this thread about it, I'm an Episcopalian Christian, having been raised as that, but only recently returned to it after having had a long journey through several other paths. It's quite important to me, and I'm what might be considered "devout", but tend to answer all questions regarding religion with "it depends". As indeed it does.

      I'm married, no kids, and have a great relationship, for which I am very, very grateful.

      I've traveled a bit, to the UK, South America, The Caribbean, Indonesia, and all around the US and Canada. I hope to do more of this.

      As for why I'm here - I know, or at least know online, several folks who are regulars here, and "story games" popped up on my radar a year or two ago. I think, from reading the forums for a while, that I'm going to dig this. Great, thoughtful conversations about the very topics that interest me most about role-playing.
    • Adam_Dray
      March 2012
      Welcome, everyone. Glad you made your saving throw, Dave!

      Malcolm, if you want to start a thread about your experiences with Tekumel, I'd love to hear about it. I've been one of those people who follow it in a vague sort of way but I've always been way too intimidated by it to play it.
    • rterryjr
      March 2012 edited March 2012
      Who am I? That is a valid question.

      My name is Raymond Terry, I am an African American male, 46 years old, who loves both video games and tabletop role-playing games, finds it hard that there are not more African Americans in the gaming industry, and feels that it is time I dipped my hand back into the tabletop RPG cookie jar.

      My interest are reading, gaming, watching movies, and taking a stab at blogging. I wanted to be a writer, and actually had something written, but never finished it. That is one of my ongoing projects that I occasionally take out and dust off for old times sake. Now I am moving more into the blogosphere to get some practical experience writing and keeping on task with projects.

      Current projects:
      Designed and maintain gaming blog called “Old Gamerz”, and have begun work on a game inspired by the old DC heroes RPG published by Mayfair Games back in the early 90's.

      I am also on Google + , Twitter, and Facebook. Mostly on Google + though.
    • Apeiron
      March 2012
      i'm Todd, aka Apeiron.

      i joined this site ages ago, but i recently played Lady Blackbird so i'm looking to help and get help (with my games).

      If i'm awake, i'm probably thinking about games. i've been doodling games of various kinds since i was 9. i'm an idea hamster. i can generate ideas faster than i can write them. By the time i've jotted the idea onto paper i'm already bored with it and moving on to the next thing.

      i grew up in Alabama and Germany. Spent four years in the USAF as an intel analyst (i'd have to kill you if i said more than that). Got my degree at Columbia College Chicago. Since then i've been working mostly in IT. These days i'm a house husband, starving artist and aspiring game designer.
    • tymotzues
      March 2012
      Hi all
      I'm Tim
      grew up in australia, moved myself to england and now I'm back in australia with a wife and four year old (who is currently trying to stiffle my typing ability)

      I started RPGing at 6, started DMing at 7, started designing at 8 and haven't really looked back since.
      That said I've been in denial that I really want to design RPGs and so studied creative writing, computer science, animation, linguistics and finally illustration.
      With all that behind me I've spent the past ten years congealing all my known RPG experience into FateStorm and have just released the first title Ascendancy - Rogue Marshal
      I've was in the infantry for four years, worked at a bank in central london for four more, travelled the world, witnessed a murder, been mugged by drug addicts, Dj'd, danced till my toes bled
      and have a west highland white terrier called Skye
      Oh, and just for Matt, I am on IMDB for my work in feature films of which one won an Oscar and a BAFTA





    • robosnake
      March 2012
      I'm Doug Hagler, a 32 year old Presbyterian minister and chaplain and also a writer, editor and game designer.

      I'll put spaces between many of my sentences.

      I've lived a lot of different places, but no place that's incredibly interesting - Florida, Connecticut, Ohio, California.

      I don't know if I have an interesting anecdote. I once made a mocha for Robin Williams, and he was as short as me and looked like he was just as tired, but he smiled and was polite and thankful for the caffeine.

      I'm married to a historian/early childhood educator and have a cute baby girl who is 7 months old.

      In a month and a half I'll be unemployed and technically homeless, though we're able to move in with friends so thankfully not entirely homeless.

      I also have a new sci-fi RPG that just went up on Kickstarter [http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/2072399402/the-parsec-rpg]. I'm proud of all the work that I put into it and afraid that everyone who reads it when it is finally printed will hate it.
    • SpaceHobo
      March 2012

      I'm someone who used to frequent all these indie-story-game forums five or six years ago, but fell away. I'm a little surprised (and encouraged) by the fact that this site is still here and doesn't say "WE GAVE UP: FIND US ON FACEBOOK" the way so many web fora have.

    • Agemegos
      April 2012
      Posted By: AgemegosI'm single, my house is way too big, and I have an elderly Labrador retriever named "Lily".

      The house is still way too big.
